**Checksum, check value** Basic error-detection technique that involves
calculating a characteristic value from some digital
data which is transmitted or stored with the data, and
can be checked to verify integrity of the data
transmission or storage. “A value generated by an
algorithm and associated with an input value and/or
whole input file. The checksum value can be used to
assess its corresponding input data or file later and
verify that the input has not been maliciously altered.
If a subsequent checksum value no longer matches
the initial value, the input may have been altered or
corrupted” _(ISACA glossary)_. “A value that is
computed by a function that is dependent on the
contents of a data object and is stored or transmitted
together with the object, for the purpose of detecting
changes in the data” ( _SANS glossary_ ). “Verifies or
checks the integrity of data. A good checksum
algorithm: is easily to compute; will usually output a
significantly different value, even for small changes
made to the input; and can detect many types of data
corruptions ... often used to verify the integrity of
operating system, programme, library or other
programmatic elements, images and firmware
updates ... check digits and parity bits are special
uses of checksums” _(NZISM)_. See also hash, parity.

**Chip-n-PIN, chip and
PIN, chip card**

```
Physically secure payment, charge, store, bank,
credit, or debit, card containing an embedded
cryptographic module – in practice, a small
I ntegrated C ircuit chip laminated within the card.
Compared to magnetic stripe cards, it is extremely
difficult for forgers to duplicate well-designed and
implemented cryptographic modules due to their
physical and logical security controls. Normally, the
user must enter their correct PIN code into the chip-
n-PIN card reader to authenticate themselves and
‘unlock’ the card ( M ulti F actor A uthentication),
further controlling against loss or theft of the card,
provided neither the card reader nor the PIN code has
been compromised (two known modes of attack).

**Class, classify,
classification, category**

```
Pragmatic grouping-together and labelling of similar
or related information assets that are believed to
share similar risks and hence control requirements.
While classification is a quick process that reduces
the need individually to risk-assess and identify
security controls needed to protect every single asset
in each class, the appropriate generic controls still
need to be applied. Furthermore, generic controls
may not be ideal for a specific situation; hence,
higher classes may require more intense risk analysis
and bespoke controls. Classification typically
involves confidentiality or privacy criteria but more
complex schemes may also take account of integrity
and availability requirements. Unfortunately, there is
no universal agreement on classification labels and
their meanings; hence, in addition to the conformity
```

```
issues within any organisation there are additional
risks of misinterpretation leading to inadequate or
inappropriate security when classified materials are
shared between organisations or business units with
different understandings. “The identification of two
or more categories in which an item belongs”
(ISACA glossary). “The categorisation of systems
and data according to the expected impact if it was to
be compromised” (AusISM).
```
**Classical data analysis** “A data analysis technique where data collection is
followed by the imposition of a model, and the
analysis, estimation, and testing that follow focus on
the parameters of that model” _(NIST SP 800-55v1)_.
_Cf_. **E** xploratory **D** ata **A** nalysis.

```
Classification scheme Formal description of an organisation’s classification
processes; applicability, authority, rôles,
responsibilities, and accountability; criteria/rules to
be applied; levels, tags, or labels; and the associated
controls. May cover upgrading/downgrading and
relabelling arrangements, assurance controls,
enforcement, and more.
```
```
Classified data “Data that would cause damage, serious damage or
exceptionally grave damage to the national interest,
an organisation or an individual if compromised ( i.e.
data assessed as PROTECTED, SECRET or TOP
SECRET)” (AusISM).
```
**Classified information** Information with a designated class or level. In the
government/military context, the designations
usually concern confidentiality requirements such as
SECRET. “Government information that requires
protection from unauthorised disclosure” _(_ NZISM _)_.

```
Classified system “Systems that process, store or communicate

Clear, wipe Basic low-assurance form of sanitisation or plain
deletion of data. Typically leaves residues that may
be recovered trivially or with concerted effort and
maybe forensic tools and techniques. “Cause one or
more storage locations to be set in a prescribed state,
usually that corresponding to zero or that
corresponding to the space character” (ISO/IEC
2382 ). “Sanitize using logical techniques on data in
all user-addressable storage locations for protection

using the same interface available to the user”
(ISO/IEC 27040).

**Clickbait, click-bait,
click bait**

```
Something attractive or intriguing (such as fake
news, kittens, and scantily clad people) that lures
unsuspecting computer users to click a link, open an
attachment, install or run a program or whatever,
leading typically to their devices being infected with
malware and/or their being defrauded or otherwise
compromised. A form of social engineering. The
thriving underground market in clickbait pays a
premium for clickbait pages with tens or hundreds of
thousands of affluent and/or naïve visitors.
```
```
Click fraud Fraud techniques targeting click-through affiliate
marketing schemes that pay a bounty for visitors’
clicks. In one form, malware surreptitiously swaps
genuine affiliate codes embedded in U niform
R esource L ocators and cookies for codes linked to
the fraudsters’ own accounts. In another, malware
racks up large pay-per-click charges and/or
```

```
artificially inflates website reputational ratings (and
hence commercial value) by ‘clicking’ online
advertisements.
```
```
Clickjacking Hacking technique that surreptitiously an
unexpectedly diverts visitors’ browsers to a different
website, typically then launching malware attacks
against visitors’ devices. See also click fraud.
```
```
Click-regret That sinking feeling that follows an unwise click on
a dubious link, app, attachment, or security warning
message.
```

Client Customer, recipient, or beneficiary of a service.
“Functional unit that receives shared services from a
server” (ISO/IEC 2382).
```
**Client-server** Technical architecture or design typically involving
dedicated and powerful **I** nformation **T** echnology
systems (servers) providing shared information
services via networks to individual
distributed/remote systems (clients), _e.g._ a web
server providing website content to browser
applications running on various user devices.
“Pertaining to a method of distributed processing in
which a client obtains services from a server”
_(ISO/IEC 2382 )_. “A term used to broadly describe
the relationship between the receiver and provider of
a service. Generally, the client-server describes a
networked system where front-end applications, like
the client, make service requests to another
networked system. Client-server relationships are
defined primarily by software. In a local area
network (LAN), the workstation is the client, and the
file server is the server. However, client-server
systems are inherently more complex than file-server
systems. Two disparate programs must work in
tandem, and there are many more decisions to make
about separating data and processing between the
client workstations and the database server. The


```
database server encapsulates database files and
indexes, restricts access, enforces security and
provides applications with a consistent interface to
data via a data dictionary” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Climate General or local conditions of weather, ecology,
economy, business, market, etc. “The collective
perception about self, surroundings, and others –
including perceptions about culture, some aspect of
culture, or some topical area” (OCEG GRC
Glossary).
```
**Climate change** Long-term global temperature increases leading to
potentially existential risks for organisms (including
humans!) that cannot survive sustained mean
temperatures a few degrees warmer or the associated
environmental impacts such as rising sea levels,
melting ice caps, droughts, food shortages, and more
extreme weather incidents.

```
Clipper chip Failed US government initiative in the mid-1990s to
introduce a cryptographic subsystem on a proprietary
computer chip using Skipjack with cryptographic
keys recoverable by the authorities, allowing them to
decrypt data at will. Aside from flaws in the
cryptographic design, introducing additional security
vulnerabilities, and the obvious trust, privacy, and
oversight issues relating to key escrow and
surveillance, black hats would simply avoid Clipper,
thus negating its alleged purpose. The project’s
incredible naïveté hints at ulterior motives: the real
goal might have been to raise awareness of the social
issues arising from the use of strong encryption,
particularly by criminals and terrorists. Side-effects
included stimulating the dissemination and use of
other strong encryption systems, and a backlash
against invasions of privacy by the authorities.
```
```
Clipping Removing the extremes of a signal or data set, i.e.
values that are likely to cause processing issues or
```

```
dubious outliers that would otherwise skew the
analysis. “A technique for handling outliers.
Specifically, clipping includes reducing feature
values that are greater than a set maximum value
down to that maximum value. It also involves
increasing feature values that are less than a specific
minimum value up to that minimum value” (ISACA
glossary).
```

tokens and passes, keys, virtual systems, D ata B ases,
and programs are vulnerable to being
duplicated/copied illicitly unless there are adequate
preventive a n d/or de t ective controls. They may also
be cloned for legitimate reasons such as backups,
B usiness C ontinuity M anagement, D isaster
R ecovery, hardware replacement, testing or forensic
purposes.

to oversee public places for disorder, crimes, and

Modern CCTV systems use networked high-

individual assets, e.g. automatically disabling
manufacturing robots or dangerous machinery if
workers enter safety-critical zones.

engineered. However, cloud computing can also raise
governance, ownership, compliance, and other
information security and privacy issues.
“Convenient, scalable on-demand network access to
a shared pool of resources that can be provisioned
rapidly and released with minimal management
effort or service provider interaction” (ISACA
glossary). “Uses a network of external servers
accessed over the internet, rather than a local server
or a personal computer, to store or transfer data. This
could be used, for example, to host a website or
corporate email accounts, or for storing or
```

```
transferring data files” (UK Cyber Security Breaches
Survey 2023 ). “Utilization of remote servers in the
data-center of a cloud provider to store, manage, and
process your data instead of using local computer
systems” (SANS glossary). “Just someone else’s
computer” (Internet meme).
```

C loud C ontrols M atrix
(CCM)
```
```
Generic suite of information security controls
applicable to various types of cloud computing

https://cloudsecurityalliance.org/research/working-
groups/cloud-controls-matrix/

```
CloudCracker Cloud-based commercial service offered to crack by
brute force attack on the NT hash values used as part
of the P oint-to- Point T unnelling P rotocol and MS-
CHAP cryptographic processes.
```
```
Cloud environment Cloud computing environment. “A virtualized
environment that provides convenient, on-demand
network access to a shared pool of configurable
resources such as network, computing, storage,
applications, and services. There are five essential
characteristics to a cloud environment: on-demand
self-service, broad network access, resource pooling,
rapid elasticity, and measured service. Some services
offered through cloud environments include
Software as a Service (SaaS), Platform as a Service
(PaaS), and Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS)” (CIS
Controls).
```

**(CSA)**

Industry body for C loud S ervice P roviders and their

C loud S ervice P rovider

Organisation offering cloud computing services,
usually on a commercial basis. See also A pplication

S ervice P rovider. Cf. C ontent S ecurity P olicy.

```
Cloud Smart Common name of a US government federal strategy

**Cloud storage, Web
storage, online storage**

```
Service allowing remote access to stored data
through the Internet. As with cloud computing, the
geographical storage location may be unknown to the
user which can raise governance, ownership,
compliance, and other information security and
privacy issues, while the involvement of external
organisations and network communications may
expose proprietary data to various risks including
unauthorised access, corruption, and D enial- o f-
S ervice.
```
```
Cluster Two or more closely coupled computer servers
configured to appear as a single operating unit,
sharing the processing load and (usually) disks. Can
provide higher availability/resilience and
performance than a single computer, albeit with
additional costs, complexity, and associated
constraints. The architectural principle extends to
cloud servers with virtualisation, potentially across
regions sharing fast (low-latency) network
connections.
```

Cluster controller “A communication terminal control hardware unit
that controls a number of computer terminals. Note:
All messages are buffered by the controller and then
transmitted to the receiver” (ISACA glossary).

```
Clustering Process of defining, forming, and maintaining a
cluster. “An algorithm for dividing data instances
into groups—not a predetermined set of groups, but
groups identified by the execution of the algorithm
because of similarities found among the instances.
```

```
The center of each cluster is known as the ‘centroid’”
(ISACA glossary).
```

processed for a consistent functional purpose. Note:
Clusters of PII are described independently of the
technical representation of data objects. On a regular
basis, the clusters of PII also include PII which is not
stored electronically” _(ISO/IEC 27555)_.

**Co-adaptation** “A process by which neurons predict patterns in
training data by relying almost exclusively on
outputs of other specific neurons instead of the
network _’_ s behavior as a whole” _(ISACA glossary)_.

```
Cobalt Strike Powerful red team penetration testing/hacking tool,
described by its vendor as ‘threat emulation
software.’ ‘Beacon’ is the name of the
multifunctional payload. An example of dual-use
technology, popular with black, grey, and white hats.
More info: https://www.cobaltstrike.com/
```
```
COBIT ISACA’s conceptual framework for corporate
technology governance, management, risk, and
control. “The current [2019] iteration of COBIT,
which builds on and integrates more than 25 years of
developments in the field of enterprise governance of
information and technology (I&T). It not only
incorporates new insights from science but also
operationalizes these insights as practices. COBIT is
a broad and comprehensive I&T governance and
management framework that continues to establish
itself as a generally accepted framework for I&T

https://www.isaca.org/resources/cobit
```

**Code, coding scheme,
codify, codification**

```
a. Use of words, symbols, strings, phrases, sounds,
or images to represent and communicate
messages via an encoding process. A crude form
of substitution, potentially made more secure
through the use of multiple code books, O ne-
T ime P ads, steganography, etc. “Collection of
rules that maps the elements of a first set onto
the elements of a second set. Notes: The
elements of either set may be characters or
character strings. The first set is called coded set
and the second set is called code set. Each
element of the code set may be related to more
than one element of the coded set but the
reverse is not true” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). See also
coding, PIN code.
b. Explicit ‘codified’ behavioural framework or
structure, or an implicit understanding,
appreciation, and acknowledgement of the
principles and rules of appropriate/inappropriate
behaviour, such as a code of ethics, code of
conduct, code of practice, or A cceptable U se
P olicy.
```
```
Code audit Audit of source code to gain assurance regarding
aspects such as code quality, security,
appropriateness, maintainability, and I ntellectual
P roperty R ights ( e.g. conformity with policies and
other requirements; well documented with no
backdoors or dubious functions). “An independent
review of source code by a person, team or tool to
verify compliance with software design
documentation and programming standards.
Correctness and efficiency may also be evaluated.
This contrasts with code inspections, code reviews
and code walkthroughs” (ISACA glossary).
```

```
Code book, codebook If a list of code words is too long to remember and
communicate reliably to those who need to code or
decode messages, it may be necessary to prepare and
distribute one or more lists from which to lookup
codes and their plaintext equivalents. The security
issues are similar to those associated with the
generation and distribution of encryption keys, e.g.
ensuring that code books do not fall into enemy
hands and cannot simply be reconstructed by the
enemy through educated guesswork, known plaintext
attacks, or other forms of cryptanalysis.
```
```
Code injection Hacking techniques to insert malicious content into
programs during their execution, exploiting various
O perating S ystem and application flaws and bugs,
specifically injection flaws. Used by some malware.
See also AtomBombing, Cross-Site Scripting,
HTML injection.
```
**Codename, codeword** Private monicker or tag for an initiative, tactic,
project, planned attack, _etc._ enabling insiders to talk
discreetly about the subject, hopefully without
tipping off outsiders. An example of security by
obscurity. “A short (usually a single word)
description of a project, operation or activity,
typically assigned used for reasons of reliability,
clarity, brevity, or secrecy. Each code word is
assembled in accordance with the specific rules of
the code and assigned a unique meaning” _(NZISM)_.

```
Code of conduct Set of corporate rules for acceptable/unacceptable
worker behaviours, typically expressed as a policy,
guideline, agreement, rulebook, etc. “Sets out the
principles, values, standards, or rules of behavior that
guide the organization ’ s decisions, procedures, and
systems. The Code of Conduct is, in effect, a set of
the most important core policies” (OCEG GRC
Glossary). See also code, code of ethics, code of
practice.
```

```
Code of ethics Comprehensive set of rules, ideals, objectives,
principles, practices, and/or values deemed ethical by
the organisation, culture, or society. Given that a
written code cannot realistically cover all possible
ethical issues, a substantial part inevitably remains
unstated: however, workers are expected to interpret
and apply the guidance sensibly when facing novel
situations and dilemmas, acting in the best interests
of the organisation, culture, or society. “A document
designed to influence employees ’ individual and
organizational behavior by defining organizational
values and the rules to be applied in certain
situations. Note: A code of ethics is adopted to assist
those in the enterprise called upon to make decisions
in understanding the difference between ‘right’ and
‘wrong’ and to apply this understanding to their
decisions” (ISACA glossary). See also code of
conduct, code of practice.
```
```
Code of practice Codification of flexible, pragmatic guidelines or
principles indicating how organisations should
behave in situations or contexts. Intended to
supplement and achieve or improve compliance or
conformity with laws/regulations and standards. See
also code of conduct, code of ethics, A cceptable U se
P olicy.
```
```
Code Red Network worm that infected unpatched vulnerable
web servers running Microsoft IIS software in 2001.
Compromised websites were defaced with “HELLO!
Welcome to http://www.worm.com! Hacked By
Chinese!”
```
**Code repo** sitory **(code
repo)**

```
Online archival facility or library for storing,
managing, controlling access to, and sharing
software source code (applications, utilities,
functions, libraries) plus the associated
documentation, test data, testing scripts, metadata,
etc. within a development team. With strong version
control, code changes are tracked and can be reverted
```

```
if necessary, e.g. if conflicts arise when parallel
changes are merged. Checking out the specific
materials needed to build a particular software
release can automatically generate the S oftware B ill
o f M aterials. A key part of a structured change
management process for software companies.
```
```
Coding a. Writing source code for software or firmware.
“1. In software engineering, the process of
expressing a computer program in a
programming language. 2. The transforming of
logic and data from design specifications
(design descriptions) into a programming
language” (ISACA glossary).
b. Translating or transliterating messages or other
information content into code. See also encode.
c. Tagging financial transactions with accounting
codes or classifying them into relevant classes
or categories for further processing (or similar
activities for other types of data).
```
```
Coercion Assertively or aggressively forcing someone to do
something against their wishes ( e.g. pay a ransom to
recover their data), typically through physically
intimidating, threatening, or blackmailing them,
putting them under duress.
```
**Coercivity** Magnetic force that will completely demagnetise a
ferromagnetic material such when wiping the data
stored on hard disk or mag-stripe bank card.
Measured in Teslas. “A measure of the resistance of a
magnetic material to changes in magnetisation,
equivalent to the field intensity necessary to
demagnetise any magnetised material. The amount of
coercive force required to reduce any residual
magnetic induction to zero. Normally used in
describing the characteristics of degaussing magnetic
media” _(NZISM)_. “A property of magnetic material,
used as a measure of the amount of coercive force


```
required to reduce the magnetic induction to zero
from its remnant state” (AusISM).
```
**Cognitive computing** “Category of AI systems that enables people and
machines to interact more naturally. Note: Cognitive
computing tasks are associated with machine
learning, speech processing, natural language
processing, computer vision and human-machine
interfaces” _(ISO/IEC 22989)_.

```
Cognitive hacking See social engineering.
```
```
Coinhive Species of cryptominer malware in the wild in 2018.
Infected systems mined Monero cryptocurrency.
```
```
CoinVault Species of ransomware that used 256-bit A dvanced
E ncryption S tandard.
```
```
Cold site, shell site Secondary facility with a minimalist I nformation
T echnology setup – little more than a vacant
office/suite provided with electrical power and air
conditioning. It may take days, perhaps weeks to
bring the site fully into operation as a data centre if a
disaster befalls the primary site, assuming sufficient
IT equipment, data backups, people, etc. are
available or can be obtained in that timescale. This
minimalist approach to IT D isaster R ecovery may be
somewhat faster and less risky than buying or renting
suitable accommodation on the open market and may
be appropriate for low-availability IT services that
are not business-critical but is far from best practice.
“Facility with at least the equipment necessary to
support the installation and operation of an
alternative data processing system” (ISO/IEC 2382 ).
“An IS backup facility that has the necessary
electrical and physical components of a computer
facility but does not have the computer equipment in
place. Notes: The site is ready to receive the
necessary replacement computer equipment in the
event that the users have to move from the main
```

```
computing location to the alternative computer
facility” (ISACA glossary). See also warm, hot, and
mirror site.
```
**C** ollaborative **R** esearch
**I** nto **T** hreats **(CRITS)**

```
MITRE project and open-source Unix-based web-
based platform/tool for specialists to share artefacts
and collaborate with trusted colleagues to analyse
malware and other cyber threats, systematically
archiving valuable information for future analyses.
See also ATT&CK, TAXII. More info:
https://www.mitre.org/our-impact/intellectual-
property/collaborative-research-threats-crits
```
```
Collateral a. Associated, related, proximal (as in ‘collateral
damage’).
b. Asset offered as a guarantee to a lender, that
may be forfeited if the borrower defaults on the
loan.
```
```
Collection, collect a. [Noun] Set or group of related or associated
items collated (systematically gathered
together), such as data in a D ata B ase or postage
stamps in an album.
b. [Verb] To locate and retrieve or gather and
amass valuable materials such as forensic
evidence, intelligence, or personal information.
“Process of gathering the physical items that
contain potential digital evidence” (ISO/IEC
27037 ). “The process of obtaining personal
information from the individual directly (for
example, through the individual’s submission of
an internet form or a registration form) or from
another party such as a business partner” ( T rust
S ervices C riteria).
```
```
Collector, handler Someone who gathers intelligence on/about or from
certain targets, potentially using OSINT, HUMINT,
SIGINT, TECHINT, COMINT, IMINT, ELINT,
black bag ops, agents, and other sources plus
```

```
techniques such as deception, surveillance, and
subterfuge. See also agent, spy, spook.
```
```
Collision When two or more things ( e.g. vehicles, network
packets, D ata B ase data changes, or hash values)
coincide, arriving at the same place at the same time.
“Condition that results from concurrent
transmissions on the transmission medium”
(ISO/IEC 2382). “When multiple systems transmit
simultaneously on the same wire” (SANS glossary).
```
```
Collusion Conspiracy and nefarious collaboration between
individuals or organisations to negate the division of
responsibilities, breach Chinese walls, commit fraud,
etc.
```
```
Co-location Shared use of commercial data centre facilities by
multiple customers. “Installation of
telecommunications facilities on the premises of
other telecommunications carriers” (ISO/IEC 2701 1 ).
```
```
Colossus World’s first digital programmable computer,
designed by Alan Turing, Max Newman, Tommy
Flowers, and colleagues at the UK Government Code
and Cypher School at Bletchley Park North of
London in 1943 during the second World War.
Although it was programmed mechanically using
patch cables and switches, its sole purpose was to
break encrypted teleprinter messages by brute force
attack on the keys used on the German Lorenz
cryptography machines; hence, arguably it was not a
general-purpose computer ( Cf. ENIAC) but was the
first cyberweapon.
```

number]**

See PIN code.

```
Combination lock Physical lock that can be unlocked with the correct
numeric sequence (a PIN code).

Comfort zone Domain within which we feel safe and secure, and
beyond which we feel uncomfortable – possibly
threatened and vulnerable, in other words at risk.

COMINT
(Communications
Intelligence)

```
Spying on the content (data) and nature (metadata) of
communications to gather useful intelligence
information. Part of SIGINT. See also HUMINT,
TECHINT, OSINT, COMINT, IMINT, ELINT.
```
```
Command a. [Noun] Direct order or mandatory instruction.
b. [Verb] To exert control, be in charge of, or have

c. [Verb] To engender, as in command respect.

**Command and Control
(C**^2 **, C2, C&C)**

```
Generally, systems and processes for directing and
monitoring diverse operations. In the hacking
context, C^2 normally refers to the covert remote
direction and management of malware botnets
through the Internet by a bot master. In the military
context, C2 or C&C refers to the command structure,

```
```
Commercially
confidential,
commercial-in-
confidence
```
```
Class of business information whose value to its
owner relies at least in part on it being withheld from
unauthorised parties such as competitors and
customers. See also trade secret.
```
```
C ommercial O ff- T he-
S helf (COTS)
```
```
Generic, commodity, mass-market software package,
as opposed to bespoke software developed or
customised specifically for individual customers.
“Items that can be purchased from a commercial
supplier and used without tailoring” (ISACA
glossary).
```
```
Commit a. To make a commitment, e.g. “We commit to
deliver on time.”
b. To carry out, perpetrate, or perform an act, e.g.
commit new data to a D ata B ase, commit fraud.
```

```
Commitment Promise, pledge, declared intention or agreement.
“Declarations made by management to customers
regarding the performance of one or more systems
that provide services or products. Commitments can
be communicated in written individualized
agreements, standardized contracts, service level
agreements, or published statements (for example, a
security practices statement). A commitment may
relate to one or more trust services categories.
Commitments may be made on many different
aspects of the service being provided or the product,
production, manufacturing, or distribution
specifications” ( T rust S ervices C riteria).
```
```
Commit point Timepoint at which new, altered or deleted data
records are committed to (recorded in) a D ata B ase.
Well-designed database systems incorporate controls
such as locks and control totals to detect and prevent

before the commit point, plus journaling and
checkpoints to recover from some subsequent
incidents.
```
```
Committed value “A value of an indicator that is likely to be achieved
given current assumptions and planned execution”
(OCEG GRC Glossary).

**S** ecurity **S** ystems

US government body responsible for defining policy

assurance, and related matters for US government
and defence systems, formed from the N ational

C ommittee O f the

O rganizations of the

```
Primarily known for its “Internal Control –

processes. “A joint initiative of five private-sector
```

organizations and is dedicated to providing thought

C riteria). More info: https://www.coso.org/

```
Common control,
general control
```
```
Commonplace, popular, and widespread information
security control.
a. Information security control shared between
multiple organisations, departments, people,
applications, networks, systems, etc. “A security
or privacy control that is inherited by multiple
information systems or programs. Note: a
control is inherited by an information system

**C** ommon **C** ontrols **H** ub
**(CCH)**

```
Commercial service from the U nified C ompliance
F ramework providing detailed information on
compliance obligations and other information
security, privacy, information risk management, and

within CCH) recommended or required by about a

a suite (a security baseline) rather than individually
and perhaps repeatedly to satisfy each compliance
```

```
obligation separately. See also S ecure C ontrols

**C** ommon **C** riteria **(CC)** Formal, internationally recognised scheme defined in
the ISO 15408 standards to specify, design, develop,
test, evaluate, and certify secure **I** nformation
**T** echnology systems for government and defence
customers, where ‘secure’ is explicitly and formally
defined through the **T** arget **O** f **E** valuation, **P** rotection
**P** rofile, **S** ecurity **T** arget, **S** ecurity **F** unctional
**R** equirements, **S** ecurity **A** ssurance **R** equirements,
and **E** valuation **A** ssurance **L** evel. The **I** nformation
**T** echnology **Sec** urity Evaluation scheme distributes
the substantial costs across participating
organisations (product vendors and customers) while
also improving quality, reducing duplication, and
facilitating use of common assurance mechanisms by
various nations, agencies, _etc_. “A formal,
internationally-recognised scheme, defined in the
ISO 15408 standard [which] describes process to
specify, design, develop, test, evaluate and certify as
secure IT systems, where ‘secure’ is explicitly and

standard for product evaluations” _(AusISM)_. _Cf._

configuration

**C** ommon **V** ulnerability
**S** coring **S** ystem **(CVSS)**

```
Free and open system for determining the severity of
disclosed I nformation T echnology system
vulnerabilities by a generic, supplier-agnostic

generating severity scores between 0 and 10 to help

E numeration (CWE)

```

```
Companion virus Virus that takes advantage of the O perating S ystem’s
prioritisation of file names with certain extensions,
e.g. a virus executable named game.com may be
executed in preference to game.exe, the program the
user intended to run. Companion viruses typically
execute covertly, then launch the intended program,
hoping that the user remains blissfully unaware of
the subterfuge.

**Compartmentalisation** Separating things between compartments, zones,
categories, _etc_. according to particular
characteristics, such as classification levels, and
restricting communication/passage between them in
order to isolate them and mitigate risks. “Division of
data into isolated blocks with separate security
controls for the purpose of reducing risk. Example:
The division of data relative to a major project into
blocks corresponding to subprojects, each with its
own security protection, in order to limit exposure of
the overall project” _(ISO/IEC 2382 )_. “A process for
protecting very high-value assets or environments
where trust is an issue. Access to an asset requires
two or more processes, controls or individuals”
_(ISACA glossary)_.

**Compensating control,
compensating security
measure**

```
Control that is suboptimal but sufficient to mitigate a
risk to some extent and/or achieve compliance with a
security obligation, requirement, or expectation
where, in practice, the ideal control (such as patching
or replacing an insecure application or system) is not
presently feasible, e.g. due to strict change controls
for compliance, business, or safety reasons. A
temporary, pragmatic workaround, substitute or
compromise control that to some extent compensates
for control gaps, vulnerabilities, practical or resource
constraints, issues, etc. “An internal control that
reduces the risk of an existing or potential control
weakness resulting in errors and omissions” (ISACA
glossary).
```

**Competence,
competent, competency**

```
Capability of doing something properly, skilfully,
expertly. “Ability to apply knowledge and skills to
achieve intended results” (ISO/IEC 27000 ). “The
ability to perform a specific task, action or function
successfully [and] The strengths of an enterprise or
what it does well. Note: Can refer to the knowledge,
skills and abilities of the assurance team or
individuals conducting the work” (ISACA glossary).
“The degree to which an Assurance Provider can use
sophisticated, professional, and structured techniques
to evaluate subject matter” (OCEG GRC Glossary).
“Knowledge, skills, and abilities” (IIA GIAS). “The
skills, knowledge and understanding required to
carry out a role, evidenced consistently over time
through performance in the workplace. The ability to
apply knowledge and skills to achieve intended
results” (FSRCoP). Cf. incompetent.

```

described in the Network and Information Systems
(NIS) Regulations 2018. There are multiple
competent authorities responsible for different
sectors covered by NIS” (UK National Cyber
Security Strategy 2022).

(ISACA glossary).

```
Complex Multifactorial, complicated, involved, tortuous,
obscure, poorly understood, difficult, not simple or
straightforward ... “A property that refers to the
interconnected, interdependent, and interrelated
nature of the parts of a system that often gives rise to
nonlinear dynamics, emergent properties and
unpredictable outcomes” (OCEG GRC Glossary).
```
```
Complexity Risks relating to or arising from the sophistication
and fragility of complex technologies, systems,
```

```
processes, relationships, etc. that generally constrains
the level of information security achieved in practice,
although paradoxically complexity is beneficial for
security in the case passwords, cryptographic keys,
and ciphertext. “Condition of an organizational
system with many diverse and autonomous but
interrelated and interdependent components or parts
where those parts interact with each other and with
external elements in multiple end non-linear ways.
Note: Complexity is the characteristic of a system
where behaviour cannot be determined only as the
sum of individual variables behaviours” (ISO
22300 ).
```
```
Compliance Fulfilment of obligations or mandatory requirements
formally imposed on the organisation or individuals
by third-parties or authorities through legislation
(laws), industry regulations or contracts, for which
they can be held accountable. There are costs,
benefits, and uncertainties (risks) associated with
both compliance and noncompliance, making this a
business and personal matter with strong ethical
overtones. “A term that refers to the adherence to,
and the ability to demonstrate adherence to,
mandated requirements defined by laws and
regulations, as well as voluntary requirements
resulting from contractual obligations and internal
policies” (ISACA glossary). “A measure of the
degree to which obligations are proven to be
addressed” (OCEG GRC Glossary). “Adherence to
laws, regulations, contracts, policies, procedures, and
other requirements” (IIA GIAS). Cf. conformity.
```
```
Compliance audit Competent, independent determination of the extent
to which the organisation complies with and fulfils
its obligations or expectations under applicable
laws/regulations, standards, contracts, etc.
```
**Compliance control** Control designed to mitigate unacceptable
compliance risks, ideally achieving compliance and


```
being able to demonstrate or prove it if required.
Implies the need for compliance obligations to be
clearly identified and mandated, e.g. in applicable
laws, regulations, or executed and enforceable
contracts. Alternative strategies or tactics (such as
seeking to deny, avoid, or evade compliance checks;
fabricating evidence or concealing/destroying
evidence of noncompliance; coercing compliance
checkers; restricting, frustrating, and delaying their
checks; or callously accepting the possibility of
compliance penalties as a cost of doing business) are
considered unethical and may be illegal, making
them risky, particularly for those deemed
accountable. See for example dieselgate. Cf.
conformity control.
```
**Compliance document** Compliance document. “Policies, standards and
procedures that document actions that are required or
prohibited. Violations may be subject to disciplinary
actions” _(ISACA glossary)_. See also **C** ommon
**C** ompliance **H** ub.

management

```

**Computer, computer

```
System, device, equipment, or apparatus that
computes, ranging from an abacus and slide rule to a
supercomputer and everything in between.
Deliberately vague, all-inclusive term covers a wide
variety of digital and analogue I nformation,
O perational, S mart, V irtual and C ommunications
T echnologies. Prior to the 1940s, the original
‘computers’ were people diligently performing
mental arithmetic. “Functional unit that can perform
substantial computations, including numerous
arithmetic operations and logic operations without
human intervention. Notes: A computer may consist
```

```
of a stand-alone unit or several interconnected units.
In English, in information processing, the term
computer usually refers to a digital computer”
(ISO/IEC 2382 ). “[Computer] 1. A functional unit
that can perform substantial computations, including
numerous arithmetic operations (or logic operations),
without human intervention during a run. 2. A
functional programmable unit that consists of one or
more associated processing units and peripheral
equipment, is controlled by internally stored
programs and can perform substantial computations,
including numerous arithmetic operations, or logic
operations, without human intervention. [and]
[Computer system] A functional unit consisting of
one or more computers and associated peripheral
input and output devices and software that uses
common storage for all or part of a program and all
or part of the data necessary for the execution of the
program. A computer system executes user-written or
user-designated programs; performs user-designated
data manipulation, including arithmetic and logic
operations; and can execute programs that modify
themselves during their execution. A computer
system may be a stand-alone unit or may consist of
several interconnected units” (ISACA glossary).

```
Confidential information. “Information that is not
intended to be made available or disclosed to
unauthorized individuals, entities or processes”
(ISO/IEC 27002 ). “It’s in a diary” (Dire Straits,
Private Investigations).
```
```
Confidentiality,
sensitivity, secrecy
```
```
Preventing inappropriate or unauthorised access to,
or disclosure of, valuable, sensitive or private
information. A core objective of information security,
along with availability and integrity (the CIA triad).
“Property of data that indicates the extent to which
these data have not been made available or disclosed
to unauthorized individuals, processes, or other
```

```
entities” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “Property that information
is not made available or disclosed to unauthorized
individuals, entities, or processes” (ISO/IEC 27000 ).
“Preserv i ng authorized restrictions on access and
disclosure, including means for protecting privacy
and proprietary information” (ISACA glossary). “The
assurance that data is disclosed only to authorised
entities” (AusISM). “To ensure that information is
disclosed only to authorized parties” (SCP QRG).
“Preserving authorized restrictions on information
access and disclosure, including means for protecting
personal privacy and proprietary information” (NIST
SP 800-171).
```
**Confidentiality control** Control designed to mitigate unacceptable
confidentiality risks. Its primary purpose is to
prevent unauthorised or inappropriate recipients from
accessing, obtaining, or receiving confidential
information. See also integrity control, availability
control.

```
Confidentiality risk Risk involving or affecting confidentiality, e.g. the
possibility of inappropriate disclosure of sensitive
information, someone’s refusal to divulge vital
personal information ‘for privacy reasons,’ or the
ability of an encryption algorithm to withstand
cryptanalysis. See also information risk, information
security risk, integrity risk, availability risk.
```
```
Configurable control Control with adjustable rather than fixed parameters,
e.g. a system’s security setting for minimum
password length can typically be modified by a
privileged administrator. “Typically, an automated
control that is based on, and therefore dependent on,
the configuration of parameters within the
application system” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Config uration,
config ure (config)
```
```
Particular arrangement of items and parameter
settings determining the operation and security of a
system.
```

**C** onfiguration **I** tem **(CI)** Piece of technology (such as a particular item of
hardware, source code or compiled program,
hardware device/equipment, _etc_ .) plus related
technical information (such as parameters or
setpoints) being managed through the organisation‘s
**C** onfiguration **M** anagement **S** ystem. “Component of
an infrastructure—or an item, such as a request for
change, associated with an infrastructure—that is (or
is to be) under the control of configuration
management. Note: May vary widely in complexity,
size and type, from an entire system (including all
hardware, software and documentation) to a single
module or a minor hardware component” _(ISACA
glossary)_. _Cf._ **C** ritical **I** nfrastructure, **C** ompetitive
**I** ntelligence, **C** ounter- **I** ntelligence, **C** onfidential
**I** nformant.

```
C onfiguration
M anagement (CM)
```
```
Subset of change management activities involving
the configuration of computer systems and
infrastructure, including the parameters or settings
and relationships ( e.g. a certain combination of
specific versions of the hardware, firmware,
O perating S ystem, and layered software might be
tested thoroughly as a complete system, those tests
potentially being invalidated if changes such as
patches or updates are made to any part). An
invaluable integrity control for critical or vital
systems. “The control of changes to a set of
configuration items over a system life cycle” (ISACA
glossary). “Establish a known baseline condition and
manage it” (SANS glossary). “A collection of
activities focused on establishing and maintaining
the integrity of information technology products and
systems through the control of processes for
initializing, changing, and monitoring the
configurations of those products and systems
throughout the system development life cycle” (NIST
SP 800-171).
```

```
C onfiguration
M anagement S ystem
(CMS)
```
```
I nformation T echnology system plus related
engineering processes for administering and using
data relating to C onfiguration I tems in support of
C onfiguration M anagement.
```
**Configuration settings** “The set of parameters that can be changed in
hardware, software, or firmware that affect the
security posture and/or functionality of the system”
_(NIST SP 800-171)_.

```
Conflict of interest Situation in which a person or organisation’s loyalty
is (potentially or actually) divided between mutually
exclusive responsibilities, e.g. where their
obligations to a third party ( e.g. to report a security
incident) conflict with their self-interest ( e.g. if
disclosure would trigger an investigation and perhaps
enforcement for noncompliance). “A situation,
activity, or relationship that may influence, or appear
to influence, an internal auditor’s ability to make
objective professional judgments or perform
responsibilities objectively” (IIA GIAS).
```
```
Confirmability Capability of being tested, checked, verified,
validated, or audited in some way, in order to provide
adequate assurance. Purely faith-based statements,
claims, or assertions are inherently untestable.
“Measure of the extent to which a program is
designed and structured in such a manner that all of
its parts can be readily tested” (ISO/IEC 2382).
```
```
Confirmation Positive, supportive, or agreeable assurance. “The
number of blocks added to the blockchain after the
network accepts that a particular transaction has been
executed” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Conformity,
conformance
```
```
Discretionary acceptance and
adoption/implementation of a standard, policy,
contractual term, etc. or, more generally, fulfilment
of a requirement or expectation. There are costs,
```

```
benefits, and uncertainties (risks) associated with
both conformity and nonconformity, making this a
business and personal matter with strong ethical
overtones. “Fulfilment of a requirement. Note: the
term ‘conformance’ is synonymous but deprecated”
(ISO/IEC 27000). Cf. compliance.
```
**Conformity assessment** Process of generating assurance that specified and
applicable conformity requirements, obligations, or
expectations are satisfied. “Demonstration that
specified requirements are fulfilled” _(ISO/IEC
17000 )_. “The process of verifying whether the
essential cybersecurity requirements set out in Annex
I have been fulfilled” _(EU CRA)_.

```
C onformity A ssessment
B ody (CAB)
```
```
See C ertification B ody. “Body that performs
conformity assessment activities, excluding
accreditation” (ISO/IEC 17000).
```
**Conformity assessment
scheme, conformity
assessment program**

```
“Set of rules and procedures that describes the
objects of conformity assessment, identifies the
specified requirements and provides the
methodology for performing conformity assessment.
Notes: A conformity assessment scheme can be
managed within a conformity assessment system. A
conformity assessment scheme can be operated at an
international, regional, national sub-national, or
industry sector level. A scheme can cover all or part
of the conformity assessment functions” (ISO/IEC
17000 ).
```
**Conformity assessment
system**

```
Recognised assurance approach to assessing (and
generally certifying) conformity. “Set of rules and
procedures for the management of similar or related
conformity assessment schemes. Note: A conformity
assessment system can be operated at an
international, regional, national, sub-national, or
industry sector level” (ISO/IEC 17000).
```

```
Conformity control Control intended to mitigate conformity risks, ideally
achieving conformity by fulfilling the requirements
and expectations, and being able to demonstrate or
prove it if required. Implies the need for those
requirements and expectations to be clearly
identified and accepted, e.g. in the terms and
conditions of a formal policy, agreement, or
understanding between the parties. Alternative
strategies or tactics (such as seeking to deny, avoid,
or evade conformity checks; fabricating evidence or
concealing/destroying evidence of nonconformity;
coercing conformity checkers; restricting, frustrating,
and delaying their checks; or callously accepting the
possibility of penalties and other adverse
consequences) are considered unethical, making
them risky, particularly for those deemed
accountable. Cf. compliance control.
```
**Conformity Monkey** Simian Army tool that checks the configuration of
cloud servers against good practices, shutting down
non-conformant systems. See also Security Monkey.

```
Conformity risk Business or individual risk associated with or arising
from conformity or nonconformity, e.g. the
possibility of some sort of sanction such as distrust
and perhaps termination of a productive business or
employment relationship if nonconformity is
identified or strongly suspected, hinting at the
uncertainties of being both caught in contravention
and penalised.
```
```
Conformity [or
conformance] tester
```
```
Person assessing conformity. “Individual assigned to
perform test activities in accordance with a given
conformance testing standard and associated testing
methodology. An example of such a standard is
ISO/IEC 19790 and the testing methodology
specified in ISO/IEC 24759” (ISO/IEC 19896-1).
```
```
Congestion Capacity constraint, e.g. where the volume of traffic
entering a network path exceeds the available
```

```
bandwidth. Typically reduces performance and
Q uality o f S ervice, increases latency, and may lead
to timeouts or dropouts (availability events, issues,
or incidents). Whereas congestion is normally
unintentional, hackers may deliberately
inject/generate spurious network traffic in order to
conceal their nefarious activities or cause computer
systems to delay/drop critical security
event/alert/alarm messages or fail-insecure.
```
```
Connected places “A community that integrates information and
communication technologies and IoT devices to
collect and analyse data to deliver new services to
the built environment, and enhance the quality of
living for citizens” (UK National Cyber Security
Strategy 2022 ).
```
**Connection forwarding** “The use of network address translation to allow a
port on a network node inside a local area network to
be accessed from outside the network. Alternatively,
using a Secure Shell server to forward a
Transmission Control Protocol connection to an
arbitrary port on the local host” _(NZISM)_.

```
Connectionism,
connectionist
paradigm,
connectionist model,
connectionist approach
```
```
“Form of cognitive modelling that uses a network of
interconnected units that generally are simple
computational units” (ISO/IEC 22989).
```

ConOp Abbrev: Con cept of Op eration.
```
```
C onsensus A ssessment
I nitiative Q uestionnaire
(CAIQ)
```
```
Crude cloud computing security checklist from the
C loud S ecurity A lliance concerning compliance with
the C loud C ontrols M atrix, provided as “a set of
questions a cloud consumer and cloud auditor may
wish to ask of a cloud provider ... a simplified
distillation of the issues, best practices, and control
specifications from [the CSA’s] Guidance and CCM,
intended to help organisations build the necessary
```

```
assessment processes for engaging with cloud
providers.” Anticipates simple binary yes/no answers
to complex issues; hence (being cynical),
respondents are likely to offer the most flattering
responses (a systematic bias). Cf. I nternal C ontrols
Q uestionnaire.

**Consensus mechanism** “A fault-tolerant mechanism used in
blockchain/distributed ledger systems to achieve the
necessary agreement on data values or the state of
the network among distributed processes or
multiagent systems” _(ISACA glossary)_.

```
Consent Permission granted freely (without coercion) and
explicitly by an adequately informed person.
“Personally identifiable information (PII) principal’s
freely given, specific and informed agreement to the
processing of their PII” (ISO/IEC 29100 ). “Any
freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous
indication of the data subject ’ s wishes by which he
or she, by a statement or by a clear affirmative
action, signifies agreement to the processing of
personal data relating to him or her” ( G eneral D ata
P rotection R egulation). “Any freely given, specific,
informed and unambiguous indication of the data
subject’s wishes by which he or she, by a statement
or by a clear affirmative action, signifies agreement
to the processing of personal data relating to him or
her” (ISACA glossary). “This privacy requirement is
one of the fair information practice objectives.
Individuals must be able to prevent the collection of
their personal data, unless legally required. If an
individual has a choice about the use or disclosure of
his or her information, consent is the individual’s
way of giving permission for the use or disclosure.
Consent may be affirmative (for example, opting in)
or implied (for example, not opting out). There are
two types of consent: explicit consent – a
requirement that an individual “signifies” his or her
agreement with a data controller by some active
```

```
communication between the parties; [and] implied
consent – when consent may reasonably be inferred
from the action or inaction of the individual” ( T rust
S ervices C riteria). See also informed consent.
```
```
Consequence,
consequential
```
```
Material effect, net result, harmful outcome, or
impact of a causal relationship when the cause of an
event materialises, such as when a threat acts on a
vulnerability leading to a harmful incident. The
immediate impacts may lead to further issues for
other organisations or individuals, spreading but
gradually dissipating over time and distance like
ripples on a pond. “Outcome of an event affecting
objectives. Notes: A consequence can be certain or
uncertain and can have positive or negative direct or
indirect effects on objectives; Consequences can be
expressed qualitatively or quantitatively; Any
consequence can escalate through cascading and
cumulative effects” (ISO 31000). “<loss> loss of life,
damage to property or economic disruption,
including disruption to transport systems, that can
reasonably be expected as a result of an attack on an
organization in the supply chain or by the use of the
supply chain as a weapon” (ISO 22300). “The result
of a realized risk. A consequence can be certain or
uncertain and can have positive or negative, direct or
indirect effects on objectives. Consequences can be
expressed qualitatively or quantitatively” (ISACA
glossary). “The outcome or potential outcome of an
event or series of events” (OCEG GRC Glossary).
```
**Consistent, consistency** Reliable, dependable, staying essentially the same
over time with only minor and explainable
deviations, if any. An information integrity property,
important when communicating messages, metrics,
_etc_. as an indication that important matters are in fact
sufficiently well understood and controlled. “The
degree of uniformity, standardization and freedom
from contradiction among the documents or parts of
a system or component” _(ISACA glossary)_.


**Consistency checker** Person, function, device, or tool intended to identify
inconsistency (howsoever defined). “A software tool
used to test requirements in design specifications for
consistency and completeness” _(ISACA glossary)_.

```
Console Specially designated terminal device or port on a
system intended for system
management/administrative purposes such as
displaying security events, alerts, and alarms, and
configuring the system. Due to its privileged nature,
the console should be physically secured, e.g.
adjacent to the server, PABX in a secure access-
controlled area. On some systems, users who have
been automatically locked out of other
terminals/ports ( e.g. as a result of someone
repeatedly trying and failing to enter their
passwords) are still able to logon at the console, a
control against that particular form of D enial- o f-
S ervice.
```
```
Console log Log of privileged console activities and messages.
“An automated detail report of computer system
activity” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Conspicuous
consumption
```
```
Without a credible explanation for their wealth,
successful fraudsters, and other criminals living the
high life on their ill-gotten gains risk being noticed,
reported to, and investigated by the authorities.
```
```
Conspire To collude nefariously/secretly with the intention of
jointly committing something unethical,
inappropriate, deceptive, harmful, and/or illegal
(such as fraud).
```
```
Conspiracy Nefarious/secret plan to conspire.
```
```
Consumer Customer who buys a retail product, typically for
their own or their family’s consumption and benefit.
“Natural person who is acting for purposes that are
```

```
outside their trade, business, craft or profession.
Note: Person who is a potential buyer of a labelled
product” (ISO/IEC 27404 DRAFT). “One who
utilizes goods” (ISACA glossary). “A natural person
who acts for purposes which are outside that person’s
trade, business, craft or profession” (EU CRA).
```
```
Consumer guide “Product specific advice concerning evaluated
products can consist of findings from mutually
recognised information security evaluations. This
may include the Common Criteria, findings from
GCSB internal evaluations, any recommendations
for use and references to relevant policy and other
standards” (NZISM).
```

Contact event “Occurs when a Threat Agent establishes a physical
or virtual ( e.g ., network) connection to an Asset” (O-
RT).

**Contact frequency** “The probable frequency, within a given timeframe,
that a Threat Agent will come into contact with an

```
Container Physical or virtual vessel to contain something, such
as a portable software package including the
associated library functions, capable of executing
under various O perating S ystems. “A packaged
environment that includes all necessary
dependencies, executables and code for particular
applications to run separately from the host
computing device” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Containment Time-critical process to restrict the spread of

disease, or disinformation. “Actions taken to limit
exposure after an incident has been identified and
confirmed” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Contaminate Taint or discredit forensic evidence, e.g. through
gaps in the chain of custody or unexplained physical
```

```
or logical changes.

```
Contamination “Introduction of data of one security classification or
security category into data of a lower security
classification or different security category”
(ISO/IEC 2382).
```
```
C ontent D elivery
N etwork (CDN)
```
```
Essentially a geographically dispersed commercial
web content caching service that, where possible,
delivers popular content from copies held on web
servers near to the user rather than from the original
sources. Reduces latency, increases download
speeds, and can help mitigate the effect of D enial- o f-
S ervice attacks and other incidents.
```
```
Content filter, content
filtering
```
```
“A filter that examines content to assess
conformance against a security policy” (AusISM).
“The process of monitoring communications such as
email and web pages, analysing them for suspicious
content, and preventing the delivery of suspicious
content to users” (NIST SP 800-114). “The process of
monitoring communications, including email and
web pages, analysing them for any suspicious or
unwanted content, and preventing the delivery of
suspicious or unwanted content” (NZISM).
“Controlling access to a network by analyzing the
contents of the incoming and outgoing packets, and
either letting them pass or denying them, based on a
list of rules. Note: Differs from packet filtering in
that content filtering analyzes the data in the packet
and packet filtering analyzes the attributes of the
packet itself, e.g ., source/target IP address and
transmission control protocol (TCP) flags” (ISACA
glossary).
```
**C** ontent **S** ecurity **P** olicy
**(CSP)**

```
Instructions in the HTML header concerning what
the browser should or should not do with content
from an appropriately coded web page, e.g. not
loading or interpreting third party files containing
JavaScript, ActiveX, fonts, etc that might be used for
```

```
cross-site scripting or other code injection attacks on
the browser. An exception allows browser plug-ins to
override the CSP, though, creating a vulnerability.
However, the presence of malicious plug-ins on a
system suggests even more significant issues. Cf.
C loud S ervice P rovider.
```
```
Context Surrounding environments or situation within which
things have purpose and meaning. “External and
internal factors to be taken into account when
undertaking a capability assessment. Notes: External
context includes the following: the cultural, social,
political, legal, regulatory, financial, technological,
economic, natural and competitive environment,
whether international, national, regional or local; key
drivers and trends having an impact on the objectives
of the organization; relationships with, and
perceptions and values of, external interested parties.
Internal context includes: the organization’s
mandate; business sensitivity; governance,
organizational structure, roles and accountabilities;
resources and knowledge [ e.g. capital, time, people,
processes, systems and technologies]; organizational
culture” (ISO 22300). “The overall set of internal and
external factors that might influence or determine
how an enterprise, entity, process or individual acts.
Note: Context includes: Technology context
(technological factors that affect the ability of an
enterprise to extract value from data); Data context
(data accuracy, availability, currency and quality);
Skills and knowledge (general experience and
analytical, technical, and business skills);
Organizational and cultural context (political factors
and whether the enterprise prefers data over
intuition); Strategic context (strategic objectives of
the enterprise)” (ISACA glossary).

**Contextual
information [or data]**

```
Metadata that may provide additional context or
supporting information enabling the nature of the
```

```
associated data or information content to be guessed
or interpreted more readily.
```
```
Conti Species of ransomware in the wild in 2022. The
Conti group dismantled its infrastructure and
disbanded in mid-2022, its members dispersing
among other hacker groups such as Hive.
```
```
Contingency Unanticipated and often inherently unpredictable
situation, incident or disaster ( e.g. a bomb, plane
crash, flood, or fire), logical/technical disaster ( e.g.
malware outbreak, equipment breakdown, software
flaw/bug, hack or similar attack on a major business
system or network), and business disaster ( e.g. a
serious fraud or hostile takeover attempt). The
appropriate responses are contingent (dependent) on
the exact nature, scale and severity of the incident,
the context ( e.g. timepoint) in which it occurs, and
the resources available. “Possible future event,
condition or eventuality” (ISO 22300).
```
**Contingency plan,
contingency
management,
contingency thinking**

```
Forward-thinking, flexible planning approach for
preparing, motivating, and marshalling the
organisation’s people and other resources to cope as
effectively as possible in a contingency situation
such as a major incident or disaster. Involves
preparing and exercising general-purpose plans or
preparations (such as forming a crisis management
team from competent, capable people still available),
stocking up on tools and resources (such as duct
tape, walkie-talkies, and white boards), and building
capabilities (such as resourcefulness, adaptability,
and a willingness to ‘go the extra mile’ and ‘do
whatever it takes’) ahead of time. Incidents that are
expected or predictable should be covered by
conventional risk management activities such as
mitigating controls, resilience, and D isaster
R ecovery plans. “Plan for backup procedures,
emergency response, and post-disaster recovery”
(ISO/IEC 2382 ). “Process of developing advance
```

```
arrangements and procedures that enable an
enterprise to respond to an event that might occur by
chance or unforeseen circumstances [and] Plan used
by an enterprise or business unit to respond to a
specific systems failure or disruption” (ISACA
glossary). “A plan for emergency response, backup
operations, and post-disaster recovery in a system, as
part of a security program, to ensure availability of
critical system resources and facilitate continuity of
operations in a crisis” (ENISA RM glossary).
```

improvement
```
```
Determined, conscious effort to mature or get better
at doing something (or at least not to get any worse!)

```
**C** ontinuing **[** or
**C** ontinued] **P** rofessional
**E** ducation **(CPE)**

Continuity Continuing without significant interruption or

to ensure an organization’s ability to continue
operating outside of normal operating conditions. It
applies not only to for-profit companies, but to
organizations of all types, such as non-governmental,
public interest and governmental” (ISO 22300).
```

```
“Preventing, mitigating and recovering from
disruption. Note: The terms business resumption

planning also may be used in this context; they all
concentrate on the recovery aspects of continuity”

**Continuous availability** Absolute requirement for systems providing critical
or vital services, where the impacts of disruptive
incidents are untenable, the associated risks are
extreme, and effective mitigating controls (such as
high-availability fault-tolerant architectures) are
therefore essential. More generally, a reasonable
objective for most other systems although the risks
may be lower. “Nonstop service, with no lapse in
service; the highest level of service in which no
downtime is allowed” _(ISACA glossary)_.

Continuous
improvement, Kaizen
```
```
Q uality A ssurance philosophy and risk management
processes involved in identifying and addressing
production issues or potential concerns routinely and
systematically in order to minimise Q uality C ontrol
failures without compromising other business
objectives (such as cost management and resilience).
“The goals of continuous improvement (Kaizen)
include elimination of waste (activities that add cost,
but do not add value); just-in-time (JIT) delivery;
production load leveling of amounts and types;
```

```
standardized work; paced moving lines; and right-
sized equipment. Notes: A closer definition of the
Japanese usage of Kaizen is to take it apart and put it
back together in a better way. What is taken apart is
usually a process, system, product or service. Kaizen
is a daily activity whose purpose goes beyond
improvement. It is also a process that, when done
correctly, humanizes the workplace, eliminates hard
work (both mental and physical), and teaches people
how to do rapid experiments using the scientific
method and how to learn to see and eliminate waste
in business processes” (ISACA glossary).

plan**

control monitoring

“A process that includes: Developing a strategy to

technology (I&T)-related controls/metrics;
Recording and evaluating I&T-related events and the

C ontinuous T hreat
E xposure M anagement
(CTEM)
```
```
Misleading marketing buzzword for cybersecurity
activities intended to identify, prioritise, and mitigate
topical risks involving networked systems. It actually
involves automated monitoring of attack surfaces,
```

```
meaning exposed known vulnerabilities, as opposed
to threats.

```
Contract Binding agreement between two or more parties, for
various strengths of ‘binding.’ Formal contracts
prepared by qualified lawyers and signed
(‘executed’) by duly authorised representatives are
normally legally binding on the parties but may be
unenforceable (especially any terms deemed ‘unfair’
by the courts or overridden by laws such as the fair
use provisions of copyright law). Verbal, informal,
presumed, or social contracts may also be legally
binding, although naturally they are harder to prove
and hence enforce. If someone breaks the seal on
shrink-wrapped software, for instance, they may be
deemed to have accepted the licence terms and
conditions visible through the clear plastic film,
implying a contractual commitment. Generally
speaking, contracts may not be unilaterally imposed
by one party on the other ( e.g. email disclaimers);
hence, a signature and/or a ‘consideration’ (normally
a payment) may be necessary to demonstrate
someone’s willingness to commit. “An agreement
between two or more persons or entities, which is
intended to be enforceable at law and includes a
contract made by deed or in writing” (NZISM).
```
**Contract Account (CA)** Blockchain wallet managed automatically by a smart
contract. “The account (or address) created when a
smart contract is deployed by the smart contract
owner. Contract account contains the runtime virtual
machine bytecode for a contract” _(ISACA glossary)_.
_Cf_. **C** ertification **A** uthority.

measure, protection

```
a. [Noun] Something which mitigates risk, i.e. it

```

costs, or other adverse consequences caused or
triggered by or simply arising from an incident.
Some controls mitigate threats ( _e.g_. deterrents)
or impacts ( _e.g_. backups), although most

“Measure that maintains and/or modifies risk.
Notes: Controls include, but are not limited to,
any process, policy, device, practice or other
conditions and/or actions which maintain and/or
modify risk. Controls may not always exert the
intended or assumed modifying effect”
_(ISO/IEC 31000 )_. “The means of managing

be of an administrative, technical, management
or legal nature” _(ISACA glossary)_. “Any person,
policy, process, or technology that has the
potential to reduce the Loss Event Frequency
(LEF) – Loss Prevention Controls – and/or Loss
Magnitude (LM) – Loss Mitigation Controls”
_(O-RT)_. “Policies and procedures that are part
of the entity’s system of internal control. The

**_S_** _ervices_ **_C_** _riteria)_. “Any action taken by

established objectives and goals will be
achieved” _(IIA GIAS)_.
b. _[Verb]_ To exert influence over, dominate,
coerce, or attempt to direct and constrain
something such as a system, machine, person,
organisation, perception, process, market, and
price

meet the requirements established for protecting the

information or system” (NIST SP 800-171). See also

US government term for unclassified information

```

```

```

**Control perimeter** The notional area, domain, or zone (such as the

of control authority for an entity. Notes: For
example, if a system is within the control perimeter,


```
the right and ability exist to control it in response to

```
Control risk Uncertainties relating to a control, such as its design,

reliability, trustworthiness, and effectiveness in
practice. Mitigated by systems security engineering,

security requirements, control testing, and other
assurance measures. “Risk that assets are

(ISACA glossary). “The risk that a material error
exists that would not be prevented or detected on a

```
Cookie Small text file sent by a web server to the browser

websites or JavaScript may access and reuse the

Notes: The first time a cookie is set, a user may be

Subsequent to this, whenever the cookie ’ s message is

**Copy protection, copy
prevention**

```
Technical controls typically involving encryption and
dongles, intended to prevent or restrict the ability of
users to copy or use software and other I ntellectual
P roperty except on the original authentic storage

```
Copyright Legal and moral protection giving the creators of

information by others with the ability to permit or

or agreements, for decades (typically 70 years).
Aside from being unethical and often illegal, the

creating and releasing I ntellectual P roperty. “The

```
Corner case Unanticipated and potentially harmful situations

multiple parameters, factors or conditions

software and systems under stress. Testing can
simulate this by deliberately driving data values,
volumes, loading, temperatures, etc. towards
boundary conditions, figuratively ‘pushing things
into a dark corner’ to check whether controls
intended to rate-limit, avoid unsafe modes, generate
warnings, trigger alerts and alarms, gracefully
degrade performance, initiate failover responses, etc.
function correctly in practice. See also edge case.

prove in court) as opposed to a single fraudster or a

27033-1).

sustainability,

actions & controls

countermeasure

```
Counterfeit a. [Noun] Pirated, fake, fabricated copy

P roperty R ights and defrauding the purchaser.

Intelligence activities and methods to protect

```
Countermeasure Generally synonymous with control. May refer more
specifically to a reactive or corrective control in
some contexts. “Action, device, procedure,
technique, or other measure that is designed to
minimize vulnerability” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “Action
taken to lower the likelihood of a security threat
scenario succeeding in its objectives, or to reduce the

glossary). “Actions, devices, procedures, or
techniques that meet or oppose ( i.e ., counters) a
threat, a vulnerability, or an attack by eliminating or
preventing it, by minimizing the harm it can cause,
or by discovering and reporting it so that corrective
action can be taken” (CNSSI 4009 ). “Reactive
methods used to prevent an exploit from successfully
occurring once a threat has been detected. Intrusion
Prevention Systems (IPS) commonly employ

```
Counterstrike,
counter-hack
```
```
Retaliatory attack directed against the alleged or
apparent perpetrator of a prior attack. Aside from
escalating tensions and perhaps being illegal, a
counterstrike may be misdirected, for instance if the
perpetrator was incorrectly identified, perhaps
because the original attack involved spoofing or
other covert, coercive, or deceptive false-flag
techniques. A highly risky approach.
```

```
Counterterrorism Government-sponsored activities such as
propaganda, intelligence, surveillance, and
cybertage, intended to counteract, undermine,

```
```
Cover, coverage Scope, type, or nature of insurance provided,
normally defined in the policy in terms of events,
perils, or hazards, assets, etc. included or excluded,
plus the limits of liability and specified terms and
conditions. “The proportion of known attacks
detected by an intrusion detection system (IDS)”
(ISACA glossary).
```
```
Coverage analysis “The determination and assessment of measures
associated with the invocation of program structural
elements to determine the adequacy of a test run.
Coverage analysis is useful when attempting to
execute each statement, branch, path or iterative
structure in a program. Tools that capture this data
and provide reports summarizing relevant
information have this feature” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Covert Covered. Refers to secretive, hidden, surreptitious,
undercover, quiet, or silent activities or devices,
often unauthorised and malicious in nature, such as
bugs used for surveillance or spying. See also covert
control, cryptic.
```
**Covert channel, back
channel**

```
Covert or cryptic mechanism allowing confidential
information to be discreetly communicated and
extracted from a supposedly secure system, network,
or location (such as a S ensitive C omparted
I nformation F acility) bypassing confidentiality
controls. Examples include steganography and out-
of-band communications, e.g. manipulating a
circuit’s current demand using specific operating
sequences in order to pass information to a
compromised or illicitly attached current-monitoring
device, micro-manipulating the timing of network
packets to convey information that would normally
```

```
be dismissed as jitter, or using wideband spread-
spectrum radio transmissions that resemble noise.
“Transmission channel that may be used to transfer
data in a manner that violates security policy”
(ISO/IEC 2382 ). “The means by which information
can be communicated between two parties in a
covert fashion using normal system operations. For
example by changing the amount of hard drive space
that is available on a file server can be used to
communicate information” (SANS glossary). See
also backdoor. Cf. side channel.
```
**Covert control** Control designed to be covert such as a ‘silent alarm’
that summons a response without audibly alerting
intruders on-site, various forms of monitoring and
logging that discreetly record evidence of incidents
for later analysis, and surveillance in general.

organisations hit by ransomware, such as negotiating
ransoms.

```

force attacks and shell interactions on UNIX-based
servers, for analysis. More info:
https://www.cowrie.org/
