**Crack, cracker,
cracking**

```
Malicious hack or cybercriminal act, generally
motivated by the prospect of personal gain.
Passwords, cryptosystems, and safes may be
cracked, e.g. by brute force attacks. “To ‘break into’
or ‘get around’ the security of a software program.
Notes: For example, certain newsgroups post serial
numbers for pirated versions of software. A cracker
may download this information in an attempt to
crack the program so he/she can use it. Crack is
commonly used in the case of cracking
(unencrypting) a password or other sensitive data”
(ISACA glossary).
```
```
Crambus Iranian-backed group of cyber-spooks, also known
variously as APT34, Cobalt Gypsy, OilRig, and
Helix Kitten. Active since 2014. Allegedly used
PowerShell-based and other malware to compromise
a middle-Eastern government’s target networks and
systems in 2023.
```
```
Crash, abend a. Unplanned sudden computer system,
application, process, or device failure resulting
from an unhandled exception/error condition
triggered accidentally, e.g. by a bug, flaw, or
power glitch, or deliberately by a hack,
malware, or cybertage. “The sudden and
complete failure of a computer system or
component” (ISACA glossary).
b. Sudden, energetic, unplanned, and hazardous
impact between physical objects, perhaps
resulting from catastrophic failure of the
collision-avoidance capabilities of an
autonomous vehicle.
c. Drastic reduction of stock values on the stock
markets, causing instability and perhaps
collapse of the global financial industry.
```
```
Crash dump File containing a snapshot of the contents of main
memory at the time of a crash. Used by software
developers to analyse the status of the stack, heap,
```

```
registers, buffers, pointers, etc. to discover what
caused the crash. Used by hackers to find
confidential information such as passwords and
encryption keys that had been held temporarily in
memory. Used by malware analysts to identify
cryptic malware.
```
```
CRC Abbrev: C yclic R edundancy C heck.
```
```
C reative C ommons
(CC)
```
```
Not-for-profit organisation promoting free access to
and use of I ntellectual P roperty as in copyleft. Their
standardised licences cater for various situations
ranging from placing information unencumbered into
the public domain, through requiring attribution of
the owner, to restrictions on commercial use and
modification. Cf. C ommon C riteria, C ertified in
C ybersecurity.
```
```
Credential Something a person, system, etc. presents to confirm
(authenticate) their asserted identity ( e.g. a passport,
password, biometric, security token, or digital
certificate) or professional capabilities ( e.g. résumé
or curriculum vitae plus the original, authentic
qualification or competence certificates). “Data that
are transferred to establish the claimed identity of an
entity” (ISO/IEC 2382 ).
```
**Credentialed analysis** “In vulnerability analysis, passive monitoring
approaches in which passwords or other access
credentials are required. Note: Usually involves
accessing a system data object” _(ISACA glossary)_.

```
Credential stuffing Automated brute force attack involving attempting to
logon to multiple websites using lists of usernames,
passwords, and other credentials accumulated from
other sources, such as previous hacks. If a logon
succeeds (proving the credentials valid), further
information may be obtained from the compromised
userID, perhaps leading to direct exploitation and
further compromises (identity fraud).
```

```
Credible Believable. Social engineers and fraudsters work
hard to make their pretexts credible to fool their
targets into trusting them inappropriately.
```
```
Credit card number See P rimary A ccount N umber.
```
```
Credit risk Uncertainty relating to credit, e.g. the possibility of a
borrower defaulting on a mortgage, and the debtor
foreclosing on the property. “The potential that a
borrower or creditor will fail to meet financial
obligations in accordance with agreed terms” (ISACA
glossary).
```
```
Crenelated Classic ╓┐_╓┐_╓┐_╓┐_╓┐ shaped tops to the
battlements of Mediaeval castles. Archers cowered
behind the uprights of the parapet for protection
while raining down arrows upon the attackers below
through the crenels (notches). An ancient physical
security control.
```
**CREST (International)** UK-based government-supported not-for-profit
organisation and scheme to test and accredit
penetration testers. Given the trusted, privileged
nature of the work, pentesters must be competent in
order for their clients to place any reliance on their
assurance efforts, and must be trustworthy since they
are likely to gain access to valuable and/or
confidential information assets if (when!) tested
security controls fail. Offers CREST Practitioner,
CREST Registered, and CREST Certified
qualifications. See also CBEST. More info:
https://www.crest-approved.org/

```
Crib Useful hint for a cryptanalyst, often consisting of
some known plaintext that might reveal if the correct
decryption key has been found by a brute force
attack on the ciphertext. Standard or routine parts of
a message (such as a date/timestamp, predictable
```

```
sequence number, message type or protocol
identifier, greeting or signature) may be useful cribs.
```
```
Crime Act prohibited by law that can be punished by
government authorities under the criminal justice
system. Can range from minor offenses such as
traffic violations, to serious offenses such as violent
assault and murder. See also cybercrime. Cf. tort.
```
```
C rime P revention
T hrough E nvironmental
D esign (CPTED)
```
```
Physical architectural design philosophy that seeks to
deter attacks by criminals against people innocently
using shopping malls, railway stations, walkways
between parking lots and buildings, etc. or against
the properties. Even lighting and landscaped areas
free of hidey-holes permit more effective
surveillance monitoring and escape routes for
potential victims, while barriers and visual cues help
distinguish private from public property. Thorny
bushes near windows and walls, and razor wire deter
casual if not professional intruders. “Process for
analysing and assessing crime and security risks to
guide development, urban design, site management
and the use of the built environment in order to
prevent and reduce crime and the fear of crime, and
to promote and improve public health, quality of life
and sustainability. Note: Environmental design refers
to the applied arts and sciences dealing with creating
the human-designed environment” (ISO 22341).
```
**Crimeware, crimeware
kit, attack toolkit,
exploit kit**

```
Software package used to generate and/or distribute
malware using libraries of technical exploits, plus the
infection and remote-control elements including
functions to report statistics on the status of the
exploitation process. A few crimeware kits (such as
Carberp and Zeus) have been released onto the
Internet. Some are traded commercially on the black
market or hacker underground. Most are jealously
guarded by the hackers who created and maintain
them and/or the cybercriminals who pay for and
exploit them. “A type of malware used by cyber
```

```
criminals. The malware is designed to enable the
cyber criminal to make money off of the infected
system (such as harvesting key strokes, using the
infected systems to launch Denial of Service Attacks,
etc.)” (SANS glossary). See also malware,
ransomware, adware, scareware, spouseware,
stalkerware, spyware.
```
```
Criminal a. [Noun] Person who commits crime.
b. [Adjective] Relating to crime.
```
```
Criminality Illegal acts, punishable under criminal law.
```
**Criminal underground** See black market and hacker underground.

```
CRISC Abbrev: C ertified in R isk and I nformation S ystems
C ontrol.
```
```
Crisis Chaotic situation associated with a serious incident
or emergency, characterised by some disorder and
instinctive behaviours or panic. Literal survival of
the affected people, organisation, group, team,
political party, nation, etc. is generally the overriding
priority in a crisis; hence, other considerations
(including security) may be downplayed or
disregarded at least until the crisis subsides.
“Unstable condition involving an impending abrupt
or significant change that requires urgent attention
and action to protect life, assets, property or the
environment” (ISO 22300).
```
```
Crisis management Management activities during a crisis such as
evacuating buildings, calling the emergency services,
triage, and initiating incident management activities
as order is gradually restored. “Holistic management
process that identifies potential impacts that threaten
an organization and provides a framework for
building resilience, with the capability for an
effective response that safeguards the interests of the
organization’s key interested parties, reputation,
```

```
brand and value-creating activities, as well as
effectively restoring operational capabilities. Note:
Crisis management also involves the management of
preparedness, mitigation response, and continuity or
recovery in the event of an incident, as well as
management of the overall programme through
training, rehearsals and reviews to ensure the
preparedness, response and continuity plans stay
current and up to date” (ISO 22300).
```
**Crisis management
team**

```
Workers responsible for crisis management. “Group
of individuals functionally responsible for directing
the development and execution of the response and
operational continuity plan, declaring an operational
disruption or emergency/crisis situation, and
providing direction during the recovery process, both
pre- and post-disruptive incident. Note: The crisis
management team can include individuals from the
organization as well as immediate and first
responders and interested parties” (ISO 22300).
```
```
Criteria Plural of criterion. Conditions, specification,
parameters, or demands that are expected or required
to be satisfied. Used for direction, evaluation,
assurance, measurement, and other purposes. “The
benchmarks used to measure or evaluate the subject
matter” ( T rust S ervices C riteria). “The standards
and benchmarks used to measure and present the
subject matter and against which an IS auditor
evaluates the subject matter. Notes: Criteria should
be: Objective—free from bias; Measurable—provide
for consistent measurement; Complete—include all
relevant factors to reach a conclusion; Relevant—
relate to the subject matter. In an attestation
engagement, benchmarks against which
management’s written assertion on the subject matter
can be evaluated. The practitioner forms a
conclusion concerning subject matter by referring to
suitable criteria” (ISACA glossary).
```

```
Critical, criticality a. Crucial, essential, extremely valuable, or utterly
indispensable. An imprecise overused
emotionally charged context-dependent
adjective. “Qualitative description used to
emphasize the importance of a resource, process
or function that must be available and
operational constantly or available and
operational at the earliest possible time after an
incident, emergency or disaster has occurred”
(ISO/IEC 27031 ). “The importance of a
particular asset or function to the enterprise, and
the impact if that asset or function is not
available” (ISACA glossary).
b. Particularly serious or grave situation or highly
risky event capable of causing, precipitating, or
developing into a crisis.
c. Involving painstaking and perhaps biased or
prejudiced criticism or critique.
d. Particularly negative, demeaning, or damning.
Cf. vital.

```

```
on production or generation, transmission, storage
and distribution of electric power, gas, oil and heat”
(ISO/IEC 27019).
```

**(CCP)**

```
“Point, step or process at which controls can be

22300 ). “(QA) A function or an area in a
manufacturing process or procedure, the failure of
which, or loss of control over, may have an adverse
effect on the quality of the finished product and may
result in an unacceptable health risk” (ISACA
glossary).
```
```
Critical customer a. Customer who complains, bitterly, about crappy
products, such as a dead parrot.
b. “Entity, the loss of whose business would
threaten the survival of an organization” (ISO
```

```
22300 ).
```

```
information
```
```
Data or information that, for some objective or

“Data that are identified during the risk assessment
```

**Critical design review** Unusually important or utterly indispensable design
review. “A review to verify that the detailed design

the configuration items and other items of
equipment, facilities, software and personnel; to
assess risk areas for each configuration item; and, as

support documents” _(ISACA glossary)_.

```
Critical discipline “The background disciplines that comprise the

Security & Continuity, and Audit & Assurance”
```

```
Critical facility Critical facility. “Physical structure, network or other
asset that provide services that are essential to the
```

```
Critical finding Critical finding. “Findings or results that meet one or
more of the following criteria: (a) Have a significant
impact on the opinion provided. (b) Cannot be
repeated or checked in the absence of the

conclusion of the examination of an incident, fire,
```

**Critical findings check** Competent assessment and evaluation of critical
findings for assurance reasons, _e.g._ to determine
whether they qualify as admissible evidence. “A
check on any critical finding to ensure they are
acceptable” _(FSRCoP)_.

```
Critical function Critical function. “Business activities or information
```

```
Critical indicator Critical indicator. “Quantitative, qualitative or
descriptive measure used to assess the hazard being
monitored to identify the potential for the
development of an incident, accident or emergency.
Note: Critical indicators provide information about
```

```
C ritical I nfrastructure
(CI), C ritical C orporate
I nfrastructure (CCI),
C ritical E nterprise
I nfrastructure (CEI),
C ritical N ational
I nfrastructure (CNI)
```
```
Shared infrastructure services and supplies, such as
electricity, water, fuel, food, telecommunications,
government, law enforcement, armed services, and
the security services (CI), that are considered critical
for a nation (CNI) or organisation (CCI, CEI).
Significant failure of any of these, perhaps as a result
of a physical or electronic attack on the computer
equipment, networks, things , or people monitoring
and controlling them, is likely to cause immediate
disruption and substantial economic damage as well
as perhaps causing injuries, deaths, environmental
```

```
incidents, etc., making these attractive targets in
cyberwar and for ransomware attacks. “Systems and
assets, whether physical or virtual, so vital to the
United States that the incapacity or destruction of
such systems and assets would have a debilitating
impact on cybersecurity, national economic security,
national public health or safety, or any combination
of those matters” (NIST C yber S ecurity F ramework).
“Those critical elements of infrastructure (namely
assets, facilities, systems, networks or processes and
the essential workers that operate and facilitate
them), the loss or compromise of which could result
in: (a) major detrimental impact on the availability,
integrity or delivery of essential services – including
those services whose integrity, if compromised,
could result in significant loss of life or casualties –
taking into account significant economic or social
impacts; and/or (b) significant impact on national
securi t y, national d e fence, or th e functioning of the
state” (UK National Cyber Security Strategy 2022 ).
“Set of organizations and facilities that are essential
for the functioning of society and the economy as a
whole. Note: A failure or malfunction of such
organizations and facilities can result in sustained
supply shortfalls, make a significant impact on
public security and have other wide-ranging
impacts” (ISO/IEC 27019 ). “Systems whose
incapacity or destruction will have a debilitating
effect on the economic security of an enterprise,
community or nation” (ISACA glossary). See also
cyberinfrastructure. Cf. C onfiguration I tem,
C ompetitive I ntelligence, C ounter- I ntelligence,
C onfidential I nformant.
```

```
Critical thinking Ability to consider, discern, and take account of the

ignoring, discounting, or challenging dubious,
biased, or malicious sources in order to develop
informed, sound, objective understandings and valid
opinions. An increasingly valuable skill, given the
```

```
Web hacking technique in which badly designed

```

**CrowdStrike incident,
CrowdStrike glitch**

```
CrowdStrike is a US-based cybersecurity company.
On Friday July 19th 2024, a faulty update to its
Falcon e X tended D etection and R esponse software
was released with inadequate pre-release testing.
Following rapid automatic deployment to thousands
of corporate customers, more than 8 million systems
crashed worldwide, causing widespread business
disruption for days and US$5 billion in estimated
losses.
```
```
CRUD (C reate, R ead,
U pdate, D elete )
```
```
Fundamental operations or activities on stored data
in a D ata B ase, i.e. C reate (generate a new record),
R ead (retrieve stored data), U pdate (modify stored
data), and D elete (erase a record or else flag it as
such if it needs to be retained due to still being
referenced elsewhere).
```
```
Cryptanalysis,
cryptanalyst,
cryptanalytic, crypto
```
```
Study and practice of breaking cryptosystems by any
means, normally through a combination of
mathematics, language analysis, brilliant intuition,
lots of time, powerful computers, and sheer hard
work. The cryptanalyst may attempt to find and
exploit mathematical or technical weaknesses in the
algorithm (perhaps inserted deliberately, i.e.
backdoors) and/or the system and processes that
implement it, guess the keys by brute force, or
somehow disentangle the relationships between
known plaintext such as a crib and the corresponding
```

```
ciphertext. “Analysis of a cryptographic system, its
inputs or outputs, or both, to derive sensitive
information, such as plaintext” (ISO/IEC 2382 ).
“The mathematical science that deals with analysis
of a cryptographic system in order to gain knowledge
needed to break or circumvent the protection that the
system is designed to provide. In other words,
convert the cipher text to plaintext without knowing
the key” (SANS glossary). Cf. cryptography.
```
```
Cryptic Surreptitious, deliberately hidden, secretive,
concealed or non-obvious, such as a fiendishly
difficult crossword puzzle. Not necessarily
unauthorised or malicious. See also covert.
```
```
C rypt- K ey (CK) “The term used to describe the UK’s use of
cryptography to protect the critical information and
services on which the UK government, military and
national security community rely, including from
attack by our most capable adversaries” (UK
National Cyber Security Strategy 2022).
```
```
Crypto Ambiguous contraction of crypto graphy (usually),
otherwise crypto logy, crypto currency, etc.
depending on context.
```
```
Crypto AG Swiss-based high-grade commercial/national security
cryptographic equipment supplier covertly owned by
the US ( C entral I ntelligence A gency) and German
( B undes N achrichten D ienst) intelligence agencies
until 2018. “Operation Rubicon” was a scandalous
supply chain compromise of a type the spooky
intelligence community warns and worries about.
```

crypto, cybercurrency**


**Cryptographic erase** With various important provisos concerning the level
of risk, overall process, technology, algorithm, key
length and complexity, _etc._ encrypting data or
overwriting it with ciphertext, and then destroying

permanently irretrievable. “Method of sanitization in

```
Value used to transform data in a cryptographic
operation by controlling the algorithm in a particular
manner, e.g. to decrypt a message previously
encrypted with the same key in symmetric
cryptography. Note: ‘cryptovariable’ may be the
correct technical term but almost nobody except
über-crypto-geeks use it: ‘key’ is simpler and more
widely understood. “Bit string that controls the
operations of encryption or decryption” (ISO/IEC
2382 ). Cf. physical (non-cryptographic) key.
```
**Cryptographic module** Tamper-resistant computer subsystem consisting of
data processing, storage, and communications
hardware and firmware, designed to perform
cryptographic operations such as receiving,
encrypting, and returning a nonce using a private key
in a challenge-response authentication scenario.

```
protocol
```

```
using encrypted communications” (NZISM). “An
agreed standard for secure communication between
two or more entities to provide confidentiality,
integrity, authentication and non-repudiation of data”
(AusISM).
```

```
software

```

```
P ublic K ey I nfrastructure. “Documents, devices,
equipment, and associated techniques that are used
```

```
together to provide a means of encryption or

security services. Most often, the term is used in

“A related set of hardware or software used for
cryptographic communication, processing or storage,
```

```
From Ancient Greek ( κρυπτός or kryptós meaning
hidden and γράφειν or graphein meaning writing),
the science, study, and practice of creating systems to
hide information and to find and retrieve it when
needed. Involves the use of mathematical algorithms
for encryption, hashing, authentication, etc.
“Discipline that embodies the principles, means, and
methods for the transformation of data in order to
hide their semantic content, prevent their
unauthorized use, or prevent their undetected
modification” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “The study of
mathematical techniques related to aspects of
information security, such as confidentiality, data
integrity, entity authentication and data origin
authentication” ( ISACA glossary ). “The study of
secure communications techniques that allow only
the sender and intended recipient of a message to
view its contents” (NZISM). “The science or study of
analysing and deciphering codes and ciphers;
cryptanalysis” (UK National Cyber Security Strategy
2022 ). Cf. cryptanalysis, cryptology.
```

```
infected systems without their owners’ knowledge
and consent. See also cryptojacking.
```

```
C entre to “organisations responsible for vitally

focus on essential functions which if compromised
```

Armageddon**

```
Full-blown unrestrained cyberwar between highly
```

```
Attack staged primarily through electronic means,
particularly through the Internet. “An attack, via
cyberspace, targeting an enterprise’s use of
cyberspace for the purpose of disrupting, disabling,
destroying, or maliciously controlling a computing
environment/infrastructure; or destroying the
integrity of the data or stealing controlled
information” (CNSSI 4009 ). “Malicious attempts to
exploit vulnerabilities in information systems or
physical systems in cyberspace and to damage,
disrupt or gain unauthorized access to these systems”
(ISO/IEC TS 27100) ... [additional note: “Common
cyber attacks to consumer IoT are basic attacks that
could be carried out by script kiddies and amateur
hackers” (ISO/IEC 27404 DRAFT). “A malicious
and deliberate attempt by an individual or
organisation to breach the information system of
another individual or organisation” (UK Cyber
Security Breaches Survey 2023 ). “Deliberate
exploitation of computer systems, digitally-
dependent enterprises and networks to cause harm”
(UK National Cyber Security Strategy 2022 ). “A
malicious ICT-related incident caused by means of
an attempt perpetrated by any threat actor to destroy,
expose, alter, disable, steal or gain unauthorised
access to, or make unauthorised use of, an asset”
(DORA).
```

```
Cyberbully Someone who uses social media, email, etc. to
harass, embarrass, intimidate, threaten, coerce,
and/or traumatise victims.
```
**Cyber command** Military command centre for cyber operations, such
as the US Cyber Command reportedly based at Fort
Meade, Maryland.

```
Cybercop “An investigator of activities related to computer
crime” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Cybercrime Crime in cyberspace. Colloquially, the use or
exploitation of I nformation T echnology and/or the
Internet by cybercriminals to plan, coordinate,
commit/perpetrate, or profit from crime. “Category
of crime involving technology that may or may not
involve the Internet” (ISACA glossary). “Involves
gaining unauthorised access, or causing damage, to
computers, networks, data or other digital devices, or
the information held on those devices. Examples of
cyber crime include hacking or unauthorised access
into online accounts ( e.g. banking, email or social
media accounts), denial of service attacks, or devices
being infected by a virus or other malicious software
(including ransomware)” (UK Cyber Security
Breaches Survey 2023 ). “Cyber-dependent crime
(crimes that can only be committed through the use
of ICT devices, where the devices are both the tool
for committing the crime and the target of the crime);
or cyber-enabled crime (crimes that may be
committed without ICT devices, like financial fraud,
but are changed significantly by use of ICT in terms
of scale and reach)” (UK National Cyber Security
Strategy 2022).
```

```
Cybercriminal,
cybercrook

```

```
into modern society that we have become highly
reliant (dependent) on it, particularly in relation to
critical infrastructure providing power, water, food,
```

Cyber Essentials Plus**

```
Government-backed basic (minimalist)
organisational cybersecurity certification scheme
from the UK National Cyber Security Centre,
revolving around just five key controls: firewalls,
secure configurations, patching, user access controls,
and malware prevention. The ‘Plus’ version increases
assurance with stronger conformity assessments.
“The NCSC recommends Cyber Essentials as the
minimum standard of cyber security for all
organisations.” Sets the very lowest of low hurdles,
too low even for a supple Caribbean island limbo
dancer. More info:
https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/cyberessentials/overview
```

```
and control over sensitive and/or valuable
information in order to coerce victims out of money,
```

```
etc. Attacks typically involve the use of hacking,
malware ( e.g. ransomware), and social engineering
to steal or leverage the value of data, I ntellectual
P roperty, storage media, or I nformation T echnology
devices. See also extortion.
```

relation to money, services, property or goods, which
uses data or access obtained through one or more of
the following: ransomware; viruses, spyware or
malware; denial of service attacks; hacking –
unauthorised access to devices (including,
computers, smartphones and other internet-connected
devices), as well as online takeovers; phishing
attacks” _(UK Cyber Security Breaches Survey 2023)_.

**Cybersecurity, cyber-
security, cyber security**

```
Primarily refers to technological/ I nformation
T echnology security controls protecting computer
systems, networks, and the associated data against
attacks from the Internet. However, the definition is
sometimes widened to include information security
as a whole, while some refer specifically to defensive
countermeasures within cyberwar, Internet security,
C ritical N ational I nfrastructure security, or even
securing virtual worlds. Caveat lector. “Safeguarding
of people, society, organizations and nations from
cyber risks. Note: Safeguarding means to keep cyber
risk at a tolerable level” (ISO/IEC TS 27 100 ). “The
activities necessary to protect network and
information systems, the users of such systems, and
other persons affected by cyber threats” (EU
Cybersecurity Act). “The protection of information
assets by addressing threats to information
processed, stored and transported by internetworked
information systems” (ISACA glossary). “Prevention
of damage to, protection of, and restoration of
computers, electronic communications systems,
electronic communications services, wire
communication, and electronic communication,
including information contained therein, to ensure its
availability, integrity, authentication, confidentiality,
```

```
and nonrepudiation” (DoD dictionary). “The ability
to protect or defend the use of cyberspace from cyber
attacks” (CNSSI 4009 ). “The process of protecting
information by preventing, detecting, and responding
to attacks” (NIST CSF). “Includes any processes,
practices or technologies that organisations have in
place to secure their networks, computers, programs
or the data they hold from damage, attack or
unauthorised access” (UK Cyber Security Breaches
Survey 2023 ). “Measures used to protect the
confidentiality, integrity and availability of systems
and data” (AusISM). “The protection of internet-
connected systems (to include hardware, software
and associated infrastructure), the data on them, and
the services they provide, from unauthorised access,
harm or misuse. This includes harm caused
intentionally by the operator of the system, or
accidentally, as a result of failing to follow security
procedures or being manipulated into doing so” (UK
National Cyber Security Strategy 2022).
```


```
cybersecurity
framework
```
```
a. NIST’s “Framework for Improving Critical
Infrastructure Cybersecurity” reflects the
timeline of an incident and the need for
appropriate information security controls that
precede, accompany, or follow an incident
through the identify, protect, detect, respond,
and recover phases (called ‘functions’ within
CSF). The US Cybersecurity Enhancement Act
2014 required NIST to develop “a prioritised,
flexible, repeatable, performance based, and
cost-effective approach, including information
security measures and controls that may be
voluntarily adopted by owners and operators of
critical infrastructure to help them identify,
assess, and manage cyber risks.” It is essentially
a simple risk and incident management structure
to help protect the US C ritical N ational
I nfrastructure against cyber risks (called
‘cybersecurity risks’ within CSF), drawing on
several other standards and methods for the
controls. Cf. C ritical S uccess F actor. More info:
https://www.nist.gov/cyberframework
b. “Basic set of concepts used to organise and
communicate cybersecurity activities” (ISO/IEC
27110 ).
```

**Cyber security incident** Security incident involving
cybersecurity/technology. “An unwanted or
unexpected cyber security event, or a series of such
events, that has either compromised business
operations or has a significant probability of
compromising business operations” ( _AusISM_ ). Cf.
_cyber security event_.

```

unpredictable), or disordered (of unknown status).

```

**D** ata **B** ase **(DB** or **db),
database system**

```
Structured and managed collection of data
and information. The structuring,
accumulation, and collation of data, plus the
relationships between items, along with the
software functions to manage, manipulate,
and report them, can make DBs far more
valuable than plain, unmanaged ‘flat files’ or
```

```
simple lists and tables. The most important

organized according to a conceptual
structure describing the characteristics of
these data and the relationships among their
corresponding entities, supporting one or
more application areas” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “A

redundancy, organized according to a
schema to serve one or more applications.
The data are stored so that they can be used
by different programs without considering
the data structure or organization. A
common approach is used to add new data
and modify and retrieve existing data”
(ISACA glossary). “Organized collection of
data, generally stored and accessed
electronically from a computer system.
Databases can reside remotely or on-site.
Database Management Systems (DMSs) are
used to administer databases, and are not
considered part of a database for this
document” (CIS Controls). “A collection of
information (often but not exclusively
electronic) in a structured format allowing
searching which may be used for purposes
of interpretation” (FSRCoP).
```

```
L earning A rtificial I ntelligence systems.
Advanced audio-visual techniques can ‘put

politicians, activists, and adversaries,
making them appear to express something
they did not. Just as written materials can be
edited or fabricated, small changes to
genuine audio-visual content (such as

dramatically affect the meaning or
interpretation of, say, a political speech or
public statement. As the technology
advances, wholescale changes are becoming
even easier to make and yet harder to spot,
leading to de novo fabrication of lengthy
video clips in fake settings with fake
```

```
audiences. There are serious implications for

coercion, blackmail, fraud, espionage,
information warfare and cyberwar,

accountability, trust, critical thinking, and
society at large. “Media manipulated by

representations of faces and facial
expressions, sounds, voices, and speech, to
```

**Degauss, degaussing** Secure erasure process that applies an

```
extremely strong magnetic field to magnetic
data storage media such as computer disks
or tapes to destroy the stored data. In
addition to concerns over the equipment and
operating procedures, the extremely high
density of modern magnetic storage
methods, high coercivity of the materials,
and use of disk mirroring and similar
redundant storage/error correction
techniques make degaussing less reliable in
practice than it may appear, although
subsequent physical destruction of
degaussed media increases assurance.
“Render data unreadable by applying a
strong magnetic field to the media”
(ISO/IEC 27040 ). “The application of
variable levels of alternating currents for the
purpose of demagnetizing magnetic
recording media. Notes: The process
involves increasing the alternating current
field gradually from zero to some maximum
value and back to zero, leaving a minimal
residue of magnetic induction on the media.
Degauss generally means to erase” (ISACA
glossary). “A process for reducing the
magnetisation of a magnetic storage device
to zero by applying a reverse (coercive)
```

```
magnetic force, rendering any previously
stored data unreadable” (AusISM).
```
```
Degausser Device or person that degausses. “An
electrical device or permanent magnet
assembly which generates a coercive
magnetic force to destroy magnetic storage
patterns in order to sanitise magnetic media”
(NZISM). “An electrical device or
permanent magnet assembly which
generates a coercive magnetic force for the
purpose of degaussing magnetic storage
devices” (AusISM).
```
```
Deidentification Systematic process of removing,

aggregating, summarising, or otherwise
preventing access to specific information
capable of identifying individuals,

confidentiality, discretion, discrimination,
commercial, national security, compliance,
ethical or other reasons. “Information that
cannot reasonably identify, relate to,
describe, be associated with or linked,
```

```
Delegate a. [Verb] To pass a responsibility to a

```

```
b. [Noun] Subordinate to whom
```

**Delegated authority,
delegation, delegator,
delegate, delegatee**

```
Refers to someone (the delegator) passing
some of their authority (responsibility and
power) to someone else (the delegate or
delegatee, generally a subordinate) within
specified parameters, e.g. giving them the
ability to sign-off (authorise) expenses
claims or procurement orders up to a certain
dollar value, make decisions within a certain
area, or represent (stand in for) them at a

controls such as oversight and mentoring.
While the delegate is personally accountable
for any incidents arising from their actions
and inactions, the delegator generally shares
the risk and remains personally accountable
for their decision to delegate authority.
```

```
Deletion [of personal
information ]
```
```
“Process by which personally identifiable
information (PII) is changed in a manner so
that it is no longer present or recognizable
and usable and can only be reconstructed
with excessive effort. Notes: In this
document the term deletion covers all such
synonyms: disposition mechanism, erasure,
destruction, destruction of data storage
```

```
media [while] deletion refers to the
elimination of the bit patterns or comparable
practices, not simply marking or moving the
data to be hidden. As a result, excessive
effort for PII reconstruction will be required,
considering all the means likely reasonably
to be used, e.g. available state of the art of
technology, human and technical resources,
costs and time. For selecting the methods for
deletion, a risk-based approach is to be
taken into account, including sensitivity of
PII and potential use of forensic tools.
Required measures can change during time
depending on the state of the art of
technology and other factors. PII can be also
changed by applying an irreversible de-
identification technique. Such data often fall
out of privacy legislation. Further guidance
on a de-identification technique can be
found in ISO/IEC 20889-11” (ISO/IEC
27555 ).
```

```
of personally identifiable information (PII)
```

```
Demand letter See cease and desist letter.
```

**D** e- **M** ilitarised **Z** one
**(DMZ), perimeter
network, screened
subnet, no man’s land**

```
Special network segment in between
external networks (such as the Internet) and
internal corporate networks, within which
proxy servers and firewalls are intended to
identify and restrict unauthorised traffic
while passing legitimate traffic. Systems
that need to connect to the Internet (such as
web servers, D omain N ame S ystem servers,
application servers or front-ends, and mail
servers) are typically located in the DMZ,
and are hardened. “Perimeter network (also
known as a screened sub-net) inserted as a
‘neutral zone’ between networks” (ISO/IEC
27033-1). “A small, isolated network that
serves as a buffer zone between trusted and
untrusted networks. Note: A demilitarized
zone is typically used to house systems,
such as web servers, that must be accessible
from both internal networks and the
Internet” (ISACA glossary). “A small
network with one or more servers that is
kept separate from an agency’s core
network, either on the outside of the
agency’s firewall, or as a separate network
protected by the agency’s firewall.
Demilitarised zones usually provide public
domain information to less trusted networks,
such as the Internet” (NZISM). See also
zone.
```
```
Demodulation The converse of modulation, i.e. retrieving
the original modulating information from a
modulated signal, without the carrier. “The
process of converting an analog
telecommunications signal into a digital
computer signal” (ISACA glossary).
```

**D** enial- **o** f- **S** ervice **(DoS)** Type of information security event, incident,

```
or attack that impacts information
availability, e.g. by deliberately or
accidentally overloading a system or
network, thereby impeding or preventing its
legitimate use. “Prevention of authorized
access to resources or the delaying of time-
critical operations” (ISO/IEC 2382 ).
“Prevention of authorized access to a system
resource or the delaying of system
operations and functions, with resultant loss
of availability to authorized users” (ISO/IEC
27033-1). “An assault on a service from a
single source that floods it with so many
requests that it becomes overwhelmed and
either stops completely or operates at a
significantly reduced rate” (ISACA
glossary). “The prevention of authorized
access to a system resource or the delaying
of system operations and functions” (SANS
glossary). “An attempt by an adversary to
prevent legitimate access to online services
(typically a website), for example, by
consuming the amount of available
bandwidth or the processing capacity of the
server hosting the online service” (AusISM).
See also D istributed D enial- o f- S ervice,
D istributed R eflective D enial- o f- S ervice.
```
```
Deny list Politically correct form of blacklist. “A set
of items to be excluded, blocked or
prevented from execution ... the opposite of
an allow list which confirms that items are
acceptable” (NZISM).
```

```
DEP Abbrev: D ata E xecution P revention.
```

```
R esources, or I nformation T echnology.
```

```
Dependable,
dependability
```
```
Measure of the extent to which a system,

Dependability includes availability,
```

```
dependency
```

```
Reliance on the presence, assets/resources,
```

```
Deposition Legal process requiring someone in court
```

```
Deprecated Withdrawn and no longer recommended for
```

```
Derived measure “Measure that is defined as a function of

often expressed as ratios, composite indices
```

**Derived requirement** Additional
system/application/service/product
requirement or expectation reasonably
inferred and specified by systems analysis,
supplementing or elaborating on those
actually specified by users, managers,
customers, _etc_. Detailed nonfunctional


```
requirements relating to compliance,
application/system/network/data
administration, support, maintenance,
security, and assurance, for instance, are

let alone detailed technical internals. Even
functional requirements may be

“Requirements not explicitly stated in

Requirements needed to specify a solution
```

```
behaviours/activities as ‘normal,’ ‘typical,’
```

```
or ‘conventional’ passively encourages most

manner – the number of incident reports
```

```
shape, or other characteristics of a

C riteria).
c. [Verb] To analyse requirements

A critical part of the S oftware
D evelopment L ife C ycle and product
```

```
quality of the architecture. “Occurring when
```

```
Design factors “Factors that can influence the design of an

technology (I&T). In COBIT® 2019, design
```

```
factors include: enterprise strategy,
```

```
during the design and perhaps later during

“Broad design decisions to address an
```

```
where the design may remain somewhat
```

```
fluid for some time ... but by the same
```

**Desk check, desk-
check**

```
Paperwork/administrative check performed

```

```
trace of its prior existence ( e.g. deleting
```

- an event or incident. A core function

Function enables timely discovery of

b. To extract information from a
modulated radio transmission.

```
incident or a control failure) is expected to

```

```
time if it occurs. One of several factors
```

development
methodology**

```
Defines the overall approach to product
development ( e.g. sequential waterfall or
iterative methods for software development)

mandatory and discretionary documentation,
```

```
software
```

```
authentication
```

```
insecure communication path without
exchanging sensitive information (not least,
the secret itself) such that it is easy for both
parties to compute the shared secret but
extremely difficult for an eavesdropper to
derive it from intercepted information. The
shared secret is typically then used as a key
for symmetric cryptography of data
transmissions between the parties. The
foundation for secure communications over
V irtual P rivate N etworks and T ransport
L ayer S ecurity. Published by Whitfield
Diffie and Martin Hellman in 1976.
```

```
Digest See hash.
```

```
Digisig Abbrev: Dig ital sig nature.

```

```
One of the characters 0 through 9 in the

b. Abbrev: Dig ital b it. See bit.
```

**Digital certificate** Data file containing information about a

```
evidence that has been produced to maintain

both the digital evidence and verification

be either embedded in or independent from
```

```
the tools used in doing the verification”
```

```
D igital E vidence F irst
R esponder (DEFR)

```

```
D igital E vidence
S pecialist (DES)

```

```
E ncryption S tandard.
```

forensics, computer

```
is legally acceptable in any legal
```

**D** igital **F** orensics and
**I** ncident **R** esponse
**(DFIR)**

```
Identification, investigation, and
```

**Digital investigation** Digital investigation. “Use of scientifically

```
derived and proven methods towards the

digital sources, while obtaining proper
authorizations for all activities, properly
```

```
D igital M illennium
C opyright A ct 1998
(DMCA)
```
```
US law prohibiting piracy
technologies/devices that may be used to
bypass or defeat software/hardware copy
protection mechanisms.
```

```
Digital nomad Free-ranging (nomadic) remote worker

connectivity.
```

```
Digital operational
resilience
```
```
See cyber resilience. “The ability of a

third-party service providers, the full range
```

```
Digital preservation Archival of data. “The coordinated and
```

```
D igital R ights
M anagement (DRM)
```
```
Cryptographic access controls used to
permit or deny certain types of use of
I ntellectual P roperty according to the

```
**D** igital **S** ervice **P** rovider
**(DSP)**

```
Commercial supplier of digital information
services such as I nformation T echnology
hardware and software maintenance, cloud

network, cloud computing and applications”

```

```
Digi tal sig nature
(digisig)
```
```
Cryptographic hash of a message or file,
constructed with the sender’s private key,
used to ‘seal’ the message/file, thus enabling
any subsequent changes to be detected, and
so authenticate both the message (for data

repudiation and resistance to
impersonation). “Data appended to a

message” (ISO/IEC 2382). “An electronic
identification of a person or entity using a
public key algorithm that serves as a way for
the recipient to verify the identity of the
sender, integrity of the data and proof of
transaction” (ISACA glossary). “A
cryptographic process that allows the proof
of the source (with non-repudiation) and the
verification of the integrity of that data”
(AusISM). “A hash of a message that
uniquely identifies the sender of the
message and proves the message hasn ’ t
changed since transmission” (SANS
glossary).
```
**D** igital **S** ignature
**A** lgorithm **(DSA)**

```
Asymmetric cryptographic algorithm used
to generate and validate digital signatures.
“An asymmetric cryptographic algorithm
that produces a digital signature in the form
of a pair of large numbers. The signature is
computed using rules and parameters such
that the identity of the signer and the
integrity of the signed data can be verified”
(SANS glossary).
```
```
D igital S ignature
S tandard (DSS)
```
```
“The US Government standard that specifies
the Digital Signature Algorithm (DSA),
```

```
which involves asymmetric cryptography”
(SANS glossary).
```
**Digital storage medium** “Device on which digital data may be

```
recorded” (ISO/IEC 27037 , adapted from
ISO/IEC 10027).
```
```
Digital twin Virtual and often real-time emulation of live
I nformation T echnology or O perational
T echnology systems, used for requirements
analysis, planning, developing and testing
changes, training, auditing, etc. “A virtual
replica or representation of assets, processes,
systems, or institutions in the built, societal,
or natural environments that provides insight
into how complex physical assets and
citizens behave, helping organisations
improve decision-making and optimise
processes. Changes in the real world are

```
```
D igital V alue
M anagement S ystem
(DVMS)
```
```
Overarching governance/cybersecurity
framework or model for generating,

F ramework. Draws on good practices from

risk, resilience, and strategic value. Cf.

https://dvmsinstitute.com/
```
```
[Data] Diode “A device that allows data to flow in only
one direction” (NZISM).
```

```
Dip Momentary/transient reduction in supply

milliseconds. Most dips pass without

```
```
Direct evidence Forensic evidence that derives from or is

```
```
Direct reporting
engagement
```
```
Internal audit or consulting engagement

to client management, rather than to third
parties. “An engagement in which

assertion about the effectiveness of their

```
**Direction-setting
criteria**

```
“The criteria used to set the direction for the
organization and its objectives based on
external/internal context, culture, and
stakeholder needs” (OCEG GRC Glossary).
```
```
Disaster Terrible, potentially existential incident such
as a major fire, flood, earthquake, fraud,
hack, or ransomware attack. Distinguished
from ordinary events, incidents, or crises by
its severity, scale, and lasting impact on the
nations, organisations, and individuals
directly or indirectly involved. “Situation
where widespread human, material,
economic or environmental losses have
```

```
occurred that exceeded the ability of the
affected organization, community or society
to respond and recover using its own
resources” (ISO 22300). “An emergency
event of such great magnitude that it
overwhelms the capacity to respond and
takes considerable time from which to
recover” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Disaster declaration Formal invocation of an appropriate
response (initiating the relevant parts of a
D isaster R ecovery P lan) following rapid

signals a distinct change of business
priorities and governance ( e.g. greater local

power). “The communication to appropriate
internal and external parties that the disaster
recovery plan (DRP) is being put into
operation” (ISACA glossary).
```
**D** isaster **R** ecovery **(DR)** Fallback arrangements to recover computer

```
systems, data, and services supporting
critical business functions from backups,
perhaps at an alternative/secondary location
using cloud-based or mobile I nformation
T echnology facilities, following a major
incident affecting the primary IT and
datacommunications production facilities.
“Ability of the ICT elements of an
organization to support its critical business
functions to an acceptable level within a
predetermined period of time following a
disruption” (ISO/IEC 27031 ). “Activities
and programs designed to return the
enterprise to an acceptable condition. The
ability to respond to an interruption in
```

```
services by implementing a disaster
recovery plan (DRP) to restore an
enterprise ’ s critical business functions”
(ISACA glossary). “The process of restoring
a system to full operation after an
interruption in service, including equipment
repair/replacement, file
recovery/restoration” (ENISA RM glossary).
```
```
D isaster R ecovery P lan
(DRP)
```
```
Documentation of an organisation’s D isaster
R ecovery arrangements, covering various
aspects and scenarios. “A set of human,
physical, technical and procedural resources
to recover, within a defined time and cost,

recovery plan] Clearly defined and
documented plan which recovers ICT
capabilities when a disruption occurs. Note:
It is called ICT continuity plan in some
organizations” (ISO/IEC 27031 ). “The

event of a disruption or disaster” (SANS
glossary).
```
**Disaster recovery plan
desk check**

```
“Typically a read-through of a disaster
recovery plan (DRP) without any real
actions taking place. Notes: Generally
involves a reading of the plan, discussion of
the action items and definition of any gaps
that might be identified” (ISACA glossary).
```
**Disaster recovery plan
walk-through**

```
“Generally a robust test of the recovery plan
requiring that some recovery activities take
place and are tested. A disaster scenario is
often given and the recovery teams talk
through the steps that they would need to
```

```
take to recover. As many aspects of the plan
as possible should be tested” (ISACA

```
**Disaster risk reduction** “Policy aimed at preventing new and

```
reducing existing disaster risk and managing
residual risk, all of which contribute to

achievement of sustainable development”
(ISO 22300).
```
```
Disaster tolerance Composite measure, evaluation, estimation,
or projection of an organisation, community,
or nation’s capability, capacity, and
willingness to survive and recover from
various disasters. Highly subjective and
context-dependent. “The time gap during
which the business can accept the non-
availability of IT facilities” (ISACA

```
```
Disclaimer Attempt to share risk by explicitly and

Often used to limit legal liabilities. See also
notification.
```
```
Disclosure Revelation of confidential information. May
be deliberate and voluntary ( e.g. tax

coercion, blackmail or social engineering),
authorised and permitted, or unauthorised
and forbidden. “Violation of computer
security whereby data have been made
available to unauthorized entities” (ISO/IEC
2382 ). “The release, transfer, provision of
access to, or divulging in any other manner
```

```
of information outside the entity holding the
information. Disclosure is often used
interchangeably with the terms sharing and
onward transfer” ( T rust S ervices C riteria).
See also discovery.
```
```

information whose very existence might

organisation or individuals concerned ( e.g.

recommendations that were not taken

non-party concerning a matter. Note:
Discovery is applicable more broadly than
to parties in adversarial disputes. Discovery
is also the disclosure of hardcopy
documents, Electronically Stored
Information and tangible objects by an
adverse party. In some jurisdictions the term
disclosure is used interchangeably with

disclosure, deposition, interrogatory,
subpoena.
```
**Discovery sample** Two-phase audit sampling method using a

```
preliminary evaluation of initial samples to
identify any dubious datasets worthy of
additional analysis/testing, e.g. those whose
sample reveals a higher-than-expected error
count. “A form of attribute sampling that is
used to determine a specified probability of
finding at least one example of an
```

```
occurrence (attribute) in a population”
(ISACA glossary). See also attribute sample,
stratified sample, random sample,
systematic stratified sample, time series
analysis, convenience sample.
```
```
Discretion, discreet a. Avoiding unwelcome exposure or
notoriety by actively evading publicity,

valuable if fragile control.
b. Freedom, latitude, or permission to
make important decisions and act
independently, perhaps non-
compliantly, given circumstances,
```

```
Discretionary,
nonmandatory
```
```
Optional, voluntary, freely chosen, reflecting

otherwise mandatory, generally for business,
ethical or other reasons.
```

**D** iscretionary **A** ccess
**C** ontrol **(DAC)**

```
Decisions on whether and how to control

DAC system using their discretion, as
```

**Discussion forum,
forum, discussion
group, group, email

```
Social networking capability for group
members to circulate and discuss/debate
matters of common interest. Messages
(potentially including spam, misinformation,
disinformation, or other
inappropriate/unwelcome content) sent to
the group by a member through email or the

all members by email and may be archived
on a website allowing them to be searched.
Messages containing sensitive content ( e.g.
intended for a specific group member or
someone else entirely) may be exploited
directly or forwarded/disclosed by members,
perhaps used for profiling and social
engineering ( e.g. blackmail, coercion).
“Functional unit that replicates a message as
```

```
Dishonest Someone ‘ethically challenged’ who lies,
deceives, cheats, or defrauds others for their
own benefit. They cannot be relied upon,
making them untrustworthy and probably
unworthy of and unsuitable for various
privileges and responsibilities.
```
```
Disinfect Eliminate a malware infection from a

to prevent reinfection. “To remove malware
from within a file” (NIST SP 800-114).
```
```
Disinformation Information that is intended deliberately to
mislead, deceive, coerce, or manipulate
```

```
(such as propaganda or obfuscation).
“[Information] deliberately created to
mislead, harm, or manipulate a person,
social group, organization, or country”

A gency). “Information that is intentionally
```

```
Disintegrate Fall to pieces or rip asunder. “Destruct by

```
```
Disk image a. Copy of the digital data on a computer

b. In digital forensics, a bit-copy of the

c. In virtualisation, a virtual disk made
```

(R** edundant **A** rray of

```
Technique in which data are simultaneously
```

```
that uses hardware or software to write
```

**D** isk **O** perating **S** ystem
**(DOS)**

```
O perating S ystem that loads from disk, such
```

```
Disposal Act or process of discarding something. “A

```
```
Disposition Eventual outcome or result of something –

```
```
Disrupt, disruption,
disruptive
```
```
Causing harmful and often somewhat
chaotic interruption, discontinuity, or

```

```
“A circumstance or event that interrupts or
prevents the correct operation of system
services and functions” (SANS glossary).
```
```
Disruptive event Disruptive event. “Occurrence or change
that interrupts planned activities, operations
or functions, whether anticipated or

```
```
Distraction Misdirection technique commonly used by

vulnerability.
```
```
Distress An extreme, highly emotional and
debilitating form of stress such as that

exhausted. May result in floods of tears,

```
**D** istributed **C** ontrol
**S** ystem **, D** igital **C** ontrol
**S** ystem **(DCS)**

```
Originally a term for a process control
computer system that uses digital
technology rather than analogue
electromechanical controls. Latterly used to
denote SCADA-like I ndustrial C ontrol
S ystems/ O perational T echnology
distributed around industrial plant, usually

autonomous.
```
```
D istributed D enial- o f-
S ervice (DDoS)
```
```
Type of D enial- o f- S ervice attack using
numerous systems (typically bots) to
generate large volumes of network traffic,
```

```
thereby flooding and possibly overloading
the target systems or network, causing them
to slow or stop providing I nformation
T echnology services, becoming
unresponsive. Can also occur by accident,
e.g. when a website is swamped by an

of-service (DoS) assault from multiple

See also D istributed R eflective D enial- o f-
S ervice.
```
**D** istributed **R** eflective
**D** enial- **o** f- **S** ervice
**(DRDoS)**

```
Some D istributed D enial- o f- S ervice attacks
use U ser D atagram P rotocol rather than
T ransmission C ontrol P rotocol, taking
advantage of UDP servers (such as D omain
N ame S ystem servers) to amplify the
volume of traffic, and I nternet P rotocol
address spoofing to forward the amplified
responses to a victim’s system rather than
back to the originator. No relation to
DRDoS, an early D isk O perating S ystem
from D igital R esearch. See also D enial- o f-
S ervice.
```
```
Distributed scan “Scan that uses multiple source addresses to
gather information” (SANS glossary).
```
```
Distribution system “Distribution grid for the transport of

oil or heat” (ISO/IEC 27019).
```
```
Distributor “A natural or legal person in the supply
chain, other than the manufacturer or the
```

```
importer, that makes a product with digital

without affecting its properties” (EU CRA).
```
**Divergent thinking** Using creative problem-solving techniques

```
such as brainstorming to develop, consider,
and refine a broader range of possibilities,
options, approaches, and potential solutions.
“Considering all possibilities, conditions and
events, circumstances, and outcomes”
(OCEG GRC Glossary). Cf. convergent
thinking.
```
```
Diverse routing Innate capability of a packet-switched
network architecture whereby individual
data packets may safely take various routes
between source and destination nodes ( e.g.
dynamically re-routing around links with
performance constraints) before being
assembled to deliver the message content
intact, in the correct sequence. The
redundancy increases flexibility, availability,
and resilience. “A method of routing traffic
through split cable facilities or duplicate
cable facilities. Notes: This can be
accomplished with different or duplicate
cable sheaths. If different cable sheaths are
used, the cable may be in the same conduit
and, therefore, subject to the same
interruptions as the cable it is backing up.
The communication service subscriber can
duplicate the facilities by having alternate
routes, although the entrance to and from the
customer premises may be in the same
conduit. The subscriber can obtain diverse
routing and alternate routing, including dual
entrance facilities, from the local carrier.
```

```
However, acquiring this type of access is
time-consuming and costly. Most carriers
provide facilities for alternate and diverse
routing, although the majority of services
are transmitted over terrestrial media, which
are usually located in the ground or
basement. Ground-based facilities are at
great risk due to the aging infrastructures of
cities. In addition, cable-based facilities
usually share space with mechanical and
electrical systems that can pose great risk
due to potential human error and disasters”
(ISACA glossary).
```
```
Diversify,
diversification
```
```
Business continuity technique involves
deliberately reducing dependence on
individual products, suppliers, workers,
communication paths, etc. by seeking

```

```
domain name ‘www.sans.org’ locates an
Internet address for ‘sans.org’ at Internet

named ‘www.’ The ‘org’ part of the domain
name reflects the purpose of the
organization or entity (in this example,
‘organization’) and is called the top-level
domain name. The ‘sans’ part of the domain
name defines the organization or entity and
```

```
Network protocols and systems let us refer

```

**D** omain **N** ame **S** ystem
**poisoning (DNS
poisoning), DNS cache
poisoning, cache
poisoning**

```
Attack that subverts D omain N ame S ystem
servers or records to direct victims covertly
to a malicious domain, phishing or
infectious website, etc. instead of the benign
one they anticipated, e.g. by ‘poisoning’
cached DNS data with false linkages or by
exploiting the ‘zone transfer’ process used to
share data among DNS servers. “Corrupts
the table of an Internet server’s DNS,
replacing an Internet address with the
address of a vagrant or scoundrel address.
Notes: If a web user looks for the page with
that address, the request is redirected by the
scoundrel entry in the table to a different
address. Cache poisoning differs from
another form of DNS poisoning in which the
attacker spoofs valid email accounts and
floods the in-boxes of administrative and
technical contacts. Cache poisoning is
related to URL poisoning or location
poisoning, in which an Internet user’s
behavior is tracked by adding an
identification number to the location line of
the browser that can be recorded as the user
visits successive pages on the site” (ISACA
glossary). See also pharming.
```

```
such overrides should preferably trigger
indicators (such as a flashing warning light),
```

```
determine a file’s type according to the final

stop ( e.g. files containing executable
programs often end with .exe ). Systems may
not display the extension for known file
types. Additional full-stops and characters
preceding the final extension (such as .txt
and .exe ) may be treated as part of the file
name. Some malware uses this and other
```

```
Double-entry
bookkeeping
```
```
Financial accounting process used since
Roman times in which every transaction is
recorded as a complementary pair of credits
and debits (equal in value but opposite in
sign) in the relevant accounts or ledgers.
Any discrepancy between the running totals
of the paired accounts when they are
reconciled generally indicates a simple data
entry or calculation error but could point to
fraud, corruption, or theft.
```

```

deprecated cryptographic algorithms for
backwards compatibility. Adversaries
exploit these downgrade capabilities to
weaken and then hijack the connections,
inject malicious content, steal credentials,
etc.
```

```
malware dynamically, e.g. to evade antivirus
software, attack specific new targets, or
```

```
movements of products and services that
occur after an entity in the supply chain
takes custody of the products and
```

**Failsafe, fail-safe, fail-
secure, fail-closed**

```
Engineering principle/approach used heavily in safety-
critical (vital) and other high-security system and
process architectures whereby a control failure or some
adverse situation leaves the system/process in an
inherently safe or secure – albeit perhaps only partially
functional – state or condition. “Pertaining to
avoidance of compromise in the event of a failure”
(ISO/IEC 2382 ). “A system or component that
automatically places itself in a safe operational mode
in the event of a failure” (IEEE). See also secure-by-
default, secure-by-design, P ower- O n S elf- T est.
```
```
Fail-soft, failsoft, fail-
gracefully, fail-gently
```
```
Resilience arrangement that identifies impending
performance/capacity constraints or other operational
issues and responds dynamically by, for instance, de-
prioritising relatively unimportant activities, shedding
non-critical loads, or requesting additional resources in
the hope of avoiding incidents. “Pertaining to a
functional unit continuing to function in a degraded
mode despite faults or manual out-of-limits operations.
Note: Fault tolerance is a means for achieving failsoft
operations” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “Selective termination of
affected nonessential processing when hardware or
software failure is determined to be imminent” (CNSSI
4009 ). See also fault tolerance.
```

**Fail-unsafe, fail-
unsecure, fail-insecure,
fail-open**

```
Undesirable state for systems and processes that have
not been explicitly designed to be safe and secure ( i.e.
failsafe) under all conditions, and hence are ‘fragile’,
e.g. an access control that fails spontaneously or is
actively disabled or bypassed in an attack, may permit
inappropriate access that it was supposed to have
prevented or at least detected. In the absence of
compensating controls, security by obscurity can fail
spectacularly if details of a supposedly obscure
vulnerability are widely disclosed.
```
```

problematic situation, occurrence, event, or incident.
“The inability of a system or component to perform its
functions within specified performance requirements”
(IEEE).
```

```
Failure analysis Analysis of evidence relating to a failure in order to
diagnose and determine the cause/s or factors that
caused it ... or that failed to prevent it (a different class
of failure). “Determining the exact nature and location
of a program error to fix the error, to identify and fix
other similar errors and to initiate corrective action to
prevent future occurrences of this type of error.
Contrasts with debugging” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Failure mode Circumstances, conditions, or situations responsible
for a failure, potentially precipitating an incident.
“Manner by which a failure is observed. Note: It
generally describes the way failure occurs and its
impact on the operation of the system” (ISO/IEC
27031 ).
```

```
Administrative control function/process to monitor
```

```
analysing any kind of fingerprint create practical
constraints on the achievable accuracy; hence, there is
a small but finite possibility that fingerprints from
different individuals, systems, or data may not be
distinguished in practice. Furthermore, being
biometrics, confidentiality is a challenge for the owner,
especially as they cannot be changed if compromised,
at least not without surgery. “Sending strange packets
to a system in order to gauge how it responds to
determine the operating system” (SANS glossary). See
also hash.

```

```
Forensic, forensics Relating to the law courts, e.g. forensic evidence.
‘Forensic’ is the adjective form. ‘Forensics’ is the
noun. “Related to, or used in, courts of law. Note: This

```

```
Forensic copy In order to guarantee the integrity of digital evidence,
forensic analysis is performed on evidential copies that
have been produced by appropriate methods and can
```

```
be verified correct, while retaining the pristine best
evidence to be presented in court. More than merely a
duplication of an item of forensic evidence, a forensic
copy is produced using a specified, forensically sound
method that gives an extremely high level of assurance
that the copy is an authentic and complete duplicate of
the original, e.g. a bitwise image of a computer disk,
created using proven and trustworthy forensic tools,
with a cryptographic hash value identical to the
original. “A bit-for-bit reproduction of the information
contained on an electronic device or associated media,
whose validity and integrity has been verified using an
accepted algorithm” (NIST SP 800-101).
```

```
F orward E rror
C orrection (FEC),
```

```
Digital datacommunications technique/protocol using
an E rror- C orrection C ode algorithm to incorporate
redundancy within the data stream, allowing a
receiving system to detect and, if possible, reverse
some data errors, reconstructing uncorrupted content
ideally without the need for retransmissions. Has

```

```
communications, as well as networking, satellite and
```

**Fragmentation, frag** Splitting something ( _e.g._ network packets or files) into
pieces for some reason ( _e.g._ to limit the maximum
size) while allowing them to be reassembled correctly
later on. “The process of storing a data file in several
‘chunks’ or fragments rather than in a single
contiguous sequence of bits in one place on the storage
medium” _(SANS glossary)._ See also defrag.

```
Fragment Overlap
Attack
```
```
“A TCP/IP Fragmentation Attack that is possible
because IP allows packets to be broken down into
fragments for more efficient transport across various
media. The TCP packet (and its header) are carried in
the IP packet. In this attack the second fragment
contains incorrect offset. When packet is
reconstructed, the port number will be overwritten”
(SANS glossary).

```


```
b. Permanent physical structure into which a door or
window is attached. Its inherent strength plus that

hinges, catches, or locks, are critical to the ability
to resist brute force attacks, fires, accidents, etc.
c. Conceptual boundary, scope, or context (‘frame
of reference’).
```

linking related items together, providing a logical basis
or structural foundation for construction,
understanding, and use. Expressed in the form of
blueprints, architecture, and design specifications,
wire-frame diagrams showing nodes with linkages,
systems (including **M** anagement **S** ystems), methods,
approaches, protocols, standards, policies, guidelines,
_etc_. May be theoretical or practical, rigid and formal,
or flexible and customisable. Information security
frameworks typically concern governance, information
risk, compliance, privacy, and related matters, in whole
or in part. “A basic conceptual structure used to solve
or address complex issues. An enabler of governance.
A set of concepts, assumptions and practices that
define how something can be approached or
understood, the relationships among the entities
involved, the roles of those involved and the
boundaries (what is and is not included in the
governance system)” _(ISACA glossary)._

```
Fraud, con Theft, misappropriation, or similar crime involving
deliberate deception or misrepresentation of the
target/victim by a fraudster, usually for unfair
```

```
advantage or gain. Many forms of fraud are known,
e.g. assuming someone else’s name and masquerading
as them (identity fraud), promising a large payout on
receipt of an advance fee, causing people unwittingly
to call a premium-rate phone number and so rack up a
large bill (toll fraud), tricking people into downloading
malware or visiting unsavoury/undesirable websites
(clickbait and phishing), falsifying or inflating
expenses claimed (expenses fraud), falsifying financial
records (accounting or tax fraud), substituting bank
account numbers (payment fraud). “Any act involving
the use of deception to obtain illegal advantage”
(ISACA glossary). “Any intentional act characterized
```

supports monitoring, detection, and management of
fraud or other misuse across users ( _e.g_. customers),
accounts, channels, products and other entities ( _e.g_.
kiosks). Note: To deploy the fraud detection system,
enterprise applications can integrate with a fraud
detection engine that assesses the fraud risk of a
transaction, from user navigation and application
access, to any type of activity, such as a change of
address, payment or retrieval of sensitive information”
_(ITU-T X.1157)._

```
gullibility, and susceptibility in earlier incidents and
may still be ignorant or in a psychological state of
```

```
denial, hence being relatively vulnerable to subsequent
frauds by selfish heartless exploitative nasty low-life
```

**Fraudster, con artist** Deceitful, deceptive person who commits fraud.

```

ciphertext or code, e.g. e and i are the most frequent

are very common two-, three-, or four-character
```

programmed to follow the same frequency sequence.
“Repeated switching of frequencies during radio
transmission according to a specified algorithm, to

```
minimize unauthorized interception or jamming of

```

```
resulting in the activation of a protective or corrective

the act of providing mitigation to reduce the
consequence of the hazardous event. The aspect of the
overall safety of a solution, solution component or
piece of equipment that depends on the automatic
```

```
protection mechanisms operating correctly in response
```

function” _(NZISM)._

```
Functional test Category/type of test concerning the functionality
required of a computer system, device, thing , product,
cloud service, control, etc. “1. Testing that ignores the
internal mechanism or structure of a system or
component and focuses on the outputs generated in
response to selected inputs and execution conditions.
```
2. Testing conducted to evaluate the compliance of a
system or component with specified functional
requirements and corresponding predicted results
Synonymous with black-box testing and input/output
driven testing. Contrasts with testing, structural”

```
Fuzzing, fuzz testing Software security assurance method (a form of black
box testing) typically using large volumes of generated
data to verify processing and application controls
around boundary conditions, perhaps identifying
vulnerabilities or other inappropriate system
behaviours such as undefined internal states or
conditions. “A method used to discover errors or
potential security vulnerabilities in software”
(AusISM). “Similar to fault injection in that invalid
data is input into the application via the environment,
or input by one process into another process. Fuzz
testing is implemented by tools called fuzzers, which
are programs or script that submit some combination
of inputs to the test target to reveal how it responds”
(NIST SP 800-95). “The use of special regression
testing tools to generate out-of-spec input for an
application in order to find security vulnerabilities”
(SANS glossary).
```

```
Geolocation Some portable computer devices and things use
G lobal P ositioning S ystem, cell-sites, Wi-Fi
services, or other means to identify their
locations, and by implication the whereabouts of
the corresponding users. Locational information
can be sensitive, for instance allowing high-
worth individuals/marks (such as executives,
politicians, and celebrities) to be targeted. It can
also be very valuable, e.g. to track a lost/stolen
smartphone or vehicle, or a pet, child,
Alzheimer’s sufferer, or convict on day-release.
```

```
Geolocation service using a network of orbiting
radio satellites running extremely accurate
atomic clocks, allowing a receiver to calculate
its three-dimensional position (latitude,
longitude, and altitude) to within a few meters
by simultaneous reference to several satellite
signals. A GNSS receiver unit in a vehicle, for
instance, can track the vehicle’s position and
report it remotely if coupled with a radio
transmitter such as a cellphone, creating
surveillance capabilities and raising privacy
implications. Vulnerable to interference caused
by physical obstructions, electrical noise, solar
flares, etc., or to deliberate spoofing or
jamming. A useful way of tracking valuable
portable information assets such as backup tape
carriers, missiles, executives, politicians,
celebrities, wilderness hikers, spooks, high-
worth/vulnerable individuals, things , criminals,
terrorists, and assets in general. “A constellation
of Earth-orbiting satellites that provide
positioning, navigation, and timing (PNT)
services worldwide. The primary function of a
GNSS is to determine the precise location of
receivers on Earth’s surface or in near-Earth
space. The system allows electronic receivers to
determine their location within a few meters”
( I nternational T elecommunications U nion). See
also G lobal P ositioning S ystem, B ei D ou
Navigation S atellite System, Glo balnaya

```

```
controlling, and evaluating an entity by
constraining and conscribing resources” (OCEG
GRC Glossary). “The combination of processes
and structures implemented by the board to
inform, direct, manage, and monitor the
activities of the organization toward the
achievement of its objectives” (IIA GIAS). See

```

```
Hack, hacking At MIT in the late 1950’s, a ‘hack’ was an
ingenious, quick, inelegant, and superficial
modification to a system that accomplished
the desired goal without fundamentally
changing its architecture. Later came to
mean a benign and obsessive fascination
with technology. Now refers to accessing,
exploring, and often exploiting vulnerable
computer systems, networks, and things
without the owners’ authorisation,
knowledge, and/or permission; hence,
unethical and often both malicious and
illegal, although cracking is more specific.
“Intentionally accessing a computer system
without the authorization of the user or the
owner” (ISO/IEC 27032).
```

**Hacker, haxxor, h4xx0r
...**

```
Someone who hacks. ‘Haxxor,’ plus
variants such as ‘h4xx0r,’ are Leet versions.
“Technically sophisticated computer
enthusiast who uses his or her knowledge
and means to gain unauthorized access to
protected resources” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “An
individual who attempts to gain
unauthorized access to a computer system”
(ISACA glossary). “Unauthorized user who
attempts to or gains access to an
information system” (CNSSI 4009 ). See also
cracker.
```
```
Hacker underground Somewhat covert social network or
community of individuals and groups of
hackers, crackers, malware authors (VXers),
script kiddies, bot masters, etc. linked
through Internet websites, chat rooms,
bulletin boards, conferences and club
meetings, etc. Increasingly linked to
criminal gangs, cybercriminal activities
( e.g. the use of crimeware), and the black
market.
```
```
Hacktivism, hacktivist,
hactivism, hactivist
```
```
Use of hacking/cracking techniques to
further the aims of ideological
activist/extremist groups promoting human
rights, anarchy, and religious/national
bigotry,. e.g. through website defacement.
May be a part of, or provide a cover for,
more sinister attacks such as terrorism,
sabotage, cybertage, industrial espionage,
spying, or information warfare. “Hacking
for a politically or socially motivated
purpose” (ISO/IEC 27032).
```

**Hallucination** a. False human perceptions involving

```
strange dream-like sights, sounds,
smells/tastes, or feelings.
b. Inaccurate albeit credibly and
confidently presented response from an
A rtificial I ntelligence/ L arge L anguage
M odel. An unfortunate drawback to the
M achine L earning approach of
systematically analysing natural
language samples to derive and apply
linguistic rules mechanistically, despite
limited comprehension or appreciation
of often complex subject matter. To be
fair to the robots, we humans are also
prone to ‘reading between the lines’,
‘jumping to conclusions’ and ‘faking
```

```
Hanlon’s razor Robert J. Hanlon wrote “Never attribute to
malice that which can be adequately
explained by stupidity.” Naturally risk-
averse information security professionals
tend to assume that most incidents are
caused intentionally by malicious
adversaries, whereas many are simple
accidents, coincidences, and
‘misfortune’/’bad luck’ (meaning random
factors). Stupidity may involve ignorance
and/or incompetence.
```

than hurtful or violent but it’s a matter of
degree and perception by the victim.

```
Hardening, harden Process of making something more robust
```
