removing unnecessary software, and
applying relevant security patches. “Process
of securing a system by reducing its surface
of vulnerability. Note: Hardening typically
includes the removal of unnecessary
software, unnecessary usernames or logins
and the disabling or removal of unnecessary
services” (ISO/IEC 27033-6). “The process
```

```
of configuring a computer or other network
device to resist attacks” (ISACA glossary).
“The process of identifying and fixing
vulnerabilities on a system” (SANS
glossary).

term for ICT equipment” (AusISM).

wetware, malware, ransomware, adware,

**Hash, hash value, hash
code, digest, message
digest, cryptographic
hash, hash function,
hashing, trapdoor
function, irreversible
encryption,
irreversible
encipherment, one-way
encryption**

```
Characteristic output value produced by
passing a string or file (the ‘message’)
through a so-called ‘one-way encryption’ or
‘trapdoor’ cryptographic hashing function
such as SHA-2. Although the original
content may not be reliably recreated from
the hash value, its validity and integrity can
be verified by recalculating and comparing
the hash against one calculated previously,
stored, and communicated securely. Used to
validate passwords, digital certificates,
digital evidence, plus electronic files,
messages, functions, and transactions, and
for pseudorandom bit generation.
“Encryption that produces ciphertext from
which the original data cannot be
reproduced. Note: Irreversible encryption is
useful in authentication. For example, a
password might be irreversibly encrypted
and the resulting ciphertext stored. A
password presented later would be
irreversibly encrypted identically and the
two strings of ciphertext compared. If they
are identical, the presented password is
correct” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “[Hashing] 1. A
technique involving using a hash function
(algorithm) to create hash valued or
checksums that validate message integrity.
```
2. In data processing and machine learning,
a mechanism for bucketing categorical data,
particularly when the number of categories
is large, but the number of categories
actually appearing in the dataset is
comparatively small. [and] [Hash] A


cryptographic function takes an input of an
arbitrary length and produces an output
(also known as a message digest) that is a
standard-sized binary string. The output is
unique to the input in such a way that even a
minor change to the input results in a
completely different output. Modern
cryptographic hash functions are also
resistant to collisions (situations in which
different inputs produce identical output); a
collision, while possible, is statistically
improbable. Cryptographic hash functions
are developed so that input cannot be
determined readily from the output. [and]
[Hash function] 1. An algorithm that maps
or translates one set of bits into another
(generally smaller) so that a message yields
the same result every time the algorithm is
executed using the same message as input.

2. Fixed values derived mathematically
from a text message” _(ISACA glossary)._
“The result of a one-way, cryptographic
function that converts a data string of any
length into a unique fixed-length bit string.
Typically applied to passwords and
messages to protect against loss and/or add
resistance to attacks. Hashing algorithms or
functions are often are designed as a one-
way cryptographic transformation so that
it’s impossible to reverse the hash process
and reconstitute the original string. The
values returned by a hash function are
variously described as hash values, hash
codes, digests, or simply hashes. One
common use of a hash is a data structure
called a hash table, widely used in computer
software for indexing and rapid retrieval of


```
database elements. Note that a hash is not
the same as data encryption although it does
utilise cryptographic functions” (NZISM).
“An algorithm (the hash function) which
takes as input a string of any length (the
message) and generates a fixed length string
(the message digest or fingerprint) as
output. The algorithm is designed to make it
computationally infeasible to find any input
which maps to a given digest, or to find two
different messages that map to the same
digest” (AusISM). “The process of using a
mathematical algorithm against data to
produce a numeric value that is
representative of that data” (NIST SP 800-
101 ). “An algorithm that computes a value
based on a data object thereby mapping the
data object to a smaller data object.
(Cryptographic) hash functions are used to
generate a one way ‘check sum’ for a larger
text, which is not trivially reversed. The
result of this hash function can be used to
validate if a larger file has been altered,
without having to compare the larger files to
each other. Frequently used hash functions
are MD5 and SHA1” (SANS glossary).
```
**H** ash-based **M** essage
**A** uthentication **C** ode
**(HMAC) algorithm**

```
“A cryptographic construction that can be
used to compute Message Authentication
Codes using a hash function and a secret
key” (AusISM). “In cryptography, a keyed-
hash message authentication code (HMAC)
is a specific type of message authentication
code (MAC) using a cryptographic hash
function and a cryptographic key” (NZISM).
```

**Hash collision** It is possible, although unlikely, for two

```
different input strings or files to produce the
same hash due to the finite number of
possible hash values that hashing algorithms
generate (the hash-space). Relatively weak
hashing algorithms such as MD5 with small
hash-spaces are more likely to suffer
collisions and are deprecated in favour of
stronger algorithms with much larger hash-
spaces such as the SHA-2 or SHA-3
families. “Occurrence of the same hash
value for two or more different keys”
(ISO/IEC 2382).
```

**Hysteresis [loop]** Feature of controls designed to keep a
measured parameter (such as pressure)
within a defined tolerance range rather than
attempting to maintain a setpoint precisely.
The parameter cycles between upper and
lower limits, giving the control (such as
running a pump or opening a relief valve)
more time to act. Plotting the controlled
parameter against time gives two sigmoid
curves that separate between the increasing
and decreasing phases, forming a loop with
some lag or slack in the control action.
Helps prevent the control oscillating too
rapidly about the start/stop setpoint,
stressing, and perhaps prematurely wearing
out mechanical switches, relays, motors,
_etc_. at the cost of reduced precision.

(ISO/IEC 27037 ). “Process of recognizing the

```

```
I d entify (ID) a. To determine, with sufficient assurance for the

F ramework along with protect, detect,

Understanding the business context, the

and business needs” (NIST CSF).

b. To discover or reveal – see detect.

```

Management applies organisation processes,

**Identity fraud, identity
theft**

```
Type of fraud in which the fraudster masquerades
as, impersonates, or falsely assumes the victim’s
identity, typically as a prelude to stealing or
misappropriating financial or other assets such as
confidential information. Often involves theft ( e.g.
using infostealer malware), falsification
(counterfeiting or faking), or guessing of
credentials used to authenticate the holder’s
claimed identity, exploiting I dentification &
A uthentication vulnerabilities, and
misrepresentation.
```
```
Identity theft See identity fraud. Strictly speaking, the theft of
personal information is just the first step and
sometimes it is not even stolen but willingly
provided or disclosed by data subjects for some
reason ( e.g. on a typical LinkedIn profile or
C urriculum V itae).
```
```
Idle standby “A fail-over process in which the primary node
owns the resource group and the backup node runs
idle, only supervising the primary node. Notes: In
case of a primary node outage, the backup node
takes over. The nodes are prioritized, which means
that the surviving node with the highest priority
will acquire the resource group. A higher priority
node joining the cluster will thus cause a short
service interruption” (ISACA glossary).
```

```
Protocol for synchronising one or more email

with IMAP, while the email client has a ‘view’ of

folder structure from any logged-on device; also
IMAP connections between email client and mail
server ( including the user’s mail server logon
credentials) can be encrypted. See also SMTP.

**Immutable storage** Data storage mechanism designed to prevent the

_e.g._ a WORM drive or cloud storage with suitable
security controls. Should prevent ransomware or
other incidents damaging backups and archives,
provided it functions as designed. “[Immutable] A
term that describes something that is unable to be

QRG). “The result or effect of an event. The event

“With respect to security, the effect on

respect to privacy, the adverse effects that

**Impact analysis,
consequence analysis**

```
Systematic, structured exploration and
consideration of the potential, likely, or actual
consequences of various incidents on the
organisation, workers, or other affected parties.
“Process of analysing all operational functions and
the effect that an operational interruption can have
upon them. Note: Impact analysis is part of the risk
assessment process and includes business impact
analysis. Impact analysis identifies how the loss or
damage will manifest itself; the degree for potential
escalation of damage or loss with time following an
incident; the minimum services and resources
```

```
(human, physical, and financial) needed to enable
business processes to continue to operate at a

extent within which activities, functions and
services of the organization should be recovered”
(ISO 22300). “A study to prioritize the criticality of

the costs (or consequences) of adverse events. In an
impact analysis, threats to assets are identified and
potential business losses are determined for
different time periods. This assessment is used to
justify the safeguards required and recovery time
frames. This analysis is the basis for establishing
the recovery strategy” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Impact assessment Impact assessment – see impact analysis. “A review
of the possible consequences of a risk ” (ISACA
glossary).
```
```
Impact value “The assessed worst-case potential impact that
could result from a compromise of the
confidentiality, integrity, or availability of
information expressed as a value of low, moderate,
or high” (NIST SP 800-171).
```
```
Impairment “A condition that causes a weakness or diminished
ability to execute audit objectives. Notes:
Impairment to organizational independence and
individual objectivity may include personal conflict
of interest; scope limitations; restrictions on access
to records, personnel, equipment, or facilities; and
resource limitations (such as funding or staffing)”
(ISACA glossary).
```
**Impartial, impartiality** Capability and intention to be and remain neutral,
objective, and substantially free of bias and
prejudice in a given situation. _“_ Actual or perceived
presence of objectivity. Notes: Objectivity means
that conflicts of interest do not exist or are resolved


```
so as not to adversely influence subsequent
activities. Other terms commonly used to convey
the element of impartiality are objectivity,
independence, freedom from conflict of interests,
freedom from bias, lack of prejudice, neutrality,
fairness, open-mindedness, even-handedness,
detachment and balance” (ISO 22300).
```
```
Imperative Elaboration on the process, resources, and decisions
leading to an objective, as in planning Cf.
declarative.
```
```
Impersonation Masquerading as another person (identity fraud),
computer system, organisation, authority, manager,
contact, partner, counterparty, etc. for social
engineering purposes. “An entity that mimics a
system, process or person in an attempt to
manipulate the user into an action that can cause an
unexpected or unwanted event to a system” (ISACA
glossary).
```
```
Implant “Electronic device or electronic equipment
modification designed to gain unauthorized
interception of information-bearing emanations”
(CNSSI 4009). See also bug, mole.
```
**Implementation,
implement**

```
a. Process of putting something into practice or
production, such as configuring and releasing
a newly installed computer system or
application. “The process of translating a
design into hardware components, software
components or both” (ISACA glossary). See
implementation phase.
b. End result of implementing something. “In
business, the full economic life cycle of an
investment program through retirement ( i.e .,
when the full expected value of the investment
is realized, as much value as is deemed
possible has been realized or it is determined
```

```
that the expected value cannot be realized and
the program is terminated)” (ISACA glossary).
```
**Implementation phase,
release**

```
Implementation and change management activities
that occur between constructing/delivering and
starting to use and hopefully gain the benefit of a
computer system, information service, strategy,
plan, project, policy, procedure, etc. Arguably the
most risky and stressful phase in the software
development lifecycle (crunch time!) with the
distinct possibility of ‘teething problems’ or abject
failure, especially if a new, unfamiliar, and as-yet-
unproven system is replacing or substantially
modifying an existing one, or if it is innovative,
critical/vital, complex, inadequately tested, poorly
specified, under-resourced, rushed, etc. “The period
of time in the software life cycle during which a
software product is created from design
documentation and debugged” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Importer “A natural or legal person established in the Union
who places on the market a product with digital
elements that bears the name or trademark of a
natural or legal person established outside the
Union” (EU CRA).
```
```
Imputation Process of filling-in and smoothing-over knowledge
gaps with information of dubious value, just as I am
doing right now in attempting to define this obscure
term. “Procedure where missing data are replaced
by estimated or modelled data” (ISO/IEC 22989 ).
“The replacement of unknown, unmeasured, or
missing data with a particular value. The simplest
form of imputation is to replace all missing values
with the average of that variable” (NIST SP 800-
55v).
```
```
IMSI Abbrev: I nternational M obile S ubscriber I dentity.
```

**IMSI-catcher** Device to capture **I** nternational **M** obile **S** ubscriber
**I** dentities from nearby phones by masquerading as
a cellular base station and spoofing the
authentication. See also Stingray.

```
IMT Abbrev: I ncident M anagement T eam.
```
```
In-band “Communication or transmission that occurs within
a previously established communication method or
channel. Note: The communications or
transmissions often take the form of a separate
protocol, such as a management protocol over the
same medium as the primary data protocol”
(ISO/IEC 27040). Cf. out-of-band.
```
```
Incentive Inducement, promised or anticipated benefit or
gain. “Financial and non-financial things that
encourage favorable conduct” (OCEG GRC
Glossary).
```
```
Incident Situation in which an information risk materialises,
i.e. one or more threats exploit one or more
vulnerabilities (typically exposed or inadequately
protected by inadequate, weak/ineffective, failed, or
absent information security controls) causing
material impacts on the organisation and
stakeholders. Includes the result of deliberate
breaches plus serious accidents and natural events.
Provided adequate detective controls are in place,
incidents typically generate alarms or alerts and log
entries, ideally early in the process allowing the
organisation to respond promptly, thus minimising
the impacts. “ Single or a series of unwanted or
unexpected information security events that have a
significant probability of compromising business
operations and threatening information security”
(ISO/IEC 27005 ). “Single or a series of unwanted
or unexpected information security breaches or
events, whether of criminal nature or not, that have
```

```
a significant probability of compromising business
operations or threatening information security”
(ISO/IEC 27043 ). “Event that can be, or could lead
to, a disruption, loss, emergency or crisis” (ISO
22300 ). “A violation or imminent threat of violation
of computer security policies, acceptable use
policies, guidelines or standard security practices”
(ISACA glossary). “An event that has been assessed
as having an actual or potentially adverse effect on
the security or performance of a system” (ENISA
RM glossary). “An occurrence that actually or
imminently jeopardizes, without lawful authority,
the confidentiality, integrity, or availability of
information or an information system; or
constitutes a violation or imminent threat of
violation of law, security policies, security
procedures, or acceptable use policies” (NIST SP
800-171). “An adverse network event in an
information system or network or the threat of the
occurrence of such an event” (SANS glossary). See
also near-miss, event, crisis, emergency.
```
```
Incident command See incident management. “Process that is
conducted as part of an incident management
system, and which evolves during the management
of an incident” (ISO 2230 0 ).
```
**Incident coordinator** “Person responsible for leading all incident
response activities and coordinating the incident
response team. Note: an organization can decide to
use another term for the incident coordinator”
_(ISO/IEC 27035-1)._ The professionals who
“manage and coordinate cross-government
response to significant incidents and engage with
victims” _(UK NCSC)._

```
Incident detection Until an information security incident has been
noticed by the affected parties, it cannot be
analysed and no specific response can be triggered.
```

```
This is a critical first step in the incident
management process with implications for detective
controls, alarms, alerts, logging, etc. and, of course,
information risks.
```
```
Incident handlers The professionals who “manage and respond to
incidents, engage with victims and where necessary
support coordinators on significant incidents” (UK
NCSC).
```
```
Incident handling Actions undertaken by incident handlers and other
experts to address incidents. “Actions of detecting,
reporting, assessing, responding to, dealing with,
and learning from information security incidents”
(ISO/IEC 27035-1). “An action plan for dealing
with intrusions, cyber-theft, denial of service, fire,
floods, and other security-related events. It is
comprised of a six step process: Preparation,
Identification, Containment, Eradication, Recovery,
and Lessons Learned” (SANS glossary).
```
**Incident management** Rational direction of activities to bring an incident
under control, assess the situation, and respond
accordingly. Follows on from crisis management
and leads into contingency management. “The
management and coordination of activities to
investigate, and remediate, an actual or potential
occurrence of an adverse cyber event that may
compromise or cause harm to a system or network”
_(UK National Cyber Security Strategy 2 022 )._

```
I ncident M anagement
S ystem (IMS)
```
```
Management system for various types of incident,
or at least some sort of system supporting incident
management. “System that defines the roles and
responsibilities of personnel and the operating
procedures to be used in the management of
incidents” (ISO 22300).
```

```
I ncident M anagement
T eam (IMT)
```
```
“Team consisting of appropriately skilled and
trusted members of an organization responsible for
leading all information security incident
management activities, in coordination with other
parties both internal and external throughout
incident lifecycle. Note: The head of this team can
be called the incident manager who has been
appointed by top management to adequately
respond to all types of incidents” (ISO/IEC 27035-
1 ). See also I ncident R esponse T eam.
```
**Incident preparedness** Readiness to deal with incidents. “Activities taken
to prepare for incident response” _(ISO 22300)._

```
Incident recovery Final clear-up phase following an incident which
achieves a return to (near) normality.
```
```
Incident reporters The professionals who “produce professional
products on incidents to ensure all relevant
government partners and agencies are updated on
developments” (UK NCSC).
```
```
Incident response What the I ncident R esponse T eam does, i.e.
investigate, assess, react appropriately to, and in
time resolve and help the organisation learn from,
incidents. “Actions taken to mitigate or resolve an
information security incident, including those taken
to protect and restore the normal operational
conditions of an information system and the
information stored in it” (ISO/IEC 27035-1).
“Actions taken in order to stop the causes of an
imminent hazard and/or mitigate the consequences
of potentially destabilizing events or disruptions,
and to recover to a normal situation. Note: Incident
response is part of the emergency management
process” (ISO 22300 ). “The response of an
enterprise to a disaster or other significant event
that may significantly affect the enterprise, its
people or its ability to function productively.
```

```
Incident response may include evacuation of a
facility, initiating a disaster recovery plan (DRP),
performing a damage assessment or any other
measures necessary to bring an enterprise to a more
stable status” (ISACA glossary). “The activities that
address the short-term, direct effects of an incident,
and may also support short-term recovery” (UK
National Cyber Security Strategy 2022 ). “The
structured process of identifying, managing, and
mitigating the effects of cybersecurity incidents to
minimize damage, recover operations, and prevent
future occurrences” (SANS glossary).
```
**I** ncident **R** esponse **P** lan
**(IRP)**

```
Planned procedure enabling the organisation to deal
promptly, efficiently and effectively with one or
more information security incidents. “The
operational component of incident management
(also called IRP). Note: The plan includes
documented procedures and guidelines for defining
the criticality of incidents, reporting and escalation
processes and recovery procedures” (ISACA
glossary). “The documentation of a predetermined
set of instructions or procedures to detect, respond
to, and limit consequences of an incident against an
organisation’s IT system(s)” (CNSSI 4009 ). “A plan
for responding to information security incidents as
defined by the individual agency” (NZISM). “A
document that describes the plan for responding to
cyber security incidents” (AusISM).
```
```
I ncident R esponse
T eam (IRT)
```
```
People readied (trained, motivated, primed, and
prepared) to respond promptly, efficiently, and
effectively to various security incidents. “Team of
appropriately skilled and trusted members of an
organization that respond to and resolved incident
in a coordinated way. Notes: there can be several
IRTs, one for each aspect of the incident. Computer
Emergency Response Team (CERT) and Computer
Security Incident Response Team (CSIRT) are
```

```
specific examples of IRTs in organizations and
sectorial, regional, and national entities wanting to
coordinate their response to large scale ICT and
cybersecurity incidents” (ISO/IEC 27035-1). See
also CERT.
```
```
Incinerate Destroy by burning, a technique used to prevent
further disclosure of information on storage media.
“Destruct by burning media completely to ashes”
(ISO/IEC 27040).
```
```
Incompetent,
incompetence
```
```
Literally, not sufficiently competent, skilled,
experienced, and capable to perform an activity,
duty, task, or rôle to the required level. Often used
pejoratively as a personal criticism, implying
idiocy, carelessness, etc.
```
```
Inconsistent,
inconsistently
```
```
Lacking in consistency and therefore unreliable,
untrustworthy, and of dubious value. Particularly
significant for anything important, significant,
serious, critical, or vital.
```
**Incremental backup** Backup of files that have been created or changed
since the previous incremental or image backup. To
restore a computer system fully, it is generally
necessary to restore the entire sequence of
incremental backups subsequent to the most recent
image backup. “Incremental backups only backup
the files that have been modified since the last
backup. If dump levels are used, incremental
backups only backup files changed since last
backup of a lower dump level” _(SANS glossary)._
See also differential backup.

```
Incremental
development
```
```
Software development approach (such as iterative
or R apid A pplication D evelopment) involving
sequential delivery of relatively minor evolutionary
program and functional changes rather than fewer
but more significant step-changes (the waterfall
```

```
method). “A software development technique in
which requirements definition, design,
implementation and testing occur in an overlapping,
iterative (rather than sequential) manner, resulting
in incremental completion of the overall software
product. Contrasts with rapid prototyping, the spiral
model and the waterfall model” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Incremental test Assurance process focused on testing changes made
since the previous test, rather than retesting
previously tested aspect every time. Presumes full
knowledge of the changes made, and a high degree
of independence between changes not often found
in systems, hence is normally complemented by
regression tests and others. “The deliberate testing
of only the value-added functionality of a software
component” (ISACA glossary). See also integration
test, system test, penetration test, load test, stress
test, security test, acceptance test.
```
```
Incriminate,
incriminating,
incrimination
```
```
Provision of information indicating someone’s guilt
or involvement in an illegal or otherwise
inappropriate, unauthorised, or forbidden activity.
```
**Inculpatory evidence** Forensic evidence allegedly proving that someone
or something _was_ involved in an incident, and
hence, they may be culpable (guilty of some
offence). “Evidence that tends to increase the
likelihood of fault or guilt” _(NIST SP 800-101).Cf._
exculpatory.

```
Independent Not dependent, reliant, linked, or associated but
free of external influence, control or constraint,
objective, unbiased, and dispassionate. Along with
personal integrity, a fundamental requirement for
science, forensics, and auditing (see audit
independence), and important for other forms of
assurance such as testing and product evaluation.
```

**Independent attitude** “An attitude with an impartial point of view. This
attitude allows an IS auditor to act objectively and
with fairness” _(ISACA glossary)._

```
I ndependent T est
L aboratory (ITL)

Independent, competent, and trustworthy
commercial scientific testing facility. “Third-party

```
I ndependent
V erification and
V alidation (IV&V)

```
“A comprehensive review, analysis, and testing

requirements” (CNSSI 4009 ).
```
```
Indicator Something that gives ‘an indication’ – often an
indirect, approximate, vague, and/or imprecise
measure or symptom of something, as opposed to a
metric. “ Measure that provides an estimate or
evaluation of something” (ISO/IEC 27000 ). “A
measure of progress toward or status of an
objective” (OCEG GRC Glossary).
```
```
I ndicator O f A ttack
(IOA)
```
```
Incident response or threat intelligence term for the

systems are currently in the process of being
compromised by hackers or malware, e.g. malicious
network probes used to enumerate devices, map the
network, and search for exploitable vulnerabilities.
See also I ndicator O f C ompromise.
```
```
I ndicator O f
C ompromise (IOC)
```
```
Incident response or threat intelligence term for the
characteristic evidence indicating that computer
systems have been compromised by hackers or
malware. Artefacts such as log entries, executable
files, scripts, running processes, network services,
and open ports may provide useful clues about the
```

```
existence and nature of even covert incidents ( e.g.
spyware and rootkits). See also I ndicator O f
A ttack.
```
```
Indirect connection “A connection to a device or network, which does
not take place directly but rather as part of a larger

```
**Induction,
responsibility
induction, orientation,
sheep-dip**

```
Process of introducing new workers to the
organisation, its business, history, mission,
objectives, governance and management, culture,
rules, rôles, responsibilities, etc. Informing and
motivating them have to be balanced against the
possibility of eroding the very qualities that led to
their being employed, and overloading them at the
start. In practice, the process extends well beyond
the typical H uman R esources-led training session
as newcomers interact with their new managers,
peers, and other colleagues, gradually becoming
assimilated into the team and corporate culture and
hopefully security-aware.
```
```
I ndustrial A utomation
and C ontrol S ystem
(IACS)
```
```
O perational T echnology system monitoring and
controlling industrial plant, geographically
dispersed utility equipment (remote valves,
switches, temperature/pressure gauges), etc. See
also A utomation and C ontrol S ystem, S upervisory
C ontrol A nd D ata A cquisition, I ndustrial C ontrol
S ystem.
```
```
Industrial complex Alludes to a sinister and oppressive widespread
conspiracy between large, powerful commercial
organisations and the state (more specifically, the
deep state), not unlike Big Brother. Trigger term
linked to misinformation and disinformation, or to
information depending on one’s perspective. See
also narrative.
```

```
I ndustrial C ontrol
S ystems (ICS)
```
```
Low-level embedded systems and related
O perational T echnology equipment ( I ndustrial
I nternet o f T hings smart things , actuators, relays,
and sensors) controlling industrial plant (valves,
pumps, motors, machine tools, ovens, robots, etc. ).
“An information system used to control industrial
processes such as manufacturing, product handling,
production, and distribution. Industrial control
systems include supervisory control and data
acquisition systems used to control geographically
dispersed assets, as well as distributed control
systems and smaller control systems using
programmable logic controllers to control localized

National Cyber Security Strategy 2022 ). See also
S upervisory C ontrol A nd D ata A cquisition,
I ndustrial A utomation and C ontrol S ystem, P rocess

**Industrial espionage** Use of unethical, illicit, surreptitious, and often
illegal surveillance, spying, and similar techniques
to gather sensitive and valuable information from
competitors, either directly ( _e.g._ by physical site
penetration or coercing insiders) or via common
business partners or other third parties such as
private detectives or information brokers.

```
I ndustrial I nternet o f
T hings (IIoT)
```
```
I nternet o f T hings applied to industrial ( e.g.
manufacturing shop floor automation) and
commercial contexts ( e.g. reading and controlling

consumer/home/personal purposes. Industrial
things include robotic plant, most S upervisory
C ontrol A nd D ata A cquisition/ I ndustrial C ontrol
S ystem devices, modern smart vehicles, and

```
Infect, infection,
infectious
```
```
By analogy to the biological process, malware is
said to ‘infect’ vulnerable computer systems when
it spreads to, executes on, and thus compromises
them.
```
```
Inference Logically surmising, presuming, or deducing
something from available information. “Reasoning
by which conclusions are derived from known
premises. Notes: In AI, a premise is either a fact, a
rule, a model, a feature or raw data; The term
‘inference’ refers both to the process and its result”
(ISO/IEC 22989).
```
```
Inference attack a. Type of cryptanalytic attack that relies on
inferring certain properties or values to break
the cryptosystem.
b. Type of D ata B ase or A rtificial I ntelligence
system attack in which certain combinations of
queries, perhaps in conjunction with
information obtained separately, can be used to
infer additional, often sensitive information
that is not directly available ( e.g. queries that
report results quickly are probably working
with smaller datasets or samples than
equivalent queries of similar complexity that
take much longer to execute).
c. Some other kind of attack involving logical
analysis. “Inference attacks rely on the user to
make logical connections between seemingly
unrelated pieces of information” (SANS
glossary).
```
**Infiltrator, infiltration,
ingress**

```
Outsider who somehow manages to work their way
into a privileged position of trust within the
organisation or penetrate its computer systems and
networks, gaining internal/insider access to
corporate assets typically with the intent of stealing
proprietary information (industrial espionage),
```

```
sabotaging critical business processes, committing
cybertage, and/or recruiting insiders. Long-term
physical infiltration by moles and sleepers is
popular in spy novels but uncommon in the
commercial world due to the high costs and risks
compared to, say, employing, bribing or coercing
insiders, social engineering, short-term physical site
penetration ( e.g. trespass, draining), deploying
malware, hacking, etc. Cf. exfiltration.
```
**INFOCON
(INFormation
Operations
CONdition)**

```
US military indicator of cyberwar status, ranging
from 5 (normal) up to 1 (maximum readiness).
```
```
Information Expression of knowledge that has meaning and
hence value. Knowledge itself is intangible
information, although it may be represented, stored,
expressed, communicated, and processed in the
form of writing, diagrams, speech, expressions,
mime, sign language, Morse code, semaphore,
smoke signals, computer data, etc. “Knowledge
concerning objects, such as facts, events, things,
processes, or ideas, including concepts, that within
a certain context has a particular meaning”
(ISO/IEC 2382 ). “Data processed, organized and
correlated to produce meaning” (ISO 22300). “An
asset that, like other important business assets, is
essential to an enterprise’s business. It can exist in
many forms. It can be printed or written on paper,
stored electronically, transmitted by post or by
using electronic means, shown on films, or spoken
in conversation” (ISACA glossary). “Any
communication or representation of knowledge
such as facts, data, and opinions in any medium or
form, electronic as well as physical. Information
includes any text, numerical, graphic, cartographic,
narrative, or any audio or visual representation”
(NZISM). “Any communication or representation of
```

```
knowledge such as facts, data, or opinions in any
medium or form, including textual, numerical,
graphic, cartographic, narrative, electronic, or
audiovisual forms” (OMB Circular A-130).
```
**Information actions &
controls**

```
“Communications and reports up, down, and across
the organization used to address risk, reward, and
compliance” (OCEG GRC Glossary).
```
```
I nformation and
C ommunications
T echnology (ICT)
```
```
Explicit extension of I nformation T echnology to

“IT” almost always implies both aspects. “Includes:

infrastructure; and technology-enabled business
processes and services” (NZISM). “Technology for

and transmitting information” (ISO 9241). Cf.
O perational T echnology, M obile T echnology,

```
Information and
communication
technology disaster
recovery
```
```
See D isaster R ecovery. “Ability of the information
and communication technology elements of an

```
Information and
communication
technology disaster
readiness
```
```
See D isaster R ecovery. “State of an information
and communication technology (ICT) function in
which it has the knowledge, skills, processes,

technologies in preparation for a potential event
that would lead to either an intolerable disruption of
ICT or an intolerable data loss” (ISO/IEC 27031).
```
```
Information and
systems
```
```
“Refers to information in electronic form
(electronic information) during its use, processing,
transmission, and storage and systems that use,
process, transmit or transfer, and store information
```

```
or that produce, manufacture, or distribute
products” ( T rust S ervices C riteria).
```
```
Information
architecture
```
```
High-level design perspective on the sources,
flows, stores, processing and legitimate exploitation
of information or data within the enterprise, and
perhaps beyond ( e.g. information content and
services provided to or by third parties). “One
component of IT architecture (together with
applications and technology)” (ISACA glossary).
```
**Information asset** Valuable information and, in some interpretations,
the computer systems, storage media, or people that
store/hold and/or process it. Vulnerable to various
information risks. Depending partly on the
jurisdiction and situation, an information asset held
by the organisation may legally belong to the
organisation, to an individual ( _e.g._ personal
information), to a third party who revealed or
entrusted it to another (thereby creating a custodial
responsibility, whether explicit or implicit), or may
be a part of the common wealth or public property
or of unknown origin and provenance. “Any
information or related equipment has value to an
organisation. This includes equipment, facilities,
patents, intellectual property, software and
hardware. Information Assets also include services,
information, and people, and characteristics such as
reputation, brand, image, skills, capability and
knowledge” _(NZISM).“_ Data and the associated
software and infrastructure used to process,
transmit, and store information or to produce,
manufacture, or distribute products” _(_ **_T_** _rust_
**_S_** _ervices_ **_C_** _riteria)._ “A collection of information,
either tangible or intangible, that is worth
protecting” _(DORA)._

owner**

```
See information owner.
```

I nformation A ssurance
(IA)
```
```
Act of assessing and evaluating the suitability and
adequacy of arrangements protecting valuable
information. “Measures that protect and defend
information and information systems by ensuring
their availability, integrity, authentication,
confidentiality, and non-repudiation. These

```
Information broker Someone who trades commercially in information.
While the consulting, publishing, news, and other
industries trade legitimately in information,

Information capital “Data, communications, and intelligence” (OCEG

information user**

“An individual, group, or any entity that receives
information” (OCEG GRC Glossary).
```
```
Information flow
control
```
```
Control over the passage or movement of
information between endpoints, e.g. permitting
bidirectional or unidirectional flow. “Procedure to
ensure that information transfers within a system do
not violate the security policy” (NIST SP 800-171).
```
```
I nformation
M anagement (IM)
```
```
Systematic, professional management of one or
more types/classes of information to achieve
objectives specified by its owners, custodians, and
other stakeholders.
```
```
Information need Strong desire, requirement, or desperate demand for
information. “Insight necessary to manage
```

```
objectives, goals, risks and problems”
(ISO/IEC/IEEE 15939).
```
```
I nformation O perations
(IO)
```
```
Information operations. “The integrated
employment of the core capabilities of electronic
warfare, computer network operations,
psychological operations, military deception, and
operations security, in concert with specified
supporting and related capabilities, to influence,
disrupt, corrupt, or usurp adversarial human and
automated decision-making process, information,
and information systems while protecting our own”
(CNSSI 4009).
```
```
Information overload Subjective human impression or experience that
new information is arriving faster than it can be
processed, potentially leading to stress, exhaustion,
and withdrawal (dysfunction, zoning-out,
depression). See also overload.
```
```
Information owner Organisation, rôle, or person who notionally or
literally owns and is responsible and usually
accountable to management or other authorities for
the proper protection and legitimate exploitation of
valuable information. May be a custodian, steward,
or agent acting on behalf of the legal owner. May
be required or expected to: commission and sponsor
information risk analyses, approve risk evaluations
and fund the corresponding risk treatments
including controls, define access policies and
authorise access, and review and monitor the
effectiveness of the controls and own the residual
risks. See also asset owner, control owner, data
owner, infrastructure owner, network owner,
process owner, risk owner, system owner, service
owner, problem owner.
```
**Information processing** Archaic term for **I** nformation **T** echnology.
“Systematic performance of operations upon


```
information, that includes data processing and may
include operations such as data communication and
office automation. Note: The term information
processing must not be used as a synonym for data
processing” (ISO/IEC 2382).
```
**Information processing
facility**

```
Archaic term for data centre, computer suite/room,
etc. “Any information processing system, service or
infrastructure, or the physical location housing it”
(ISO/IEC 27002).
```
```
Information producer “An individual, group, or any entity that produces
data/information to send to another individual,
group, or entity” (OCEG GRC Glossary).
```
```
Information
protection, data
protection
```
```
Whereas privacy is the primary concern of
information/data protection laws, they may also
require accuracy, informed consent, usage only for
stated purposes and destruction once the purpose is
achieved, extending the remit beyond
confidentiality and control or ownership.
```
```
Information resource See information asset. “Information and related
resources, such as personnel, equipment, funds, and
information technology” (NIST SP 800-171).
```
```
I nformation R etrieval
(IR)
```
```
Recalling or remembering previously stored
information. “Task of retrieving relevant documents
or parts of documents from a dataset, typically
based on keyword or natural language queries”
(ISO/IEC 22989).
```
```
Information risk Risk involving or affecting information, normally
involving the deliberate, incidental, or accidental
action of [one or more] threats on [one or more]
exposed vulnerabilities relating to [one or more]
information assets, causing [one or more] impacts.
See also information security risk.
```

```
I nformation R isk
A ssessment
M ethodology No 2
(IRAM2)
```
```
Second version of the I nformation S ecurity
F orum’s systematic information risk management
process involving scoping, B usiness I mpact
A ssessment, threat profiling, vulnerability
assessment, risk evaluation, and risk treatment.
```
**I** nformation **R** isk
**M** anagement **(IRM),
I** nformation **R** isk **and
S** ecurity **M** anagement
**(IRSM)**

```
Activities involved in identifying, evaluating, and
treating risks pertaining to information, particularly
the use of information security controls to mitigate
unacceptable information risks. Includes the
governance arrangements and management
activities such as preparing and executing
strategies, policies, plans, etc. ; monitoring
performance and other metrics; managing incidents;
and integrating these with other business activities
(such as risk management, B usiness C ontinuity
M anagement , compliance management, and I nternal
A udit) in support of the organisation’s mission and
objectives.
```
```
I nformation R isk
M anagement S ystem
(IRMS)
```
```
M anagement S ystem by which the organisation’s
information risks are systematically identified,
assessed, evaluated, treated, and monitored,
supporting the achievement of business objectives.
See also I nformation S ecurity M anagement
S ystem.
```
```
Info rmation sec urity
(infosec)
```
```
Act of securing, guarding, or protecting information
without unduly restricting its legitimate
exploitation. In more detail, the risk management
and assurance activities involving the specification,
design, implementation, operation, measurement,
management, monitoring and maintenance of
controls, and other risk treatments in order to
satisfy requirements for confidentiality, integrity,
and availability of information by constraining the
number and/or severity of incidents. Broader in
scope than I nformation T echnology security or
cybersecurity since it encompasses other
```

```
technologies (such as O perational T echnology) and
information of all forms (including knowledge and
I ntellectual P roperty), not just digital data and
computer systems. “Preservation of confidentiality,
integrity and availability of information. Note: in
addition, other properties, such as authenticity,
accountability, non-repudiation, and reliability can
also be involved” (ISO/IEC 27000 ). “The assurance
that information is protected against disclosure to
unauthorized users (confidentiality), improper
modification (integrity) and nonaccess when
required (availability). Information security deals
with all formats of information—paper documents,
digital assets, intellectual property in people’s
minds and verbal and visual communications”
(ISACA glossary). “The protection of information
and systems from unauthorized access, use,
disclosure, disruption, modification, or destruction
to provide confidentiality, integrity, and availability.
Note: the term ‘cybersecurity’ can be used
interchangeably with ‘information security’” (NIST
SP 800-55v1). “Measures relating to the
confidentiality, availability and integrity of
information that is processed, stored and
communicated by electronic or any other means”
(NZISM). “Refers to the practice of protecting
information from unauthorized access, disclosure,
alteration, destruction, or disruption” (SANS
glossary).
```
**Information security
architecture**

```
High-level architectural blueprint or design for the
organisation’s information security arrangements,
linking even higher-level information security,
information, risk, compliance, and business
strategies through to security designs for individual
computer systems, business processes,
technologies, applications, etc. “An embedded,
integral part of the enterprise architecture that
describes the structure and behavior for an
```

```
enterprise’s security processes, information security
systems, personnel and organizational sub-units,
showing their alignment with the enterprise’s
mission and strategic plans” (NIST SP 800-39).
```
```
I nformation S ecurity
A ssessment (ISA)
```
```
a. Assurance process to quantify residual
information risks by reviewing the

b. Excel spreadsheet detailing information
security control requirements for automotive
companies, derived from ISO/IEC 27001 :2013
Annex A under the TISAX scheme by
V erband D er A utomobilindustrie, an
automotive industry trade body. “An
information security requirements catalogue
based on key aspects of the international
standard ISO/IEC 27001. It is used by

https://www.vda.de/dam/jcr:80a83325-3287-
456f-a4f1-
01afb2cc063f/ISA6_EN_FINAL.xlsx

**Information security
breach**

```
Incident that compromises information.
“Compromise of information security that leads to
the undesired destruction, loss, alteration,
disclosure of, or access to, protected information
transmitted, stored or otherwise processed”
(ISO/IEC 27002).
```
**Information security
continuity**

```
Business continuity arrangements for any business-
critical parts or functions of the information

ensuring continued information security
operations” (ISO/IEC 27000).
```

**Information security
control**

```
Control designed to mitigate unacceptable

maintaining adequate levels of information
confidentiality, integrity, and availability (the CIA
triad).
```
**Information security
design**

```
Architecture for the controls addressing information
security risks and control objectives or other
requirements of a system or process. May comprise

among various design, development and operations
documents, policies, procedures, change records,
etc. or be undocumented, merely implicit.

**Information security
event**

```
Event involving the compromise of information
security. “Identified occurrence of a system, service
or network state indicating a possible breach of

a previously unknown situation that may be
security relevant” (ISO/IEC 27000 ). “Occurrence
indicating a possible information security breach or
failure of controls” (ISO/IEC 27002 ). “Occurrence
indicating a possible breach of information security
or failure of controls” (ISO/IEC 27035- 1 ). See also
security event.
```
```
I nformation S ecurity
F orum (ISF)
```
```
Professional/trade body that conducts original
research and develops information security
standards, guidelines, methods, tools, and services

members. Its conferences are highly regarded and
free for members. Was originally the E uropean
S ecurity F orum. More info:
https://www.securityforum.org/
```
**Information security
governance**

```
Governance of the information security function
and activities. “The set of responsibilities and
practices exercised by the board and executive
management with the goal of providing strategic
```

```
direction, ensuring that objectives are achieved,
ascertaining that risk is managed appropriately and
verifying that the enterprise’s information security
resources are used responsibly” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Information security
incident
```
```
See incident. “One or multiple related and
identified information security events that can harm
an organization’s assets or compromise its
operations” (ISO/IEC 27002 ). “Single or a series of
unwanted or unexpected information security
events that have a significant probability of
compromising business operations and threatening
information security” (ISO/IEC 27035-1). “Related
and identified information security events that can
harm an organization’s assets or compromise its
operations” (ISO/IEC 27035- 1 ). “An occurrence or
activity that may threaten the confidentiality,
integrity or availability of a system or the
information stored, processed or communicated by
it or by any other process or system and processes”
(NZISM).
```
**Information security
incident management**

```
See incident management. “Exercise of a consistent
and effective approach to the handling of
information security incidents” (ISO/IEC 27002 ).
“Processes for detecting, reporting, assessing,
responding to, dealing with, and learning from
information security incidents” (ISO/IEC 27000 ).
“Collaborative activities to handle information
security incidents in a consistent and effective way”
(ISO/IEC 27035-1).
```
```
Information security
investigation
```
```
“Application of examinations, analysis and
interpretation to aid understanding of an
information security incident. [SOURCE: ISO/IEC
27042, modified]” (ISO/IEC 27035-1).

```
I nformation S ecurity
M anagement (ISM)
```
```
Corporate function responsible for day-to-day
management of information security, managing
```

```
technical, procedural, and physical controls,
systems, processes, standards, etc. Led by the
I nformation S ecurity M anager.

**I** nformation **S** ecurity
**M** anagement **S** ystem
**(ISMS)**

```
M anagement System by which information
security strategies are defined and executed, and
security operations are designed, directed,
monitored, overseen, and controlled in order to
mitigate unacceptable information risks. “The
policies, procedures, guidelines, and associated
resources and activities, collectively managed by an
organisation, in the pursuit of protecting its
information assets ... a systematic approach for
establishing, implementing, operating, monitoring,
reviewing, maintaining and improving an
organisation’s information security to achieve
business objectives ... based upon a risk assessment
and the organisation’s risk acceptance levels
designed to effectively treat and manage risks ...
analysing requirements for the protection of
information assets and applying appropriate
controls to ensure the protection of these
information assets, as required, contributes to the
successful implementation of an ISMS ...”
(ISO/IEC 27000 ). Note : although ‘information
security management system’ is not formally
defined as such in the glossary section of ISO/IEC
27000, both ‘information security’ and
‘management system’ are separately defined, the
abbreviation ‘ISMS’ is expanded in Section 0.1
‘Overview’ and an ISMS is described in Section 3.2
“What is an ISMS?.” See also I nformation R isk
M anagement S ystem, P rivacy I nformation
M anagement S ystem.

**I** nformation **S** ecurity
**M** anagement **S** ystem
**(ISMS) professional**

```
“Person who establishes, implements, maintains
and continuously improves one or more
information security management system
processes” (ISO/IEC 27000).
```

```
I nformation S ecurity
M anagement S ystem
(ISMS) scope
```
```
Formally documented description of the boundary
of an organisation’s I nformation S ecurity
M anagement S ystem, defined in terms that make
sense in the business context, e.g. the ISMS may
apply to the entire enterprise (potentially with
exceptions) or a specified part ( e.g. one or more
business units, departments, functions,
sites/locations, countries, etc .). The scope could
also be defined in relation to the organisation’s
information risks ( e.g. ‘The ISMS is used to
manage information risks classed as high or above’)
or information assets ( e.g. ‘The ISMS protects
digital data, computer systems and networks’) or
some combination of factors. “The organization
shall determine the boundaries and applicability of
the information security management system to
establish its scope. When determining this scope,
the organization shall consider: a) the external and
internal issues referred to in 4.1; b) the
requirements referred to in 4.2; c) interfaces and
dependencies between activities performed by the
organization, and those that are performed by other
organizations. The scope shall be available as
documented information” (ISO/IEC 27001 clause
4.3).

```
I nformation S ecurity
M anager (ISM)

Manager (leader) of the I nformation S ecurity

I nformation S ecurity O fficer.

**Information security
objective**

```
Requirement or expectation relating to information
security. An obvious objective is to ensure the
confidentiality, integrity, and availability of
information but there are other possibilities, such as
facilitating the legitimate exploitation of
information, providing assurance, competently
managing information risks, or cost-effectively
managing information security. Can be framed in
technology, process, risk, business, strategic,
```

```
operational, or other terms according to the context.
Can declare desired goals and/or unwanted anti-
goals (such as reducing the number and severity of
incidents). Can be broad or specific. Usually
phrased in terms of anticipated outcomes but may
specify methods, approaches or techniques to
achieve intended outcomes. See also control
objective.
```
```
Information security
policy
```
```
Policy concerning, or relating in some way to, the
security and protection of information. “A high-
level document that describes how an agency
protects its systems. The CSP [ C yber S ecurity
P olicy?] is normally developed to cover all systems
and can exist as a single document or as a set of
related documents” (NZISM).
```
**Information security
policy manual or suite**

```
Organisation’s collection of policies relating to
information risk and information security. May
incorporate or reference policies in related areas
such as physical security, privacy, governance,
compliance, cybersecurity, incident management,
and B usiness C ontinuity M anagement.
```
```
Information security
program
```
```
a. The organisation’s current and/or planned
activities, projects, investments, initiatives,
etc. concerning information security and
related areas, in whole or in part. “The
combination of technical, operational and
procedural measures and management
structures implemented to provide for the
confidentiality, integrity and availability of
information based on business requirements
and risk analysis” (ISACA glossary).
b. Software application providing information
security functions.
```
```
Information security
risk
```
```
Uncertain possibility of incidents involving or
affecting information security, in particular the loss
```

```
of information confidentiality, integrity, and/or
availability (the CIA triad). “Potential that a threat
will exploit a vulnerability of an asset or group of
assets and thereby cause harm to an organisation”
(ISO/IEC 27000 ). “The risk to organizational
operations (including mission, functions, image,
reputation), organizational assets, individuals, other
organizations, and the Nation due to the potential
for unauthorized access, use, disclosure, disruption,
modification, or destruction of information and/or
information systems” (NIST SP 800-39). See also
information risk, confidentiality risk, integrity risk,
availability risk.
```
```
Information service Service revolving around the generation,
processing, and provision of information, such as
electronic publishing, email, or espionage. Usually
but not necessarily automated using technology.
```
```
Information sharing
community
```
```
“Group of organisations that agree to share
information. Note: an organisation can be an
individual” (ISO/IEC 27000).
```
```
Information
superiority
```
```
Given the strategic importance of obtaining an
adversary’s information and its value, spooks
generally aim to be even better than their peers and
opponents at gathering, interpreting, and making
use of foreign intelligence while, at the same time,
protecting domestic intelligence from disclosure,
interception, surveillance, spying, etc.
```
**I** nformation **S** ystem **(IS)** System, computer, _thing_ , host, node, device, client,
server, application, process, service, technology,
_etc_. involved in generating, storing, processing,
manipulating, using/exploiting, and communicating
information. Often ambiguously shortened to
‘system’: is that just the computer itself or the
whole structure? “Information processing system,
together with associated organizational resources


```
such as human, technical, and financial resources,
that provides and distributes information [and]
system consisting of a conceptual schema,
information base, and information processor,
forming together a system for keeping and
manipulating information” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “Set of
applications, services, information technology
assets, or other information-handling components”
(ISO/IEC 27002 ). “The combination of strategic,
managerial and operational activities involved in
gathering, processing, storing, distributing and
using information and its related technologies.
Note: Information systems are distinct from
information technology (IT) in that an information
system has an IT component that interacts with the
process components” (ISACA glossary). “A discrete
set of information resources organized for the
collection, processing, maintenance, use, sharing,
dissemination, or disposition of information” (NIST
SP 800-171).
```

related security risks**

800-39).

resilience

```

consistent with mission needs” (NIST SP 800-39).
“The ability of an information system to operate
under adverse conditions or stress, even if in a
degraded or debilitated state, while maintaining
```

```
essential operational capabilities, and to recover to
an effective operational posture in a time frame
consistent with mission needs” (OMB Circular A-
130 ).

**I** nformation **T** echnology
**(IT), technology**

```
Encompasses all aspects of technology and tools
used to create, store, process, exploit, manage, and
communicate/share information, including
hardware, software, firmware, C ommunications
T echnology, O perational T echnology, M obile

```

**I** nformation **W** arfare

```
Unethical and often illegal activities to obtain trade
secrets or other proprietary or confidential
information from a competitor or other adversary,

```
Informed consent Just as patients are required to consent to (permit)

informed about how their personal information will
be used and protected at the time it is collected
from them, giving them the choice to opt-out.

Assessors Program

“An initiative of the Australian Cyber Security

```
```
Infostealer Contraction of info rmation stealer , a prevalent and
sinister type of malware intended to exfiltrate
valuable information surreptitiously from a
compromised system, device, network,
organisation, or even individual. The stolen info
may be exploited in many non-exclusive ways, e.g.
offered for sale on the black market via information
brokers, sold to clients who commissioned the
```

```
attack, used to coerce payments from the victim by

```

or of a country, state, city, organisation, home,
person, etc. May include physical structures such as
foundations, columns, and beams. Usually involves
the provision of food and water, safety and security,
housing, healthcare, wealthcare, power, and more.
In the I nformation T echnology context, it is mostly
computing and networking hardware platforms and
cables, plus shared services that integrate the
systems, providing monitoring, management, and
access. “The collection of physical or virtual
resources that supports an overall IT environment,
including the server, storage, and network
elements” ( T rust S ervices C riteria). See also
cyberinfrastructure, C ritical I nfrastructure, P ublic
K ey I nfrastructure.

Cloud computing services model providing
customers with access to Internet-based virtual

middleware, and applications. The service
provider’s responsibilities, including the

metal, hypervisor, and network access. “A form of

```

```
including operating systems and applications”

**Infrastructure control,
infrastructural control**

```
a. Control designed to mitigate unacceptable
risks to an infrastructure service, e.g. laws,
regulations, contractual terms, and standards
concerning the security (resilience, reliability,
...) of electrical power supplied by generators
to the grid. Includes various controls
within/integral to the infrastructure, e.g. grid
status monitoring, performance management,
and proactive maintenance.
b. Control designed to mitigate unacceptable
risks from an infrastructure service to
customers/users, e.g. generator-backed
U ninterruptible P ower S upplies for critical
servers and vital equipment.
```
```
Infrastructure owner Organisation, rôle, or person who literally/legally
or notionally owns an infrastructure (as a whole or
just a part, e.g. the electrical distribution grid in a
given region) along with any associated property
rights and obligations, responsibilities, or social
expectations. May be a custodian, steward, or agent
acting on behalf of the legal owner. May be
accountable for its protection/security and
legitimate exploitation to optimise its value. See
also asset owner, information owner, network
owner, system owner, service owner.
```
```
Infrastructure
resilience
```
```
Techniques to ensure the availability and continuity
of corporate and national infrastructures delivering
essential services such as datacommunications,
power, and water, despite potentially disruptive
```

```
events, incidents, and disasters (infrastructure
risks). “The timely and efficient prevention,
absorption, recovery, adaptation and transformation
of national infrastructure’s essential structures and
functions, which have been exposed to current and
potential future hazards. Implementing resilience
across all disruption phases should be done through
collaborative risk and uncertainty management,
multi-hazard assessment, and methods that embrace
the systemic nature of national infrastructure”
(Principles for Resilient Infrastructure, UN Office
for Disaster Risk Reduction, 2022).
```
```
Infrastructure risk Uncertain possibility of incidents involving or
affecting an infrastructure. “The risk that
information and technology (I&T) infrastructure
and systems may be unable to effectively support
the current and future needs of the business in an
efficient, cost-effective and well-controlled
fashion” (ISACA glossary).

Infringement
notification,
infringement letter

```
See cease and desist letter.

```

& controls” (OCEG GRC Glossary).

**Inherent risk, raw risk,
untreated risk,
baseline risk**

```
Amount of risk that is believed to exist in a
situation regardless of any risk treatments intended
to mitigate it – essentially the starting point for risk
management activities, and potentially the current
or actual risk level if treatments are ineffective.
“The level of risk or exposure that does not account
for the actions management has taken or might take
( e.g ., implementing controls)” (ISACA glossary).
“The level of risk in the absence of actions &
controls” (OCEG GRC Glossary). “The
combination of internal and external risk factors
```

```
that exists in the absence of any management
actions” (IIA GIAS).
```
**Initial Access Broker** Someone specialising in breaking in to a network
by phishing, hacking, or malware, who then sells
that illicit access or foothold to cybercriminals.

```
I nitialisation V ector
(IV)
```
```
Random or pseudorandom number used in
conjunction with a private key to encrypt data.
Must have sufficient entropy to resist brute force
attacks ... unlike W ired E quivalent P rotocol. “A
vector used in defining the starting point of an
encryption process within a cryptographic
algorithm” (FIPS 140-2). See also seed.
```
```
I nitial P rogram L oad
(IPL)
```
```
Boot process for a mainframe or other computer.
“The initialization procedure that causes an

```
```
Injection, inject “A general term for attack types that inject code
that is then interpreted/executed by the application”
( OWASP ). “Scripted piece of information inserted
into an exercise that is designed to elicit a response
or decision and facilitate the flow of the exercise.
Note: Injects can be written, oral, televised and/or
transmitted via any means ( e.g. phone, email, fax,
voice, radio or sign)” (ISO 22300).
```
```
Injection flaw Category of software design flaws that allow
attackers to manipulate input data in such a way
that vulnerable applications mistakenly interpret
and act upon malicious commands within user-
supplied data. Normally mitigated by validation
routines that explicitly check input data for
invalid/inappropriate content (such as escape
characters signalling embedded commands and
end-of-string markers) prior to passing them to the
```

```
application: clearly, the validation routines must
themselves be resistant to injection attacks. See also
code injection, HTML injection, Cross-Site
Scripting.
```
**Injunctive norm** Prematurely describing or implying that _intended_
behaviours are ‘normal,’ ‘typical,’ or ‘conventional’
actively encourages most people to change their
ways and conform with expectations. For instance,
discussing the few incident notifications recently
received as if they were commonplace can increase
incident reporting. “Perceived behavior of what
most people approve of, providing information on
what one ‘should’ do” _(OCEG GRC Glossary). Cf._
descriptive norms.

```
Ingress Moving into a building, system, network, etc.
“Traffic that comes into a network” (ISACA
glossary). Cf. egress.
```
```

network, e.g. to prevent recognised inbound
hacking attacks or spam reaching their destinations.
“Filtering inbound traffic” (SANS glossary).Cf.
egress filtering.
```
```
Input control a. Control designed to mitigate unacceptable
input risks, such as data entry validation by a
computer system or fact-checking by a critical
thinker. “Techniques and procedures used to
verify, validate and edit data to ensure that
only correct data are entered into the
computer” (ISACA glossary).
b. More generally, control relevant to inputs to a
process, business unit, or organisation, such as
Q uality C ontrol and invoicing integrity checks
for raw materials and products received by a
manufacturer.
```

```
Input data Digital data or information fed into a system or

predicted output or inference” (ISO/IEC 22989).
```
```
Input risk Uncertain possibility of issues with inputs to a

unauthorised, inappropriate, or malicious

```

entry validation
```
```
Validation of data entered manually or fed
automatically to an application, system, function,
etc. applying various predefined rules to block
invalid data types, values, ranges, etc. while passing
valid data. Can be quite sophisticated, dynamically
applying business logic and explicit security tests
relevant to the business and processing context, e.g.
to detect and respond appropriately to both casual

**Input validation attack** Input validation attack. “Where an attacker

Insecurity a. Lack of, or inadequate, security. See unsecure.

```

```

friend, family member, broker, or another

**I** ntegrated **T** est **F** acility
**(ITF)**

```
a. Self-assessment function built in to a computer
system or application. “A testing methodology
in which test data are processed in production
systems. Notes: The data usually represent a
set of fictitious entities such as departments,
customers or products. Output reports are
verified to confirm the correctness of the
processing” (ISACA glossary). Cf. integration
test.
b. Laboratory setup using automation to conduct

```
```
Integration test Testing phase in conventional software
development methods where, having been tested
individually (unit tests), functional modules,
subsystems, etc. are brought together and
interoperate as a partial or complete system.
“Progressive linking and testing of programs or
modules in order to ensure their proper functioning
in the complete system” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “An
orderly progression of testing in which software
elements, hardware elements or both are combined
and tested to evaluate their interactions, until the
entire system has been integrated” (ISACA
glossary). See also system test, regression test,
P roduction A cceptance T est.
```
```
Integrity Cluster of information properties or characteristics
such as completeness, currency, authenticity,
quality, accuracy, and trustworthiness of
```

```
information, data, systems, people, organisations,
etc. One of the core information protection
objectives of information security alongside
confidentiality and availability (the CIA triad).
“Property of accuracy and completeness” (ISO/IEC
27000 ). “ Property of safeguarding the accuracy and
completeness of assets” (ISO 22300). “Property
whereby data have not been altered in an
unauthorized manner since they were created,
transmitted, or stored” (ISO/IEC 29167-19). “The
guarding against improper information
modification or destruction, and includes ensuring
information non-repudiation and authenticity”
(ISACA glossary). “The state of being whole and
complete by fulfilling obligations, honoring
promises, and cleaning up the mess if a promise is
broken” (OCEG GRC Glossary). “The assurance
that data has been created, amended or deleted only
by authorised individuals” (AusISM). “The
assurance that information is accurate, complete
and valid, and has not been altered by an
unauthorized action” (SCP QRG). “In information
security, integrity means that information has not
been changed accidentally, or deliberately, and is
accurate and complete” (UK National Cyber
Security Strategy 2022 ). “Behavior characterized
by adherence to moral and ethical principles,
including demonstrating honesty and the
professional courage to act based on relevant facts”
(IIA GIAS). “Guarding against improper
information modification or destruction and
includes ensuring information non-repudiation and
authenticity” (NIST SP 800-171). “The need to
ensure that information has not been changed
accidentally or deliberately, and that it is accurate
and complete” (SANS glossary).
```
**Integrity control** Control designed to mitigate unacceptable integrity
risks. Its primary purpose is to keep information,


```
information systems and services reasonably
complete, accurate, functional, valuable, current,
trustworthy, reliable, etc. using cryptographic
hashes, referential integrity, data entry/input
validation, assurance, transparency, honesty and
ethics, policies and procedures, etc. See also
confidentiality control, availability control.
```
```
Integrity risk Risk involving or affecting integrity, such as the

trust following an incident. “The risk that data may
be unavailable due to incompleteness or
inaccuracy” (ISACA glossary). See also information
risk, information security risk, confidentiality risk,
availability risk.

Laws and regulations in several jurisdictions
concern the authorised and unauthorised
monitoring/capturing of communications for
various purposes by various parties using various
means. The basic principles were established way
back when commercial and military secrets were
passed by couriers and letters, and have been
updated to cover computer data and
telecommunications.
```
```
Interdiction Physical security threat that compromises electronic
products at some point in the supply chains linking
their designers and manufacturers to the consumers,
```

```
e.g. by substituting firmware or inserting tiny
surveillance chips on P rinted C ircuit B oards.

**Interested party** Person or organisation that is materially involved
with or directly affected by something, as opposed
to merely having a casual interest in it. “Person or
organization that can affect, be affected by, or
perceive itself to be affected by a decision or
activity” _(ISO/IEC 27002 )._ “Person or organization
that can affect, be affected by, or perceive itself to
be affected by a decision or activity” ( _ISO/IEC
27002_ ). “Person or organization that can affect, be
affected by, or perceive itself to be affected by a
decision or activity. EXAMPL _E_ : Customers,
owners, personnel, providers, bankers, regulators,
unions, partners or society that can include
competitors or opposing pressure groups. Notes: A
decision maker can be an interested party. Impacted
communities and local populations are considered
to be interested parties. This constitutes one of the
common terms and core definitions of the high
level structure for ISO management system
standards. The original definition has been
modified by adding the example and the notes to
entry” _(ISO 22300)._ See also third party,
stakeholder.

```
Interface Functional, logical, or physical junction between
two or more parts, across which information flows,
such as an A pplication P rogramming I nterface or a
network interface. “1. A shared boundary between
two functional units, defined by functional
characteristics, common physical interconnection
characteristics, signal characteristics and other
characteristics, as appropriate. The concept
involves the specification of the connection of two
devices having different functions. 2. A point of
communication between two or more processes,
persons or other physical entities. 3. A peripheral
```

```
device that permits two or more devices to
communicate. [and] A shared boundary across
components, humans, services, hardware or
software that needs or exchanges information or
data. Either the term ‘interface’ or ‘connection’ may
be used to describe this boundary” (ISACA
glossary).
```
```
Interference a. Contemporaneous transmissions on the same
frequencies preventing or degrading reception
of wanted electromagnetic signals, whether
intentionally ( e.g. jamming) or accidentally
transmitted ( e.g. intermodulation, spurii, static,
solar flare).
b. More generally, impeding, delaying, or
preventing something, e.g. someone
participating reluctantly (‘passive-
aggressively’) in an investigation or audit,
producing information slowly and only that
explicitly requested or conversely
accompanied by a large volume of extraneous
material.
```
```
Interim audit See surveillance audit.
```
```
Interlock Vital (safety-critical) mechanical,
electromechanical, or electronic control device or
linkage, e.g. a relay that removes power to the air
conditioning fans if the fire system enters an alarm
condition upon detecting heat or smoke, in order
not to fan the flames (literally!).
```

Internal Within the outer physical or notional perimeter or
boundary of a person, system, network,
organisation, site/property, etc. Cf. external.

Audit conducted on behalf of the organisation by
I nternal A udit D epartment, or by suitably
independent and competent workers or consultants.
Generally scoped and approved by, and reported to,
senior management and maybe other stakeholders.

organization itself for management review and
other internal purposes, and which can form the
basis for an organization’s self-declaration of
conformity. Note: In many cases, particularly in
smaller organizations, independence can be
demonstrated by the freedom from responsibility
for the activity being audited” (ISO 22300). “An
independent, objective assurance and advisory
service designed to add value and improve an
organization’s operations. It helps an organization
accomplish its objectives by bringing a systematic,
disciplined approach to evaluate and improve the
effectiveness of governance, risk management, and
control processes” (IIA GIAS). “Sometimes called a
first-party audit, conducted by, or on behalf of, the
organisation itself for internal purposes” (FSRCoP).

Internal context, the situation, circumstances, and

by the organization; capabilities, understood in

Internal context can include: governance,

“Categories of sources and forces that originate

**Internal control** Discretionary control voluntarily adopted by the
organisation, as opposed to one mandated or
imposed upon it by some authority. Various types
are used, often in combination, _e.g._ technological,
process, administrative, and physical controls.
Collectively, internal controls form the enterprise-
wide system of governance and management
activities intended to ensure that the organisation
achieves its objectives in a controlled manner,
overcoming risks by design and intent (deliberately
and systematically reducing uncertainties) rather
than by sheer good fortune. “The policies,
procedures, practices and organizational structures
designed to provide reasonable assurance that
business objectives will be achieved and undesired
events will be prevented or detected and corrected”
_(ISACA glossary). “_ A process, effected by an
entity’s board of directors, management, and other
personnel, designed to provide reasonable
assurance regarding the achievement of objectives
relating to operations, reporting, and compliance”
_(_ **_T_** _rust_ **_S_** _ervices_ **_C_** _riteria)._

```
