**Intrusion, penetration** a. Hacking attack on a network or system
originating externally. “Unauthorized access to
a network or a network-connected system, _i.e_.
deliberate or accidental unauthorized access to
an information system, to include malicious
activity against an information system, or
unauthorized use of resources within an
information system” _(ISO/IEC 2703 3-1)._ “Any
event during which unauthorized access
occurs” _(ISACA glossary)._ “Gaining


```
unauthorized logical access to sensitive data
by circumventing a system’s protections”
(SANS glossary). Cf. extrusion.
b. Unauthorised physical access to, or infiltration
of, a site/location/facility, e.g. by an industrial
spy, saboteur, burglar, or other outsider, or
indeed by an insider.
c. Form of attack on communications systems
involving the injection of modified or
fabricated messages intended to confuse and
deceive.
```
**Intrusion detection** Process to identify and log the presence of
unauthorised visitors or users on a computer
system, network device, or physical location and
(normally) raise an intrusion alert or alarm,
triggering the appropriate incident response. A
particular form of incident detection. “Formal
process of detecting intrusions, generally
characterized by gathering knowledge about
abnormal usage patterns as well as what, how, and
which vulnerability has been exploited so as to
include how and when it occurred” _(ISO/IEC
27039 )._ “The process of monitoring the events
occurring in a computer system or network to
detect signs of unauthorized access or attack”
_(ISACA glossary)._

```
I ntrusion D etection
S ystem (IDS)
```
```
Electronic ( e.g. H ost-based I ntrusion D etection
S ystem or N etwork I ntrusion D etection S ystem) or
physical controls ( e.g. infrared detectors,
microswitches or vibration detectors on doors and
windows, and pressure pads under access routes) to
detect intruders as part of intrusion detection. IDS
typically works either generically by detecting
anomalies (such as movement within an office in
the dead of night – prone to false positives), or
specifically by detecting the signatures or
characteristics of known types of attack (such as the
```

```
distinctive sound of breaking glass – prone to false
negatives). A form of defensive security. “Technical
system that is used to identify that an intrusion has
been attempted, is occurring, or has occurred and
possibly respond to intrusions in information
systems and networks” (ISO/IEC 27039 ). “A
system that inspects network and host security
activity to identify suspicious patterns that may
indicate a network or system attack” (ISACA
glossary). “An automated system used to identify
an infringement of security policy from an internal
or external source” (NZISM). “An automated
system used to identify an infringement of security
policy. IDS can be host-based or network-base”
(AusISM). “A security management system for
computers and networks. An IDS gathers and
analyzes information from various areas within a
computer or a network to identify possible security
breaches, which include both intrusions (attacks
from outside the organization) and misuse (attacks
from within the organization)” (SANS glossary).
See also I ntrusion P revention S ystem, S ecurity
I nformation and E vent M anagement, N etwork
T raffic A nalysis U ser B ehaviour A nalytics.
```
**Intrusion prevention** Process to identify the presence of unauthorised
visitors or users, and, where appropriate,
automatically take the necessary action to deny
them further access ( _e.g._ blocking or diverting
suspicious network traffic emanating from
presumably compromised systems or networks).
“Formal process of actively responding to prevent
intrusions” _(ISO/IEC 27033-1)._ “A preemptive
approach to network security used to identify
potential threats and respond to them to stop, or at
least limit, damage or disruption” _(ISACA
glossary)._ See also **I** ntrusion **P** revention **S** ystem.


```
I ntrusion P revention
S ystem (IPS)
```
```
Computer system to automate or support intrusion
prevention by responding appropriately to detected
intrusions – an obvious yet fiendishly difficult
extension of I ntrusion D etection S ystems. “Variant
on intrusion detection systems that are specifically
designed to provide an active response capability”
(ISO/IEC 27039 ). “A system designed to not only
detect attacks but also prevent the intended victim
hosts from being affected by the attacks” (ISACA
glossary). “A security device, resident on a specific
host, which monitors system activities for malicious
or unwanted behaviour and can react in real-time to
block or prevent those activities” (NZISM). See also
S ecurity I nformation and E vent M anagement, U ser
B ehaviour A nalytics, N etwork T raffic A nalysis.
```
```
Intrusive monitoring See surveillance. “In vulnerability analysis, the
process of gaining information by performing
checks that affect the normal operation of a system
or by crashing the system” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Intumescent strip Special material affixed to gaps around doors that
swells in the heat of a fire, thereby sealing the gaps
and so limiting both the exit of heat and smoke and
the entry of fresh oxygenated air. A physical
security control.
```
```
Invalid a. Not valid.
b. Physically weak or disabled person.
```
**Inverse split tunnelling** “A particular configuration of split tunnelling
where only specifically authorised and trusted
systems are able to be simultaneously
communicated with via the external network
connection” _(NZISM). Cf._ split tunnelling.

```
Investigation Act or systematic process of gathering information
on and analysing a situation, occurrence or non-
occurrence, event, or incident. “Systematic or
```

```
formal process of inquiring into or researching, and
examining facts or materials associated with a
matter. Note: Materials can take the form of
hardcopy documents or ES” (ISO/IEC 27050-1).
“Application of examinations, analysis, and
interpretation to aid understanding of an incident”
(ISO/IEC 27042 ). “The collection and analysis of
evidence with the goal to identify the perpetrator of
an attack or unauthorized use or access” (ISACA
glossary).
```
**I** nvestigatory **P** owers
**A** ct **(IPA), snoopers’
charter**

```
2016 UK law gave spooks, the police, Inland
Revenue and other authorities (snoops) powerful
rights to gather evidence (including both data and
metadata) of serious crime through surveillance.
The right to intercept communications sent by or to
individuals overseas, in bulk (mass surveillance),
raised substantial concerns over civil liberties and
privacy, leading to the Data Retention and
Acquisition Regulations 2018 which aligned the
Act with European laws.
```
```
Invicti Vendor of a commercial application security testing
tool that uses both D ynamic A pplication S ecurity
T esting and I nteractive A pplication S ecurity
T esting scanning. An example of dual-use
technology, popular with black, grey, and white
hats. More info: https://www.invicti.com/
```

```
Involuntary
behaviours
```
```
“Automatic, often instinctual human actions
informed by beliefs and values and governed by
nature” (OCEG GRC Glossary).
```

**Invulnerable** Literally, not vulnerable. Paradoxically, the
supreme confidence stemming from the belief that
one is invulnerable to something itself constitutes a
vulnerability to unanticipated modes of attack or
compromise, as well as control failures and
mistaken risk analysis. Absolute security is literally
unattainable, an oxymoron.

```
TERM MEANING
```
```
Jackpotting Attack on a bank A utomated T eller
M achine that causes it to spew out cash like
hitting the jackpot on a Las Vegas fruit
machine. Various techniques are used,
mostly by overcoming the physical security
controls to manipulate the cash dispenser
mechanism directly and/or to compromise
its control circuits and software.
```
```
Jail See sandbox.
```
```
Jailbreak Overcome or bypass O perating S ystem
security functions intended to restrict
applications to a sandbox, thereby limiting
privileged access to I nformation
T echnology devices, primarily for
information security or commercial reasons
( e.g. to prevent the installation of apps not
authorised and sold through the official app
store). Can be (partially) overridden by
users, hackers, spyware, or other malware.
```
```
Jamming Deliberately using a powerful transmitter or
RF noise source to block the reception of
radio signals, e.g. interfering with and so
```

```
preventing legitimate use of a wireless
network, G lobal P ositioning System ,
satellite or microwave communications,
radar, broadcasting, cellphone, wireless
C losed C ircuit T ele V ision camera, or a
security guard’s walkie-talkie. “An attack in
which a device is used to emit
electromagnetic energy on a wireless
network’s frequency to make it unusable”
(NIST SP 800-48).
```
```
Java Popular programming language for mobile
code.
```
```
J ava S cript (JS) Programming language widely used on the
Web to code user interactivity into web
pages, e.g. menus that slide open to reveal
the site structure when moused over. Cf.
Java.
```
**Jerusalem, Black Box** One of the earliest computer viruses, first
discovered in Jerusalem in 1987. This **D** isk
**O** perating **S** ystem virus repeatedly inserted
itself into DOS programs when they were
executed but since it was only ~1800 bytes,
the infection often remained unnoticed
unless it broke those programs or, on Friday
13th, it displayed a black box while deleting
files.

```
Jigsaw Species of ransomware.
```
```
Jitter Precise timing of packets and transmission
elements over a communications path varies
slightly due to differences in the
transmissions and random factors such as
noise. Datacommunications protocols
```

```
therefore incorporate sufficient tolerance.
Potentially constitutes a covert channel.
“Short-term noncumulative variations of the
significant instants of a digital signal from
their ideal positions in time” ( ISO/IEC
2382 ). “The modification of fields in a
database while preserving the aggregate
characteristics of that make the database
useful in the first place” (SANS glossary).
```
```
John the Ripper,
“John”
```
```
Hacking/penetration testing tool used to
perform brute force attacks against
inadequately secured hashed password files.
```
```
Joint PII controller “Personally identifiable information (PII)
controller that determines the purposes and
means of the processing of PII jointly with
one or more other PII controllers” (ISO/IEC
27701 ).
```
**J** oint **T** errorism
**A** nalysis **C** entre **(JTAC)**

```
UK intelligence unit responsible for
coordinating activities and sharing
information pertaining to terrorism. Based
within MI5 but collaborates with
G overnment C ommunications
H ead Q uarters, S ecret I ntelligence S ervice,
and other British and foreign intelligence
agencies.
```
**J** oint **T** est **A** ction **G** roup
**(JTAG)**

```
Hardware interface standard/serial port
allowing very low-level testing of chips on
P rinted C ircuit B oards, intended for Q uality
C ontrol at the end of PCB production,
firmware debugging, etc. using physically
connected or networked diagnostic
equipment. Potentially vulnerable to
sophisticated attacks undermining the R oot
```

```
o f T rust, e.g. by replacing trusted firmware
with a hacked version containing a
backdoor.
```
**Journal, journaling D** ata **B** ase security/control method in which

```
steps leading up to a commit point are saved
temporarily (cached) until the commit
successfully completes, enabling the
sequence to be reversed or reapplied if
interrupted by an incident, for instance a
power, system, or network failure, bug, or
data collision (simultaneous but conflicting
changes to the same data item).
```
```
JTAC Abbrev: J oint T errorism A nalysis C entre.
```
```
JTAG Abbrev: J oint T est A ction G roup.
```
```
Jump server, jump
host, jump box
```
```
Hardened security device that controls
access and traffic flows between two
network zones/domains, e.g. system
administrators using dedicated and secure
internal systems to manage servers located
in the DMZ. “A computer which is used to
manage important or critical resources in a
separate security domain. Also known as a
jump host or jump box” (AusISM).
```
```
Jurisdiction Physical or logical domain within which a
person, court, or other body has the (legal)
authority to act.

```


```
Kerberos Cryptographic I dentification &
A uthentication protocol or architecture
developed by MIT. “A means of verifying
the identities of principals on an open
network. It accomplishes this without
relying on the authentication,
trustworthiness, or physical security of hosts
while assuming all packets can be read,
modified and inserted at will. It uses a trust
broker model and symmetric cryptography
to provide authentication and authorization
of users and systems on the network” (NIST
SP 800-95). “A system developed at the
Massachusetts Institute of Technology that
depends on passwords and symmetric
cryptography (DES) to implement ticket-
based, peer entity authentication service and
access control service distributed in a client-
server network environment” (SANS
glossary).
```
**Kerckhoffs’ principle** In ~1883, Auguste Kerchchoffs wrote “The

```
design of a system should not require
secrecy and compromise of the system
should not inconvenience the
correspondents ” ; in other words it should be
irrelevant whether a cryptographic
algorithm or cryptosystem (as distinct from
the key) is disclosed or published. Inspired
Claude Shannon’s maxim “The enemy
knows the system.” Note: competent
professional scrutiny of a cryptosystem
(which implies its disclosure) is an
important assurance control since “Anyone
```

```
can invent a security system that he himself
cannot break” (Schneier’s law, an example
of the Dunning–Kruger effect).
```
```
Kernel Tasty core protected by the hard outer shell
of a nut. O perating S ystem kernels handle
critical functions, including many low-level
privileged security functions such as
mediating access to memory pages, storage,
and peripheral devices, plus security
logging and alerting. If the kernel protection
is compromised ( e.g. by malware or
hackers), system security is largely if not
totally negated. “The essential center of a
computer operating system, the core that
provides basic services for all other parts of
the operating system. A synonym is nucleus.
A kernel can be contrasted with a shell, the
outermost part of an operating system that
interacts with user commands. Kernel and
shell are terms used more frequently in
Unix and some other operating systems than
in IBM mainframe systems” (SANS
glossary).
```

**Latency, dwell time** Delay, _e.g._ the pregnant pause between a

```
message (a data packet) being sent from one
system onto a network connection and its
delivery to the destination system – a
combination of the time taken for physical
transit between the ends at something
approaching the speed of light, and the
processing involved in message
transmission and reception. In some
contexts ( e.g. disk drives and C entral
P rocessing U nits), latency may include the
time taken to acknowledge, process, and
respond to messages, commands,
transactions, etc. In networking, latency
generally excludes the time taken to
establish or tear down a semi-persistent
link, only measuring message transit times.
Latency constrains the achievable
speed/performance and responsiveness and
relates to the capacity/throughput of the
mechanisms used ( e.g. parallel vs. serial
data, fibre-optic vs. satellite links). “The
time it takes a system or network to
respond. Notes: More specifically, system
latency is the time a system takes to retrieve
data. Network latency is the time it takes for
```

```
a packet to travel from source to
destination” (ISACA glossary).Cf. lag time.
```

**Least privilege,
minimum privilege**

```
Information security principle involving

intended purpose. “Restriction of the access
rights of a subject to only those rights that
are necessary for the execution of
authorized tasks” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “The
principle that a security architecture should
be designed so that each entity is granted
the minimum system resources and
authorizations that the entity needs to
perform its function” (CNSSI 4009 ). “The
minimisation of access rights and
permissions for users, accounts,
applications, systems, devices and
computing processes to the absolute
minimum necessary in order to perform
routine, authorised activities and maintain
the safe and secure operation of agency or
organisational systems” (NZISM). “The
principle that a security architecture is
designed so that each entity is granted the
minimum system authorizations and
```

```
resources needed to perform its function”
(NIST SP 800-171). “The principle of
allowing users or applications the least
amount of permissions necessary to perform
their intended function” (SANS glossary).

```

```

as ‘1337’) is a contraction and deliberate
misspelling of ‘elite,’ referring to the

perceive themselves as higher life forms

mortals. See also pwn, n00b, warez, pr0n.

```

```

alarms and alerts, and may be recorded in
audit trails and security logs for
accountability and auditing purposes.

act of connecting to a network or system,

```

```
Class/type of attacks in which an
adversary/attacker/red team/agent/unknown
enemy (not necessarily a man!) intercepts
and compromises authentication and other
messages passing between two
parties/systems, generally using
masquerading to fool each party into
believing that they are the legitimate
counterparty. May involve stolen, faked, or
genuine digital certificates obtained under
false pretences (social engineering/fraud),
malware, hacking the processes and
systems, and evading/bypassing or negating
various controls. Exploits the trust placed in
connections that communicating parties
```

```
believe to be direct and secure. “A strategy
in which the attacker intercepts the
communication stream between two
components of the target system and then
replaces the traffic with the intruder’s own,
eventually assuming control of the
communication” (ISACA glossary). “A man-
in-the-middle attack is a type of cyber
attack in which the attacker secretly
intercepts and relays messages between two
parties who believe they are communicating
directly with each other. The attack is a type
of eavesdropping in which the attacker
intercepts and then controls the entire
conversation” (SANS glossary). See also
proxy, POODLE, bogus boss.
```

**Mass surveillance** Dark, foreboding term with strongly
Orwellian overtones concerning the
widespread, systematic, intrusive, and
largely indiscriminate surveillance of the
public by government agencies, ostensibly
for the purposes of crime and threat
detection, counterterrorism, _etc_. From the
authorities’ perspective, a legitimate and
necessary public safety/security mechanism.
From other perspectives, potentially a
substantial threat to privacy, human rights,
liberty, and democracy, made worse by the
resources and sheer power of the authorities
operating under a cloak of secrecy with
dubious regulatory oversight and
accountability ...


```
Master key Whereas a conventional physical lock can
only be opened by keys of the pattern
matching that lock, locks can be designed as
a set that can be opened using either master
keys with special patterns that work across
the entire set or with the correct sub-master
or change keys. Janitors and security guards
may use sub-master keys to clean, check,
and lock particular offices, stores, buildings,
cell-blocks, etc., while the Chief Security
Guard, Facilities Manager, or Warden holds
the master key, the physical security
equivalent of the ROOT password on a
computer server giving full access. If the
master key is ever lost or compromised ( e.g.
stolen or copied), all the master-keyed locks
may have to be changed to restore security.
```

```

```

```
the start point, perhaps also the detection
point. “ A metric that tracks the average
amount of time that a problem exists before
it is found” (NIST SP 800-55v1).
```

```
Memory-safe
programming
languages
```
```
Some programming languages can prevent
developers inadvertently introducing bugs
affecting memory usage, e.g. by attempting
to read or write memory locations either
side of a declared range (‘out of bounds’),
or within the declared range where data
have been deleted (‘use after free’). Such
issues are common with memory-unsafe
languages such as C and C++; therefore,
short of systematically hunting down and
fixing all such issues, moving to memory-
safe languages such as Rust, C#, Swift, and
Go can improve the quality and security of
software. “Programming languages that
prevent the introduction of security
vulnerabilities related to memory use.
Examples of memory-safe programming
languages include C#, Go, Java, Ruby, Rust
and Swift. Examples of non-memory-safe
programming languages include Assembly
and C/C++” (AusISM).
```

```
Memory-scraping
malware, RAM-
scraper
```
```
Type of malware that monitors and captures
confidential data in working memory in the
course of processing. While such malware
commonly infects point-of-sale systems
implying a criminal motive, the technique
has broader application for national and
industrial espionage and other nefarious
purposes such as stealing valuable
intellectual assets such as cryptographic
keys and passwords ( e.g. keyloggers), for
surveillance or cybertage. See also Spectre.
```
```
Merkle tree Cryptographic architecture patented by
Ralph Merkle in 1979 in which hash values
for two or more data blocks are themselves
hashed, and so on ‘up the tree,’ thus
ensuring integrity of the entire data
structure. “A data structure within which all
nodes other than ‘leaf nodes’ (nodes to
which no subnodes are attached) include the
hash values of all subnodes. Use of a
cryptographically strong hashing function
( i.e., a message digest) can allow rapid
(logarithmic) verification of the integrity of
all nodes on the tree” (ISACA glossary). See
also blockchain.
```

```
output. Modern cryptographic hash
functions are also resistant to collisions
(situations in which different inputs produce

possible, is statistically improbable.
Cryptographic hash functions are developed
so that the input cannot be determined
readily from the output” (ISACA glossary).

```

```

```

```

which the amounts stolen tend to be
extremely small, possibly fractions of the
smallest discrete unit of currency ( e.g.

are normally subject to rounding rules
designed to avoid systematic bias but
successful micro-fraudsters subvert the
process and the associated checks and
balances.
```

```
site

```

**Mobile device, mobile
end user device**

```
Portable computing and
telecommunications device such as a
smartphone, portable or tablet PC. Thanks
to innovative M obile T echnology, modern
mobile devices are effective platforms but
constraints such as miniaturisation,
portability, wireless connections, battery

memory capacity, which in turn makes them
hard to secure against malware and hacks,
plus simple theft, damage, or loss. On top of

controls, e.g. jailbreaking. “A small mobile

communications device. For example,
smartphones, tablets and laptops” (AusISM).

with intrinsic wireless capability, such as
smartphones and tablets. Mobile end-user
devices are a subset of portable end-user
devices, including laptops, which may
require external hardware for connectivity”
(CIS Controls). “A small hand-held device
that has a display screen with touch input
and/or a QWERTY keyboard and may
provide users with telephony capabilities”
```

```
(NIST SP 800-101). “A portable computing
device that has a small form factor such that

individual; is designed to operate without a

storage; and includes a self-contained power
source. Mobile devices may also include
voice communication capabilities, on-board
sensors that allow the devices to capture
information, or built-in features that
synchronize local data with remote
locations. Examples include smartphones,
tablets, and e-readers” (NIST SP 800-171).
```

**Monte Carlo method
[or analysis]**

```
Modelling technique involving multiple
runs of a model with fuzzing of one or more
input parameters within defined bounds, and
statistical analysis to determine their
influence on the outputs and hence the
model’s sensitivity to various factors. Term
alludes to, say, a roulette table at the famous
casino. “A probabilistic sensitivity analysis
used to account for uncertainty” (NIST SP
800-55v1). “The use of randomly generated
numbers as part of an algorithm” (ISACA
glossary).
```
```
Moral hazard Believing themselves adequately protected
by controls such as insurance, people may
accept more risk than otherwise – and why
not? This can be taken into account by the
insurer determining insurance premiums
that reflect the anticipated risks after
insurance is in effect, rather than before, and
specifying various security controls the
insured organisations are required to have in
place.
```

```
Strengthened form of user authentication in
which different types of credential are
required ( e.g. a secret password plus a
security token or a biometric plus a device
location determined by GPS). Multiples of a
single credential type ( e.g. two passwords)
are not considered multifactor. “A
combination of more than one
authentication method, such as token and
password (or personal identification number
[PIN]) or token and biometric device”
(ISACA glossary). “An electronic
authentication method in which a user is
granted access to a network or application
only after successfully presenting two or
more pieces of evidence to an authentication
mechanism ( e.g. a password and a one-time
passcode)” (UK Cyber Security Breaches
Survey 2023 ). “A security system that
verifies a user’s identity by requiring
multiple credentials, which may be of the
same factor or type. Initial authentication
normally requires a username and password.
MFA requires other—additional—
credentials, for example as a code from the
user’s smartphone, the answer to a security
question, a fingerprint, or facial
recognition” (NZISM). “Authentication
using two or more different authentication
factors. This may include something users
know, something users have or something
users are” (AusISM). “ Authentication using
two or more different factors to achieve
authentication. Factors include something
```

```
you know ( e.g., PIN, password), something
you have ( e.g., cryptographic identification
device, token), or something you are ( e.g.,
biometric)” (NIST SP 800-171).
```

```
(NZISM). “ICT equipment that combines
printing, scanning, copying, faxing or voice

simultaneously” (AusISM).
```

```
Term adapted from the aviation industry, referring

valuable learning and improvement opportunities
if reported, analysed, evaluated, and responded to
as if it was an actual security incident. “Negative

may help to isolate the significant features of the
latter” (ISO/IEC 2382 ).
```

**Network** a. Datacommunications connections linking
various computers, _i.e_. the cables, wireless
links and devices such as routers, switches,
and hubs. “A system implemented with a
collection of interconnected components.
Such components may include routers, hubs,
cabling, telecommunications controllers, key
distribution centers, and technical control
devices” _(NIST SP 800- 171 )._ “A system of
interconnected computers and the
communication equipment used to connect
them” _(ISACA glossary)._
b. Community of people, organisations, _etc_.
with common interests, connected by
personal interactions and contacts, social
media, messaging, email, _etc_. – see social
network.
c. Datacommunications infrastructure as a
whole, _i.e_. the linkages _plus_ the linked
devices _plus_ the network services and traffic,
possibly also the associated users. Indistinct
and dynamic, hence often portrayed as a
cloud. “Arrangement of entities and their
interconnections. Note: In network topology
or in an abstract arrangement, the
interconnected entities are points on a


```
scheme, and the interconnections are lines on
the scheme. In a computer network, the
interconnected entities are computers or data
communication equipment, and the
interconnections are data links” (ISO/IEC
2382 ).
```

```
Network address Similar to an email or postal address, identifies the
source/origin and/or destination/target nodes,
computer systems, or networks for
datacommunications messages. Used for network
routing, management, logging, tracing/tracking,
broadcasting, etc. Specified in most network
protocols. For obvious reasons, should be
unambiguous for efficient delivery and unique
within a given network to avoid conflict and
confusion. For security reasons, may require
authentication to mitigate the risk of spoofing.
```

```
N etwork A ddress
T ranslation (NAT)
```
```
Basic firewall, router, or server function to spoof
public I nternet P rotocol addresses externally on
packets originating within a private internal
network, without breaking various network
protocols. Keeping internal IP addresses
confidential makes it slightly harder for Internet
hackers to discover and map the internal network
architecture, and allows additional security, e.g.
raising the alarm if packets with internal IP
addresses appear on the public side of the NAT
server, indicating a possible breach/incident or a
firewall configuration failure. “A methodology for
modifying network address information in IP
datagram packet headers while they are in transit
across a traffic routing device for the purpose of
remapping one IP address space into another”
(ISACA glossary). “[NAT] is used to share one or a
small number of publicly routable IP addresses
among a larger number of hosts. The hosts are
assigned private IP addresses, which are then
‘translated’ into one of the publicly routed IP
addresses. Typically home or small business
networks use NAT to share a single DLS or Cable
modem IP address. However, in some cases NAT
is used for servers as an additional layer of
protection. [and] The translation of an Internet
Protocol address used within one network to a
different IP address known within another
network. One network is designated the inside
network and the other is the outside” (SANS
glossary).
```
**Network

```
The original “NIS” was E uropean U nion directive
(EU 2016/1148) requiring certain critical
infrastructure providers serving the EU to ensure
resilience through appropriate I nformation
T echnology/cyber and physical security controls.
NIS applied regulatory oversight to the provision
of critical energy, transport, health, and drinking
water suppliers, plus cyberinfrastructure such as
online marketplaces, search engines, and cloud
computing services, and was implemented by
national laws in member states. It was replaced in
2024 by EU directive 2022/2555 “NIS2,” covering
a wider range of organisations classified as either
critical or important. The core aim remains to
achieve adequate cyber risk management
consistently for the EU’s critical infrastructure,
thereby improving resilience.
```

```
I ntrusion D etection S ystem involving monitoring
all the network traffic traversing the cables or
wireless channels, as opposed to monitoring
network traffic destined for or generated by a
particular servers or nodes (see H ost-based
I ntrusion D etection S ystem). “A network-based
IDS system monitors the traffic on its network
segment as a data source. This is generally
accomplished by placing the network interface
card in promiscuous mode to capture all network
traffic that crosses its network segment. Network
traffic on other segments, and traffic on other
means of communication (like phone lines) can’t
be monitored. Network-based IDS involves
looking at the packets on the network as they pass
by some sensor. The sensor can only see the
packets that happen to be carried on the network
segment it’s attached to. Packets are considered to
be of interest if they match a signature. Network-
based intrusion detection passively monitors
network activity for indications of attacks.
Network monitoring offers several advantages
over traditional host-based intrusion detection
```

```
systems. Because many intrusions occur over
networks at some point, and because networks are
increasingly becoming the targets of attack, these
techniques are an excellent method of detecting
many attacks which may be missed by host-based
intrusion detection mechanisms” (SANS glossary).
```

**Network security
policy**

```
Policy concerning network security. “Set of
statements, rules and practices that explain an
organisation’s approach to the use of its network
resources, and specify how its network
infrastructure and services should be protected”
(ISO/IEC 27033-1).
```
```
Network service Application running on a network node, host, or
server providing information services or functions
through the network, e.g. email, cloud storage,
cloud computing, cellular phones, SMS/TXT
messaging.
```
```
Network stack Conceptual model comprising an integrated,
modular set of interoperable layers providing
network services and protocols, building up from
the base physical layer (hardware converting
digital bits to/from analogue modulation on a
cable or wireless interface) through increasingly
sophisticated mid-layers to the application layer at
the top (where applications such as email and web
browsers can communicate over networks without
having to handle the entire process, e.g. the
establishment of sessions and message routing).
The OSI model has 7 layers whereas TCP/IP
merges some, ending up with just 4. Security
functions (such as authentication, encryption, and
error correction) are provided by various layers,
the entire stack working together to deliver
effective network security. See also layer 8+.
```

```
Network tap “Hardware devices that hook directly onto the
network cable and send a copy of the traffic that
passes through it to one or more other networked
devices” (SANS glossary).
```
**Network topology** Design or architecture of a network, primarily in
terms of the physical configuration – the structure
created by connections between nodes ( _e.g._ star,
ring, bus, mesh, or hybrid networks) – or the
logical security arrangements forming distinct
layers or domains sharing a single network
structure ( _e.g._ to prioritise the communication of
time-critical video content over email and web
content that can wait its turn). Even social
networks have topologies with clusters of close
social connections, special interest groups, more
distant or remote acquaintances, plus social
influencers. “The basic configuration and
architecture of a set of interconnected nodes”
_(ISACA glossary)._

**N** eural **N** etwork **(NN),
neural net, artificial
neural network**

```
Machine learning model originally inspired by the
structure of the brain with layers of interconnected
nodes (mathematical functions representing
neurons). The outputs of one layer are input to the
next. Connections between nodes are weighted as
the network learns from training data. Weights are
trained by backpropagation, an algorithm that
calculates the error of the network’s output and
adjusts the weights accordingly. “Network of
primitive processing elements connected by
weighted links with adjustable weights, in which
each element produces a value by applying a
nonlinear function to its input values, and
transmits it to other elements or presents it as an
output. Notes: Neural networks are modeled on
the functioning of neurons in the nervous system.
The nonlinear function is usually a threshold
function” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “Network of one or
more layers of neurons connected by weighted
links with adjustable weights, which takes input
data and produces an output. Notes: Neural
networks are a prominent example of the
connectionist approach; Although the design of
neural networks was initially inspired by the
functioning of biological neurons, most works on
neural networks do not follow that inspiration
anymore” (ISO/IEC 22989). “Networks, inspired
by the structure of the human brain, that learn by
processing data through three layers (input,
hidden, and output). They can be trained to match
any input to various outputs, including binary
ones, making them versatile tools in deep learning
(DL) for tasks like image recognition” (ISACA
glossary).
```

```
P rogramming (NLP)
```

```
Unscientific and discredited theory touted by some
social engineers concerning their supposed ability
to exploit interactions between neurology and
linguistics to ‘program’ behaviour. Pure snake oil,
although NLP proponents who believe they have
superpowers are likely to be highly self-confident
and therefore persuasive – a kind of placebo effect
or self-fulfilling prophecy. Cf. N atural L anguage
P rocessing.
```
```
Neuron Brain cell. “Primitive processing element which
takes one or more input values and produces an
output value by combining the input values and
applying an activation function on the result. Note:
Examples of nonlinear activation functions are a
threshold function, a sigmoid function and a
polynomial function” (ISO/IEC 22989).
```

```
Understanding, perhaps contractual and legally
binding, between two or more parties to share
confidential information ( I ntellectual P roperty that
may be proprietary, personal, or official) between
themselves but not to disclose it to third parties
except by mutual authorisation, or unless legally
obliged to do so. May not expressly prohibit the
recipient from exploiting the information
themselves, although most Westerners would
consider that unethical and inappropriate. “A legal
contract between at least two parties that outlines
confidential materials the parties wish to share
with one another for certain purposes but wish to
restrict from generalized use; a contract through
```

```
which the parties agree not to disclose information
covered by the agreement. Notes: Also called a
confidential disclosure agreement (CDA),
confidentiality agreement or secrecy agreement,
an NDA creates a confidential relationship
between the parties to protect any type of trade
secret. As such, an NDA can protect non-public
business information. In the case of certain
governmental entities, the confidentiality of
information other than trade secrets may be
subject to applicable statutory requirements, and in
some cases must be revealed to an outside party
requesting the information. Generally, the
governmental entity will include a provision in the
contract to allow the seller to review a request for
information that the seller identifies as
confidential and the seller may appeal such a
decision requiring disclosure. NDAs are
commonly signed when two companies or
individuals are considering doing business
together and need to understand the processes used
in one another’s businesses solely for the purpose
of evaluating the potential business relationship.
NDAs can be ‘mutual,’ meaning that both parties
are restricted in their use of the materials provided,
or they can only restrict a single party. It is also
possible for an employee to sign an NDA or NDA-
like agreement with a company at the time of
hiring; in fact, some employment agreements will
include a clause restricting ‘confidential
information’ in general” (ISACA glossary).
```

```
Packet filter First-generation firewalls examined network
packets individually, either passing or
blocking them according to the packet
content considered in isolation. Simply
fragmenting unauthorised content across
multiple packets was often sufficient to
bypass such crude security checks.
“Controlling access to a network by
analyzing the attributes of the incoming and
outgoing packets and either letting them
pass or denying them, based on a list of
rules” (ISACA glossary). Cf. stateful
firewall.
```

```
protocols and software that break large

switching/diverting individual packets along
the most appropriate routes), then
reassemble them correctly on receipt. “The
process of transmitting messages in
convenient pieces that can be reassembled
at the destination” (ISACA glossary).
“Where individual packets each follow their
own paths through the network from one
endpoint to another” (SANS glossary).
```

**Parallel test, parallel
run**

```
Processing essentially the same data
through two variants of the same software
( e.g. the original and updated or
replacement versions) allows them to be
checked for differences in the outputs as
well as assessing factors such as ease of use
and performance. Although it takes
substantial effort to run them both,
systematically compare the results and
analyse any unexpected differences, the
increase in familiarity and confidence in a
new/changed system may make the testing
worthwhile, especially if processing
integrity issues are identified and resolved.
“The process of feeding test data into two
systems, the modified system and an
alternative system (possibly the original
system), and comparing results to
demonstrate the consistency and
inconsistency between two versions of the
application” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Parameter, model
parameter
```
```
Characteristic, i.e. information that
characterises something. In software, a
variable passed to a function or subroutine.
“Specific value describing the measurable
or theoretical features of the elements of a
```

```
system” (ISO 22300). “Internal variable of a
model that affects how it computes its
outputs. Note: Examples of parameters
include the weights in a neural network and
the transition probabilities in a Markov
model” (ISO/IEC 22989).
```
```
Parity Literally, equivalence. In
datacommunications and data storage, a
crude, low-cost data integrity control
involves simply appending an extra bit to
each byte or word such that the numeric
sums of all the bits are even (even parity) or
odd (odd parity). Later, if the calculated
sum does not remain even or odd,
respectively, it appears that at least one bit
must have changed. “A general hardware
control that helps to detect data errors when
data are read from memory or
communicated from one computer to
another. Notes: A 1-bit digit (either 0 or 1) is
added to a data item to indicate whether the
sum of that data item’s bit is odd or even.
When the parity bit disagrees with the sum
of the other bits, the computer reports an
error. The probability of a parity check
detecting an error is 50 percent” (ISACA
glossary). See also C yclic R edundancy
C heck, checksum.
```
**Parkerian hexad** In 1998, information security guru Donn

```
Parker extended the classic CIA triad with
three additional concepts, namely
possession/control, authenticity, and utility.
While authenticity may be considered an
integral part of integrity, the other two
```

```
aspects are intriguing security objectives
worth considering.
```
```
Partial-knowledge
attack
```
```
Attempt to compromise an A rtificial
I ntelligence system, etc. by an adversary
with some prior knowledge of the target.
“Attack carried out by an attacker who has
full understanding of the system inputs and
outputs, but only a limited understanding of
its internal design and operations. Note:
This type of attack does not assume
knowledge of credentials” (ISO/IEC 27090
DRAFT). See also grey box testing. Cf.
perfect- and zero-knowledge attacks.
```
```
Participant Person, group, or organisation that takes
part in an activity, market, etc. “Person or
organization who performs a function
related to an exercise” (ISO 22300).
```
```
Partitioning a. Separation of bare metal and host
O perating S ystem resources between
guest systems in virtualisation.
b. Separation of networks, physical areas,
etc. into segments or zones with
differing risks and controls, an
application of the information security
principles of classification and access
control.
```
**Part-of-speech tagging** “Task of assigning a category ( _e.g._ verb,

```
noun, adjective) to a word based on its
grammatical properties” (ISO/IEC 22989).
```
```
PAS 1192 (Publicly
Accessible
Specification No 1192)
```
```
Withdrawn multipart UK standard
concerning (in part) the security of
information about the architecture and
```

```
construction of smart buildings and other
physical facilities. More info:
https://knowledge.bsigroup.com/search?
query=pas+1 192
```
```
Passable Forged, fake, or counterfeit item that
resembles the genuine article closely
enough to be accepted as original; hence, it
can be passed (handed, given) to the
recipient ( e.g. passable counterfeit
banknotes are likely to be accepted by
shopkeepers).
```
```
Pass card See access card.
```
**P** assive **I** nfra **R** ed **(PIR)
detector**

```
Detection device that identifies the presence
of people and other warm-blooded animals
or warm bodies (such as motor vehicles) in
the detection zone by the infrared radiation
they emit. Commonly used to turn on lights
when someone enters the area, perhaps
covertly triggering C losed C ircuit
T ele V ision recording and intruder alarms.
```
```
Passkey Digital credential for FIDO M ulti F actor
A uthentication using asymmetric
cryptography in which a user’s private keys
are generally stored in a secure subsystem
or vault on the user’s personal device, such
as a smartphone. The user first authenticates
to the device using a USB hardware token,
biometric, PIN code, or password to unlock
the stored private keys, then uses the
relevant key to authenticate (logon) to a
website or app that has been designed to
accept passkeys, having first authenticated
the website or app using its public key to
```

```
reduce the possibility of being phished. For
convenience across devices (albeit at some
risk), passkeys may also be synchronised
and stored in the cloud, while FIDO
Security Keys allow recovery of lost
passkeys.
```
```
Passphrase Confidential phrase, sentence, saying, lyric,
poem, etc. that is either used directly as a
long and hence strong password, or is used
as a prompt to recall one ( e.g. forming a
nonsense password from the initial letters of
the words in a memorable song or poem) or
to open a password vault. “A sequence of
words used for authentication” (AusISM).
```
**Pass The Hash** Hacking technique that exploits

```
vulnerabilities in some authentication
mechanisms to accept cached password
NTLM hashes presented by the hacker,
avoiding the need first to determine the
corresponding passwords ( e.g. by brute
force attack on a stolen password file).
```
```
Password Confidential string of characters (ideally not
a recognisable word or phrase) which can
authenticate a person or system as a
response to a challenge. A type of
credential. Vulnerable to dictionary and
brute force attacks, especially if too short or
obvious, and to being disclosed
inappropriately ( e.g. due to ignorance,
carelessness, social engineering, or
coercion). “A protected, generally
computer-encrypted string of characters that
authenticate a computer user to the
computer system” (ISACA glossary). “A
```

```
sequence of characters used for
authentication” (AusISM).
```
**P** assword
**A** uthentication **P** rotocol
**(PAP)**

```
Basic user authentication protocol option
within P oint-to- P oint P rotocol passes
userIDs and passwords by unencrypted
(plaintext) datacommunications from clients
to servers for validation. Due to its
vulnerability to interception en route and
replay attacks, PAP is deprecated. Specified
in RFC 1334. “A simple, weak
authentication mechanism where a user
enters the password and it is then sent
across the network, usually in the clear”
(SANS glossary).
```
```
Password complexity Password complexity. “The use of different
character sets, such as lower-case
alphabetical characters (a–z), upper-case
alphabetical characters (A–Z), numeric
characters (0–9) and special characters”
(AusISM).
```
```
Password cracker See brute-force password attack. “A tool
that tests the strength of user passwords by
searching for passwords that are easy to
guess. It repeatedly tries words from
specially crafted dictionaries and often also
generates thousands (and in some cases,
even millions) of permutations of
characters, numbers and symbols” (ISACA
glossary). “The process of attempting to
guess passwords, given the password file
information” (SANS glossary).
```
```
Passwordless
authentication
```
```
User authentication using credentials other
than passwords such as biometrics or
```

```
security tokens. “Authentication that
doesn’t involve the use of something users
know. Passwordless authentication may be
single-factor or multi-factor, with the later
often referred to as passwordless multi-
factor authentication” (AusISM).
```
**P** asswordless
Multi **F** actor
**A** uthentication **(MFA)**

```
User authentication using multiple factors
(credentials) of different kinds other than
passwords, e.g. biometrics and security
tokens. “Multi-factor authentication using
something users have that is unlocked by
something users know or are. Note, while a
memorised secret may be used as part of
passwordless multi-factor authentication
( e.g. to unlock access to a cryptographic
private key stored on a device) it is not the
primary authentication factor, hence the use
of the passwordless terminology” (AusISM).
```
```
Password-protected Although this dismissive phrase implies the
use of strong cryptographic controls, critical
details such as password complexity rules
and algorithms are rarely specified. In
practice, paradoxically, it usually indicates a
basic and rather weak form of user
authentication, barely better than nothing.
“The ability to protect the contents of a file
or device from being accessed until the
correct password is entered” (NIST SP 800-
101 ).
```
```
Password sniffing See sniffing. “Passive wiretapping, usually
on a local area network, to gain knowledge
of passwords” (SANS glossary).
```

**Password
synchronisation**

```
Crude way to reduce the burden of having
to recall numerous passwords for different
systems by setting an identical password on
them all, but naturally if the password is
compromised at any point, all the systems
are at risk of being accessed improperly.
Deprecated in favour of more sophisticated
controls such as S ingle S ign O n, password
vaults, biometrics, and M ulti F actor
A uthentication.
```
```
Password vault Trusted program and/or hardware designed
to store passwords, cryptographic keys, PIN
codes, userIDs, and other credentials or
highly confidential pieces of information
securely (meaning encrypted using a key
derived from the one strong password or
passphrase that the user must remember),
and regurgitate them on demand by the
authorised user when logging on to the
relevant systems or websites. Good
password vaults help the user generate
much stronger ( i.e. longer and more
complex) passwords or passphrases than
anyone other than a memory freak can
manage and store reliably in their heads,
limited only by the constraints of the target
systems. Bad password vaults may be rogue
software, Trojans, or spyware, and may
have architectural flaws and bugs creating
security vulnerabilities.
```
```
Patch, patching Implementation of one or more piecemeal
changes to computer programs, e.g. to fix
bugs or architectural flaws causing security
vulnerabilities. A patch may replace one or
more broken parts within executable
```

```
software or firmware (such as subroutines,
functions, or various lines of code) or may
replace complete programs within a
software package. However, unlike version
updates, patches seldom offer additional
functionality. Occasionally because of
inadequate quality assurance, they may even
cause additional problems, requiring further
corrections (more patches!) or workarounds
(compensating controls). “Fixes to software
programming errors and vulnerabilities”
(ISACA glossary). “A piece of software
designed to remedy security vulnerabilities,
or improve the usability or performance of
software and ICT equipment” (AusISM). “A
small update released by a software
manufacturer to fix bugs in existing
programs [and] the process of updating
software to a different version” (SANS
glossary).
```
```
Patch cable “A metallic (usually copper) or fibre optic
cable used for routing signals between two
components in an enclosed container or rack
or between adjacent containers or racks”
(NZISM).
```
**Patch management** Process of updating software/firmware

```
promptly when applicable updates are
released. “An area of systems management
that involves acquiring, testing and
installing multiple patches (code changes)
to an administered computer system to
maintain up-to-date software and often to
address security risk. Notes: Patch
management tasks include maintaining
current knowledge of available patches,
```

```
deciding what patches are appropriate for
particular systems, ensuring that patches are
installed properly, testing systems after
installation and documenting all associated
procedures, such as specific configurations
required. A number of products are
available to automate patch management
tasks. Patches are sometimes ineffective and
can sometimes cause more problems than
they fix. Patch management experts suggest
that system administrators take simple steps
to avoid problems, such as performing
backups and testing patches on noncritical
systems prior to installations. Patch
management can be viewed as part of
change management” (ISACA glossary).
“About software security being regularly or
automatically patched” (UK Cyber Security
Breaches Survey 2023).
```
**Patch panel** “A group of sockets or connectors that

```
allow manual configuration changes,
generally by means of connecting cables to
the appropriate connector. Cables could be
metallic (copper) or fibre optic” (NZISM).
```
```
Patent Legal protection for novel inventions that
have been properly registered with the
relevant patent authorities. A form of
I ntellectual P roperty R ight. Patent laws
typically offer protection for 15–30 years
depending on the jurisdiction and the type
of invention ( e.g. the US treats design,
utility, and plant patents separately).
“Protection of research and ideas that led to
the development of a new, unique and
useful product to prevent the unauthorized
```

```
duplication of the patented item” (ISACA
glossary).
```
```
Patent troll Organisation that assertively threatens legal
action as a means to coerce other
organisations into paying weighty fees for
the right to continue using designs and
methods for which it holds the patents or
other Intellectual P roperty R ights.
Depending on one’s perspective, they are
either legitimately exercising their
ownership rights, or warty sleaze balls
covered in putrid slime.
```
```
Path Actual or figurative route through
something, such as a maze. “A sequence of
instructions that may be performed in the
execution of a computer program” (ISACA
glossary).
```
**Path analysis** Path analysis. “Analysis of a computer
program ( _i.e.,_ source code) to identify all
possible paths through the program, to
detect incomplete paths or discover portions
of the program that are not on any path”
_(ISACA glossary)._

```
Patsy See target.
```
```
Pattern Some devices with touch screens allow
users to authenticate by sliding a finger
through a specific sequence of moves to
trace a shape, rather than simply tapping the
numbers of a PIN code. A weak biometric
control.
```
```
Payload
```

```
a. Malicious function (the harmful
‘business end’) of malware that
performs unauthorised activities such
as deleting or modifying files and
exfiltrating sensitive/valuable
information. “A piece of malicious
software that lets an attacker control a
compromised computer system. The
payload is typically attached to and
delivered by an exploit” (ISACA
glossary).
b. Valuable data content of network
packets as distinct from metadata such
as source and destination addresses.
“The actual application data a packet
contains” (SANS glossary).
```
```
Paywall Some commercial information providers
restrict access to their I ntellectual P roperty
through the Internet, requiring visitors to
register and pay for the information. Visitors
seeking the information are generally
stonewalled by a user logon/registration
screen requiring them to identify and
authenticate themselves, although many
sites offer sneak previews of the
information, enticing visitors to register and
pay up for access permission.
```
```
PBX Abbrev: P rivate B ranch e X change.
```

**PCAP (Packet
Capture)**

```
Family of basic file formats used to record,

Wireshark, and Snort.
```

```
PCI DSS (Payment
Card Industry Data
Security Standard)
```
```
Cybersecurity standard imposed on card
```

```
PCS Abbrev: P rocess C ontrol S ystem. Cf.
P ersonal C omputer s (PCs).
```

```
PDA (Personal Digital
Assistant), palmtop
```

```
Handheld computer device, popular in the

Although some later models offered WiFi,
```

Brief)**

```
US intelligence/security services online
briefing to keep the President and close
```

```
PDF Abbrev: P ortable D ocument F ormat.
```

```
PDoS Abbrev: P ermanent D enial- o f- S ervice. See
bricking.
```

```
Peer [level, unit or
layer]
```
```
Person, colleague, organisation, group,
team, function, department, system, etc.
having a similar or equivalent status,
capability, hierarchical level, etc. to another.
“Organizational units that are lateral to the
organization and often report to or are
accountable to the s ame superior unit”
(OCEG GRC Glossary).
```
**Peer review, work
product inspection**

```
Critique of a draft report, proposal, paper,
etc. by a colleague. “Process used by a
reviewer to examine the performance of a
host, provide feedback on an analysis area
and learn lessons that are transferable to its
own context. Notes: A peer review can
cover multiple analysis areas. The host can
replace ‘review’ with a synonym such as
‘assessment,’ ‘appraisal’ or ‘analysis’ to
better describe the activity” (ISO 22300 ).
“The examination of work products
performed by similarly skilled personnel
during the development of work products to
identify defects for removal” (ISACA
glossary). “A complete check of the work
done involving reviewing all of the
```

```
Pegasus ‘Military grade’ mobile device spyware
used for civil and governmental surveillance
against various countries and targets,
developed by the Israeli cyber intelligence
company NSO Group. See also Graphite.
```

```
Penetration See intrusion. “Gaining unauthorized
logical access to sensitive data by
circumventing a system’s protections”
(SANS glossary).
```
**Penetration test
(pentest), red teaming**

```
Officially authorised/sanctioned/requested
and hence legitimate test of an
organisation’s cybersecurity controls by
competent and trustworthy experts (the red
team). Primarily intended to detect
exploitable vulnerabilities exposed
externally (particularly via the Internet), it
feeds into risk identification, analysis, and
evaluation, a blend of assurance and risk
management. The scope of a given pentest
may include or exclude checks of network,
physical, procedural, and/or other security
controls and specific systems, locations, etc.
“A live test of the effectiveness of security
defenses through mimicking the actions o f
real-life attackers” (ISACA glossary).
“Where staff or contractors try to breach the
cyber security of an organisation on
purpose, in order to show where there might
be weakness e s in cyber security” (UK
Cyber Security Breaches Survey 2023 ).
“Designed to exercise real-world scenarios
in an attempt to achieve a specific goal,
such as compromising critical systems or
data” (AusISM). “Used to test the external
perimeter security of a network or facility”
(SANS glossary). See also T hreat- L ed
P enetration T est.
```
```
P en R egister, T rap and
T race (PRTT)
```
```
Originally, an electromechanical device
used by the authorities to monitor a phone
line, recording on paper the electrical pulses
```

```
denoting the number when someone makes
or receives a call. Although the term is still
used, electromechanical plotters have long
since been superseded by covert electronic
recording devices (which generally store
both the addressing information and the
audio stream) and by direct access to the
telephone companies’ call routing/charging
systems.
```
```
PenTest+ CompTIA’s qualification for professional
penetration testers and red teamers. Covers:

and enumeration, vulnerability discovery
and analysis, attacks and exploits, and post-
exploitation and lateral movement. More
info: https://www.comptia.org/en-
us/certifications/pentest/v3/
```
```
People actions &
controls
```
```
“Human factors, including structure,
accountability, education, and enablement
used to address risk, reward, and
compliance” (OCEG GRC Glossary).
```
**People aspects of
business continuity**

```
“Elements associated with the management
of people involved in, or affected by, an
incident in order to minimize distress,
maximize productivity and recovery, and
achieve the recovery objectives of the
organization’s business continuity
programme” (ISO 22300).
```
```
People at risk “Individuals in the area who could be
affected by an incident” (ISO 22300).
```
```
People control a. Manual, administrative, or
management control performed by
```

```
people such as workers.
b. Control of people, such as the police
monitoring and guiding (corralling)
crowds of demonstrators.
c. One of four ‘control themes’ in
ISO/IEC 27002, defined in the
standard as “Controls that concern

Eight types of people control are

movers, and leavers. Cf. physical
```

**P** erfect **F** orward **S** ecrecy
**(PFS)**

```
Architecture of cryptographic
datacommunications protocols such as
Diffie–Helman, intended to maintain the
confidentiality of previously captured
communications sessions, even if a private
key is subsequently compromised, by
encrypting sessions with ephemeral session
keys derived independently and securely
communicated by the original parties ( e.g.
using a O ne- T ime P ad or key loader).
“Additional security for security
associations in that if one security
association is compromised subsequent
security associations will not be
compromised” (NZISM).
```
```
Perfect-knowledge
attack
```
```
Test simulating insider threats, i.e. attacks
on a system by an adversary who already
knows its internal architecture,
cybersecurity arrangements, etc ., such as its
owners, designers, and administrators.
“Attack on a system that assumes no prior
```

```
knowledge about the internal information of
the system under attack. Note: The
adversary can use context or historical
information to infer model vulnerability.
The attacker can probe the system to inform
system vulnerabilities” (ISO/IEC 27090
DRAFT). See also white box testing. Cf.
zero-knowledge, partial-knowledge attacks.
```
**Performance** a. Effective speed and efficiency at which
a computer system, network, process,
team, _etc_. operates, affecting the
services delivered. Technology with
insufficient capacity for the applied
load performs badly, affecting
availability ( _e.g_. becoming unreliable,
partially, or completely failing), and
may expose other vulnerabilities when
under extreme stress ( _e.g._ if controls
fail-unsafe). “Measurable result. Notes:
performance can relate either to
quantitative or qualitative findings.
Performance can relate to the
management of activities, processes,
products (including services), systems
or organizations” _(ISO/IEC 27000)._ “In
IT, the actual implementation or
achievement of a process” _(ISACA
glossary)._
b. Artistic act, such as a plausible
scenario played out by a social
engineer hoping to fool a victim into
falling for their pretext, or a job
interview by a candidate hoping to
persuade an employer to fall for their
charms.


```
Performance driver Factor of particular significance to
performance. “A measure that is considered
the ‘driver’ of a lag indicator. It can be
measured before the outcome is clear and,
therefore, is called a ‘lead indicator.’ Notes:
There is an assumed relationship between
the two that suggests that improved
performance in a leading indicator will
drive better performance in the lagging
indicator. They are also referred to as key
performance indicators (KPIs) and are used
to indicate whether goals are likely to be
met” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Performance
evaluation
```
```
Process, or the results, of analysing or
testing performance, particularly the extent
to which objectives are met. “Process to

criteria” (ISO 22300).
```
**Performance indicator** Measurable performance parameter or

```
characteristic, such as the time taken to
complete certain activities, the rate of
consumption of resources, the output quality
achieved, and the reliability (variation under
different loads, operating or environmental
conditions). “A set of metrics designed to
measure the extent to which performance
objectives are being achieved on an on-
going basis. Note: Performance indicators
can include service level agreements
(SLAs), critical success factors (CSFs),
customer satisfaction ratings, internal or
external benchmarks, industry best practices
and international standards” (ISACA
glossary). See also K ey P erformance
I ndicator.
```

```
Performance
management
```
```
Management of performance. “In IT, the

including employee, team, process,
operational or financial measurements. The
term connotes closed-loop control and
regular monitoring of the measurement”
(ISACA glossary). “The act of managing
processes and resources to pursue reward
while addressing risk” (OCEG GRC
Glossary).
```
```
Performance
parameter
```
```
See performance indicator. “Measurable
criteria used to monitor progress toward
quantitative objectives. Collectively,
performance parameters provide a metric
for determining the success of the business

```
**Performance test** Analysis of the performance achieved by a

```
system, process, team, etc. under various
loading or environmental conditions. “A test

other equivalent systems using well-defined
benchmarks [and] Functional testing to

component with specified performance
requirements” (ISACA glossary). See also
performance evaluation, stress test, down
for everyone or just me?
```

```
Perimeter Outermost physical and/or logical/notional
boundary around a collection of assets, such

or facility, or a network boundary
partitioning or dividing the organisation’s

```

```
external networks. Often but not always

fence.
```
```
Perimeter network See D e- M ilitarised Z one.
```

**Peripheral, peripheral
device, peripheral
equipment**

```
Something supplemental, supporting, or
```

```
Peripheral switch “A device used to share a set of peripherals
```

```
Permission Authorisation to do something, e.g. a data
```

```
Permit, consent
```

```
a. [Verb] To allow, authorise, or fail to

b. [Noun] Formal document or credential
from an authority confirming that
someone has their permission,
```

```
Permit-list See whitelist.
```

```
Permutation See transposition. “Keeps the same letters
```

```
Perpetrator, perp Person who (allegedly or actually) commits
```

```
Persirai Species of I nternet o f T hings malware in
the wild in 2017. Infects particular web
cameras, recruiting them to a botnet.
```
**Persistence, persistent** a. Digital forensics term describing the

```
Persistent remote
access
```
```
Hackers, crackers, and cyber-spooks
generally aim to extend their illicit remote
access to compromised systems/networks
by remaining covert and installing backdoor
mechanisms, enabling them to regain
control if their primary access mechanisms
are blocked ( e.g. by enhanced network or
system security). However, this redundancy
also increases their vulnerability to being
detected and perhaps traced and prosecuted.
It’s not just their victims who face
information risks!
```

```
Weak numeric password or authentication

PIN pads rather than full alphanumeric

normally, and very low entropy, PINs alone

unless compensating controls (such as
security awareness, M ulti F actor
A uthentication, throttling, and CCTV
recording) are applied. Commonly used to
authenticate the holders of security tokens
such as chip-n-PIN bank cards and access
```

```
cards, reducing the risk of someone simply
using a found or stolen card to withdraw
cash through a bank’s A utomated T eller

number assigned to an individual) that, in
conjunction with some means of identifying
the individual, serves to verify the
authenticity of the individual. Note: PINs
have been adopted by financial institutions
as the primary means of verifying customers
in an electronic funds transfer (EFT)
system” (ISACA glossary).
```

**Personal information,
P** ersonally **I** dentifiable
**I** nformation **(PII)**

```
Information or data associated with a
particular human being that is considered
valuable and/or sensitive/confidential, with
privacy implications. Note: specific terms
are explicitly defined in laws and
regulations with some significant
differences between jurisdictions. Data
relating to dead people is classed as
personal information in some but not all
places, for instance, while certain types or
items of personal information (such as
sexual orientation) are deemed particularly
confidential in some countries (see
P rotected H ealth I nformation). “Any
information that (a) can be used to establish
a link between the information and the
natural person to whom such information
relates, or (b) is or can be directly or
indirectly linked to a natural person. Notes:
The ‘natural person’ in the definition is the
PII principal. To determine whether a PII
principal is identifiable, account should be
taken of all the means which can reasonably
be used by the privacy stakeholder holding
```

the data, or by any other party, to establish
the link between the set of PII and the
natural person; This definition is included to
define the term PII as used in this
document. A public cloud PII processor is
typically not in a position to know explicitly
whether information it processes falls into
any specified category unless this is made
transparent by the cloud service customer”
_(ISO/IEC 22989 )._ “Any information relating
to an identified or identifiable natural
person (‘data subject’); an identifiable
natural person is one who can be identified,
directly or indirectly, in particular by
reference to an identifier such as a name, an
identification number, location data, an
online identifier or to one or more factors
specific to the physical, physiological,
genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social
identity of that natural person” _(_ **_G_** _eneral_
**_D_** _ata_ **_P_** _rotection_ **_R_** _egulation)._ “Information
that is or can be about or related to an
identifiable individual” _(_ **_T_** _rust_ **_S_** _ervices_
**_C_** _riteria)._ “Information that can be used to
distinguish or trace an individual’s identity,
either alone or when combined with other
information that is linked or linkable to a
specific individual” _(OMB Circular A-130)._
“A synonym for ‘personal data.’ [and] Any
information that can be used to establish a
link between the information and the natural
person to whom such information relates or
that is or might be directly or indirectly
linked to a natural person” _(ISACA
glossary)_. See also personal data.

**Pharming** Phishing-like fraud involving the

```
manipulation of D omain N ame S ystem or
other network addressing (such as the hosts
file) to redirect users silently to fake
websites that appear legitimate. “This is a
more sophisticated form of MITM attack. A
user’s session is redirected to a
masquerading website. This can be achieved
by corrupting a DNS server on the Internet
and pointing a URL to the masquerading
website’s IP. Almost all users use a URL
like http://www.worldbank.com (Not accessible as
of December 19, 2025) instead of the real IP
(192.86.99.140) of the website. Changing
the pointers on a DNS server, the URL can
be redirected to send traffic to the IP of the
pseudo website. At the pseudo website,
transactions can be mimicked and
information like login credentials can be
gathered. With this the attacker can access
the real http://www.worldbank.com (Not
accessible as of December 19, 2025) site
and conduct transactions using the
credentials of a valid user on that website”
(SANS glossary). See also DNS poisoning.
```
```
PHI Abbrev: P rotected H ealth I nformation.
```
```
Phishing Fraud involving a combination of social
engineering with technology (such as
hyperlinks in plausible emails leading to
fake user authentication web pages that
resemble the logon screens of legitimate
websites used as lures), normally used to
harvest victims’credentials (personal
information, credit card numbers,
passwords, etc. ) for identity fraud and
```

```
extortion, or to infect their systems with
malware. “Deceptive computer-based
means to trick individuals into disclosing
sensitive personal information” (NIST SP
8 00-114). “Fraudulent process of attempting
to acquire private or confidential
information by masquerading as a
trustworthy entity in an electronic
communication. Note: Phishing can be
accomplished by using social engineering or
technical deception” (ISO/IEC 27032 ). “A
type of electronic mail (email) attack that
attempts to convince a user that the
originator is genuine with the intention of
obtaining information for use in social
engineering. Notes: For example, phishing
attacks may take the form of an attacker
masquerading as a lottery organization
advising the recipient or the user ’ s bank of a
large win; in either case, the intent is to
obtain account and personal identification
number (PIN) details. Alternative attacks
may seek to obtain apparently innocuous
business information, which can be used in
another form of active attack” (ISACA
glossary). “The use of e-mails that appear to
originate from a trusted source to trick a
user into entering valid credentials at a fake
website. Typically the e-mail and the web
site looks like they are part of a bank the
user is doing business with” (SANS
glossary). See also spear phishing, whaling,
vishing.
```

```
a. Control designed to mitigate

or devices such as chains, padlocks,
```

intrusion or

```
Gaining physical access to ‘sites’ (facilities,

tailgating; social engineering of
receptionists, guards, or other workers;
masquerading as a legitimate worker,
maintenance staff, visitor, or inspector;

but may be a legitimate part of a penetration
test, installation audit, etc.
```

```
humidity/dampness, drought, climate
change, sea level rise; lightning, static
electricity; inadequate or excessive supply
voltage, surge, spike, dip, brownout,
unreliable power; electronic/equipment
failure; corrosion, stress, strain, metal
```

```
specification, engineering, construction or
maintenance, poor quality, inappropriate or

to mechanical failure or collapse, or
noncompliance with building codes;
cosmic, electromagnetic or ionising
radiation; magnetism; earthquake or

falling/moving object; theft, vandalism,
sabotage, wanton or accidental damage,

degradation, mould, decay, entropy; insect
```

**Ping, Packet Internet
(or Inter-Network)
Groper Packet Inter-
Network Groper**

```
Basic network administration utility or
function that sends an ICMP echo request to
a specified network node, anticipating an
ICMP echo reply message in return if the
node is accessible via the network,
operating normally and has not been
configured to ignore pings. Contrived name
reflects the classic sonar U-boat sound. The
round-trip delay gives an indication of
network latency. See also tracert.
```

```
PIN mailer Physical security arrangement to post initial
PIN codes to customers in a tamper-evident
form that reduces the possibility of them
being illicitly viewed, overseen, or copied
en route , e.g. an opaque covering layer
through which the PIN is printed by an
impact printer located in a physically secure
zone.
```
```
Ping of death a. Destroyer’s sonar echo from an enemy
submarine.
b. “An attack that sends an improperly
large ICMP echo request packet (a
‘ping’) with the intent of overflowing
the input buffers of the destination
machine and causing it to crash”
(SANS glossary).
```
```
Ping scan “Looks for machines that are responding to
ICMP Echo Requests” (SANS glossary).
```
```
Ping sweep “An attack that sends ICMP echo requests
(‘pings’) to a range of IP addresses, with the
goal of finding hosts that can be probed for
vulnerabilities” (SANS glossary).
```

```
PIN pad Small keypad used to enter PIN codes. Most
lay out the 10 decimal digits 0–9 plus the #
and $ or A and B characters in a 3x4 array
like a pushbutton telephone.
```

```
Plain English, plain
language
```
```
Straightforward writing style, designed to
be easily understood and readily translated.
Uses relatively short, clear sentences.
Avoids obscure words, jargon, superfluous
text and complex terms ( e.g. replacing the
pseudo-legalese “includes, but is not limited
to,” with “such as” or “ e.g.” ). However, this
ideal is not always feasible, particularly in
technical, scientific, and legal texts where
precision and lack of ambiguity are
paramount and the primary audiences are
well educated in the arcane and often
archaic language of their fields.
```
```
Plaintext, cleartext Intelligible, readable, and meaningful text,
such as this sentence, or other usable forms
of information, e.g. unencrypted data. “The
original, intelligible text, as it was before
encipherment, revealed after successful
decoding or cryptanalysis” ( A Lexicon of
Cryptography, Bletchley Park, 1943 ).
“Ordinary readable text before being
encrypted into ciphertext or after being
decrypted” (SANS glossary). “Digital
information, such as cleartext, that is
intelligible to the reader” (ISACA
glossary).Cf. ciphertext, encrypted data.
```

**P** latform- **a** s- **a** - **S** ervice

```
Cloud computing service model providing
```

```
ignorance of the remainder which remains

repudiation.
```

```
Polymorphic,

```

```
Contrived name of a M an- I n- T he- M iddle
```

```
POP3 (Post Office

```
```
Third generation of the POP protocol for
retrieving email messages from a mail
server. By default, POP3 sends users’ logon
credentials to the mail server in plaintext,
making them vulnerable to interception as
they transit the network (unless T ransport
L ayer S ecurity is used) or while on the
client or server systems. Deprecated in
favour of I nternet M essage A ccess
P rotocol. “A standard protocol used to
receive electronic mail from a server” (NIST
SP 800-101). “An Internet Standard
protocol by which a client workstation can
dynamically access a mailbox on a server
host to retrieve mail messages that the
server has received and is holding for the
client” (SANS glossary).
```

```
Port Notional point of origin or destination of

In the context of the Internet protocol a port
is a logical channel endpoint of a TCP
connection or UDP messages. Application
```

```
protocols which are based on TCP or UDP
have typically assigned default port
numbers, e.g. port 80 for HTTP” (ISO/IEC
27033-1). “A process or application-specific
software element serving as a
communication endpoint for the transport
layer IP protocols (UDP and TCP)” (ISACA
glossary). “Nothing more than an integer
that uniquely identifies an endpoint of a
communication stream. Only one process
per machine can listen on the same port
number” (SANS glossary).
```

```
File format originally created by Adobe in
```

```
Systematic process for identifying and

services, each associated with a ‘well-
known’ port number, the computer provides.
Port scanning, a favorite approach of
computer cracker, gives the assailant an idea
where to probe for weaknesses. Essentially,
a port scan consists of sending a message to
each port, one at a time. The kind of
response received indicates whether the port
is used and can therefore be probed for
```

```
Design of cryptographic algorithms that are

approaches to cryptanalysis involving
quantum computers, using techniques such
as lattice-based, code-based, hash-based,
and multivariate polynomials. Most forms
```
