encrypted messages and digital signatures
currently circulating) will become
vulnerable to novel cryptanalytical
techniques once quantum computing
technology is fully developed.

considered to be secure against a

computer” (NZISM).

performance

the organisation than most. “Activity to

```
PRISM SECRET N ational S ecurity A gency
electronic mass surveillance program,
disclosed by whistleblower Ed Snowden.
Exploits legal rights of access to data held
by I nternet S ervice P roviders such as
Google, Yahoo!, Microsoft, Apple, and
Facebook. See also BULLRUN.
```
```
Privacy Under information/data protection laws,
privacy may be defined narrowly in relation
to a data subject’s legal right to control
(permit or forbid) the release, disclosure,
use, accuracy, and retention of their
personal information. In common usage,
however, privacy is a broader concept also
encompassing freedom of expression,
personal choice, personal space, ethics and
morality, anonymity, trust, freedom from
surveillance and state interference, etc.
“Freedom from intrusion into the private
life or affairs of an individual when that
```

```
intrusion results from undue or illegal
gathering and use of data about that
individual” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “The right of
an individual to trust that others will
appropriately and respectfully use, store,
share and dispose of his/her associated
personal and sensitive information within
the context and according to the purposes
for which it was collected or derived”
(ISACA glossary). See also G eneral D ata
P rotection R egulation, D ata P rotection A ct,
C alifornia C onsumer P rotection A ct,
P ersonal I nformation P rotection and
E lectronic D ocuments A ct, H ealth
I nsurance P ortability and A ccountability
A ct , and others around the world.
Reminder: this hyperglossary is not legal
advice.
```
```
Privacy breach Incident involving actual or potential
unauthorised or inappropriate disclosure,
release, or use of personal information,
contrary to rules or expectations in laws,
regulations, policies, contracts, agreements,
or ethics. “Situation where personally
identifiable information is processed in
violation of one or more relevant privacy
safeguarding requirements” (ISO/IEC
29100 ).
```
```
Privacy breech Underwear designed to conceal one’s
privates, maybe? More likely a common
typo of privacy breach ...
```
**Privacy by default** Requirement of the **G** eneral **D** ata **P** rotection

```
R egulation that privacy and security
(primarily confidentiality) should be the
```

```
preferred, automatic state or option in
systems, services, and processes handling
personal information, e.g. the most

default unless a data subject expressly
relaxes them. An expression of opt-in. See
also privacy by design.
```
```
Privacy by design Requirement of the G eneral D ata P rotection
R egulation that privacy should be an
integral or inherent part of the design of
new systems, services, and processes
handling personal information. “The
integration of privacy into the entire
engineering process” (ISACA glossary). See
also privacy by default.

**Privacy commitment** Commitment regarding privacy.

```
“Declarations made by management
regarding the performance of a system
processing personal information. Such
commitments can be communicated in

statements (for example, a privacy practices

commitments may be made on many
different aspects of the service being

monitoring

130 ).

technical measures, e.g. policies,
procedures, guidelines, legal contracts,

```
Tools and techniques to facilitate legitimate
exploitation of personal information without
unduly compromising privacy, e.g. by

communication technology (ICT) measures,

Examples of PETs include, but are not

reduce, mask, or de-identify PII or that

29134 ). “Anything that has an effect on the

information (PII) owned by a data subject

**Privacy notice** Formal disclosure by an organisation of

```
how it intends to use and protect any

```

Framework in 2023.

Privilege Attribute of certain userIDs, applications,

**A** ccount **] M** anagement

```
Given their wide-ranging ability to degrade,
disable, or bypass automated controls,
managing and controlling access to various
privileged userIDs is critical to achieve and
maintain adequate system security. PAM
comprises the processes, built-in system
functions/utilities, and add-on tools to do
this. “An access control mechanism that
uses a combination of people, processes and
technology to safeguard identities with
special access or capabilities beyond regular
users” (ISACA glossary). “A set of
processes and tools for granting,
```

```
controlling, monitoring, and auditing
privileged access” (NZISM). See also
I dentity and A ccess M anagement.

Privileged account UserID for a privileged computer user. “A

accounts may, for example, be able to install

systems, or modify system or application
configurations. They may also have access
to data that is not normally accessible to
standard users” (NZISM). “Includes
privileged user accounts and privileged
service accounts” (AusISM). “A system
account with the authorizations of a
privileged user” (NIST SP 800-171).

specific mode” (ISO/IEC 2382).

```
Privileged user [rôle] Whereas ordinary nonprivileged user rôles
grant minimal rights of access to networks,
systems, and data for most users, privileged
user rôles confer more powerful access
rights that can bypass normal security
controls and should therefore only be
allocated to highly trustworthy workers with
additional procedural and/or technical
controls. “Any user account with greater
than basic access privileges. Typically, these
accounts have elevated or increased
privileges with more rights than a standard
user account” (ISACA glossary). “A user
```

```
that is authorized (and, therefore, trusted) to
perform security relevant functions that
ordinary users are not authorized to
perform” (NIST CSF). “A system user who
can alter or circumvent system security
protections. This can also apply to system
users who could have only limited
privileges, such as software developers,
who can still bypass security precautions. A
privileged user can have the capability to

privileges, audit logs, data files or

alter or circumvent a system’s controls. This
can also apply to users who could have only
limited privileges, such as software
developers, who can still bypass controls. A

modify system configurations, account
privileges, event logs and security
configurations for applications” (AusISM).
“A user who is authorized (and therefore,
trusted) to perform security-relevant

authorized to perform” (NIST SP 800-171).

```
Probability Mathematical chance of something such as
an incident occurring, ranging between zero
(meaning there is absolutely no possibility
whatsoever, ever) and one (it is absolutely
certain: it definitely happens). Whereas
probability is precisely defined in
mathematics ( e.g. occurrence within a
defined timescale), vague terms such as
likelihood, possibility, chance, and luck are
used informally in everyday language in
reference to uncertainty, unpredictability,
often implying the speaker’s inability to
influence or determine the outcome (‘fate’).
“Measure of the chance of occurrence
expressed as a number from 0 to 1, where 0
is impossibility and 1 is absolute certainty”
(ISO 31073). “Extent to which an event is
likely to occur” (ENISA RM glossary). “A
mathematical-driven measure of the
possibility of a specific outcome as a ratio
of all possible outcomes” (ISACA glossary).
```
**P** robability **-I** mpact
**G** raphic **(PIG)**

```
Two-dimensional graphical representation
of risks, reflecting the chances that incidents
are anticipated to occur within a finite
timescale (typically one or more years) and
the anticipated significance or severity of
the impacts if they do. Despite normally
being a qualitative, subjective, and static
representation (not a mathematical graph), a
useful means for management to
communicate/report, debate, comprehend,
and ultimately agree on the relative
significance or levels of various risks. Often
overlaid on a red-amber-green background,
visually emphasising the range, i.e. a
heatmap.
```

“The probability that a Threat Agent will act

RT).

Probe Metaphorically poke at something to find

O perating S ystems, application software,

procedure

**Problem (and solution)
owner**

```
Organisation, rôle, or person who owns and
is accountable for addressing and ideally
solving an identified problem, issue, or

owner, information owner, risk owner,

```
Procedural control See manual control.

```
Procedural knowledge Competent and experienced person’s
understanding of a process, perhaps
documented in the form of a procedure.
“Knowledge which explicitly indicates the
steps to be taken in order to solve a problem
or to reach a goal” (ISO/IEC 22989).
```
```
Procedure Formal description of a process. Procedures
are normally documented to explain
processes to those expected to perform
them, and are usually formalised through
some form of management review,
authorisation, endorsement, and/or mandate
to ensure their suitability and improve
process control, consistency, and
conformity. “Specified way to carry out an
activity or a process. Notes: Procedures can
be documented or not. When a procedure is
documented, the term ‘written procedure’ or
```

```
‘documented procedure’ is frequently used.
The document that contains a procedure can
be called a ‘procedure document’” (ISO
22300 ). “A document containing a detailed
description of the steps necessary to
perform specific operations in conformance
with applicable standards. Procedures are
defined as parts of processes” (ISACA
glossary). “A detailed articulation of what
the organization expects on a particular
topic, that describes the ‘how to’ or

“A written description of a course of action
to be taken to perform a given task” (ENISA
RM glossary). See also protocol.
```
**Process, execution,
ways**

```
a. Sequence of manual and/or automated
activities intended to achieve a specific
objective, function, or outcome. May
be described in a procedure or
protocol. “Predetermined course of
events defined by its purpose or by its
effect, achieved under given
conditions” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “Set of
interrelated or interacting activities that
transforms inputs to deliver a result”
(ISO/IEC 27002 ). “Set of interrelated
or interacting activities that uses or
transforms inputs to deliver a result.
Note: Whether the result of a process is
called an output, a product or a service
depends on the context of the
reference” (ISO/IEC 42001 ). “Set of
activities that have a common goal and
last for a limited period of time”
(ISO/IEC 27043 ). “Generally, a
```

```
collection of activities influenced by
the enterprise’s policies and procedures
that takes inputs from a number of
sources, (including other processes),
manipulates the inputs and produces
outputs. Note: Processes have clear
business reasons for existing,
accountable owners, clear roles and
responsibilities around the execution of
the process and the means to measure
performance” (ISACA glossary). “A
series of actions or steps to achieve an
objective” (OCEG GRC Glossary).
“An organized set of activities which
uses resources to transform inputs to
outputs” (ENISA RM glossary).
b. Particular instance of a program
currently running (executing) on a
computer.
```
**Process control** a. Control designed to mitigate

```
unacceptable process risks, keeping
business processes running properly
(smoothly, efficiently, effectively,
safely, securely, etc .). Implies the need

**Programmable Read-
Only Memory (PROM)**

```
Nonvolatile storage device, an I ntegrated
C ircuit that can be programmed after
manufacture. “A chip that can be
programmed using a PROM programming
device. It can be programmed only once. It
cannot be erased and reprogrammed. Each
of its bit locations is a fusible link. An
unprogrammed PROM has all links closed,
establishing a known state of each bit.
Programming the chip consists of sending
an electrical current of a specified size
through each link that is to be changed to
the alternate state. This causes the fuse to
blow, opening that link” (ISACA glossary).
See also E rasable P rogrammable R ead-
O nly M emory.
```

```
P rogrammable L ogic
C ontroller (PLC)

```
Legacy term harping back to the early days

N umerically C ontrolled milling machines,
etc. Embeddable I ndustrial C ontrol S ystem
subsystem that can be programmed to
respond to certain signals from plant with
sophisticated sequences of control signals,
alarms, alerts, etc. PLCs are physically
rugged controllers designed for reliable
operation in factory floor, outdoor, or other
harsh environments. PLC ‘programming’
evolved from setting internal option
switches through using custom connectors,
proprietary hardware and software to the
use of standardised ports and remote
network access, with ever-increasing
smarts.

```

**Promiscuous mode** Datacommunications devices such as
Ethernet and Wi-Fi cards routinely ignore
passing network packets that are not
addressed to their unique network or device
addresses, and are not broadcast or
multicast packets, discarding them at a low
level. When configured in promiscuous
mode, however, even packets destined for
other devices are passed up the network
stack, _e.g._ to a sniffer where any
unencrypted content may be read. “Allows
the network interface to capture all network
traffic irrespective of the hardware device to
which the packet is addressed” _(ISACA
glossary)._ “When a machine reads all


```
packets off the network, regardless of who
they are addressed to. This is used by
network administrators to diagnose network
problems, but also by unsavory characters
who are trying to eavesdrop on network
traffic (which might contain passwords or
other information)” (SANS glossary).
```

& controls**

“Actions & controls that increase the

P roof -O f -C oncept

```
P roof -O f -C orrectness
(POC)

```
“Proof that results from applying

```

that their captive remains alive, thereby

```
```
P roof of S take (PoS) Blockchain approach used by
cryptocurrencies such as Ethereum, in
which ‘minters’ or ‘validators’ can only add
new cryptocoins to the blockchain if they
already hold a substantial number of
bitcoins, giving them a material stake and
hence self-interest in maintaining the
integrity of the system. “A type of
consensus algorithm by which a
cryptocurrency blockchain network aims to
achieve distributed consensus. In PoS
consensus, the creator of the next block of
data is chosen via several combinations of
random selection and wealth or age ( i.e ., the
stake) within the blockchain. With PoS,
miners can mine or validate block
transactions based on amount of
cryptocurrency a miner holds. PoS was
created as an alternative to PoW, which
requires large amounts of energy. PoS gives
mining power based on the percentage of
cryptocurrency held by a miner. It is seen as
less risky in terms of network attacks and
security and used only for public
blockchains” (ISACA glossary). Cf. P roof o f
W ork.
```
**P** roof of **W** ork **(PoW)** Blockchain approach used by

```
cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin, in which
miners have to prove (cryptographically) to
the validators that they have expended a
```

```
substantial amount of computational effort
(and energy) to mine (create) new
cryptocoins, while validation takes minimal
effort. “PoW is conducted through miners
(participants who keep the blockchain
running by providing computing resources)
who are competing to solve a cryptographic
problem ( i.e ., hash puzzle). The PoW
algorithm is used to confirm transactions
and produce new blocks which are added to
the chain. With PoW, miners compete
against each other to complete transactions
on the network and get rewarded. The
computational work required to accomplish
this is fairly (and usually increasingly)
difficult for miners to perform, but easy for
the network to verify. As difficulty increases
over time, the amount of computational
power, and hence, energy consumption,
grows. Bitcoin is the first widespread
application use of PoW. PoW is applicable
to public blockchains” (ISACA glossary).
Cf. P roof o f S take.
```
**Proofread, proof read** Painstaking review of the ‘proof’ or ‘proof

copy’ – a final draft version of a book prior

as spelling mistakes, grammatical and
formatting errors identified and corrected at
this stage will not spoil the final product. An

English and grammar are acceptable”
(FSRCoP).

information deliberately
```

```

or political purposes. The content may be

depend upon the findings that have been
made at the alleged crime scene (or other

by the expert). In the context of a criminal
trial there will most often be a pair of

representing the defence’s position in
relation to a particular issue. Propositions
shall be mutually exclusive ( i.e. if one is

they cover all possibilities within the
```

others. “Set of rules that determines the

```
“The process of quickly putting together a
working model (a prototype) to test various
aspects of a design, illustrate ideas or
features and gather early user feedback.
Prototyping uses programmed simulation
techniques to represent a model of the final
system to the user for advisement and

configuring, preparing) a new user account,

```
Proximity Closeness in distance, time, form, etc. In

tend to be emphasised relative to those

```
Proxy Someone or something that ‘stands in for’
(represents and acts on behalf of) another to
pass their information to a third party, such
as the chairman of a meeting voting on
behalf of stakeholders who cannot attend
(proxy voting), or a network service
(application proxy), or network device
(proxy server). Requires trust in the proxy
from both sides, making it vulnerable to
untrustworthy people, compromised
devices, coercion, M an- I n- T he- M iddle
attacks, etc.
```
**Proxy server, Internet
proxy system**

```
Network server running software that
dissembles packets arriving at one network
interface to analyse the data content, applies
security rules according to the nature of the
```

```
content, source, destination, protocol, ports,
etc. and optionally repackages them for
onward transmission through other network
interfaces. To each of the communicating
systems, the server stands in for (proxies)
the other, in effect being an authorised and
trusted M an- I n- T he- M iddle. A type of deep
packet inspection firewall. “A server that
acts as a gateway between an individual and
the internet [and] A server that acts on
behalf of a user. Note: Typical proxies
accept a connection from a user, make a
decision as to whether the user or client IP
address is permitted to use the proxy,
perhaps perform additional authentication,
and complete a connection to a remote
destination on behalf of the user” (ISACA
glossary). “A server that acts as an
intermediary between a workstation user
and the Internet so that the enterprise can
ensure security, administrative control, and
caching service. A proxy server is
associated with or part of a gateway server
that separates the enterprise network from
the outside network and a firewall server
that protects the enterprise network from
outside intrusion” (SANS glossary).

**Pseudonymity,

```
Use of a fake/fictitious pseudonym, token,

with other information or by guessing) or by
mistake, pseudonymisation may potentially
be reversed or fail under some
circumstances, compromising privacy and
perhaps safety or security. “The processing
of personal data insuch a manner that the
personal data can no longer be attributed to
a specific data subject without the use of
additional information, provided that such
additional information is kept separately
and is subject to technical and
organisational measures to ensure that the
personal data are not attributed to an
identified or identifiable natural person”
( G eneral D ata P rotection R egulation).
“Process applied to personally identifiable
information (PII) which replaces identifying
information with an alias. Notes:
Pseudonymization can be performed either
by PII principals themselves or by PII
controllers. Pseudonymization can be used
by PII principals to consistently use a

identity to this resource or service (or
between services), while still being held
accountable for that use. Pseudonymization
does not rule out the possibility that there
can be (a restricted set of) privacy
stakeholders other than the PII controller of
the pseudonymized data which are able to
```

determine the PII principal’s identity based

**P** seudo **R** andom **N** umber
**G** enerator **(PRNG)**

```
Software algorithms used to generate
supposedly random data are only capable of
approximating true randomness. Given the
same inputs and conditions, two identical
instances of a PRNG running in parallel will
normally generate the same output
sequences. Consequently, pseudorandom
values used as encryption keys, TCP/IP
sequence numbers, etc. may conceivably be
predicted to some extent, a feature that
weakens some cryptosystems but is
legitimately exploited by others ( e.g. in
security tokens generating codes that can be
validated by the corresponding software but
cannot be guessed by an attacker without
additional knowledge). See also seed.

to mitigate the risk of finished products

```
```

**Q** uality **o** f **S** ervice
**(QoS)**

Networking techniques, functions, and
protocols allowing time-critical data (such

O ver I nternet P rotocol and streaming, or

**Quantum computing,
quantum technology,
quantum**

```
Cutting-edge computer technology based on
quantum mechanics. Quantum bits (qubits)
appear to have different values
simultaneously (a property called
superposition) and can appear to be
correlated (entanglement). Quantum has
significant potential for cryptanalysis and
other intensive purposes; hence, it is being
actively developed and exploited by the
defence, intelligence, pharmaceuticals, and
other industries. “Relies on the principles of
quantum physics. The advancing
understanding and control of what are
known as ‘quantum effects’ such as
superposition and entanglement will lead to
a new wave of advances that will underpin
our economy and society: sensing, data
transmission and encryption, timing and
computing” (UK National Cyber Security
Strategy 2022).
```
```
Quantum-safe
cryptography
```
```
Cryptographic methods, systems, and
algorithms specifically designed to resist
advanced cryptanalysis using quantum
computers.
```
```

suspected malware is diverted by antivirus
software pending further investigation. “To
store files containing malware in isolation
```

```
for future disinfection or examination”
(NIST SP 800-114).
```
```
Quasar, xRAT Open-source R emote A ccess T rojan
intended for legitimate remote Windows
system management and support, now
customised for use in A dvanced P ersistent
T hreat attacks. Originally named xRAT.
```
```
Question answering Guess! “Task of determining the most
appropriate answer to a question provided in
natural language. Note: A question can be
open-ended or be intended to have a
specific answer” (ISO/IEC 22989).
```
**Q** uick **R** esponse **(QR)
code**

```
Generally, a square monochrome image
comprising a two-dimensional pattern of
black dots similar in function to a linear
barcode. The dots can encode four data
types: numbers, alphanumeric characters,
binary values, or kanji. High-density QR
codes can communicate up to about 4,000
alphanumeric characters (roughly two A4
pages of text) with limited error correction,
although most are used for shorter U niform
R esource L ocators with strong error
correction, allowing smartphones to scan,
decode, and pass the URLs directly to the
web browser without having to be typed in
(and corrected!) manually. See also
attagging, baiting.
```

organisation’s data stored in a network, e.g.
by encrypting it (crypto-ransomware) and/or
to I nformation T echnology systems within
the network, e.g. by damaging or replacing
essential O perating S ystem files such as the
M aster B oot R ecord (lock-screen
ransomware); (2) exfiltrates valuable data;
or (3) simply presents a warning message
falsely claiming to have done (1) and
perhaps threatening to do (2) (scareware).
The primary intention is to disrupt the
victim’s operations, threaten data disclosure
or further exploitation, and so extort or
coerce the victim into paying a ransom. A
lucrative, relatively low-risk, and hence
popular cybercriminal tool and method.
Ransom payments are typically demanded
via anonymous services such as Bitcoin.
Some crypto-ransomware species can be
defeated without paying the ransom using
white hat tools ( e.g. NoMoreRansom.org).
“Malware that restricts access to the
compromised system until a ransom
demand is satisfied” (ISACA glossary). “A
type of malicious software designed to
```

```
block access to a computer system until a
sum of money (a ransom) is paid” (UK
Cyber Security Breaches Survey 2023 ).
“Malicious software that denies the user
access to their files, computer or device
until a ransom is paid” (UK National Cyber
Security Strategy 2022 ). “A type of malware
that is a form of extortion. It works by
encrypting a victim ’ s hard drive denying
them access to key files. The victim must
then pay a ransom to decrypt the files and
gain access to them again” (SANS glossary).
Cf. software, middleware, hardware,
firmware, wetware, malware, adware,
crimeware, scareware, shelfware,
spouseware, stalkerware, spyware.

**RC-4 (R** ivest **C** ipher **No
4)**

```
Quick and efficient stream cipher used in
S ecure S ockets L ayer, SYSKEY, etc.
Designed by Ron Rivest in 1987. Flaws in
the way RC-4 shared keys and nonces are
generated/exchanged have seriously
weakened common implementations such as
WEP. Further cryptographic attacks on RC-
4 have since been described, so this
algorithm is well past its ‘best before’ date
and hence is deprecated.

**Recoverability** Ability to recover some semblance of

```
normality following a serious incident, e.g.

**Recovery actions &

```
“Actions & controls that return the

```
R ecovery P oint
O bjective (RPO)
```
```
Following a serious incident requiring the
invocation of D isaster R ecovery
arrangements, this key parameter/metric
defines the point up to which all data should
have been recovered ( e.g. the previous
minute, hour, day, week, month, etc. ), and
therefore the maximum tolerable data loss
prior to the incident. Has implications for
both the business and the backup strategy,
e.g. the frequency of offsite backups. “Point
in time to which data are to be recovered
after a disruption has occurred” (ISO/IEC
27002 ). “Point to which information used
by an activity is restored to enable the
activity to operate on resumption. Note: Can
also be referred to as ’maximum data loss’”
(ISO 22300). “The earliest point in time that
is acceptable to recover data, determined
based on the acceptable data loss in case of
a disruption in operations. The RPO
effectively quantifies the permissible
amount of data loss in case of interruption”
(ISACA glossary). See also R ecovery T ime
O bjective.

```
Recovery strategy Information risk and security management
strategy to restore an organisation’s failed
```

information services and data from backups
following a disaster ( _e.g._ a ransomware
incident or data centre fire) in order to
recover/resume dependent business
activities. Complements other aspects of
**B** usiness **C** ontinuity **M** anagement such as
resilience ( _e.g._ cloud computing, cyber
resilience, supply chain risk management)
and contingency arrangements ( _e.g._ a
workforce determined and able to cope
dynamically with _any_ crisis and business
interruption insurance), plus the whole
gamut of preventive security measures and
incident management. Typically involves
clarifying requirements ( _e.g._ **B** usiness
**I** mpact **A** nalysis to explore dependencies
and priorities), policies, and key
parameters/metrics ( _e.g._ **R** ecovery **T** ime
**O** bjective), developing suitable plans,
implementing the plans ( _e.g._ stockpiling
essential resources such as backups, spare
servers, and trained workers), providing
assurance for stakeholders through exercises
and tests, and maintaining the arrangements
( _e.g._ with strong links to change
management). “An approach by an
enterprise that will ensure its recovery and
continuity in the face of a disaster or other
major outage. Notes: Plans and
methodologies are determined by the
enterprise _’_ s strategy. There may be more
than one methodology or solution for an
enterprise _’_ s strategy. Examples of
methodologies and solutions include:
contracting for a hot site or cold site,
building an internal hot site or cold site,
identifying an alternate work area, a


```
consortium or reciprocal agreement,
contracting for mobile recovery or crate and
ship, and many others” (ISACA glossary).
```
```

arrangements at any level from the overall

from scratch. Complements other assurance
measures such as D isaster R ecovery
exercises and audits. “A test to check the
system’s ability to recover after a software
or hardware failure” (ISACA glossary).

“Period of time following an incident within
which a product and service or an activity is
resumed, or resources are recovered. Note:
For products, services and activities, the
RTO is less than the time it would take for
the adverse impacts that would arise as a
result of not providing a product/service or
performing an activity to become
unacceptable” (ISO 22300 ). “The amount of
time allowed for the recovery of a business
function or resource after a disaster occurs”
```

```
(ISACA glossary). See also R ecovery P oint
O bjective.

**N** etwork **(RNN)**

```
Redaction Process of systematically identifying and
then removing, replacing, or concealing
sensitive parts of information in a document
or data in a computer file or D ata B ase prior
to its publication or disclosure in order to
maintain privacy or confidentiality, rather
than withholding the entire item. A fail-
unsafe control, prone to human errors and
technical failures in the redaction process
( e.g. overlaid opaque blocks may simply be
removed), plus various inference attacks
( e.g. the semantic context and length of a
redacted word or phrase can be clues).

database management system (DBMS), for

```

compromising one or more targets in
emulated attacks on an organisation (or site,
system, network, etc. thereof) typically
```

```
involving physical site intrusion, network
hacking, I nformation T echnology systems
penetration, and capturing the flags, in order

the defensive and the offensive capabilities.
A deadly serious form of penetration testing
... that is also great fun, highly motivational
and instructive. “A group of skilled
professionals who simulate real-world
cyberattacks, security breaches and physical

effectiveness of an enterprise’s defenses.
The red team identifies vulnerabilities,

and physical security controls. They often

(ISACA glossary). “A group of people

potential adversary’s attack or exploitation

posture. The Red Team’s objective is to

attacks and by demonstrating what works
for the defenders ( i.e ., the Blue Team) in an
operational environment” (CNSSI 4009 ).
See also blue, purple, black, and white
teams.

redundancy**

```
Resilience technique in which critical or

```

```

```

RetailTech Contraction of retail tech nology,
particularly the development and
exploitation of innovative I nformation
T echnology within the retail sector. See also
AgriTech, Biotech, EdTech, FinTech,
FoodTech, GovTech, EcoTech/GreenTech,
HealthTech, LegalTech, RegTech, and other
tech neologisms.
```
```
Retbleed See Spectre.
```

```
Retention Holding back, continuing to store and
failing to destroy information, potentially
beyond the period or purpose for which it
was originally collected or created.
Increases the risk of
inappropriate/unauthorised disclosure/theft.
According to some privacy/information
protection laws, personal information must
not be retained indefinitely but must be
securely destroyed, unless specific
exemptions apply. “A phase of the data life
cycle that pertains to how long an entity
stores information for future use or
reference” ( T rust S ervices C riteria). See
also archive.
```
**Retention period** Minimum length of time for which valuable
information is supposed or required to be
retained and made available for authorised
and legitimate purposes, for business
reasons. The actual duration may, due to
incidents, negligence, or other reasons, be
shorter (potentially a compliance exception)
but is usually longer. “Length of time for
which data on a data medium is to be
preserved” _(ISO/IEC 2382 )._ “Time period
within which the data objects ... of the
cluster of personally identifiable
information (PII) ... is required to be
available in the PII controller’s organization
because of the functional use or legal
retention obligations. Note: A specific
cluster of PII typically has the same
retention period” _(ISO/IEC 27555)._


```
Retraining Training again, in the forlorn hope that, this
time around, students learn something
useful by retaining a more substantial part
of the imparted knowledge. “Updating a
trained model by training with different
training data” (ISO/IEC 22989).
```
```
R eturn O n I nvestment
(ROI)
```
```
Estimate of the anticipated future value of
an investment over a given period (the
expected productive life of the investment),
having subtracted the costs associated with
the investment itself. Cf. R isk O f
I ncarceration.
```
```
R eturn O n S ecurity
I nvestment (ROSI)
```
```
Simply the R eturn O n I nvestment where the
investment is intended to improve security,
reduce risk and so reduce the probability
and/or impact of incidents, or improve
assurance, relative to not investing. The
return can only be estimated since it is
virtually impossible to know exactly how
much the probability and/or impact have
been reduced or to quantify the value of
improved assurance, but tracking the
appropriate metrics can help.
```
```
R eturn -O riented
P rogramming (ROP)
```
```
Family of hacking/malware techniques in
which execution of a legitimate program is
surreptitiously diverted to malicious code
“gadgets” by manipulating return calls held
in the stack, exploiting C entral P rocessing
U nit design flaws that fail to prevent such
manipulation.
```
**Revenge porn** [ography] Posting of revealing/embarrassing/explicit

```
personal photographs, videos, etc. of a
former lover or sex partner on the Internet
```

```
as a spiteful, callous, and potentially illegal
attack on the victim’s privacy or as a means
of coercion/blackmail.
```
**Reverse engineering** Working out the internals of a device,

```
program, malware, system, process, etc.
through painstaking analysis without access
to its original design, source code,
documentation, etc. Generally performed
without the owner’s permission and/or
knowledge, e.g. to steal I ntellectual
P roperty, identify exploitable vulnerabilities
in software or cryptographic processes, to
understand how malware operates or to
hack. “The process of deconstructing and
interpreting an electronic device or data
format without prior access to the creator’s
specification or design” (FSRCoP).
“Acquiring sensitive data by disassembling
and analyzing the design of a system
component” (SANS glossary).
```
```
Review Literally, to view again. Encompasses
various checks that are generally informal
and hence does not usually offer the same
level of assurance as, say, an audit.
“Activity undertaken to determine the
suitability, adequacy and effectiveness of
the subject matter to achieve established
objectives. Note: Review can be applied to a
risk management framework, risk
management process, risk or risk control”
(ISO 31073). “A re-assessment or re-
evaluation of any of the following: (a)
Findings from an examination/analysis. (b)
Evaluation/interpretation of findings from
an examination. (c) Contract requirements
```

```
(includes MoU, SLA etc .). (d) Process”
(FSRCoP).
```
```
Review object Item, issue, risk, system, control, process,
organisation, function, department,
building, person, relationship, entity, etc.
within the scope of a review, hence subject
to inspection, possibly but not necessarily
the main focus. “Specific item being
reviewed” ( ISO/IEC 27 000 ).
```
```
Review objective Aim or purpose of a review. “Statement
describing what is to be achieved as a result
of a review” (ISO/IEC 27000 ).
```
```
Review visit “Participation by reviewers in peer review
activities at the host location(s). Note:
Review visit activities include
presentations, individual interviews, focus
groups, site visits, and the observation of
live and table-top exercises” (ISO 22300).
```
```
Reviewer Person, group, function, or organisation that
reviews. “Entity that provides feedback as
part of a peer review with expert knowledge
and experience in the analysis area. Note:
The entity may be an organization,
partnership, community, city, region,
country or other body” (ISO 22300).
```
```
REvil Hacker/malware/cybercriminal gang active
in 2022.
```
**Revision management** See version control.

**Reward, performance** “A measure of the positive, favorable effect
of uncertainty on objectives” _(OCEG GRC_


```
Glossary).
```
```
Right a. Correct, proper, appropriate, etc.
b. Something that a person ororganisation
is reasonably and perhaps legally
permitted or allowed to do or expect if
they so choose. See also access right,
permission, privilege.
```
**Right to be forgotten,
right to erasure**

```
Controversial right to have certain types of
damaging or embarrassing personal
information about oneself erased from the
web including search engines, plus cached
and archived copies. Partly supported by
privacy and human rights laws. Intended to
nullify revenge porn and other embarrassing
disclosures of a personal nature, such as old
police reports concerning minor incidents
and false/unproven accusations. The right is
tricky to define, administer, and facilitate in
practice, especially given the global and
decentralised nature of the Internet (making
it hard to put the genie back in the bottle),
plus there are concerns about the right being
misused for unethical/inappropriate reasons
including political motivations, propaganda,
and fraud.
```
```
Rights holder “Legal entity either holding or authorised to
use one or more intellectual property rights”
(ISO 22300).
```
```
Risk In general, uncertainty relating to a
particular context, scenario, situation,
circumstance, asset, threat, vulnerability,
impact, outcome, consequence, etc.
Expressed mathematically,
```

precisely/absolutely, and objectively as a
probability value or range less than 1
(meaning absolute certainty), or
subjectively in imprecise, vague, and
relative terms such as doubt, ambiguity,
potential, possibility, or likelihood. Can be
reduced to some extent by risk analysis and
mitigation through controls as part of risk
management, but in practice there is
inevitably some residual risk, leading to
concerns, fears, indecision, reluctance to
commit, _etc_. In relation to information, the
predicted or projected frequency and
magnitude of future loss if a threat were to
exploit an exposed vulnerability, causing
adverse business, personal, social,
environmental or other impacts. Expressed
either in relative terms, implying degrees or
levels of risk, or as absolute values over a
defined period, preferably with specified
tolerances or margins for error given the
uncertainties. Information security controls
seldom eliminate information risks; hence,
other risk treatments (such as accepting
residual risks) are also appropriate.
“Possibility that a particular threat will
exploit a particular vulnerability of a data
processing system” _(ISO/IEC 2382 )._ “Effect
of uncertainty. Notes: An effect is a
deviation from the expected — positive or
negative. Uncertainty is the state, even
partial, of deficiency of information related
to, understanding or knowledge of, an
event, its consequence, or likelihood. Risk
is often characterized by reference to
potential events ... and consequences ... or
a combination of these. Risk is often


```
expressed in terms of a combination of the
consequences of an event (including
changes in circumstances) and the
associated likelihood ... of occurrence”
(ISO/IEC 42001 ). “A measure of the
negative, unfavorable effect of uncertainty
on objectives” (OCEG GRC Glossary).
“Combination of the probability of
occurrence of harm and the severity of that
harm” (ISO/IEC Guide 51 ). “The
combination of the likelihood of an event
and its impact” (ISACA glossary). “A
measure of the extent to which an entity is
threatened by a potential circumstance or
event, and typically a function of: (i) the
adverse impacts that would arise if the
circumstance or event occurs; and (ii) the
likelihood of occurrence” (NIST CSF). “The
possibility that an event will occur and
adve r sely affect the achievement of
objectives” ( T rust S ervices C riteria). “The
positive or negative effect of uncertainty on
objectives” (IIA GIAS). “The product of the
level of threat with the level of
vulnerability. It establishes the likelihood of
a successful attack” (SANS glossary).
```
**Risk acceptance** Management or personal decision to live

```
with rather than mitigate, share, or avoid a
risk. A form of risk treatment. Ideally such a
decision should be made explicitly
(consciously and deliberately) by a well-
informed, competent, and responsible
person who truly appreciates the
implications but, in practice, risks are often
accepted implicitly (without thinking)
and/or without being recognised and fully
```

```
understood, which itself constitutes a further
risk. “Managerial decision to accept a
certain degree of risk, usually for technical
or cost reasons” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “Informed
decision to take a particular risk. Notes:
Risk acceptance can occur without risk
treatment or during the process of risk
treatment; Accepted risks are subject to
monitoring and review” (ISO/IEC 27005 ).
“A decision to accept a risk, made according
to the risk appetite and risk tolerance set by
senior management, where the enterprise
can assume the risk and absorb any losses”
(ISACA glossary). “The appropriate risk
response when the identified risk is within
the organizational risk tolerance” (NIST SP
800-39).
```
**Risk aggregation** Association or linking of risks relevant to
the subject of analysis. Although risks may
be acceptable when considered individually
( _e.g_. blackouts and data centre fires, each
mitigated by controls), the cumulative
effects with dependencies and common or
compounding factors ( _e.g_. power failure
disabling data centre sprinklers, and fires
disabling power systems) may be
unacceptable. “Combination of a number of
risks into one risk to develop a more
complete understanding of the overall risk”
_(ISO 31073)._ “The process of integrating
risk assessments at a corporate level to
obtain a complete view of the overall risk
for the enterprise” _(ISACA glossary)._

```
Risk-agnostic General-purpose/non-specific control.
“Describes the ability of a capability,
```

```
process or response to address ‘common’
impacts of risks ( i.e. those impacts that
occur across multiple scenarios). For
example, major fires, terrorist incidents and
flooding are all likely to produce mass
casualties; developing capabilities to handle
mass casualties is, therefore, a risk-agnostic
approach” (UK Resilience Lessons Digest
2023 ).
```
**Risk analysis** In-depth analytical, investigative, or
modelling part of risk assessment, a core
part of risk management. “Systematic
method of identifying the assets of a data
processing system, the threats to those
assets, and the vulnerability of the system to
those threats” _(ISO/IEC 2382 )._ “Process to
comprehend the nature of risk and to
determine the level of risk. Notes: Risk
analysis provides the basis for risk
evaluation and decisions about risk
treatment. Risk analysis includes risk
estimation” _(ISO/IEC 27005 )._ “1. A process
by which the frequency and magnitude of
IT risk scenarios are estimated. 2. The initial
steps of risk management: analyzing the
value of assets to the business, identifying
threats to those assets and evaluating how
vulnerable each asset is to those threats.
Note: Risk analysis often involves an
evaluation of the probable frequency of a
particular event, as well as the probable
impact of that event” _(ISACA glossary)._
“Examination of information to identify the
risk to an information system” _(CNSSI
4009 )._


```
Risk appetite Expresses senior management’s willingness
or desire for the organisation to take
(accept) a specified quantity, volume, or
level of risk, provided that (in their opinion)
the likelihood of achieving business
objectives and hence anticipated business
benefits make it advantageous to do so.
Implies a mature, forward-thinking
business-focused strategic outlook. Often
expressed quite subtly, e.g. “We must
consolidate to protect our core business” or
conversely “We are pursuing innovative
opportunities to expand the business.”
“Amount and type of risk that an
organization is willing to pursue or retain”
(ISO/IEC 27005 ). “The amount of risk, on a
broad level, that an entity is willing to
accept in pursuit of its mission” (ISACA
glossary). “The level and type of risk the
organization is WILLING to address given
the level and type of reward it pursues”
(OCEG GRC Glossary). “The types and
amount of risk that an organization is
willing to accept in the pursuit of its
strategies and objectives” (IIA GIAS). “ The
types and amount of risk, on a board level,
an organization is willing to accept in
pursuit of value” (COSO). Cf. risk
tolerance.
```
**Risk articulation** Important part of the rôle of information
risk and security management professionals
involves describing and explaining relevant
risks and related items in terms that not only
make sense to the audiences, but inspire or
motivate them to make appropriate


```
decisions and act accordingly – going
beyond mere awareness.
```
**Risk assessment** Structured, formal process for

```
systematically examining and assessing
information security threats, vulnerabilities,
and impacts relating to a given system,
process, activity, or situation, prior to
determining whether additional controls or
other forms of risk treatment might be
necessary. “Overall process of risk
identification, risk analysis and risk
evaluation” (ISO/IEC 27005 ). “A process
used to identify and evaluate risk and its
potential effects. Notes: Risk assessments
are used to identify those items or areas that
present the highest risk, vulnerability or
exposure to the enterprise for inclusion in
the IS annual audit plan. Risk assessments
are also used to manage the project delivery
and project benefit risk” (ISACA glossary).
“The process of identifying, prioritizing,
and estimating risks. This includes
determining the extent to which adverse
circumstances or events could impact an
enterprise. Uses the results of threat and
vulnerability assessments to identify risk to
organisational operations and evaluates
those risks in terms of likelihood of
occurrence and impacts if they occur. The
product of a risk assessment is a list of
estimated potential impacts and unmitigated
vulnerabilities. Risk assessment is part of
risk management and is conducted
throughout the Risk Management
Framework (RMF)” (CNSSI 4009 ). “The
process of identifying risks to
```

```
organizational operations (including
mission, functions, image, reputation),
organizational assets, individuals, other
organizations, and the Nation, resulting
from the operation of a system” (NIST SP
800-171). “A scientific and technologically
based process consisting of three steps, risk
identification, risk analysis and risk
evaluation” (ENISA RM glossary). “A
structured and auditable process of
identifying potentially significant events,
assessing their likelihood and impacts, and
then combining these to provide an overall
assessment of risk, as a basis for further
decisions and action” (UK Resilience
Lessons Digest 2023 ). “The identification
and analysis of risks relevant to the
achievement of an organization’s objectives.
The significance of risks is typically
assessed in terms of impact and likelihood”
(IIA GIAS). “The process by which risks are
identified and the impact of those risks
determined” (SANS glossary). See also risk
analysis.
```
```
Risk attitude Combination of risk perception and risk
appetite with risk treatment. “Organization’s
approach to assess and eventually pursue,
retain, take or turn away from risk” (ISO
31073 ).
```
**Risk averse, risk
aversion**

```
Low risk appetite, a general reluctance to
accept risks. “Attitude to turn away from
risk” (ISO 31073). “Avoiding risk even if
this leads to the loss of opportunity. For
example, using a (more expensive) phone
call vs. sending an e-mail in order to avoid
```

```
risks associated with e-mail may be
considered ‘Risk Averse’” (SANS glossary).
```
```
Risk avoidance Form of risk treatment. Rather than
mitigating unacceptable risks using controls
or sharing them with third parties, it is
sometimes more appropriate not to enter
into risky situations in the first place ( e.g.
not deploying a risky new I nformation
T echnology system or not entering into a
risky relationship with a dubious partner) or
to pull out ( e.g. prematurely halting a risky
business venture). “Informed decision not to
be involved in, or to withdraw from, an
activity in order not to be exposed to a
particular risk. Note: Risk avoidance can be
based on the result of risk evaluation and/or
legal and regulatory obligations” (ISO
31073 ). “The process for systematically
avoiding risk, constituting one approach to
managing risk” (ISACA glossary).
```
**Risk awareness
program**

```
See security awareness. “A program that
creates an understanding of risk, risk factors
and the various types of risk that an
enterprise faces” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Risk capacity See risk appetite. “The objective magnitude
or amount of loss that an enterprise can
tolerate without risking its continued
existence” (ISACA glossary). “The
MAXIMUM cumulative level and type of
risk that the organization can address.
Anything over the risk capacity may affect
the organization’s survival” (OCEG GRC
Glossary).
```

```
Risk catalogue See risk register.
```
**Risk communication** “Exchange or sharing of information about
risk between the decision maker and other
interested parties. Note: The information
can relate to the existence, nature, form,
probability, severity, acceptability, treatment
or other aspects of risk” _(ISO 22300)._ “Set
of continual and iterative processes that an
organization conducts to provide, share or
obtain information, and to engage in
dialogue with interested parties regarding
the management of risk. Notes: The
information can relate to the existence,
nature, form, likelihood, significance,
evaluation, acceptance and treatment of
risk; Consultation is a two-way process of
informed communication between an
organization and its interested parties on an
issue prior to making a decision or
determining a direction on that issue.
Consultation is: a process which impacts on
a decision through influence rather than
power; an input to decision making, not
joint decision making” _(ISO/IEC 27005)._

```
Risk control See risk treatment. “Measure that maintains
and/or modifies risk. Notes: Risk controls
include, but are not limited to, any process,
policy, device, practice, or other conditions
and/or actions which maintain and/or
modify risk; Risk controls do not always
exert the intended or assumed modifying
effect” (ISO 31073).
```
```
Risk [and] control
matrix
```
```
Table relating risks to the associated
mitigating controls. “A tool that facilitates
```

```
the performance of internal auditing. It
typically links business objectives, risks,
control processes, and key information to
support the internal audit process” (IIA
GIAS).
```
```
Risk criteria Ranges or boundary conditions used to
classify, characterise and determine
priorities and options for treating identified
risks. “Terms of reference against which the
significance of a risk is evaluated. Notes:
Risk criteria are based on organizational
objectives, and external and internal

requirements” (ISO 31073).
```
```
Risk culture Shared, general or typical attitudes towards
risk-taking among a social group or culture.
A highly subjective comparative, dynamic,
and context-dependent assessment. “An
organization ’ s shared values and beliefs that
govern attitudes toward risk-taking, care
and integrity, and determine how openly
risk and losses are reported and discussed”
(ISACA glossary).
```
```
R isk D ata B ase See risk register.
```
**Risk description** Statement succinctly explaining or
characterising a risk in terms that make
sense to the intended audience/s, _e.g._ the
business scenario, technical situation, or
general circumstances in which, due to
various causative factors, the risk may
materialise, causing an incident with
consequences. Given uncertainties about the


```
exact nature, timing, etc ., the description
may be merely a representative/evocative
illustration of a cluster of similar risks or

```
Risk driver See risk factor. “Factor that has a major

hence, it can only ever be _estimated_ with
degrees of confidence ranging between _near_
certainty and sheer finger-in-the-air wild-
arse guesswork.

```
risks. “Process of comparing the results of

evaluation assists in the decision about risk
treatment” (ISO/IEC 27005).

```
Risk factor Factor, parameter, or characteristic relevant

vulnerability, exposure, impact, control,
treatment, severity, likelihood, decision
quality, dynamics, trend, environment, ...
“A condition that can influence the

```

```
Risk financing Contingency arrangements to fund the

Risk governance Risk governance. “Provides the

characterisation of the potential existence of

Notes: Risk identification involves the

Risk identification can involve historical

Risk indicator Information that flags or demonstrates a risk

documenting the overall risk
```

management program” _(CNSSI 4009 )_.

and responding to risk” _(NIST CSF)_.

resources to address risk while

b. Specialist corporate

in the management of financial and

audit

process

situation or incident that stresses the
regional, national, or international socio-
economic system (such as a pandemic or
trade war) can increase the probability
and/or impact of risks such as ransomware
infections, hacks, or cybertage destabilising
and perhaps disrupting an organisation’s
supply chains (affecting its suppliers,
partners, and customers).
```
**R** isk **O** f **I** ncarceration
**(ROI)**

```
Leet term for the possibility of a lawbreaker
(such as a hacker or fraudster) being caught
and imprisoned. Cf. R eturn O n I nvestment.
```
```
Risk owner Organisation, rôle, or person who notionally
‘owns’ and may be held to account if a risk
eventuates, causing unacceptable impacts,
on the basis that they patently failed to
ensure it was adequately treated, e.g.
mitigated with controls. As the explicit or
implicit owner of residual risk, they also
have an interest in the incident management
and business continuity arrangements.
“Person or entity with the accountability
and authority to manage a risk” (ISO/IEC
27005 ). “The person in whom the
organization has invested the authority and
accountability for making risk-based
decisions and who owns the loss associated
with a realized risk scenario. Note: The risk
owner may not be responsible for the
implementation of risk treatment” (ISACA
glossary).
```
```
Risk perception Awareness, appreciation and understanding
of risk. “Interested party’s view on risk.
Note: Risk perception reflects the interested
```

```
party’s needs, issues, knowledge, beliefs
and values” (ISO 31073).
```
```
Risk portfolio view “1. A method to identify interdependencies
and interconnections among risk, as well as
the effect of risk responses on multiple
types of risk. 2. A method to estimate the
aggregate impact of multiple types of risk
( e.g ., cascading and coincidental threat
types or scenarios, or risk concentration or
correlation across silos) and the potential
effect of risk response across multiple types
of risk” (ISACA glossary).
```
**Risk profile, risk
landscape, risk surface**

```
Conceptual three-dimensional view (profile)
of the organisation’s risks relative to each
other. In practice, most risks are difficult to
quantify, many change dynamically, and it
is tough to compare markedly different
kinds of risk; hence, this is a subjective
perspective. A security metric. “Description
of any set of risks. Note: The set of risks
can contain those that relate to the whole
organization, part of the organization, or as
otherwise defined” (ISO Guide 73 ). See also
security landscape, risk universe, attack
surface, heatmap.
```
```
Risk rating matrix See risk matrix. “A table showing the
likelihood and potential impact of events or
situations, in order to ascertain and visualise
risks” (UK Resilience Lessons Digest 2023).
```
```
Risk reduction See risk mitigation. “Actions taken to lessen
the probability or negative consequences, or
both, associated with a risk” (ISO 22300).
“The implementation of controls or
```

```
countermeasures to reduce the likelihood or
impact of a risk to a level within the
organization’s risk tolerance” (ISACA
glossary).
```
**Risk register, risk
inventory, risk
catalogue, risk list, risk
log, risk DataBase, ...**

```
Essentially a list, table or D ata B ase of
identified risks, normally with additional
details resulting from some form of risk
analysis giving users the ability to sort or
prioritise the list on criteria such as impact,
likelihood, current status, risk type, assets
affected, and risk owners. The scope of the
register may include all risks to the
organisation, all significant or key risks
(howsoever determined and specified), or
one or more subsets or categories of risk
such as information risks, compliance risks,
market and product risks, health and safety
risks, financial risks, currency risks, and
strategic risks. “Record of information
about identified risks. Note: Compilation for
all risks identified, analysed and evaluated
in the risk assessment process, including
information on the risk register includes
information on likelihood, consequences,
treatments and risk owners” (ISO 22300).
“A list of risk scenarios that have been
identified, analyzed and prioritized” (ISACA
glossary).
```
```
Risk reporting Provision of pertinent information
concerning risk. “Form of communication
intended to inform particular internal or
external interested party by providing
information regarding the current state of
risk and its management” (ISO 31073).
```

```
Risk response See risk treatment. “Accepting, avoiding,
mitigating, sharing, or transferring risk to
organizational operations ( i.e ., mission,
functions, image, or reputation),
organizational assets, individuals, other
organizations, or the Nation” (NIST SP 800-
39 ). “Any combination of risk avoidance,
risk acceptance, risk sharing or transfer, or
risk mitigation that leads to a situation in
which as much future residual risk ( i.e .,
current risk with the risk response defined
and implemented) as possible (usually
depending on budgets available) falls within
risk appetite limits” (ISACA glossary).
“Accepting, avoiding, mitigating, sharing,
or transferring risk to agency operations,
agency assets, individuals, other
organizations, or the Nation” (OMB
Circular A-130). “The decision to accept,
avoid, reduce, or share a risk” ( T rust
S ervices C riteria).
```
**Risk response measure** “A specific action taken to respond to an
identified risk” _(NIST SP 800-39)._

```
Risk retention See risk acceptance. “ Temporary
acceptance of the potential benefit of gain,
or burden of loss, from a particular risk.
Notes: Retention can be restricted to a
certain period of time; The level of risk
retained can depend on risk criteria”
(ISO/IEC 27005 ). “Acceptance of the
potential benefit of gain, or burden of loss,
from a particular risk. Note: Risk retention
includes the acceptance of residual risks.
The level of risk retained can depend on risk
criteria” (ISO Guide 73).
```

```
Risk scenario Hypothetical situation used for risk analysis,
security awareness and training, planning
and preparation purposes, in which one or
more threats materialise, exploiting exposed
vulnerabilities causing incidents. “Sequence
or combination of events leading from the
initial cause to the unwanted consequence”
(ISO/IEC 27005 ). “A tangible and
assessable representation of risk. Note: One
of the key information items needed to
identify, analyze and respond to risk”
(ISACA glossary).
```
```
Risk scope The scope of a risk. “The selection of items
included in the risk activities, based on
understanding the full risk universe and then
down-selecting to the specific part of the
enterprise to which the risk activities will be
applied” (ISACA glossary).
```
**Risk sharing, risk
transfer**

```
Treating risk by passing a substantial
proportion to a third party, such as an
insurer, stakeholder, customer, business
partner, auditor, standards body, regulator,
or authority. To an extent, the third party
accepts and indemnifies the directly
impacted organisation against the
consequences of incidents, in some cases
accepting defined liabilities. “Form of risk
treatment involving the agreed distribution
of risk with other parties. Notes: Legal or
regulatory requirements can limit, prohibit
or mandate risk sharing. Risk sharing can be
carried out through insurance or other forms
of contract. The extent to which risk is
distributed can depend on the reliability and
```

```
clarity of the sharing arrangements. Risk
transfer is a form of risk sharing” (ISO/IEC
27005 ).
```
**RISKS List, RISKS
Digest, RISKS Forum**

```
Since August 1985, the “ACM Committee
on Computers and Public Policy – Forum
on Risks to the Public in Computers and
Related Systems, ” chaired by Peter G.
Neumann, has produced a regular newsletter
concerning risks, incidents, controls,
security, privacy, safety, etc. involving
computers.
```
```
Risk source Origin or cause of an incident. “Element
which alone or in combination has the
potential to give rise to risk. Notes: A risk
source can be one of these three types:
human; environmental; technical. A human
risk source type can be intentional or
unintentional” (ISO/IEC 27005 ). “Element
which alone or in combination has the
intrinsic potential to give rise to risk. Note:
A risk source can be tangible or intangible”
(ISO Guide 73). See also threat agent.
```
```
Risk target “The level and type of risk the organization
EXPECTS to address given the level and
type of reward it pursues” (OCEG GRC
Glossary).
```
```
Risk taxonomy Categorisation or grouping together of risks
of similar types, natures, significance,
scopes, etc. Can help ensure that all relevant
risks are considered on a comparable basis,
but can lead to a confusing picture ( e.g. a
serious risk to the financial system may be
classified as business, financial,
```

```
technological, I nformation T echnology,
data, system, cybersecurity, serious, or some
other kind of risk). “A scheme for
classifying sources and categories of risk
that provides a common language for
discussing and communicating risk to
stakeholders ” (ISACA glossary).
```
**Risk tolerance** Relates to the mathematical concept of a

```
range defined by tolerance limits or bounds
within which the values (of risk in this case)
are deemed acceptable. A way to define
criteria for treating risks. Often confused or
conflated with risk appetite as in the amount
of risk deemed tolerable by management.
“The acceptable level of variation that
management is willing to allow for any
particular risk as the enterprise pursues its
objectives [and] Risk that is within a
tolerable or acceptable range, based on
management ’ s appetite” (ISACA glossary).
“Organization’s or interested party’s
readiness to bear the residual risk in order to
achieve its objectives. Note: Risk tolerance
can be influenced by legal or regulatory
requirements” (ISO 31073). “The level and
type of risk the organization is
UNWILLING to exceed given the level and
type of reward it pursues” (OCEG GRC
Glossary). “Acceptable variations in
performance related to achieving
objectives” (IIA GIAS).
```
```
Risk transfer See risk sharing. “The process of assigning
risk to another enterprise, usually through
the purchase of an insurance policy or by
outsourcing the service” (ISACA glossary).
```

```
Risk treatment Method to deal with ( i.e. mitigate, share,
avoid, or accept) one or more identified
risks. “Process to modify risk. Notes: Risk
treatment can involve: avoiding the risk by
deciding not to start or continue with the
activity that gives rise to the risk; taking or
increasing risk in order to pursue an
opportunity; removing the risk source;
changing the likelihood; changing the
consequences; sharing the risk with another
party or parties (including contracts and risk
financing); and retaining the risk by
informed decision; Information security risk
treatment does not include ‘taking or
increasing risk in order to pursue an
opportunity’ but the organization can have
this option for general risk management.
Risk treatments that deal with negative
consequences are sometimes referred to as
‘risk mitigation,’ ‘risk elimination,’ ‘risk
prevention’ and ‘risk reduction.’ Risk
treatment can create new risks or modify
existing risks” (ISO/IEC 27005 ). “Measures
to reduce the likelihood of an emergency
occurring from a given risk, and/or
implement measures to mitigate the impacts
of that emergency should arise” (UK
Resilience Lessons Digest 2023).
```
**R** isk **T** reatment **P** lan
**(RTP)**

```
Formally documented approach to address
identified risks by resourcing,
designing/selecting, implementing, and
monitoring and maintaining suitable risk
treatments within an ISO/IEC 27001
I nformation S ecurity M anagement S ystem.
Can be an implementation project plan,
security improvement strategy, or
```

```
something more creative (the standard is not
prescriptive). Cf. R eal-time T ransport
P rotocol.

landscape**

```
High-level broad perspective on all kinds of

“An enterprise ’ s overall conception of risk,
which encompasses the overall risk
environment, defines the areas that risk
management activities will address and
provides a structure for information and
technology (I&T)-related risk management ”
(ISACA glossary).

```
Robot Robotic electromechanical device,

some extent autonomously (according to its
programming) to perform various
designated tasks. Derived from a Czech
word for ‘slavery.’ “Automation system
with actuators that performs intended tasks
in the physical world, by means of sensing
its environment and a software control
system. Notes: A robot includes the control

The classification of a robot as industrial
robot or service robot is done according to
its intended application; In order to properly
perform its tasks, a robot makes use of
```

```
different kinds of sensors to confirm its
current state and perceive the elements
composing the environment in which it

```

Robotics Engineering discipline concerning the

(ISO/IEC 22989 ). “The design,

or semiautonomous machines capable of

```
**Robustness** Form of resilience characterised by the
inherent strength of a system, network,
service, process, lock, wall, barrier,
organisation, team, person, _etc.,_ rendering it
invulnerable to incidents that would damage
or cause weaker ones to fail or falter.
Conceptually and practically different to the
capability to failover, failsafe or recover,
robust systems, _etc._ are less likely to fail
and need to be restored to service: they
simply carry on working reliably, albeit
perhaps with reduced performance and/or
functionality (fallback). “Ability of a system
to maintain its level of performance under
any circumstances” _(ISO/IEC 22989 )._
“Ability of a system to resist virtual or
physical, internal or external attacks. Note:
Particularly, the ability to resist attempted
imitation, copy, intrusion or bypassing”
_(ISO 22300)._ “The degree to which a
software system or component can function
correctly in the presence of invalid inputs or


```
stressful environmental conditions” (ISACA
glossary). “Information Assurance entity to
operate correctly and reliably across a wide
range of operational conditions, and to fail
gracefully outside of that operational range”
(CNSSI 4009).
```
```
ROCU Abbrev: R egional O rganised C rime U nit.
```
```
Rogue Someone or something at the boundaries of
social acceptability in some way, pushing or
exceeding the limits, often unauthorised and
potentially or actually malicious ( e.g. rogue
devices or things that somehow manage to
connect to a network). Potentially ‘lovable,’
to a limited extent. More likely a vagrant,
scoundrel, and outcast.
```
```
Rogue address Disinformation about the location of a
resource, such as an I nternet P rotocol
address pointing to a malicious domain,
web page, or file, surreptitiously substituted
for the legitimate address in a D omain
N ame S ystem poisoning attack.
```
**Rogue software** Free or cheap software that is advertised
and appears to be legitimate, often security-
related ( _e.g._ antivirus programs, anti-
spyware software, and password vaults), but
is itself a Trojan, spyware, or other
malware. See also **P** otentially **U** nwanted
**P** rogram.

```
Rogue system Unauthorised computer system or thing
connected illicitly to the network, perhaps a
P ersonally O wned D evice not approved for
B ring Y our O wn D evice, or a system
```

```
installed by a spy to monitor or intercept
network traffic, perhaps to launch hacking
attacks on authorised network systems.
```
**Rogue wireless access
point**

```
Unauthorised Wi-Fi access point connected
to a network, typically installed at work by
well-meaning but naïve workers who fail to
appreciate the additional information risks
created by the wireless coverage, perhaps
not even realising that wired routers and
other devices may also have wireless
capabilities. “An unauthorised Wireless
Access Point operating outside of the
control of an agency” (NZISM).
```
```
ROI, RoI Abbrev: R eturn O n I nvestment or R isk O f
I ncarceration, depending on context.
```
```
Rôle, role Main function or purpose of a worker or
person interacting with a system or
performing a process. Rôles and job
descriptions generally change less often
than the people who perform them, and
hence require less maintenance than the

procedures.
```
```
R ôle -B ased A ccess
C ontrol (RBAC)
```
```
Access control scheme whereby users are
granted certain system, application, and/or
data access rights according to the particular
rôles they are required to perform for the
organisation and the access policy for the
information assets. Typically implemented
through some combination of group and
individual access rights, e.g. using ACLs.
“Access control based on user roles ( i.e ., a
collection of access authorizations a user
```

```
receives based on an explicit or implicit
assumption of a given role). Role
permissions may be inherited through a role
hierarchy and typically reflect the
permissions needed to perform defined
functions within an organisation. A given
role may apply to a single individual or to
several individuals” (CNSSI 4009 ). “Model
employs pre-defined roles that carry a
specific set of privileges associated with
them and to which subjects are assigned”
(NZISM). “Assigns users to roles based on
their organizational functions and
determines authorization based on those
rôles” (SANS glossary).Cf. R ule- B ased
A ccess C ontrol, R ealm- B ased Access

system administrator on UNIX

CAPITALS. “Name of the

b. Fundamental basis or lowest level of
something, such as the folder structure
on a disk, the chain of digital
certificates in a P ublic K ey
I nfrastructure, of trust, or of problem
causes.
Cf. route.
```
```
Root cause Fundamental issues, reasons, or failures that
could have and perhaps did lead to, or failed
to prevent, or might yet cause, an incident.
Failing to identify and deal with the root
```

```
causes (plural!) is a common reason for
recurring incidents, but even if they are

to remedy, so tend to persist. “The
underlying source of a defect or problem”
(ISACA glossary). “Core issue or underlying
reason for the difference between the
criteria and the condition of an activity
under review” (IIA GIAS).
```
**Root cause analysis** Systematic and thorough determination and

```
examination of root causes. “A process of
diagnosis to establish the origins of events
that can be used for learning from

based, systems approach for the

(NIST SP 800-39).
```
```
Root certificate Self-signed digital certificate belonging to a
C ertification A uthority, used to sign
certificates issued by the CA.
```
**R** oot of **T** rust **(RoT)** Secure computing relies on the

```
trustworthiness of the D ata P rocessing and
storage equipment, down to the level of the
I ntegrated C ircuits and firmware. Designing
truly secure systems involves attention to
technical details such as the P ower- O n S elf-
T est and boot sequence, T rusted P latform
M odules, JTAG ports, anti-tampering, and
other physical security controls.
```
```
Rooting a. Process of gaining unauthorised ROOT
(fully privileged) access to an
```

```
I nformation T echnology system,
normally by hacking it or installing a
rootkit.
b. Vulgar term for sexual intercourse.
Cf. routing.
```
**Rootkit** Hacker toolset typically containing malware

```
such as Trojans used to take and retain full
control of a compromised computer system.
Often includes hacked variants of normal
O perating S ystem or utility programs with
backdoors and other covert functions to
conceal the compromise and persist. May be
surreptitiously installed at any stage of the
S oftware or S ystem D evelopment
L ife C ycle, including during manufacture
(perhaps inserted by the authorities or
spooks for national security reasons).
Usually hidden deep in the system kernel,
device drivers, firmware, or microcode, and
may actively evade detection ( e.g. by
manipulating the system calls and functions
used for folder/file listings), hence very
hard to identify and eradicate. “A software
suite designed to aid an intruder in gaining
unauthorized administrative access to a
computer system” (ISACA glossary). “A
collection of tools (programs) that a hacker
uses to mask intrusion and obtain
administrator-level access to a computer or
computer network” (SANS glossary). See
also bootkit.
```

ROP Abbrev: R eturn- O riented P rogramming.

```

```
ROT13 Trivial, extremely weak substitution
function that simply ‘rotates’ each character
in the plaintext 13 positions through the
letters of the normal English alphabet
arranged in a circle. Since there are 26
letters in the alphabet, ROT13 has the
equally trivial advantage of being reversible
simply by repeating the same process.
Barely adequate for naughty kids to conceal
rude words from their elders.
```
```
Round a. Cycle. Most cryptographic algorithms
repeat steps such as transposition and
substitution several times in a specific
sequence: each run through the
sequence is called a round.
b. Approximation process to reduce the
precision of a number, typically for
convenience. According to the
mathematical function chosen for the
purpose, numbers may be rounded up
(increased to the next higher round or
whole number), rounded down
(reduced to the next lower round or
whole number), or rounded off (moved
up or down to the nearest round or
whole number, possibly with a rule to
handle a middle value consistently).
```

Route See communication path.

**Router, routing** Network device that forwards traffic

```
towards its destination via appropriate paths
through a network. Using protocols such as
```

```
B order G ateway P rotocol, a router builds,
shares, and maintains its internal routing
tables with pertinent details of paths ( e.g.
the number of hops through intermediate
routers, and transit time/delay) and their
status (up and stable, unstable or down).
“Functional unit that establishes a path
through one or more computer networks.
Note: In computer networks conforming to
the OSI model, a router operates at the
network layer” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “Network
device that is used to establish and control
the flow of data between different networks
by selecting paths or routes based upon
routing protocol mechanisms and
algorithms. Notes: The networks can
themselves be based on different protocols.
The routing information is kept in a routing
table” (ISO/IEC 27033-1). “A networking
device that can send (route) data packets
from one local area network (LAN) or wide
area network (WAN) to another, based on
addressing at the network layer (Layer 3) in
the open systems interconnection (OSI)
model. Notes: Networks connected by
routers can use different or similar
networking protocols. Routers usually are
capable of filtering packets based on
parameters such as source addresses,
destination addresses, protocols and
network applications (ports)” (ISACA
glossary).
```
**Rowhammer** Exploit that flips bits in memory directly
using electrical properties of high-density
memory chips: if particular areas (rows) of
RAM are repeatedly accessed (hammered)


```
by malware, physically adjacent memory
bits may be flipped due to leakage currents
in the silicon, even if those bits are in
supposedly protected memory that cannot
be accessed through applications or by
conventional malware. The flipped bits, in
turn, may affect system security, e.g.
granting additional privileges, permissions,
or rights.
```

restrictions, licences, agreements, and

```

```

```
Safe Harbor US privacy laws are so different from the information
protection laws in Europe and elsewhere that many non-
US organisations may be legally forbidden from sending
personal information to the US without additional
information security. The Safe Harbor scheme was
introduced as a way for US organisations to assert or self-
certify their compliance voluntarily. Widely discredited
and distrusted due to poor design, limited compliance, and
```

```
especially the obvious conflicts of interest, the scheme
finally collapsed in 2015 when ruled invalid by the
European Court of Justice. Replaced by Privacy Shield the
following year.

```

key domains of safety are workplace environment and
functional safety” (ISACA glossary). “The need to ensure
that the people involved with the company, including
employees, customers, and visitors, are protected from

security incident could therefore have grave impacts, e.g.
injury or death; hence, control systems should be designed
to fail-safe. Cf. tier 1, 2, or 3, business-critical.

```
```
Fraud in which the fraudster steals small amounts of
money through lots of separate transactions (like thin
slices of salami), each individual theft being so
insignificant as to escape the victim’s notice or concern
while accumulating a tidy sum for the fraudster. If a
discrepancy even comes to their attention, a victim will
typically assume the deficit or debit is simply a
consequence of legitimate rounding or measuring errors,
whereas it may be deliberate, unethical, illegitimate, and
perhaps illegal. “A method of computer fraud involving a
computer code that instructs the computer to slice off
small amounts of money from authorized transactions and
```

```
reroute these amounts to the perpetrator’s account”

specific to the system when hashing passwords, etc., such
