across systems. Unless the salt is also compromised along
with the hash file, salting frustrates attacks using rainbow
tables. “Random data string added to the start or the end
of a hash to strengthen its resistance to attack. Typically
used in the generation of a password hash or checksums”
(NZISM).

**Sandbox, jail, walled
garden**

```
System partition and other security controls intended to
prevent applications from accessing unauthorised
resources, particularly privileged O perating S ystem
function calls and address spaces beyond the restricted
range. Used for security testing, malware detection and
analysis, etc. Typically implemented as a virtual machine
emulating a specific OS. Analogous to keeping the kids
occupied in a play-pen: fine so long as they don’t escape
and go nuts with the crayons. “Using an isolated
environment for testing purposes” (ISACA glossary). See
also jailbreak.
```
```
Sanitisation Process or act of sanitising. “Process or method to
sanitize” (ISO/IEC 27040 ). “Actions taken to render data
written on media unrecoverable by ordinary and — for
some forms of sanitization — extraordinary means. A
process to remove information from media such that data
recovery is not possible, including the removal of all
classified labels, markings, and activity logs” (NIST SP
800-171).
```
```
Sanitise Securely overwrite, delete, or destroy sensitive data such
as personal information, passwords, and encryption keys
from storage media such that the information cannot later
be recovered or restored, even by thorough forensic
means. Theoretically unnecessary with strongly encrypted
data but in practice safer than relying indefinitely on the
strength of the encryption and confidentiality of the key.
“Removing sensitive information from a document to
```

```
reduce its sensitivity” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “Process to
remove information from media such that data recovery is
not possible at a given level of effort. Note: Clear, purge,
and destruct are actions that can be taken to sanitize
storage media” (ISO/IEC 27040 and ISO/IEC 27050-1).
“The process of making potentially harmful data safe
through the use of data removal, replacement, encoding or
escaping of the characters” (SCP QRG). See also zero-fill,
secure destruction, shredding, redaction.
```
```
Sanity test a. See smoke test.
b. Checks to determine whether a person or A rtificial
I ntelligence system is losing, or has lost, his/her/its
marbles, and has a screw loose. Is there any hope of a
return to rationality and sensible decisions, or are
there bats in the belfry? One sandwich short of a
picnic maybe, away with the fairies, more nuts than
an autumnal squirrel, lost the plot or plain bonkers?
Are the lights on but no one is home? Crazy as a box
of frogs? These are all euphemisms for someone who
inhabits a parallel reality, believes alternative facts in
a post-truth world, a knucklehead who keeps on
doing the same things while expecting different
results.
```

**Scalability, scaling,

```
Highly automated capability to alter the capacity and
performance of a system dynamically in response to, or in
expectation of, changes in demand, loading, or priorities,
typically by changing the number of allocated/assigned
resources ( e.g. cloud servers, virtual clusters, C entral
P rocessing U nits, or network paths) to maintain a

```
Scale Reference points for the absolute or relative measurement
of parameters such as quantity, size, volume, risk,
severity, and disaster. “Ordered set of values, continuous
or discrete, or a set of categories to which the attribute is
mapped. Note: the type of scale depends on the nature of
the relationship between values on the scale. Four types of
scale are commonly defined: nominal – the measurement
values are categorical; ordinal – the measurement values
```

```
are rankings; interval – the measurement values have
equal distances corresponding to equal quantities of the
attribute; ratio – the measurement values have equal
distances corresponding to equal quantities of the
attribute, where the value of zero corresponds to none of
the attribute. These are just examples of the types of
scale” (ISO/IEC/IEEE 15939).
```
```
Scam Relatively basic/simple form of fraud committed by a
scammer that normally (but not always) causes minor
impacts on each individual victim but may lead on to
more substantial incidents. Can be significant in aggregate
since most scams are ‘a numbers game.’ See also
scareware.
```
**Scammer** Low-life fraudster who commits a scam. Whereas career
criminals and fraudsters are sometimes portrayed as
cheeky chappies and lovable rogues, scammers are the
lowest-of-the-low, marginalised and despised by
everybody _including_ their peers (since they take
‘untrustworthy’ to new depths) and even, on occasions,
themselves. Entirely selfish and mean-spirited, they have
absolutely no compunction about preying on the
vulnerable, young, elderly, sick, charitable, naïve, and
intellectually challenged, let alone fine upstanding
members of society. They would _literally_ sell their own
grandmothers if only they could find a buyer dumb
enough to fall for their spiel and trust that they would ever
deliver on a deal. When caught (for they are not, as a
breed, the most significant bits in a byte), they invariably
plead poverty and desperation as if that somehow explains
and excuses their bare-faced total disregard for the
accepted social norms and reasonable expectation of any
civilised society. Incarceration and lethal injections are
too humane for them. “Off with their goolies” we say!

```

More malicious forms include bluff ransomware. See also
ransomware, adware, crimeware, spouseware,
stalkerware, spyware.

**Second line [of defence
or accountability]**

```
In the three lines model, the second line provides expert
assistance on risk management to the first line, and in turn
is overseen and audited by the third line. “Individuals and
teams that establish performance, risk, and compliance
programs for the First Line. The Second Line provides

```
Secret, secrecy Extraordinarily confidential, extremely sensitive, and/or
business-critical information that must therefore be
strongly protected against unauthorised or inappropriate
access. Examples include an organisation’s strategies,
plans, Board minutes, system security information ( e.g.
passwords, keys, firewall rules), extremely valuable trade
secrets, and other I ntellectual P roperty. “Data and/or
knowledge that are protected against disclosure to
unauthorised entities” (ISO 22300).
```
```
SECRET Commonplace classification label (often CAPITALISED
for emphasis) for highly confidential information that
must remain secret. Applies to a significant amount of
governmental and military/defence information. While the
intention is reasonably self-evident, the label, definition,
and associated controls are organisation- and context-
specific. “Information, the unauthorized disclosure of
which reasonably could be expected to cause serious
damage to the national security that the original
classification authority is able to identify or describe”
(Executive Order 13526). Cf. CONFIDENTIAL and TOP
SECRET.
```

communicate SECRET data. Such areas are not
```

```
necessarily tied to a specific level of security zone”
(AusISM).
```
```
Secret code Basic type of covert communications code explicitly
intended to be understood easily by the intended
recipient/s ( e.g. can often be decoded manually without
the need for computer technology) but unintelligible (not
so readily decoded) if intercepted by third parties. May be
physically concealed ( e.g. written in ‘secret ink,’ tattooed
under the hairline of a messenger), use simple substitution
( e.g. ROT13, code book), or rely on obscurity ( e.g. slang,
Navajo code-talkers, passwords). Generally weak and
vulnerable to cryptanalysis, e.g. “Attack at dawn!” might
be represented or signalled by the seemingly innocuous
mention of, say, “native daffodils” at some point in an
otherwise legitimate news broadcast, web page, press
release, blog posting, tweet, or private advertisement in
the personal columns of a national newspaper. Cf. encode,
encryption, steganography, war chalking.
```
```

S ervice (SIS), MI6
( M ilitary I ntelligence
branch 6)

```

cryptography; hence, keeping it confidential is crucial to

integrity and availability are crucial for authorised
purposes. “Key that is intended for use by a limited
number of correspondents for encryption and decryption”
(ISO/IEC 2382). Cf. private key.

specified minimal/baseline level of security under all
foreseeable circumstances. “A software development
principle whereby security is designed into every stage of
a product or service’s development” (AusISM). “Software,
hardware and systems that have been designed from the
ground up to be secure” (UK National Cyber Security
Strategy 2022). See also failsafe. Cf. secure-by-default.

```
Security, secure State in which assets are adequately protected to prevent,
resist, or survive incidents. A relative measure since
perfect or absolute security is literally unattainable in any
real world situation: even assets protected by strong
controls remain vulnerable to extreme, novel, or currently
unappreciated/unrecognised threats that happen to negate,
overwhelm, bypass, or undermine the controls, and to
control failures. “State of relative freedom from threat or
harm caused by deliberate, unwanted, hostile or malicious
acts” (ISO 19650-5). “Resistance to intentional,
```

```
unauthorized act(s) designed to cause harm or damage to a
system” (ISO/IEC 23643 ). “ A condition that results from
the establishment and maintenance of protective measures
that enable an organization to perform its mission or
critical functions despite risks posed by threats to its use
of systems. Protective measures may involve a
combination of deterrence, avoidance, prevention,
detection, recovery, and correction that should form part
of the organization’s risk management approach” (NIST
SP 800-171). See also information security.

security administration and other security functions, and

and applicable security, privacy, and safety controls plus
potential impacts on the existing infrastructure,
organisation, business, etc ., both during and following
implementation. See also security audit.

```

programme [or

**Security log, security-
related log file, security

```
Security log. Most I nformation T echnology systems,
applications and security appliances, and some devices,
generate records of events (such as successful access to
the system or card access-controlled door) and incidents
(such as failed access attempts) that are stored in logs, as
well as triggering alarms and alerts in specific situations
(such as when log settings or other security parameters are
changed, or when multiple events occur together).
Security logs are a critical source of evidence supporting
subsequent forensic analysis of security-relevant
situations, provided they are adequately secured against
unauthorised access, tampering, falsification,
manipulation, corruption, deletion, overwriting, or
wholesale replacement by the perpetrators or anyone else.
Security logs should be retained for as long as is
necessary to complete the review and analysis, or
according to legal and/or business requirements typically
identified in a policy. See also audit trail.
```

classification, categorization, and/or handling restrictions
applicable to the information contained therein. For
intelligence information, these could include compartment
and sub-compartment indicators and handling restrictions”
(CNSSI 4009).
```

resilience” _(ISO 22300)._ “The process of establishing and
maintaining security for a computer or network system.
Notes: The stages of the process of security management
include prevention of security problems, detection of
intrusions and investigation of intrusions and resolution.
In network management, the stages comprise controlling
access to the network and resources, finding intrusions,
identifying entry points for intruders and repairing or
otherwise closing those avenues of access” _(ISACA
glossary)._

Security policy Corporate or national policy covering one or more aspects

```

an organisation, i.e. how secure it believes or claims itself
to be. Part of its brand and reputation with a deterrent
```

```
effect and value, especially if the posture truly reflects
reality. “The level of security risk to which a system is
exposed. A system with a strong security posture is
exposed to a low level of security risk while a system with
a weak security posture is exposed to a high level of
security risk” (AusISM).
```
```
Security procedure Description of a security process. “The formal

[or program]

a. Strategy/approach, governance structure, and/or
plan/schedule for the organisation’s security-related
activities, both ongoing and forthcoming. Note:
usually spelled ‘programme’ in British English.
b. Security-related application, e.g. antivirus. Note:
usually spelled ‘program’ by the Brits.

rating
```

Metric for a security programme.

```
**Security requirement** Requirement for or relating to security. “A requirement
levied on a system or an organization that is derived from
applicable laws, Executive Orders, directives, regulations,
policies, standards, procedures, or mission/business needs
to ensure the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of
information that is being processed, stored, or
transmitted” _(NIST SP 800-171)._ “A set of design and
functional requirements that help ensure the software is
built and deployed in a secure manner” _(SCP QRG)._

```
Security researcher See hacker. Black or grey hat hackers with dubious
pedigrees and unclear or nefarious motivations often
claim to be white hat ‘security researchers’ but unless they
have been explicitly commissioned and authorised to test
security by the owners of the affected networks, systems,
```

```
devices, applications, etc., their efforts are generally
unwelcome, unethical, and may well be illegal. Genuine,
legitimate security researchers include authorised system,
application and penetration testers, and computer
scientists.
```
```
Security resilience a. Resilience of the information risk and security
management function, i.e. its ability to keep the
business on top of information risks, handle routine
security events and incidents competently, and
establish and maintain the capability to cope with
disasters.
b. Resilience in general or just of the corporate security
arrangements or function/s. “The ability to prepare
for and adapt to changing conditions and withstand
and recover rapidly from security disruptions,
including cybersecurity. Resilience includes the
capability to withstand and recover from deliberate
attack, accidents or naturally occurring threats,
vulnerabilities or other security events” (ISACA
glossary).
```
**Security review and
evaluation**

```
Review and evaluation of the organisation’s security
arrangements against requirements specified in security
strategies, policies and initiatives, compliance obligations,
and good practices, plus general business objectives and
expectations such as efficient and cost-effective
performance. Such areas are typically covered by high-
level security metrics, suggesting aspects worthy of
greater or lesser attention, improvement, and assurance.
“The coverage or inclusion of security needs, constraints,
efforts and activities in a continuous manner over time
throughout the life cycle of a solution or when triggered
by a security event. These reviews and evaluations focus
on identifying and addressing, and when possible,
preventing the most critical and urgent security issues
first. Security events, trends, potential threats and
disruptions can also trigger reviews or evaluations”
(ISACA glossary).
```
```
Security risk The uncertain possibility of security incidents such as
invasion by hostile forces. “Any event that could result in
```

```
the compromise, loss of integrity or unavailability of data
or resources, or deliberate harm to people measured in
terms of its likelihood and consequences” (AusISM). See
also information risk and information security risk.
```
```
Security risk appetite Management’s willingness, preparedness, or desire to
accept (take) some security-related risks. “Statements that
communicate the expectations of an organisation’s senior
management about their security risk tolerance. These
criteria help an organisation identify security risks,
prepare appropriate treatments and provide a benchmark
against which the success of mitigations can be measured”
(AusISM).
```
```
Security risk
management

```

process of identifying, assessing and taking steps to
reduce security risks to an acceptable level” (AusISM).

Security risk
management plan

```
See R isk T reatment P lan. “A plan that identifies the risks
and appropriate risk treatments including controls needed
to meet agency policy” (NZISM).

```
Security screw, one-
way screw

```
Tough, tamper-resistant fixture with a specially shaped
head making it easy to insert and tighten but hard to
loosen and remove. Some designs are removable using a
special tool but most (including bolts with hexagonal
heads that shear off at a certain torque once they are in
tight, leaving just a plain, embedded surface) are meant to

frames, locks, etc. firmly in place.

information, security-

“Number associated with the amount of work that is

```
**S** ecurity **T** arget **(ST)** Under **C** ommon **C** riteria, a set of specific security
requirements for an **I** nformation **T** echnology product
associated with a specific implementation as opposed to
the generic **P** rotection **P** rofile. “An artefact of Common
Criteria evaluations. It contains the information security
requirements of an identified target of evaluation and
specifies the functional and assurance security measures
offered by that target of evaluation to meet the stated
requirements” _(NZISM).“_ An artefact of Common Criteria
evaluations that specifies conformance claims, threats and
assumptions, security objectives, and security
requirements for an evaluated product” _(AusISM)._

```
Security test Test of the security protecting, provided by, or relating to
one or more computer systems, subsystems, devices,
units, interfaces, networks, D ata B ases, functions,
```

```
processes, controls, services, suppliers, models,
assumptions/beliefs, governance and management
arrangements, documentation, rôles, responsibilities,
accountabilities, architectures, policies, strategies, tactics,
plans, changes, issues/concerns, incidents, performance,
capacity, resilience, recovery, response, compliance,
conformity, etc. against the requirements specifications,
designs, and/or applicable standards and reasonable
ethical expectations to gain assurance regarding the
associated risks and, where relevant, drive improvements.
The nature, extent, and depth of testing, and hence the
assurance provided, range from a small, almost incidental
part of unit, integration, system, and self-assessments in
low-risk situations, up to major in-depth assessments,
penetration tests, or audits by teams of independent,
competent, experienced, and highly skilled specialists for
those that are business-, mission-, or safety-critical.
“Assurance that the modified or new system includes
appropriate controls and does not introduce any security
holes that might compromise other systems or misuses of
the system or its information” (ISACA glossary). See also
regression test, load test, acceptance test.

**[Network]
Segmentation, segment**

```
Logical separation or partitioning of a network into
distinct subnetworks, zones, or layers with differing trust
levels, typically monitoring traffic and controlling access
between segments at any points of contact, e.g. using
firewalls. “A logical grouping of the separate components
of a network or system for design, control, installation,
security and management purposes. This may occur where
similarities of function, control and management exist or
will be of advantage” (NZISM).
```

```

separation of key elements of a virtual system, removing

that prevents or detects errors and irregularities by
assigning the responsibility for initiating and recording
transactions and the custody of assets to separate
individuals. Note: Segregation/separation of duties is
commonly used in large IT organizations so that no single
person is in a position to introduce fraudulent or malicious
code without detection” (ISACA glossary).

Self-assessment, self-
check, self-test

```
Low-cost low-assurance review, assessment, analysis,
check, or test by a person, organisation, device, etc. of
their own performance, capability, functionality,
competence, etc. Much like ‘marking your own
homework,’ patently lacking in independence, hence
liable to bias and subjectivity, but a useful form of
motivation to improve that, if necessary, may be validated
by further checks on a sample basis to ensure sufficient
integrity. See also Dunning–Kruger effect, P ower- O n
S elf- T est.

Q uestionnaire (SAQ)

a. Process for an organisation processing less than six

b. Documentation concerning any structured review
conducted by the reviewed organisation itself rather
than by some other party (such as an auditor).

Self-defence “Protection of one’s person or property against some

F ramework (SPF)

```
Cryptographic email authentication protocol intended to

M ail, D omain-based M essage A uthentication, R eporting
and C onformance.

```
Senior management Executive management plus (in some contexts) the Board
of Directors. “The person or persons who provide the

support of organizational process improvement
effectiveness. A senior manager can be any manager who
satisfies this description, including the CEO of the
organization” (ISACA glossary). “The chief executive
officer or equivalent organizational leader and senior
```

```
management team” ( T rust S ervices C riteria). “The
highest level of executive management of an organization
that is ultimately accountable to the board for executing

persons that includes the chief executive officer or head of

Sensing function Purpose of a sensor.

Sensitive a. See confidential and private.
b. Delicate, perceptive, having heightened senses,

Sensitive attribute See sensitive information. “A human attribute that may be

personal reasons” (ISACA glossary).

S ensitive B ut
U nclassified (SBU)

```
Deprecated US government term, officially superseded by

S ensitive
C ompartmented
I nformation (SCI)

Essentially, SECRET information.

Vault specifically designed to isolate and contain

Sensitive data Confidential, private, and/or valuable data. “Data that
would cause limited damage to the national interest, an

**Sensitive information** Confidential and/or valuable information considered to be
at especially high risk of unauthorised and inappropriate
disclosure or modification, _e.g._ proprietary or personal
information. “Information that, as determined by a
competent authority, must be protected because its
disclosure, modification, destruction, or loss will cause
perceivable damage to someone or something” _(ISO/IEC
2382 )._ “Information that needs to be protected from


```
unavailability, unauthorized access, modification or public

**Sensitive information
storage or transmission**

```
“A set of controls that help ensure the software handles
the sending, receiving and storing of information in a
secure manner” (SCP QRG).
```
```
Sensitive personal
information [or
P ersonally I dentifiable
I nformation (PII) or
personal data]
```
```
Category of sensitive personal information deemed
particularly confidential for some reason, e.g. if it would
cause acute embarrassment or prejudicial treatment if
disclosed inappropriately, e.g. a person’s sexual, medical,
cultural, religious, or other attributes, preferences, history,
or orientation. Legally defined in some privacy laws.
“Category of personally identifiable information (PII),
either whose nature is sensitive, such as those that relate
to the PII principal’s most intimate sphere, or that can
have a significant impact on the PII principal. Note: In
some jurisdictions or in specific contexts, sensitive PII is
defined in reference to the nature of the PII and can
consist of PII revealing the racial origin, political opinions
or religious or other beliefs, personal data on health, sex
life or criminal convictions, as well as other PII that can
be defined as sensitive” (ISO/IEC 29100).
```
```
Sensitivity Subjective assessment of the degree to which something is

protection” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “A measure of the impact
that improper disclosure of information may have on an
enterprise” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Sensor Device or component that senses, detects, or measures
something. “A device or component that gathers
information critical to an IoT application and converts it
to data” (ISACA glossary).
```

```
Sentience, sentient Capability to experience emotions and subjective
sensations (such as joy, pain, pleasure, and guilt), to be
self-aware and feel a part of (and to some extent
committed to further the interests of) one’s surroundings,
family, community, organisation, nation, ethnic group,
team, etc. Cf. intelligence.
```
```
Sentiment analysis “Task of computationally identifying and categorizing
opinions expressed in a piece of text, speech or image, to
determine a range of feeling such as from positive to
negative. Note: Examples of sentiments include approval,
disapproval, positive toward, negative toward, agreement
and disagreement” (ISO/IEC 22989). “ The process of
automatically determining the emotional tone, such as
positive, negative, or neutral, expressed in a piece of text
( e.g., opinions, reviews, social media posts) using natural
language processing (NLP) and machine learning (ML)
models trained on labeled data” (ISACA glossary).

```
Separation,
segregation,
segmentation
```
```
Keeping incompatible things apart using logical and/or
physical and administrative controls. “Includes
partitioning and physically dividing systems and networks
into smaller components. Separation should be applied as
a design and control principle to networks where agencies
have physical control over devices and components, such
as in-office Wi-Fi systems, MFD’s, desktops, laptops and
other system or user devices [and] Architectural, design
and management strategies to limit the effect and impact
of network intrusions and system attacks and exploits.
They will improve the ability to detect, and also improve
the speed and effectiveness of any response to such
events” (NZISM).
```
**Separation of duties** See division of responsibilities. “Dividing responsibility
for sensitive information so that an individual acting alone
can compromise the security of only a limited portion of a

of splitting privileges among multiple individuals or
systems” _(SANS glossary)._

Sequence check Context-dependent determination of whether things are in
the correct or anticipated order. “Verification that the
```

```
control number follows sequentially and any control
numbers out of sequence are rejected or noted in an

or numeric and usually utilizes a key field” (ISACA
glossary).

```
Sequential
authentication
```
```
“When authentication data is requested on successive
pages rather than being requested all at once on a single
page” (SCP QRG).

**Server, computer
server, email server,
file server, application
server, web server**

```
Networked computer system providing information
services such as email, websites, applications, and file
management. “In a computer network, functional unit that
provides services to workstations, to personal computers
or to other functional units [and] functional unit that
provides shared services to workstations or to other
functional units over a data network” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “1.
A computer dedicated to servicing requests for resources
from other computers on a network. Servers typically run
network operating systems. 2. A computer that provides
services to another computer (the client) [and] A high-
speed computer in a network shared by multiple users that
holds the programs and data shared by all users” (ISACA
glossary ). “A computer used to run programs that provide
services to multiple users. For example, a file server,
email server or database server” (NZISM). “A computer
that provides services to users or other systems. For
example, a file server, email server or database server”
(AusISM). “A device or system that provides resources,
data, services, or programs to other devices on either a
local area network or wide area network. Servers can
provide resources and use them from another system at
the same time. Examples include web servers, application
servers, mail servers, and file servers” (CIS Controls). “A
system entity that provides a service in response to
requests from other system entities called clients” (SANS
glossary).
```
```
S erver M essage B lock
(SMB)
```
```
Microsoft client-server file-, printer-, and port-sharing
protocol. The original SMB v1, developed with IBM in
the 1980s and released in 1996, is deprecated due to
having numerous significant security vulnerabilities that
```

```
can be exploited by hackers and malware to infect and
spread through vulnerable organisations’ internal
networks. Later versions such as the current SMB v3.1.1
are more secure, incorporating user authentication,
encryption, and digital signatures for instance. See also
C ommon I nternet F ile S ystem, SMBGhost.
```
```
Service Package of related business activities performed and
delivered by a worker, agent, application, system, or
organisation to another, such as information, I nformation
T echnology, development, support, cloud, infrastructure,
network, platform, software, email, file, financial,
emergency, transportation, retail, government, money-
laundering, malware, ransomware, assurance, audit, or
security services. “Capability of a given layer and the
layers below it that is provided to the entities of the next
higher layer. Note: The service of a given layer is
provided at the boundary between this layer and the next
higher layer” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “An activity that provides a
promised exchange of value between a service provider
and customer, product or work product. Services do not
always produce tangible or storable products; in such
instances, the service itself is the deliverable” (ISACA
glossary). “Refers to a software functionality or a set of
software functionalities, such as the retrieval of specified
information or the execution of a set of operations.
Services provide a mechanism to enable access to one or
more capabilities, where the access is provided using a
prescribed interface and based on the identity of the
requestor per the enterprise’s usage policies” (CIS
Controls).
```
**Service account** Non-interactive userID reserved for automated
information services, applications, and scheduled
administrative activities such as backups. Often
privileged. “A dedicated account with escalated privileges
used for running applications and other processes. Service
accounts may also be created just to own data and
configuration files. They are not intended to be used by
people, except for performing administrative operations”
_(CIS Controls)._ “User accounts that are used to perform
automated tasks without manual intervention, such as


```
machine to machine communications. Service accounts
will typically be configured to disallow interactive logins”
(AusISM).
```
```
Service bureau Business/facility providing standardised information
services in volume, e.g. a high street print shop,
commercial data centre, or C loud S ervice P rovider. “A
computer facility that provides data processing services to
clients on a continual basis” (ISACA glossary).

```
Service desk See help desk. “The point of contact within the IT
organization for users of IT services” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
S ervice L evel
A greement (SLA)
```
```
Lays out requirements for services to be provided by

covering key aspects such as information security,
reliability, and quality, plus the management arrangements
such as performance evaluation and metrics, reporting,

requirements are unsatisfied. May be supported by
O perational L evel A greements for subsidiary/related
services necessary to deliver what the customer actually
needs ( e.g. cloud services typically require data centre
facilities, computing, storage, networking, and
telecommunications services). “An agreement, preferably
documented, between a service provider and the
customer(s)/ user(s) that defines minimum performance
targets for a service and how they will be measured”

```
```
Service mark Similar to a trademark but for a commercial service rather

I ntellectual P roperty, sometimes denoted by SM.

**S** ervice- **O** riented
**A** rchitecture **(SOA)**

```
Software engineering approach that weaves discrete
information services or microservices together into a

business, security, and other services may be provided by
custom-written functions and subroutines within the
program plus generic, reusable network services accessed
through A pplication P rogramming I nterfaces. “A cloud-
based library of proven, functional software applets that
```

```
can be connected together to become a useful online
application” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Service owner Organisation, rôle, or person designated as the owner of

Customer Services). Responsible and generally
accountable for its design, operation, and legitimate

```
```
Service provider Organisation, person, server, etc. providing a service.
“Abstract representation of all the entities that provide a

or external) customers” (ISACA glossary). “A supplier
(such as a service organization) engaged to provide
services to the entity. Service providers include

provide services not associated with business functions,

S ervices C riteria).

**S** ervice **S** et **Id** entifier
**(SSID)**

```
Name for a Wi-Fi network service set (group of
communicating devices), usually broadcast periodically
by access points. “A name assigned to a wireless AP”
(NIST SP 800-114). “A 32-character unique identifier
attached to the header of packets sent over a wireless local
area network (WLAN) that acts as a password when a
mobile device tries to connect to the base station
subsystem (BSS). Notes: The SSID differentiates one
WLAN from another, so all access points and all devices
attempting to connect to a specific WLAN must use the
same SSID. A device will not be permitted to join the BSS
unless it can provide the unique SSID. Because an SSID
can be sniffed in plaintext from a packet, it does not
supply any security to the network. An SSID is also
referred to as a network name because it is a name that
identifies a wireless network” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Session a. Interactive period or connection, e.g. from an
I nformation T echnology user’s logon or initial
access to a computer system, application, network, or
service until their logoff, timeout, or final access. “A
```

```
virtual connection between two hosts by which
network traffic is passed” (SANS glossary).
b. A boozy evening sharing war stories at a security
conference.
```
**S** ession **B** order
**C** ontroller **(SBC)**

```
“Security features for Voice-over IP (VoIP) traffic similar
to that provided by firewalls. Note: SBCs can be
configured to filter specific VoIP protocols, monitor for
denial-of-service (DOS) attacks and provide network

streams of real-time UC and VoIP connections. It includes
establishing, controlling, and terminating calls, interactive
media communications or other VoIP connections. SBCs
enable VoIP traffic to navigate gateways and firewalls and
ensure interoperability between different SIP
implementations. Careful selection of SBCs will provide

Session hijack See M an- I n- T he- M iddle. “Take over a session that

**S** ession **I** nitiation
**P** rotocol **(SIP)**

```
Application layer network signalling protocol to establish,
change, and terminate V oice O ver I nternet P rotocol
sessions for voice and video calls, with call forwarding,
on-hold, and call transfer functions.
```
```
Session key Key used for symmetric encryption of traffic between two
parties within single session. May be changed after a
defined period or a certain number of messages have been
exchanged. The initial key for the first session may be
generated and shared offline ( e.g. on a O ne- T ime P ad or
key loader) or exchanged securely between the parties
using asymmetric cryptography. Subsequent session keys
may be generated, encrypted with the current session key,
and passed to the counterparty, or the key establishment
process might restart from scratch (rekeying). “In the
context of symmetric encryption, a key that is temporary
or is used for a relatively short period of time. Usually, a
```

```
session key is used for a defined period of communication
between two computers, such as for the duration of a
single connection or transaction set, or the key is used in
an application that protects relatively large amounts of
data and, therefore, needs to be re-keyed frequently”
(SANS glossary).
```
```
Session management Session management. “A set of controls that help ensure
web applications handle http sessions in a secure manner”

```

SET Abbrev: S ecure E lectronic T ransaction.
```
**Setpoint, set-point, set
point**

```
Desired or optimal value configured for a controlled
parameter, such as a temperature of 4°C for the thermostat
in a refrigerator. The actual measured value varies around
the setpoint in practice due to the time taken for the
control to act, e.g. after starting and running the
compressor, it takes a while to chill the fridge including
the temperature sensor (forming a hysteresis loop).
Various business, security, and compliance objectives are
also, in a sense, setpoints with their own measurement and
control tolerances for practical reasons.
```
```
SEV Abbrev: S ecure E ncrypted V irtualisation.
```
```
Severity Quantification, measure, or relative assessment of the
significance, scale, importance, criticality, or vitality of
something. “Estimation of the magnitude of potential
impacts on the privacy of a PII principal” (ISO/IEC
29134 ).
```
```
Sexting Portmanteau of ‘sex’ and ‘texting’ involving explicit text
messages or other supposedly private person-to-person
communication between friends or lovers. Once sent,
messages may be forwarded or disclosed by the recipient
and/or by anyone who intercepts the communications or
has control of the devices, and perhaps used for
sextortion.
```
```
Sextortion Neologism concerning threatening to disclose highly
personal and private, often sexual, information about
```

```
someone (such as explicit selfies – photographs of
someone taken by them – or sexting or captured webcam
footage) as a means of coercing them into doing
something ( e.g. pay a ransom) to avoid embarrassment
and shame. See also revenge porn.
```

SFR Abbrev: S ecurity F unctional R equirement.
```
**SGX (Software Guard
eXtension)**

```
C entral P rocessing U nit instruction-set security extension
designed to isolate trusted from untrusted code as it

microarchitecture. Intended to prevent exploitation by
malware, even subverted kernel functions in O perating
S ystems.
```
```
SHA-1 (Secure Hash
Algorithm No 1)
```
```
One of a set of hash algorithms developed by the N ational
S ecurity A gency in 1995. Generates a 160-bit hash. Due
to known cryptographic vulnerabilities and successful
cryptanalytic attacks demonstrated in 2017 and 2019,
SHA1 is deprecated in favour of stronger algorithms such
as SHA-2 but lingers in some digital signatures, S ecure
S ockets L ayer, PGP, SSH, and S/MIME. “A one way
cryptographic hash function” (SANS glossary). See also
MD5.
```
```
SHA-2 (Secure Hash
Algorithm No 2)
```
```
Set of six related cryptographic hash algorithms
developed by the N ational S ecurity A gency, generating
hashes with bit lengths evident from their names ( i.e.
SHA-224, SHA-256, SHA-384, and SHA-512). Believed
strong enough for all current applications, with SHA-3
available when vulnerabilities are discovered and
disclosed.
```
```
SHA-3 (Secure Hash
Algorithm No 3)
```
```
Further generation of cryptographic hash and extendable
output algorithms approved by NIST in the FIPS PUB 202
standard in 2015. Based on Keccack, a sponge function.
Anticipated to supersede MD5, SHA-1, and SHA-2. More
info:
https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/fips/nist.fips.202.pdf
```
```
Shadow Brokers Hacker group allegedly associated with Russian
intelligence.
```

```
ShadowHammer Malware incident in 2018/2019 which initially
compromised ASUS servers, infecting motherboard
software and firmware updates distributed through the
ASUS Live Update mechanism. The updates were
digitally signed using genuine ASUSTek Computer Inc.
digital certificates, hence appeared legitimate. The
malware targeted devices with specific MAC addresses on
their network adapters, suggesting a cyber-spooky
purpose. The attack was linked to the BARIUM group.
```
```
Shadow IT Unofficial, informal, and weakly governed computer-
literate workers outside I nformation T echnology
D epartment using IT equipment ( e.g. B ring Y our O wn
D evice) and services ( e.g. cloud computing) with little if
any IT Department involvement.
Although non-IT workers are embedded in the business,
they may not be aware of and/or conform to corporate IT
strategies, policies, standards, guidelines, procedures,
protocols, good practices, or comply with applicable
laws/regulations. Implies a threat to IT Department’s
political power and management control. “The use of
systems, services, hardware or software on an enterprise
network or within an enterprise’s infrastructure without
proper vetting and approval from the IT or cyber s ecurity
department” (ISACA glossary).
```
**Shadow password file** Early networked computers saved user authentication
credentials in a plaintext ‘password file’ that was patently
vulnerable to theft and exploitation by hackers. That
highly insecure approach was soon replaced by saving
password hash values, except they too were vulnerable to
brute force attacks. Soon, passwords or hashes were
encrypted into the ‘shadow password file’ with additional
security controls to prevent intrepid hackers intercepting,
misusing, or compromising system functions to decrypt
them or bypass user authentication altogether. “A system
file in which encryption user password are stored so that
they aren _’_ t available to people who try to break into the
system” _(SANS glossary)._

```
Shadow regulations Organisations sometimes acquiesce to unofficial requests
from the authorities, e.g. to disclose sensitive information
```

```
or take offline material previously published online,
without being legally compelled to do so. Presumably
they simply agree with the intent, are persuaded on ethical
grounds, or are coerced through ‘agreements,’ ‘codes of
conduct’, etc.
```
```
Shamoon Species of malware used to attack Saudi Aramco in 2012,
with variants still in the wild as of 2019. Incorporated a
dropper and wiper.
```
**SHARE design option** “To outsource, joint ventures, partnerships, buy insurance,
or use other financial instruments to address the
opportunity, obstacle, or obligation” _(OCEG GRC
Glossary)._

```
Shared facility “Where an organisation’s facility resides within a larger
facility that is shared with one or more different
organisations” (AusISM).
```
```
Shared key, shared
secret
```
```
Cryptographic key for both encryption and decryption that
is meant to be available only to authorised users of a
symmetric cryptosystem and no others. Also known as a
secret key. Cf. private key.
```
```
Shared responsibility Information security principle that we are both

```
```
Shared responsibility
model
```
```
“The responsibility for the selection, implementation,
management and maintenance of controls in public cloud
services is shared between provider and consumer. Where
the responsibilities lie depends on the provider, and the
service and deployment models” (NZISM). “A framework
that describes the management and operational
responsibilities between different parties for a system.
Where responsibilities relating to specific controls are
shared between multiple parties, enough detail is
documented to provide clear demarcation between the
parties” (AusISM).
```

```
Shelfware Documents such as policies and procedures that are
‘collecting dust on the shelf’, i.e. disregarded, neglected,

complied with. Cf. software, hardware, firmware,
wetware, malware, ransomware, adware, crimeware,
scareware, spouseware, stalkerware, spyware.
```
```
Shellcode Malware that covertly opens a command interpreter (the
‘shell’) to call powerful low-level system commands.
```
**Shellshock, Bashdoor** Festering cluster of bugs in the Bash shell/command
interpreter, some of which trivially permit hackers or
malware root access to vulnerable UNIX systems. Nasty.
Responsible disclosure of the vulnerability by its
discoverer and ready availability of patches towards the
end of 2014 did not prevent Shellshock being widely
exploited because of patching delays caused by tardiness
and incompetence.

```
Shell site See cold site.
```
```
Shelter in place “Action to move people to predetermined areas inside the

dangers during an incident. Note: This may be referred to

immediate refuge in a protected location relevant to the

```
Shift left The earlier in the product development process that

```
Shill bid Auction bid made by the seller of an item (directly or

```

```

```
padlock without the correct key or combination.

or objectives of an urban system” (ISO 22300).

```
Shodan Search engine for Internet-connected devices ( things ),

Characterises devices by their responses to various queries

ShopAdmin Hacker term for an exploit that enables unauthorised

```

```
highly confidential or SECRET information. “Destruct by

```

Signature
```

```
a. Characteristic way that a person writes their own

H andling of A sserted
information using
to KEN s (SHAKEN)

Contrived name for a framework determining how

Significance,
significant
```
```
Importance, relevance, priority, substantiveness, value,

cybersecurity risk

```

threat

**Significant deficiency** Significant vulnerability. “A deficiency or a combination

a material weakness, yet important enough to merit

asset**

Information asset or a related group/set of information

Silk Road, Silk Road
2.0

P rotocol (SMTP)

attack]

```
Fraudsters socially engineer the mobile phone companies

banking, and other online services by diverting two-factor

```
Simulate, simulation Model or reproduce something in order to predict and
learn about its characteristics. “Use of a data processing

```

```
temperatures, and air pressures” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). Cf.

A uthentication of
E quals (SAE),
Dragonfly

```
Flawed cryptographic protocol used in WPA3 to
authenticate Wi-Fi devices to each other, prior to

**S** ingle **P** oint **o** f **F** ailure
**(SPoF)**

```
Essential component or link between components whose
failure would interrupt ( i.e. impact the availability of)
dependent services, processes, customers, etc. Eliminating
SPoFs where possible through redundancy, along with
reinforcing unavoidable SPoFs through solid engineering
practices, are valuable forms of resilience. “Element or
component of a system, a path in a system, or a system
that, if it fails, the whole system or an array of systems are
unable to perform their primary functions. Note: A single
point of failure is often considered a design flaw
associated with a critical element” (ISO/IEC 27040 ). “A
resource whose loss will result in the loss of service or
production” (ISACA glossary). See also F ailure M odes
and E ffects A nalysis.
```
```
S ingle S ign O n (SSO) Software that manages a suite of diverse passwords
unique to multiple systems. Unlike crude password
synchronisation schemes, the compromise of a password
for a single target system being managed through a well-
designed SSO system or application should not give
access to other target systems since they each have unique
passwords. However, compromising the SSO system itself
may still facilitate unauthorised access to all the
subsidiary systems; hence, security remains paramount for
the SSO system. “A single point authentication system
used by multiple systems and applications” (ISACA
glossary). See also password vault.
```
```
Sinister Dark, underhand, deceptive, surreptitious, foreboding, and
usually malicious behaviour, e.g. coercive, threatening, or
menacing. Derived from the Latin word for left, referring
to a Roman soldier’s discreet use of, say, a dagger held in
the left hand in addition to the obvious sword in his right
hand, or perhaps the tactical advantage that a left-handed
```

```
swordsman might have when fighting at tight quarters,
e.g. in a spiral staircase.
```
```
Sinkhole See bit-bucket.

```
SIP Abbrev: S ession I nitiation P rotocol.

```

up to SECRET. Authorisation to connect is required from
S IPRnet C onnection A pproval O ffice within D efense
I nformation S ystems A gency. See also NIPRnet.
```
```
SIS Abbrev: S ecret I ntelligence S ervice (UK MI6) or S pecial
I ntelligence S ervice (US).
```
**Situational awareness** Heightened appreciation of the risks inherent in a given
context, particularly significant threats to a person’s safety
in a particular locality ( _e.g._ a dark city alleyway) and time
of day ( _e.g._ at night). “The ability to identify, process and
comprehend the critical elements of information through a
cyber threat intelligence process that provides a level of
understanding that is relevant to act upon to mitigate the
impact of a potentially harmful event” _(Bank for
International Settlements and International Organization
of Securities Commissions Guidance on cyber resilience
for financial market infrastructures)._ See also vigilance,
security awareness. More info:
https://www.bis.org/cpmi/publ/d146.pdf

```
S/KEY Unix/Linux O ne- T ime P assword system, trademarked by
Telcordia Technologies. “A security mechanism that uses
a cryptographic hash function to generate a sequence of
64-bit, one-time passwords for remote user login. The
client generates a one-time password by applying the
MD4 cryptographic hash function multiple times to the
user ’ s secret key. For each successive authentication of
the user, the number of hash applications is reduced by
one” (SANS glossary).
```
```
Skill Ability to do something particularly well – more than
merely competently, perhaps expertly. “Ability to perform
```

```
a task or activity with a specific intended outcome
acquired through education, training, experience or other

TS 17027 ).
```
```
Skill gap “The difference between the current skill level and the

```
```
Skipjack Deprecated symmetric encryption algorithm (a block
cipher with an 80-bit key), presumably invented by
someone working for the N ational S ecurity A gency or
seized by them. Originally classified SECRET and
incorporated in the Clipper chip but subsequently opened
to public scrutiny. Deliberately weakened by NSA to

```
SLA Abbrev: S ervice L evel A greement.
```
```
Slack space Gap between the full extent of a file (up to the end-of-file
marker) and the remaining disk space allocated for the file
(including any further sectors in a cluster), which may
contain residual data (remnants) from files that previously
occupied the area before being moved/deleted but not
securely erased. Slack space can also exist in working
memory, depending on the O perating S ystem. See also

```
**Slander, slanderous** Transitory and generally unrecorded form of defamation,
_e.g._ a spoken statement or gesture, perhaps falsely
accusing someone of something untoward and
inappropriate. _Cf._ libel.

```
Sleeper Deep cover mole who remains under cover for an
extended period (years) in the target
organisation/group/culture in order to establish the (ill-
founded) trust of his/her colleagues and ascend to a
position of power and authority from which he/she may
be ‘awoken’ to commit an act of espionage, sabotage, or
betrayal. An extreme example of social engineering.

```

generic term for similar/copycat tools (genericide).

```
SMART (criteria) Five generic factors to consider when formulating,

glossary). “Criteria used to design/set Objectives to work
with Indicators; to be specific, measurable, achievable

```

A rtificial I ntelligence ( S mart T echnology).

```

```

**Smartcard, smart card** Credit card-sized device or token usually containing a
cryptographic processor plus gold-flashed contact pads
and/or short-range wireless networking capabilities. “A
small electronic device that contains electronic memory
and possibly an embedded integrated circuit. Note: Smart
cards can be used for a number of purposes including the
storage of digital certificates or digital cash, or they can be
used as a token to authenticate users” _(ISACA glossary)_.
“An electronic badge that includes a magnetic strip or
chip that can record and replay a set key” _(SANS
glossary)._


**Smart contract** “Software (computer code) that automatically executes
transactions and/or enforces agreements based on the
fulfillment of the terms of the agreement by leveraging
decentralized ledger technology that uses public
validation to ensure correct and reliable performance
according to agreed rules” _(ISACA glossary)._

```
Smart device Device with an embedded S mart T echnology processor,
usually also network-capable making it a thing. Some
dumb devices can be smartened-up using add-on smart
interfaces, ranging from remotely switchable power plugs
up to quite sophisticated automation involving both
monitoring/measurement and control.
```
```
Smart grid Electricity grids have long been used by the power
companies to pass low-rate data and commands to their
remote substations, switchgear, etc. through the power
cables. Modern networking technologies, communicating
either over the power lines themselves or by some other
medium (normally radio, e.g. mesh networks), allow
greater bandwidths so power companies can extend the
reach of their power control into consumer premises,
particularly industrial plants, for metering and demand
management ( e.g. shedding non-critical loads such as
household and office air conditioners if peak demands or
limited supplies threaten to overload the grid). “Electric
power system that utilizes information exchange and
control technologies, distributed computing and
associated sensors and actuators. Note: Smart grid
technologies are used for purposes such as: integrating the
behaviour and actions of the network users and other
stakeholders; efficiently delivering sustainable, economic
and secure electricity supplies” (ISO/IEC 27019 ).
```
```
Smart home Residential property that uses home automation, typically
involving a H ome A rea N etwork connecting things
( S mart T echnologies) monitoring and controlling lights,
locks, thermostats, white goods, entertainment, and
security systems.
```
```
Smart hub Smart hub interconnects a H ome A rea N etwork to the
Internet. While smart home devices and things typically
```

```
use mesh network topologies, a smart hub can provide a
focal point for monitoring, management (such as device
configuration and patching), and control ( e.g. a Wi-Fi
curfew or prohibition of unsavoury or dangerous
domains).
```
```
Smart lock Thing that locks a door and can be commanded to open
through the network, for instance when the owner’s
smartphone is detected in the vicinity, or when hacked.
```
```
Smart meter Electricity meter that can be remotely interrogated (for
meter readings) and perhaps commanded ( e.g. switching
between charging bands or dis/connecting services),
typically through a mesh network. Within a smart home or
business, the smart meter may communicate wirelessly
with things such as smart appliances, typically monitoring
and perhaps controlling them for power demand
management purposes, raising information security and
privacy concerns.
```
```
Smartphone Modern cellphones (cellular telephones) have
sophisticated processing capabilities – they are in fact
miniature networked computers and cryptographic
systems. With powerful processors running multitasking
O perating S ystems such as IOS and Android, solid-state
storage, high-resolution touch screens, access to multiple
networks, and other technically advanced capabilities such
as G lobal P ositioning S ystem, they can run a wide variety
of applications ... as well as being nifty portable
telephones, Internet terminals, and surveillance devices.
```

socket

repaired device, system, application, _etc_. will not
(figuratively or literally!) release the smoke and expire or
‘go nuts’ when powered up or executed for the first time,
and hence is stable enough for further testing.

```
Smurf attack This early Internet D istributed D enial- O f- S ervice
technique simply involved spoofing the I nternet P rotocol
address of a target system in ICMP echo request (ping)
messages sent to the broadcast addresses for numerous
systems which duly sent their ĪCMP echo replies to the
target, potentially overloading it. A type of amplification
attack. “Works by spoofing the target address and sending
a ping to the broadcast address for a remote network,
which results in a large amount of ping replies being sent
to the target” (SANS glossary).

(Status/Situation
Normal: All Fouled

```
Acronym popular in the US Marine Corp in the second
World War. The original version was cruder than ‘all

```
Snake Species or family of modular, stealthy O perational
T echnology ransomware allegedly used by FSB for
espionage purposes in more than 50 countries in 2023.
Evolved over 20 years from Uroburos malware. A very
short (128-bit) Diffie–Hellman prime enabled Western
state cryptanalysts to reverse-engineerit.
```
```
Snake oil Virtually worthless liquid medicine allegedly derived
from snakes with magical cure-all properties, sold by
charlatans to vulnerable/naïve/desperate customers in the
18th and 19th Centuries. Mobile snake oil salesmen used
hard-sell social engineering techniques to fleece
customers of their money, moving rapidly on to the next
town before victims realised they had been duped. A
classic fraud. As with today’s homeopathy, any medical
effect is probably psychosomatic – the placebo effect.
```

Using networking software or dedicated hardware (such

in networks” (ISO/IEC 27033-1). “The act of capturing

```

**Snowshoe spamming** Small-scale spamming, deliberately designed to ‘leave a
small footprint ’and thereby evade the automated checks
that normally catch and quickly block mass spamming.
Analogous to spear phishing, it typically involves
spamming a relatively small group of targets with
carefully crafted custom messages less likely to be
flagged as spam.

SOA, SoA Abbrev: S ervice- O riented A rchitecture or S tatement o f
A pplicability, depending on context.

```
SOAP Datacommunications protocol for applications to
exchange XML-formatted structured information over a
network. SOAP is transport-independent but commonly
```

```
uses H yper T ext T ransfer P rotocol. Originally known as
S imple O bject A ccess P rotocol. “A platform-independent
formatted protocol based on extensible markup language
(XML) enabling applications to communicate with each
other over the Internet. Notes: Use of SOAP may provide
a significant security risk to web application operations
because use of SOAP piggybacks onto a web-based
document object model and is transmitted via HyperText
Transfer Protocol (HTTP) (port 80) to penetrate server
firewalls, which are usually configured to accept port 80
and port 21 File Transfer Protocol (FTP) requests. Web-
based document models define how objects on a web page
are associated with each other and how they can be
manipulated while being sent from a server to a client
browser. SOAP typically relies on XML for presentation
formatting and also adds appropriate HTTP-based headers
to send it. SOAP forms the foundation layer of the web
services stack, providing a basic messaging framework on
which more abstract layers can build. There are several
different types of messaging patterns in SOAP, but by far
the most common is the Remote Procedure Call (RPC)
pattern in which one network node (the client) sends a
request message to another node (the server), and the
server immediately sends a response message to the
client” (ISACA glossary).

**SOC 1 (System and
Organization Control
report No 1)**

```
Report on an outsourced/ C loud S ervice P rovider giving
information and opinion about its controls relevant to
financial reporting, specifically. Provided by C ertified
P ublic A ccountants accredited by the A merican I nstitute
of C ertified P ublic A ccountants. Superseded SAS 70.
Requirements are defined in SSAE 18.

**SOC 2 (System and
Organization Control
report No 2)**

```
Prescriptive cybersecurity controls assurance standard for
outsourced/ C loud S ervice P roviders from the A merican
I nstitute of C ertified P ublic A ccountants. Concerns
```

```
controls other than those relating to financial reporting,
across up to five T rust S ervice C riteria: security (general
controls over access, etc. , included in all SOC 2 reports)
plus availability, processing integrity, confidentiality, and
privacy (each included only if applicable). May identify
reliance on subcontractors’ and customers’ controls to
achieve the required security. A SOC 2 Type 1 report
concerns the organisation’s conformity with the
requirements at a single point in time, a snapshot of the
controls in place. A SOC 2 Type 2 report extends the

least three months. Requirements are defined in SSAE 18 ,
SSAE 20, and SSAE 21.

and AICPA Guide SOC 2® Reporting on an Examination
of Controls at a Service Organization: Relevant to
Security, Availability, Processing Integrity,
Confidentiality, or Privacy” ( T rust S ervices C riteria).

cybersecurity objectives based on the control criteria. A
```

Social contract Refers to unwritten understandings, ethical expectations,
and commitments or undertakings between the parties,

```
Social engineering,
social hacking,
cognitive hacking
```
```
Hacking/scamming/fraud techniques involving the
manipulation of people through a combination of
deception (such as pretexting, masquerading,
misinformation, and narratives) and persuasive, coercive,
or assertive behaviour (such as ‘bravado’ and
manipulative psychological tricks), typically leading to
them revealing or permitting unauthorised access to
sensitive information. “A general term for attackers trying
to trick people into revealing sensitive information or
performing certain actions, such as downloading and
executing files that appear to be benign but are actually
malicious” (NIST SP 800-1 14 ). “An attack based on
deceiving users or administrators at the target site into
revealing confidential or sensitive information” (ISACA
glossary). “Involves manipulation of specific individuals
to extract important information, such as passwords or
personal data, from an organisation, for example, through
```

```
impersonation” (UK Cyber Security Breaches Survey
2023 ). “Refers to a broad range of malicious activities
accomplished through human interactions on various
platforms, such as email or phone. It relies on
psychological manipulation to trick users into making
security mistakes or giving away sensitive information”
(CIS Controls). “A euphemism for non-technical or low-
technology means – such as lies, impersonation, tricks,
bribes, blackmail, and threats – used to attack information
systems” (SANS glossary).
```
**Social identity, social
ID**

```
Social media applications and functions (such as those
allowing visitors to comment on news items, blogs, etc. or
review products) often invite users to identify and
authenticate themselves using their Facebook, Twitter,
Google, or LinkedIn accounts (their ‘social identities’ or
‘socials’), provided the users are willing for those social
media sites to disclose selected personal information to
the social media apps and functions. This S ingle S ign O n
approach avoids users having to register separately in
each case but raises privacy concerns.
```
```
Social insecurity Neologism refers to information security and privacy
risks, controls, and incidents directly involving human
factors and affecting people, including insecurity, social
engineering, scams, frauds, social media, social
networking, social proofing, blended attacks, phishing,
spear phishing, pretexting, coercion, spoofing, and
masquerading.
```
```
Social media Interactive websites and applications (such as Facebook,
Tumblr, LinkedIn, Twitter, Blogger, Myspace, YouTube,
blogs, and discussion forums) that facilitate social
networking and personal interaction, both benign and
malicious.
```
```
Social network Community of people, organisations, etc. with common
interests, connected by personal interactions and mutual
contacts through social media, messaging, email, etc. We
tend to drop our guards in relaxed social situations,
typically trusting people and often revealing information
and accepting things at face value, increasing our
```

```
vulnerability to social engineering. Conversely, when
needed, friends and acquaintances can provide valuable
guidance and support.
```
**Social proofing, group
affirmation, group-
think**

```
People in tight-knit social groups tend to believe in, trust,
and respect similar things. Therefore, if a friend (or
someone who has stolen a friend’s ID) recommends a link
or an application, naïve users are inclined to load it
without necessarily considering the risks of malware,
fraud, etc. Misunderstandings, misinterpretations,
misinformation, and disinformation can ‘infect’ (spread
through) a social network, particularly if members are not
adept at critical thinking.
```
```
Social protection “Preventing, managing and overcoming situations that
adversely affect people’s well-being. Note: It consists of
policies and programmes designed to reduce poverty and
vulnerability by promoting efficient labour markets,
diminishing people’s exposure to risks, and enhancing
their capacity to manage economic and social risks, such
as unemployment, exclusion, sickness, disability and old
age” (ISO 22300).
```

**Software development
[process],
programming**

```
Process of creating or modifying software by
writing/amending program source code. Some consider

and spreadsheet macros, loading model files and
parameters into C omputer N umerically C ontrolled
machine tools, and crafting A rtificial I ntelligence/ L arge
