```
determines what we read. “The process by which user
needs are translated into a software product. The process
involves translating user needs into software
requirements, transforming the software requirements into
design, implementing the design in code, testing the code
and sometimes installing and reviewing the software for
operational activities. Note that these activities may
overlap or be performed iteratively” (ISACA glossary).
See also N euro- L inguistic P rogramming and N atural
L anguage P rogramming.
```
```
S oftware D evelopment
L ife C ycle (SDLC),
system development
lifecycle, system
lifecycle
```
```
Entire cradle-to-grave sequence (lifecycle) or process
through which a software application or system is
conceived, specified, developed, tested, implemented,
operated, managed, maintained, and eventually retired or
withdrawn from service.
```
```
Software
documentation
```
```
All or part of the documentation relating to software
including software-based information/cloud services, e.g.
requirement specifications, marketing collateral; licences
and contracts; architectural designs and D ata F low
D iagrams; source code listings and comments; test cases,
findings/results, and reports; installation, configuration,
user and technical support manuals; on-screen
```

```
informational, error, warning, alert, and alarm messages.
“Human-readable technical data or information, including
computer listings and printouts, that describe or specify
design features or other details, explain capabilities, or
provide operating instructions to help users obtain desired
results from a software system. [and] Technical data or
information, including computer listings and printouts in
human-readable form, that describe or specify the design
or details, explain the capabilities or provide operating
instructions for using the software to obtain desired results
from a software system. Types of software documentation
include: Project planning documents, i.e., software
development plans and software verification and
validation (V&V) plans; Software requirements and
design specifications; Test documentation; Customer-
deliverable documentation; Program source code;
Representation of software solutions implemented in
firmware; Reports, e.g., review, audit and project status;
Data, i.e., defect detection and test; It contrasts with
software item” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Software engineer See software developer.
```
**Software engineering,
systems engineering**

```
Formal, structured, systematic, rigorous, and professional
approach to software system/product development, using
engineering principles and disciplines, e.g. investing in
the analysis necessary to prepare detailed and
comprehensive design specifications truly reflecting
stakeholders’ goals and objectives, before moving too far
ahead. “Systematic application of scientific and
technological knowledge, methods, and experience to the
design, implementation, testing, and documentation of
software to optimize its production, support, and quality”
(ISO/IEC 2382 ). “The application of a systematic,
disciplined, quantifiable approach to the development,
operation and maintenance of software, i.e., the
application of engineering to software” (ISACA glossary).
See also systems security engineering.
```
```
Software piracy Software piracy. “Unauthorized use, copying, or
distribution of software products” (ISO/IEC 2382).
```

```
Software reliability Indicator of the extent to which software can be relied
upon (trusted) to perform according to its formal
specifications, normally as demonstrated by several types
of testing and analysis. Reliability, availability, resilience,
capacity, performance, assurance, and other requirements
relate to the impacts of software/system failure, and have
significant implications for the software engineering,
architecture, and build quality. Even if the specifications
are accurate and comprehensive, reliability actually
achieved in practice, however, varies with complex
dynamic operational factors such as: the maturity and
stability of the processing platform and any required
system or network services; software configuration,
loading, usage, management, and maintenance ( e.g.
changes); competition for scarce resources; the possibility
of multiple failure modes and recovery approaches; and
the nature of threats experienced. “1. The probability that
software will not cause the failure of a system for a
specified time under specified conditions. The probability
is a function of the inputs to and use of the system in the
software. The inputs to the system determine whether
existing faults, if any, are encountered. 2. The ability of a
program to perform its required functions accurately and
reproducibly under stated conditions for a specified period
of time” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Solar flare Eruption of intensely energetic particles from the sun that
can bombard the Earth, affecting the Earth’s
magnetosphere and ionosphere, possibly unsettling
electrical power grids plus wired and wireless
communications and damaging delicate electronics,
particularly on orbiting satellites (such as those providing
G lobal P ositioning S ystem) and high-altitude aircraft. The
frequency and intensity of flares, and hence the threat,
correlate with the number of sunspots which peaks every
11 years or so, most recently in 2025.
```
**SolarWinds, Sunburst** American software company’s ‘Orion’ remote-access
network monitoring software was hacked by Cozy
Bear/APT29, a unit of the Russian foreign intelligence
service (SVR) in 2020. A **S** erver **M** essage **B** lock exploit
enabled the malware to spread laterally following initial


```
infection. Subsequently, the company unknowingly
distributed malware to 18,000 customers including 9 US
federal agencies and hundreds of US companies that were
specifically targeted, including FireEye, a US
cybersecurity company. A classic example of a supply
chain cyberattack.
```
**Solid-state drive** “Non-volatile media that uses flash memory media to
retain its information when power is removed” _(NZISM)._
“Non-volatile media that uses non-volatile flash memory
media to retain its data when power is removed and,
unlike non-volatile magnetic media, contains no moving
parts” _(AusISM)._

```
Solution a. Solute dissolved in solvent.
b. The literal or philosophical answer to a problem such
as 1 + 1 =? or how to achieve happiness and
contentment.
c. The customer outcome and value implied by a
commercial product’s glossy advertisements, coupled
with the supplier’s brands and reputation. “A
product, product component, service, service system,
service system component or delivered or acquired
product or service including relevant safety or
security components” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Sony hack Major information security incident at the end of 2014
affecting Sony Pictures Entertainment. Malicious hackers
allegedly working for the North Vietnamese government
compromised Sony’s corporate network, stealing a large
quantity of sensitive proprietary and personal information
over several months which they then used to extort Sony
by disclosing some (creating a media storm) and
threatening to disclose more embarrassing and damaging
content. Presumably in an effort to cover their tracks
(scorched earth), the hackers also unleashed a network
worm that displayed a scary graphic and threatening
messages on desktop PC screens, destroyed data, and took
critical I nformation T echnology systems out of service
for months, massively disrupting Sony’s business
activities and causing serious commercial, legal, and
brand impacts.
```

```
SOP Abbrev: S tandard O perating P rocedure.
```
```
Soraya Species of memory-scraping malware.
```
```
Source Whistleblower, spy, informant, defector, etc. who
discreetly discloses sensitive information or facilitates its
acquisition by an intelligence agency (HUMINT) or a
technological equivalent (TECHINT).
```
```
Source available Some software owners are willing to disclose their source
code to specific third parties, usually in confidence ( e.g.
after entering into a nondisclosure agreement), in order for
them to be able to check the design, functionality, quality,
supportability, security, etc.
```
```
Source code Lines in a human-readable computer programming
language comprising a program for a software application,
function, system, utility, etc. A type of code. Source code
is compiled or interpreted into the low-level machine code
instructions understood by the C entral P rocessing U nit.
“Code expressed in a form suitable for input to an
assembler, compiler, or other translator” (ISO/IEC 2382 ).
“Computer instructions and data definitions documented
in a form suitable for input to an assembler, compiler or
other translator” (ISACA glossary). “Character or bit
pattern that is assigned a particular meaning to express a
computer program in a programming language. Notes:
Source codes are instructions and data definitions
expressed in a form suitable for input to an assembler,
compiler, or other translator. Coding is the process of
expressing logic and data from design specifications or
descriptions into a programming language. A
programming language is a lan g uage used to express
computer programs” (IEC 62628). See also assembly
language.
```
**Source code escrow** Escrow of program source code, enabling it to be released
to users/customers, _etc._ under specific conditions, _e.g._ if
the developer dies, the team breaks up, the company
ceases trading or for some other reason is unwilling or
unable to continue supporting and maintaining the
software.


```
SP 800 series See NIST SP 800 series.
```
```
Spaghetti code a. Convoluted, tangled, messy, unstructured,
incoherent, opaque, and hence virtually
unmaintainable source code more likely than most to
contain design flaws and programming bugs.
“Program source code written without a coherent
structure. It implies the excessive use of GOTO
instructions and contrasts with structured
programming” (ISACA glossary).
b. Deliberately obfuscated malware, security, or other
software, intended to resist reverse engineering,
protect I ntellectual P roperty and commercial
interests ( e.g. costly support contracts), and/or
conceal nefarious functions such as backdoors or
fraud.
c. Software written by Italian developers.
```
**Spam, U** nsolicited **B** ulk
**E** mail **(UBE)**

```
Advertisements pumped out by some low-life scammer or
naïve/overzealous/unethical marketer taking advantage of
the negligible costs of emails and contact lists.
“Unsolicited emails, which can carry malicious contents
and/or scam messages. Note: While the most widely
recognized form of spam is e-mail spam, the term is
applied to similar abuses in other media: instant
messaging spam, Usenet newsgroup spam, Web search
engine spam, spam in blogs, wiki spam, mobile phone
messaging spam, Internet forum spam and junk fax
transmissions” (ISO/IEC 27032 ). “ Computer-generated
messages sent as unsolicited advertising” (ISACA
glossary). “Electronic junk mail or junk newsgroup
postings” (SANS glossary). Note: SPAM in capitals shouts
the trademarked name of a pink spiced ham product made
infamous by a 1970’s Monty Python sketch. See also
SPIM.
```
```
Spam bomb See email bomb.
```
```
Spambot Robotic program that systematically harvests email
addresses from the web and/or sends spam. Typically, part
of a botnet.
```

```
Spamtrap Honeypot system designed to improve anti-spam controls
by luring, monitoring, logging, capturing, analysing,
and/or characterising spam messages.
```
```
Speak Up Species of malware (a backdoor Trojan) in the wild in
```
2019. Installed a cryptominer on Linux systems.

```
Spear phishing Narrowly targeted phishing attack that uses information
about or of direct interest to specific target individuals as
a pretext to establish contact and false credibility with
them, thereby increasing the scammers’ chances of
success. “An attack designed to entice specific individuals
or groups to reveal important information. Social
engineering techniques are used to masquerade as a
trusted party to obtain important information, such as
passwords from the victim” (ISACA glossary).
```
**S** pecial **A** ccess **P** rogram
**(SAP)**

```
“Sensitive acquisition, intelligence, or operations and
support program, that imposes need-to-know and access
controls beyond those normally provided for access to
confidential, secret, or top secret information” (DoD
dictionary).
```
```
Special audit, special
investigation, forensic
audit
```
```
Narrowly scoped audit investigating a significant and
specific concern, suspicion, or credible report of
impropriety. Exceptional, not part of the routine audit
schedule. Discretion and rapidity are often necessary,
particularly if there has been an allegation of fraud,
embezzlement, collusion, or other illegality, in order to
gather and secure forensic evidence that might otherwise
be concealed, destroyed, or spoiled.
```
```
Special collection C entral I ntelligence A gency term for surveillance that
would require a warrant if performed within the US for
law enforcement ... but not when performed overseas, nor
if it would be permitted domestically for other purposes
(such as counterterrorism or national defence) or for
testing/training, nor if conducted by other agencies (such
as the F ederal B ureau of I nvestigation or Five Eyes) at the
CIA’s request, perhaps using information and tools ( i.e.
surveillance capabilities and tradecraft) furnished by the
```

```
CIA. This level of access is indeed ‘special,’ as in
exceptional. See also basic collection, standard collection.
```
```
S pecial I ntelligence
S ervice (SIS)
```
```
Covert counterintelligence unit of the F ederal B ureau of
I nvestigation, mostly hunting Nazi spies in South America
during World War II. Subsumed into the C entral
I ntelligence A gency. Cf. UK S ecret I ntelligence S ervice.
```
```
Special investigation See special audit.
```
```
Species By analogy to living organisms, malware is rapidly
‘evolving.’ Several distinct ‘families’ of malware are
known, containing one or more ‘species’ often with
multiple ‘variants’ or ‘mutants’ – millions of them in the
case of highly polymorphic or heavily obfuscated types.
```
```
Specification Precise, detailed description of requirements. “Detailed
formulation, in document form, which provides a
definitive description of a system for the purpose of
developing or validating the system” (ISO/IEC 2382).
```
**Spectre, Meltdown,
Chipzilla, Foreshadow,
Fallout, Retbleed**

```
Design flaws in some C entral P rocessing U nit chips
relating to pre-emptive execution allows malicious user-
mode programs to read and perhaps modify memory
supposedly reserved for trusted functions, thereby
negating a fundamental low-level security control critical
to protecting the O perating S ystem. Although OSs can be
patched as a workaround (at the cost of slower execution),
malware probably exists to exploit unpatched systems.
See also ZombieLoad.
```

```
Speech recognition,
S peech- T o- T ext (STT)
```
```
“Conversion, by a functional unit, of a speech signal to a
representation of the content of the speech” (ISO/IEC
22989 ).
```

**T** o- **S** peech **(TTS)**

```
“Generation of artificial speech” (ISO/IEC 22989).
```

```
SPF Abbrev: S ender P olicy F ramework.
```
```
Spike Momentary/transient peak in the supply voltage, typically
caused by switching heavy inductive loads such as large
```

```
motors on the same circuit, or a lightning strike on or near
the power cables and electrical/electronic devices. May
overload and cause unreliability or premature failure of
sensitive electronics having inadequate voltage regulation
or protection such as M etal O xide V aristors. See also
surge, dip, brownout, blackout, E lectro M agnetic P ulse.
```
```
Spikes Physical security control consisting of upward-pointing
sharpened strong steel rods or similar, normally firmly
fixed to the top of a wall or fence or implanted in the
ground (sometimes on hinged plates allowing vehicles to
pass safely in one direction) to deter or prevent intrusion.
```
```
[Data] Spill Incident involving the unauthorised accidental leak or
deliberate transmission or exfiltration of classified
information to a system, network, or some other recipient
classified to a lower level, perhaps unclassified.
```
**SPIM (SPam via IM)** Spam sent over **I** nstant **M** essaging, a term allegedly
created by the marketing departments of certain
antivirus/anti-spam companies desperate to sell their
services to naïve IM users.

```
Split key “A cryptographic key that is divided into two or more
separate data items that individually convey no knowledge
of the whole key that results from combining the items”
(SANS glossary).
```
```
Split knowledge Application of the principle of division of responsibility
whereby critical information (such as a trade secret, PIN
code, or cryptographic key) is deliberately divided among
multiple people, systems, etc. who are required to keep
their parts confidential so that that none of them alone
holds the complete picture. “A security technique in which
two or more entities separately hold data items that
individually convey no knowledge of the information that
results from combining the items. This is a condition
under which two or more entities separately have key
components that individually convey no knowledge of the
plaintext key that will be produced when the key
components are combined in the cryptographic module”
(ISACA glossary). “1. Separation of data or information
```

```
into two or more parts, each part constantly kept under
control of separate authorized individuals or teams so that
no one individual or team will know the whole data. 2. A
process by which a cryptographic key is split into multiple
key components, individually sharing no knowledge of
the original key, which can be subsequently input into, or
output from, a cryptographic module by separate entities
and combined to recreate the original cryptographic key”
(CNSSI 4009).
```
**Split tunnelling** Capability to pass specific network traffic through a
**V** irtual **P** rivate **N** etwork tunnel for security reasons, while
allowing other/general traffic to traverse the network
directly but insecurely, typically for network performance
and efficiency reasons. “The process of allowing a remote
user or device to establish a non-remote connection with a
system and simultaneously communicate via some other
connection to a resource in an external network. This
method of network access enables a user to access remote
devices, and simultaneously, access uncontrolled
networks” _(NZISM)._ “Functionality that allows personnel
to access both public network infrastructure and a Virtual
Private Network connection at the same time, such as an
organisation’s system and the internet” _(AusISM)._ See also
VPN split tunnelling

```
Sploit Leet/hacker slang for exploit.
```
```
Splunk Commercial application for analysing logs.
```
```
SPoF Abbrev: S ingle P oint o f F ailure.
```
```
SPOKE Obsolete and deprecated US S pecial I ntelligence S ervice
term for COMINT. See also UMBRA, MORAY.
```
```
Spoliation Deliberate (malicious) or accidental (benign) spoilage ( i.e.
destruction, discrediting, or otherwise devaluing) of
forensic evidence. “Act of making or allowing a change to
Electronically Stored Information where there is a
requirement to keep it intact. Note: Spoliation can take the
form of ESI destruction, corruption, or alteration of the
ESI or associated metadata as well as rendering ESI
```

```
unavailable ( e.g., due to encryption with no access to the
decryption key, loss of media, under the control of a third
party, etc. )” (ISO/IEC 27050-1). “Act of making or
allowing change(s) to the potential digital evidence that
diminishes its evidential value” (ISO/IEC 27037).
```
**Sponge function** Family of cryptographic algorithms that can generate an
arbitrary length output string from an arbitrary length
input string, using defined internal states, transformation,
and padding. Has applications in hashing, stream ciphers,
and pseudorandom number generation.

```
Spoof, spoofing Deliberate faking or falsification of identity information in
systems, networks, or protocols that lack adequate
authentication controls, e.g. email addresses, caller ID
numbers, IP and MAC addresses. Typically used to
conceal the perpetrator’s true identity, bypass simplistic
identity-based access controls, socially engineer a target,
commit fraud or hack. “Take action intended to deceive a
user, an observer (such as an eavesdropper), or a
resource” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “Impersonating a legitimate
resource or user” (ISO/IEC 27033-1). “The act of faking
the sending address of a transmission in order to gain
illegal entry into a secure system” (ISACA glossary).
“Attempt by an unauthorized entity to gain access to a
system by posing as an authorized user” (SANS glossary).
See also masquerade.
```
```
Spook, spooky Deliberately vague, tongue-in-cheek yet somewhat
sinister reference to someone who appears to be part of
the intelligence community, i.e. a spy, agent, intelligence
operative, source, collector, etc. working for or on behalf
of one or more government agencies. See also cyber-
spook.
```
```
Spouseware Neologism for spyware used by one partner in a personal
relationship to spy on (typically track and monitor)
another, having exploited opportunities to infect the
partner’s I nformation T echnology systems. See also
malware, ransomware, adware, crimeware, scareware,
stalkerware.
```

```
Spora Species of ransomware in the wild since 2017.
```
```
Spread spectrum Radio communications technique involving the
transmission of (usually covert) messages across a range
of frequencies simultaneously, reducing the possibility of
an unauthorised interceptor identifying the transmission
and ascertaining the information content, and accidental
or deliberate interference (jamming) corrupting the
information. “Telecommunications techniques in which a
signal is transmitted in a bandwidth considerably greater
than the frequency content of the original information.
Frequency-hopping, direct sequence spreading, time
scrambling, and combinations of these techniques are
forms of spread spectrum” (CNSSI 4009).
```
```
Spy Secret agent working undercover to gather intelligence,
usually for commercial (industrial or economic espionage)
or national security purposes. See also spook.
```
**Spying, espionage,
counterintelligence**

```
Covertly selecting, collecting, and analysing intelligence,
typically for commercial and/or national security/military
purposes but sometimes for personal reasons, e.g. to sell
to an information broker or to exploit through social
engineering, fraud, hacking, blackmail, etc.
```
```
Spyware Category of malware used to spy on victims through their
I nformation T echnology devices, e.g. covertly sending
information about the programs executed, websites
visited, or data submitted, to a remote system or hacker.
May involve surreptitious access to the microphone,
camera, and/or keyboard. “Deceptive software, that
collects private or confidential information from a
computer user. Note: Information can include matters
such as websites most frequently visited or more sensitive
information such as passwords” (ISO/IEC 27032 ).
“Software whose purpose is to monitor a computer user’s
actions ( e.g., websites visited) and report these actions to
a third party without the informed consent of that
machine’s owner or legitimate user” (ISACA glossary).
See also spouseware, stalkerware.
```

```
SQL i njection (SQLi) Versatile, effective, and hence very common means of
hacking vulnerable D ata B ase applications involving the

program instructions and privileged DB commands. A
form of code injection. “A type of input validation attack
specific to database-driven applications where SQL code
is inserted into application queries to manipulate the
database” (SANS glossary).
```

```
living in a foreign country, or asking a foreign
government for information about the same person” (CIA
```

```
Updated Executive Order 12333 Attorney General
```

```
period

```

```
E nvironment (SOE)
```

```
P rocedure (SOP)
```

```
data

```

```
and Assurance
Registry)

```

**Stateful firewall,
stateful [packet]
inspection, dynamic
packet filtering**

```
In contrast to simple packet filters, second-generation
firewalls analyse packets in context and maintain internal
state tables for the TCP/IP connections, e.g. reconstructing
fragmented packets before scrutinising the content or
identifying spoofed responses lacking the corresponding
requests. “A firewall architecture that tracks each
connection traversing all interfaces of the firewall and
makes sure they are valid” (ISACA glossary). “A firewall
architecture that works at the network layer. Unlike static
packet filtering, which examines a packet based on the
information in its header, stateful inspection examines not
just the header information but also the contents of the
packet up through the application layer in order to
determine more about the packet than just information
about its source and destination” (SANS glossary).Cf.
deep packet inspection.
```

```
Statement See instruction.
```

```
S tatement o f
A pplicability (SoA)
```

```
List or matrix identifying information security controls
needed to satisfy relevant control objectives, i.e. those that

organisation. Essentially a completeness check,
confirming that all 90+ generic controls from ISO/IEC
27001 Annex A, have been duly considered and not
ignorantly neglected by management. “Documented
statement describing the control objectives and controls
that are relevant and applicable to the organization’s
```

```
ISMS” (ISO/IEC TR 27019). “Documentation of all
necessary controls and justification for the inclusion or
exclusion of such controls” (ISO/IEC 27701 DRAFT 2nd
edition). “Documentation of all necessary controls and
justification for inclusion or exclusion of controls. Notes:
Organizations may not require all controls listed in Annex
A or may even exceed the list in Annex A with additional
controls established by the organization itself. All
identified risks shall be documented by the organization
according to the requirements of this document. All
identified risks and the risk management measures
(controls) established to address them shall be reflected in
the statement of applicability” (ISO/IEC 42001).
```

```
Static electricity Electrostatic charging and discharging of insulating
materials by very high voltages, normally induced by the
frictional movement of surfaces past each other. Static
discharges can damage semiconductor junctions in
electrostatically sensitive electronic devices, causing them
to fail immediately ... or at some future point. A lightning
storm is a dramatic demonstration of the immense power
of static discharges.
```

```
backed, or tolerated by the Iranian government, active in
2023.
```

```
Static testing See S tatic A pplication S ecurity T esting.
```

```
STE Abbrev: S ecure T erminal E quipment.
```

```
Stealth virus Cryptic virus that attempts to conceal its presence on the
system, typically by intercepting and manipulating
folder/disk access requests. When for instance an
unskilled user or a crude antivirus program searches the
disk, the virus dynamically removes or changes program
names, file names, etc. in the information
provided/presented by the O perating S ystem. More
sophisticated methods are widely used by more advanced
malware, including A dvanced P ersistent T hreats.
“Stealthing is a term that refers to approaches used by
malicious code to conceal its presence on the infected
system” (SANS glossary).
```
```
Steganalysis “The process of detecting and defeating the use of
steganography” (SANS glossary).
```

**Steganography, stego,
steg**

```
Hiding information ‘in plain sight,’ e.g. by
cryptographically manipulating the least significant data
bits of certain pixels in a graphic image causing changes
that are virtually invisible to the human eye but can be
identified by a program that checks the same pixel values.
Commonly used to watermark and assert ownership of
and copyright on digital content, or to pass covert
messages despite surveillance. “The art, science, and
practice of communicating in a way that hides the
existence of the communication” (CNSSI 4009 ). “The art
and science of communicating in a way that hides the
existence of the communication. For example, a child
pornography image can be hidden inside another graphic
image file, audio file, or other file format” (NIST SP 800-
101 ). “Methods of hiding the existence of a message or
other data. This is different than cryptography, which
hides the meaning of a message but does not hide the
message itself. An example of a steganographic method is
‘invisible’ ink” (SANS glossary).
```
```
STELLARWIND One of several secret US surveillance programs.
```
```
Stepping stone See foothold.
```
```
Stingray Family of commercial surveillance devices capable of
spoofing cellular phone base stations, enabling the police,
```

```
F ederal B ureau of I nvestigation, etc. to conduct M an- I n-
T he- M iddle attacks in order to intercept voice calls and
SMS/TXT messages, capture metadata, etc. from
cellphones within range, sometimes with valid court
orders or warrants. See also IMSI-catcher.
```

```
STIR/SHAKEN Abbrev: S ecure T elephone I dentity R evisited/ S ignature-
based H andling of A sserted information using to KEN s.
```

```
STIX (Structured
Threat Information
```

```
Structured, flexible, extensible language for sharing
```

```
Stoned One of the earliest boot-sector viruses, allegedly written

```

```
“Network whose primary purpose is the transfer of data
```

```
Stratified sample,
strata
```
```
Audit sample selected from different subsets (strata) of
```

```
Stream cipher Type of cryptographic algorithm that rapidly encrypts
each character, byte, or bit as it flows through the process
by combining (typically XORing) it with a character, byte,
or bit from a parallel pseudorandom keystream.
Examples: RC4, AES-CTR, Salsa20, ChaCha20. “Works
by encryption a message a single bit, byte, or computer
word at a time” (SANS glossary).Cf. block cipher.

```

```
dynamic pressure originated within an urban system, with
the potential for cumulative impacts on the ability and

22300 ). “A significant magnitude of force applied to the
organization” (OCEG GRC Glossary). See also distress,
```

```
Stresser, booter Commercial Internet traffic load-testing services, rentable
for minutes or hours at a time, ostensibly for legitimate
performance and capacity stress-testing of websites by
their owners but in reality mostly used by black hats for
D istributed D enial- o f- S ervice attacks, extortion, and
```

```
2382 ). “Testing to evaluate a system or component at or
```

```
Strontium State-sponsored Russian-speaking hacking/malware group
```

```
S tructured E xception
H andling (SEH)
```

```
Windows security technique to control the way various
events are dealt with during the execution of programs, in

from flaws and bugs, whether accidentally or deliberately
caused, such as divide-by-zero errors, program crashes,
```

```
T ailored A ccess O perations unit.
```

```
Neologism about identifying originators of artistic works
```

```
See expert.
```

**Subscriber Identity
Module (SIM), SIM
card**

```
Tamper-resistant smart card containing the unique
identification numbers (particularly the IMSI) used to
associate (identify and authenticate) a cellular service
subscriber (customer) with the physical device (such as a
smartphone, laptop, or smart meter) they are using. Also
stores other data such as the emergency services phone
number for the issuing country, some phone book entries,

connected to the host device via 14 standard-sized gold-
plated contact pads housed in different sizes of plastic
carrier (standard, micro, or nano SIMs). “A smart card

800-101). See also UICC, G lobal S ystem for M obile
```

```
Subsequent event Something that happens afterwards. “Events or
```

```
Substantial
modification

```

```
Subsymbolic AI “AI based on techniques and models that use an implicit
```

**_P_** _rotection_ **_R_** _egulation)_.

**Supervisory authority
concerned**

```
“A supervisory authority which is concerned by the
processing of personal data because: (a) the controller or
processor is established on the territory of the Member
State of that supervisory authority; (b) data subjects
residing in the Member State of that supervisory authority
are substantially affected or likely to be substantially
```

```
S upervisory C ontrol
A nd D ata A cquisition
(SCADA)
```
```
Control system that monitors and responds in real time to
the state of industrial plant and machinery (such as
machine tools, conveyor belts, pumps, electrical systems,
and elevators) through the associated I ndustrial C ontrol
S ystems. ‘Supervisory’ reflects the way that modern
O perational T echnology devices on industrial plant
(including I ndustrial I nternet o f T hings things ) are largely
autonomous, reacting to local conditions without real-time
remote control. SCADA typically directs, oversees, and
coordinates the distributed devices, e.g. showing operators
what is going on through a mimic panel, logging
operational parameters/metrics, updating tags on the
distributed devices, and raising alerts or alarms when
appropriate. It may intervene remotely to exert control
under certain conditions, e.g. to shut down a
malfunctioning or suspect device, particularly if that is
necessary to ensure safety. “Process control system
generally used to control dispersed assets using
centralized data acquisition and supervisory controls”
(ISO/IEC 27019). “Systems used to control and monitor
industrial and manufacturing processes and utility
facilities” (ISACA glossary). See also I ndustrial
A utomation and C ontrol S ystems.
```
```
Superzap Privileged IBM mainframe program allows the user to
override logical access controls that would otherwise
```

```
prevent their access to executable programs, in order to
apply binary patches. Exemplifies the powerful rights that
system administrators have or can potentially obtain,
emphasising the need for them to be both competent and
trustworthy.
```

```
Supplier, contractor,
producer, seller,
vendor
```
```

individual that enters into agreement with the acquirer for
the supply of a product or service. Note 1: Other terms
commonly used for supplier are contractor, producer,
seller, or vendor. Note 2: The acquirer and the supplier
can be part of the same organization. Note 3: Types of
suppliers include those organizations that permit
agreement negotiation with an acquirer and those that do
not permit negotiation with agreements, e.g. end-user
license agreements, terms of use, or open source products
copyright or intellectual property releases” (ISO/IEC
27036-1). “An entity having an agreement with an
acquirer to design, develop, manufacture, maintain,
modify, deliver or supply solutions under terms of an
agreement. Examples include individuals, partnerships,
companies, corporations, and associations” (ISACA
glossary). “Organisations, such as application developers,
ICT equipment manufacturers and service providers, that
provide products and services. Suppliers can also include
other organisations involved in distribution channels”
(AusISM).
```
```
Supplier relationship Ongoing business arrangement between a supplier and
customer involving the exchange of information pertinent
to the products supplied. “Agreement or agreements
between acquirers and suppliers to conduct business,
deliver products or services, and realize business benefit”
(ISO/IEC 27036-1).
```
**Supply chain, supply
network, supply mesh,
supply web**

```
Production and delivery of commercial products normally
involves several suppliers sequentially adding value to the
raw materials, often but not necessarily in a linear
sequence. Due to the many-to-many commercial
relationships, ‘network,’ ‘web,’ or ‘mesh’ is more
descriptive of the complexities than ‘chain.’ “Set of
organizations with linked set of resources and processes,
```

```
each of which acts as an acquirer, supplier, or both to form
successive supplier relationships established upon
placement of a purchase order, agreement, or other formal
sourcing agreement. Note 1: A supply chain can include
vendors, manufacturing facilities, logistics providers,
distribution centres, distributors, wholesalers, and other
organizations involved in the manufacturing, processing,
design and development, and handling and delivery of the
products, or service providers involved in the operation,
management, and delivery of the services. Note 2: The
supply chain view is relative to the position of the
acquirer” (ISO/IEC 27036-1). “Two-way relationship of
organizations, people, processes, logistics, information,
technology and resources engaged in activities and
creating value from the sourcing of materials through the
delivery of products or services. Note: The supply chain
may include vendors, subcontractors, manufacturing
facilities, logistics providers, internal distribution centres,
distributors, wholesalers and other entities that lead to the
end user” (ISO 22300). “A linked set of resources and
processes between multiple tiers of developers that begins
with the sourcing of products and services and extends
through the design, development, manufacturing,
processing, handling, and delivery of products and
services to the acquirer” (OMB Circular A-130).
```
**Supply chain
compromise or attack**

```
a. Some sort of incident or attack disrupting the supply
of products ( i.e. goods such as computer chips, or
services such as cloud computing) from upstream
suppliers to downstream customers.
b. Attack ultimately targeting one or more customers of
one or more compromised suppliers, exploiting the
trusted commercial relationships.
c. Compromise of one or more products at some
indeterminate upstream point in the supply chain
( e.g. surreptitious substitution or sabotage of
security-relevant hardware components, subunits or
subsystems, firmware, software, or shared library
functions, deliberate insertion or non-removal of
flaws and bugs, infection with malware, or coercion
of workers during product manufacture, logistics,
storage, installation, or maintenance) causing a
```

```
cascade of downstream risk for all dependent
customers and users.
```
```
S upply C hain
C ontinuity M anagement
(SCCM)
```
```
“Application of business continuity management to a
supply chain. Notes: Business continuity management
should be applied to all the tiers of an organization’s
supply chain. In practice, an organization usually would
only apply it to the first tier of their suppliers and
influence critical suppliers to apply SCCM to their
suppliers” (ISO 22300).
```

```
S upply - chain L evels for
```

```
Supply chain risk Uncertainty regarding or arising from supply chains.

reputation), organizational assets, individuals, other
```

```
S upply C hain R isk
```

```
Management of risks throughout a supply chain,
potentially going further than both T hird P arty R isk

```
```
Support process Typically, an administrative process or activity. “Process
that supports core processes by providing and managing
necessary resources without delivering direct customer
value” (ISO/IEC 27022 ). See also business process, core
process, management process.
```

**S** upport **V** ector **M** achine
**(SVM)**

```
“Machine learning algorithm that finds decision
boundaries with maximal margins. Note: Support vectors
```

```
are sets of data points that define the positioning of the
decision boundaries (hyper-planes)” (ISO/IEC 22989).
```
```
Surge Excessive supply voltage lasting more than just a few
micro- or milliseconds. May blow fuses or damage
electronics having inadequate voltage regulation. See also
spike, dip, brownout.
```
**Surge protector, surge
suppressor**

```
Relatively cheap, low-quality substitute for properly
engineered power regulation and protection techniques,
often consisting of nothing more than an M etal O xide
V aristor across the power supply. “Filters out electrical
surges and spikes” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Surrogation Whereas metrics are usually intended to help improve
things for the benefit of all stakeholders, individuals
sometimes find ways to game the system by intentionally
manipulating or misrepresenting the metric itself to give
the appearance of improvement, rather than truly
improving the object of measurement – particularly if they
stand to benefit individually, e.g. through enhanced
reputations, bonuses, or promotions. Surrogation may also
be unintentional, where misunderstandings, biases, or
poor metrics definitions and measurement processes lead
to inappropriate decisions and changes. ‘Managing strictly
by the numbers’ can be a risky approach if the numbers
are not sufficiently representative of and correlated with
performance.
```
```
Surveillance a. Process of covertly observing, snooping, or spying
on someone’s activities, whether literally watching
them, surreptitiously monitoring and perhaps
recording their activities and movements, or tapping
in to their network/online and/or telephone
communications, e.g. using spyware. See also mass
surveillance and workplace surveillance.
b. Overt and legitimate (above-board) process of
observing, assessing, and evaluating something – a
form of oversight, e.g. surveillance audit.
```
```
Surveillance audit,
interim audit
```
```
Periodic re-evaluation of an organisation’s conformity
with the obligations and expectations of laws/regulations,
```

```
standards, and contracts such as ISO/IEC 27001.
Typically conducted near the first and second anniversary
of a certification audit.
```
```
Survivability Capability to survive serious and potentially existential
incidents or disasters, not necessarily unscathed but still
operating to some extent.
```
```
Susceptibility Vulnerability or inability to avoid being successfully
attacked.
```
```
Suspense file See hold file. “A computer file used to maintain
information (transactions, payments or other events) until
the proper disposition of that information can be
determined. Notes: Once the proper disposition of the
item is determined, it should be removed from the
suspense file and processed in accordance with the proper
procedures for that particular transaction. Two examples
of items that may be included in a suspense file are receipt
of a payment from a source that is not readily identified or
data that do not yet have an identified match during
migration to a new application” (ISACA glossary).
```
**Suspicion, suspicious** Something that strikes an alert and security-aware person
as unusual and causes concern as a potential information
security matter, such as a stranger in a controlled area,
information assets unexpectedly going missing, or the
belief that confidential information may have been
disclosed inappropriately. While some suspicious events
may turn out to be entirely innocuous or benign, some
may be near-misses, events, or incidents worth reporting
to management or the Help Desk.

```
Sustainability Since few information risks are short-term, it is generally
necessary for the corresponding information security
controls to persist, operating effectively for considerable
periods (years or decades). Sustainable controls are self-
perpetuating, justifying their continued operation because
of the risk mitigation value they generate, provided the
stakeholders appreciate that as a result of appropriate
metrics and information about threats and incidents.
```

```
SVM Abbrev: S upport V ector M achine.
```
```
Swap Mutual exchange A ⇄ B, e.g. when pages or segments of
data are swapped back-and-forth between fast primary
memory (RAM) for processing and relatively slow
secondary (disk) storage, or in social engineering scams
such as bait-and-switch and SIM swap.
```
```
SWG Abbrev: S ecure W eb G ateway.
```
**Swiss cheese model** Conceptual model in which, under unfortunate
circumstances, imperfections (holes) in overlapping but
imperfect layers of control (cheese slices) may align,
allowing safety hazards, dangers or threats to penetrate
multilayered defences and so harm or compromise a
vulnerable resource.

```
Switch a. [Noun] L ocal A rea N etwork device providing
interconnections with basic network traffic
management and routing capabilities at layers 2 (data
link) or 3 (network) of the OSI stack. “Device which
provides connectivity between networked devices by
means of internal switching mechanisms, with the
switching technology typically implemented at layer
2 or layer 3 of the OSI reference model” (ISO/IEC
27033-1). “A data link layer device that enables local
area network (LAN) segments to be created and
interconnected, giving the added benefit of reducing
collision domains in Ethernet-based networks”
(ISACA glossary). Cf. hub.
b. [Noun] Electromechanical or purely electronic
device to open or close an electrical connection – a
binary choice.
c. [Verb] To swap items, generally surreptitiously, e.g.
bait-and-switch.
```
```
Symbolic AI “AI based on techniques and models that manipulate
symbols and structures according to explicitly defined
rules to obtain inferences. Notes: Compared to
subsymbolic AI, symbolic AI produces declarative
outputs, whereas subsymbolic AI is based on statistical
```

```
approaches and produces outputs with a given probability
of error” (ISO/IEC 22989). See also subsymbolic AI.
```
**Symmetric
cryptography,
symmetric
cryptographic system,
symmetric cipher**

```
Cryptosystem in which an identical or trivially related key
is used for both encryption and decryption. Clearly the
key must be kept secret from anyone not authorised to
encrypt or decrypt the information, and must be
sufficiently long and complex to resist brute force attacks
or simple guesses. “Cryptography in which the same key
is used for encryption and decryption” (ISO/IEC 2382 ).
“An algorithm that encrypts data using a single key. In
symmetric cryptographic algorithms, a single key is used
for encipherment (encrypting) and decipherment
(decrypting)” (ISACA glossary). “A branch of
cryptography involving algorithms that use the same key
for two different steps of the algorithm (such as
encryption and decryption, or signature creation and
signature verification). Symmetric cryptography is
sometimes called ‘secret-key cryptography’ (versus
public-key cryptography) because the entities that share
the key” (SANS glossary). Cf. asymmetric cryptography.
```
```
Synchronous
transmission
```
```
Type of digital datacommunications protocol or
modulation method in which each character of a message
is transmitted with precise timing that is matched
accurately by the receiving system. With no need for start
and stop bits surrounding each character, this is a more
efficient process that relies on stable clocks at both ends,
possibly with a special (re)synchronisation sequence at
various points in the transmission. “Block-at-a-time data
transmission” (ISACA glossary). Cf. asynchronous
transmission.
```
```
SYN flood “A denial of service attack that sends a host more TCP
SYN packets (request to synchronize sequence numbers,
used when opening a connection) than the protocol
implementation can handle” (SANS glossary).
```
```
SYNful Knock Persistent exploit against Cisco routers involving the
installation (using a privileged userID) of a hacked
version of the O perating S ystem (malware) with a C 2
```

```
capability allowing the router to be remotely controlled
through HTTP and custom TCP packets.
```
**Sysinternals** Microsoft’s suite of Windows system, network, and
security management tools. Useful to diagnose problems
with performance, slow booting, spyware, _etc_. Originally
open-source thanks to the generosity of its original author
but no longer, having been absorbed by Redmond like a
whale consumes a plankton.

```
SYSKEY Windows function optionally encrypts stored password
hashes to frustrate brute force and rainbow table attacks in
the event a hacker successfully obtains the S ecurity
A ccounts M anager (called the ‘Windows Account
Database’ by SYSKEY.exe). The RC-4 encryption key is
normally stored in the registry but Windows can be
configured to demand that it is typed in or provided on
removable media as a password at startup in order to
continue booting. Fake ‘Microsoft support’ phone
scammers sometimes socially engineer this configuration
change in order to lock victims out of their own
computers and so coerce them into paying a ransom,
unless they simply revert the change by loading a previous
restore point or registry backup ... assuming they have
one and it hasn’t been deleted or corrupted by the
scammers.
```
```
Syslog De facto technical standard for system and application
logging, primarily on UNIX systems. “The system
logging facility for Unix systems” (SANS glossary).
```
```
System Elements, components, subsystems, etc. working together
in harmony to achieve objectives. Usually, in the
technology context, refers to a computer system, i.e.
hardware platform plus the associated firmware and
software forming a discrete functional unit. Otherwise, an
integrated suite of related items and processes, such as a
M anagement S ystem or O perating S ystem, or an even
broader holistic assemblage including the associated
people, processes, physical environment, business, social
context, etc. “Combination of interacting elements
organized to achieve one or more stated purposes”
```

```
(ISO/IEC/IEEE 21840). “A related set of IT equipment
and software used for the processing, storage or
communication of information and the governance
framework in which it operates” (NZISM). “Combination
of interacting elements organised to achieve one or more
stated purposes. Notes: A system can be considered as a
product or as the services it provides. In practice, the
interpretation of its meaning is frequently clarified by the
use of an associative noun, e.g. aircraft system.
Alternatively, the word ‘system’ can be substituted simply
by a context-dependent synonym, e.g. aircraft, though this
can then obscure a system principles perspective”
(ISO/IEC 27036-1). “A generic term covering the
operating systems, web server, application frameworks
and related infrastructure” (SCP QRG). “Refers to the
infrastructure, software, people, processes, and data that
are designed, implemented, and operated to work together
to achieve one or more specific business objectives (for
example, delivery of services or production of goods) in
accordance with management-specified requirements”
( T rust S ervices C riteria). “An interconnected set of
information resources under the same direct management
control which shares common functionality. A system
normally includes hardware, software, information, data,
applications, communications, and people. A system can
be, for example, a local area network (LAN) including
smart terminals that supports a branch office, an agency-
wide backbone, a communications network, a
departmental data processing center including its
operating system and utilities, a tactical radio network, or
a shared information processing service organization
(IPSO)” (OMB Circular A-130). See also device, V irtual
M achine, host, node, server.
```

```

2382 ). “A systematic investigation of a real or planned
```

```
Systematic Methodical, step-by-step, structured, considered, logical,
```

```
infrastructure, software, people, processes, and data”
```

```
System design a. The architectural design of a system, showing how

```

```
components, modules, interfaces and data for a
```

```
System event Event affecting or involving a system. “An occurrence
that could lead to the loss of, or disruption to, operations,

arise from actual or attempted unauthorized access or use
by internal or external parties and (a) impair (or
potentially impair) the availability, integrity, or
confidentiality of information or systems; (b) result in
unauthorized disclosure or theft of information or other
assets or the destruction or corruption of data; or (c) cause
```

**S** ystem for **C** ross-
domain **I** dentity
**M** anagement **(SCIM)**

```
Protocol to automate the provisioning, de-provisioning
and synchronisation of userIDs, groups, and access rights.
Defines a consistent schema and RESTful A pplication
P rogramming I nterface for creating, reading, updating,
and deleting identity resources, allowing different systems
to exchange identity data in a standardised manner. “An
application-level protocol for provisioning and managing
identity data specified through SCIM schemas. A SCIM
server provides a set of resources, the allowable contents
of which are defined by a set of schema URIs and a
resource type. SCIM ’ s schema is not a document-centric
```

```
System files Primarily software comprising a computer’s O perating
```

```
Systemic Pertaining to a system. Cf. systematic.
```

```
System incident,
systemic incident
```
```
Incident affecting or involving a system. “A system event
that requires action on the part of entity management to
prevent or reduce the impact of a system event on the

S ervices C riteria).
```

```
System integrity System integrity. “Quality of a data processing system
```

**S** ystem on **C** hip **(SoC) I** ntegrated **C** ircuit containing multiple logical units ( _e.g._
**C** entral **P** rocessing **U** nit, memory and input/output

```
Systems engineering The engineering of systems – particularly computer
```

```
engineering
```

```
risks. A specialism within systems engineering. “A
specialty engineering discipline of systems engineering. It
applies scientific, mathematical, engineering, and
measurement concepts, principles, and methods to deliver,
consistent with defined constraints and necessary trade-
offs, a trustworthy asset protection capability that satisfies
stakeholder requirements; is seamlessly integrated into the
delivered system; and presents residual risk that is deemed
acceptable and manageable to stakeholders” (OMB
Circular A-130).
```
```
System test Test to gain assurance of a complete system’s conformity
with and satisfaction of the specifications, expectations, or
requirements. “Testing conducted on a complete,
integrated system to evaluate the system ’ s compliance
with its specified requirements. Notes: System test
procedures are typically performed by the system
```

```
maintenance staff in their development library. [and] The
process of testing an integrated hardware and software
system to verify that the system meets its specified
requirements. Such testing may be conducted in the
development environment and the target environment”
(ISACA glossary). See also unit test, integration test,
smoke test, load test, stress test, security test, penetration
test, acceptance test, regression test.
```
**System time** “Time generated by the system clock and used by the
operating system, not the time computed by the operating
system” _(ISO/IEC 27037)._

**System user** See user. “A general user or a privileged user of a system”
_(NZISM)._ “An individual or (system) process acting on
behalf of an individual that is authorized to access a
system” _(NIST SP 800-171).
