```
is executed under specified conditions, the
results are observed or recorded and an
evaluation is made of some aspect of the
system or component” (ISACA glossary). “The
determination of one or more characteristics
according to a procedure and, although
typically quantitative, it can be qualitative ( e.g.
a presumptive test with a colour change)”
(FSRCoP). See also structured and
unstructured test; black, grey, and white box
test; unit test, smoke test, usability test, stress
test, system test, regression test, security test,
acceptance test, self-test, penetration test
(among others), oh, and audit. And
qualification. And fact-check.
```
```
Test case Business or technical scenario with the
associated test data, used to test or exercise a
system or some part of it. May be based on an
actual situation or one created expressly for the
purpose, e.g. simulating an obscure hack or an
unusual combination of circumstances.
Essentially an experiment or trial with a
predicted or desired outcome. “Documentation
specifying inputs, predicted results and a set of
execution conditions for a test item” (ISACA
glossary).
Innovative court case exploring the meaning
and ramifications of a particular law in order to
set a legal precedent. It tests the particular
understanding and interpretation of the statute,
e.g. an ambiguous clause or apparent conflict.
```
**Test data, evaluation
data**

```
Digital data, ideally generated entirely
artificially for testing a system, process,
product, function, device, etc. against the
specified requirements for security, privacy,
```

```
resilience, performance, capacity, etc. That
implies deep knowledge of the data structures,
values, ranges, and relationships, requiring
competent systems analysis. More often,
however, test data are sampled and modified
from production data raising confidentiality,
integrity, privacy, and other concerns. “Data
used to assess the performance of a final
model. Note: Test data is disjoint from training
data and validation data” (ISO/IEC 22989 ).
“Simulated transactions that can be used to test
processing logic, computations and controls
actually programmed in computer applications.
Individual programs or an entire system can be
tested” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Test design “Documentation specifying the details of the
test approach for a software feature or
combination of software features and
identifying the associated tests” (ISACA
glossary).
```
```
Test documentation Documentation concerning the scoping,
objectives, planning, execution,
results/findings, analysis, and eventual
outcome/conclusion of testing.
“Documentation describing plans for, or results
of, the testing of a system or component. Types
include test case specification, test incident
report, test log, test plan, test procedure and
test report” (ISACA glossary).
```
**T** est **-D** riven
**D** evelopment **(TDD),
test-first development**

```
Software development method that involves
preparing test criteria, test cases, etc. from the
system specifications at the earliest
opportunity, possibly during the specification
phase as an integral activity. Software is then
```

```
developed and if necessary modified explicitly
to pass the tests, thereby satisfying the
specified requirements. The method is
critically dependent on, and hence should
improve, the quality (accuracy,
comprehensiveness, appropriateness, integrity)
of the specifications and analysis, but may
struggle with changes that emerge during the
development process ( e.g. additional control
requirements to resist newly recognised
threats).
```
```
Test environment Set of computer systems, networks, devices,
data, and supporting tools and processes used
for testing and gaining assurance on developed
software. Ideally isolated from both
development and production environments
using separate hardware or virtual systems to
strengthen change control and reduce risks,
particularly to production services and data.
See also sandbox.
```
```
Test harness,
automated test
framework
```
```
Combination of a test execution engine
(software to automate the testing process) and
a repository of test scripts (details of the tests
to be conducted plus the associated test data),
used for regression testing of software.
```
```
Test procedure “A formal document developed from a test
plan that presents detailed instructions for the
setup, operation and evaluation of the results
for each defined test” (ISACA glossary).
```
**T** ETRA **E** ncryption
**A** lgorithm **(TEA)**

```
Set of four proprietary cryptographic
algorithms (TEA1 through TEA4) specified
and licenced by the E uropean
T elecommunications S tandards I nstitute for
```

```
use in TETRA ( Te rrestrial Tr unked R adio)
systems. These are stream ciphers, used to
encrypt and decrypt digital messages streaming
through a TETRA network. TEA1 is known
(through reverse engineering and
cryptanalysis) to use just 32 bits selected from
an 80-bit key, a fundamental flaw and a classic
illustration of the weakness of security by
obscurity.
```
```
THC Hydra, Hydra Brute force network authentication attack tool
from T he H acker’s C hoice, a hacker group.
Can perform dictionary attacks on more than
50 protocols. More info: https://www.thc.org/
```
**T** he **A** mnesic **I** ncognito
**L** ive **S** ystem **(TAILS)**

```
Linux-based open-source portable O perating
S ystem and applications designed to leave
behind no forensic evidence of user activity on
the computer and to conceal online activities.
Used by hackers, spies, spooks, activists,
investigative journalists, and others attempting
to ensure their anonymity.
```
```
TheHarvester Google application ostensibly designed to
support the target research initial phase of
penetration testing, or as a means to check how
much information about one’s organisation is
publicly accessible on the web through search
engines, social media, etc. An example of dual-
use technology that can be used for both
offensive and defensive purposes. More info:
https://cod e.g oogle.com/archive/p/theharvester/
```
```
The Internet Worm See Morris Worm.
```
```
Thermal runaway Exothermic (heat-generating, energy-releasing)
processes or reactions that become even more
```

```
exothermic at higher temperatures can become
uncontrollable, leading to smoke, fire, and
meltdown incidents. A destructive form of
positive feedback. Physical damage,
overloading, or short circuits in lithium-ion
batteries, for instance, can be significant risks
for M obile T echnologies such as in E lectric
V ehicles and portable electronics. Likewise
control failures, accidents, or cyber incidents
affecting chemical plants, oil refineries,
B attery E nergy S torage S ystems, nuclear
power stations, etc.
```
**_Thing_** , **Internet of**
**_Things_** **device, system,
equipment** _etc_

```
Networkable smart device, e.g. B uilding
M anagement S ystem, H eating, V entilating,
and A ir- C onditioning system, alarm system,
lighting controller or lightbulb, home
entertainment system, door lock, garage door
opener, refrigerator, vending machine, baby
monitor, meter, vehicle, smartphone, laptop,
smart sensor ( e.g. fitness monitor), pacemaker,
or some other such gizmo (including
processors embedded within or attached to
dumb equipment) that is, or could become, part
of the I nternet o f T hings. Often but not
necessarily cheap, small, and low-powered,
with limited D ata P rocessing capabilities and
storage capacity. Vulnerable to design flaws
and bugs, hacking, and malware, including
ransomware and physical threats.
```
```
Third line [of defence
or accountability]
```
```
In the three lines model, the third line provides
assurance through audit and oversight of the
second-line experts advising the first line on
risk management. In World War I, the third line
trenches were for reserves, while the second
line supported brave troops in the front (first)
```

```
line, sent over the top into no man’s land.
“Individuals and teams that specialize in and
provide a high level of assurance on activities
performed by the First Line and Second Line.
The Third Line may include internal audit,
external audit or outside experts who are
sufficiently objective and competent” (OCEG
GRC Glossary).
```
```
Third party, third-
party, member of the
extended enterprise
```
```
Independent person or external organisation
not directly employed or owned by the
organisation itself (the first party). “A natural
or legal person, public authority, agency or
body other than the data subject, controller,
processor and persons who, under the direct
authority of the controller or processor, are
authorised to process personal data” ( G eneral
D ata P rotection R egulation). “Privacy
stakeholder other than the personally
identifiable information (PII) principal, the PII
controller and the PII processor, and the natural
persons who are authorized to process the data
under the direct authority of the PII controller
or the PII processor” (ISO/IEC 29100 ). “A
partner that conducts substantial actions &
controls on behalf of the organization” (OCEG
GRC Glossary). “An individual or organization
other than the entity and its employees. Third
parties may be customers, suppliers, business
partners, or others” ( T rust S ervices C riteria).
See also external party.
```
**T** hird **P** arty **R** isk
**M** anagement **(TPRM)**

```
Techniques to identify, assess, evaluate,
address, and gain assurance regarding supply
chain risks relating to business relationships
with third parties (not necessarily suppliers, as
with V endor R isk M anagement).
```

**Threat** Person, organisation, situation, or event

```
(whether deliberate or accidental, targeted, or
generic in nature) that is hazardous or
dangerous, capable of acting on an exposed
vulnerability to cause or trigger an information
security incident. An essential element of risk.
“Potential violation of computer security”
( ISO/IEC 2382 ). “Potential cause of an
unwanted incident, which can result in harm to
a system or organization” (ISO/IEC 27000 ).
“Potential cause of an unwanted incident,
which could result in harm to individuals,
assets, a system or organization, the
environment or the community” (ISO 22300).
“Potential cause of an unwanted incident,
which can result in harm to a system,
individual or organization” (ISO/IEC 27032 ).
“Potential source of danger, harm, or other
undesirable outcome. Notes: A threat is a
negative situation in which loss is likely and
over which one has relatively little control; A
threat to one party may pose an opportunity to
another” (ISO 31073). “Potential, deliberate
action that can cause harm to an asset. Note: A
threat is always related to a threat actor, which
can be an individual or an organization” (ISO
23234 ). “Anything ( e.g ., object, substance,
human) that is capable of acting against an
asset in a manner that can result in harm”
(ISACA glossary). “Any circumstance or event
with the potential to adversely impact
organizational operations (including mission,
functions, image, or reputation), organizational
assets, individuals, other organizations, or the
Nation through an information system via
unauthorized access, destruction, disclosure,
modification of information, and/or denial of
```

```
service” (CNSSI 4009 ). “Anything that is
capable of acting in a manner resulting in harm
to an Asset and/or organization; for example,
acts of God (weather, geological events, etc .),
malicious actors, errors, failures” (O-RT).
“Malicious risks such as acts of terrorism,
hostile state activity and cyber-crime. Contrast
with hazard” (UK Resilience Lessons Digest
2023 ). “A potential for violation of security,
which exists when there is a circumstance,
capability, action, or event that could breach
security and cause harm” (SANS glossary). See
also risk source.
```
**Threat actor, threat
agent**

```
Normally the person responsible for, or capable
of, deliberately causing an information security
incident e.g. a fraudster, hacker, or cyberteur.
May be an organisation enabling, supporting,
sponsoring, or commissioning such attacks
( e.g. competitor, adversary, or sworn enemy) or
their agent/s, perhaps acting independently.
Conceivably could also be a natural event or
situation such as an accident, flood, or climate
change, or an authority enforcing compliance
obligations. “Methods and things used to
exploit a vulnerability. Note: Examples include
determination, capability, motive and
resources” (ISACA glossary). “Any agent ( e.g .,
object, substance, human) that is capable of
acting against an Asset in a manner that can
result in harm” (O-RT). “Any entity which may
have a negative impact on the system. This
may be a malicious user who wants to
compromise the system ’ s security controls;
however, it could also be an accidental misuse
of the system or a more physical threat like fire
or flood” (SCP QRG). See also risk source.
```

```
Threat analysis Analysis (rational examination, investigation,
or study) of one or more threats. “Process of
identifying, qualifying and quantifying the
potential cause of an unwanted incident, which
could result in harm to individuals, assets, a
system or organization, the environment or the
community” (ISO 22300). “ An evaluation of
the type, scope and nature of events or actions
that can result in adverse consequences,
identification of the threats that exist against
enterprise assets. Note: The threat analysis
usually defines the level of threat and the
likelihood of it materializing” (ISACA
glossary). Cf. threat assessment, risk analysis,
risk assessment.
```
```
Threat assessment Cursory examination of one or more threats.
“The identification of types of threats that an
organization might be exposed to” (SANS
glossary).
```
```
T hreat cap ability
(TCap)
```
```
One of the risk parameters in the FAIR method
estimating the ability of a threat agent to
compromise the information asset/s under
analysis. “The probable level of force (as
embodied by the time, resources, and
technological capability) that a Threat Agent is
capable of applying against an Asset” (O-RT).
See also C ontrol S trength, P robable L oss
M agnitude, L oss E vent F requency, T hreat
E vent F requency.
```
**Threat community** “A subset of the overall Threat Agent
population that shares key characteristics” _(O-
RT)._


```
Threat event See attack. “Any event during which a threat
element/actor acts against an asset in a manner
that has the potential to directly result in harm”
(ISACA glossary). “Occurs when a Threat
Agent acts against an Asset” (O-RT).
```
**T** hreat **E** vent **F** requency
**(TEF)**

```
One of the risk factors in FAIR estimates the
probability of a threat agent coming into
contact with and acting upon the information
asset/s under analysis. It alludes to the assets
being exposed to threat agents. “The probable
frequency, within a given timeframe, that a
Threat Agent will act against an Asset” (O-RT).
See also C ontrol S trength, P robable L oss
M agnitude, L oss E vent F requency, T hreat
Cap ability.
```
```
Threat intelligence
(threat intel), cyber
threat intelligence
```
```
Actionable intelligence about actual, emerging,
or potential threats to an organisation’s
information and technologies, and hence its
business. There are strategic ( e.g. novel types
of attacks and attackers), tactical ( e.g. attack
vectors), and operational ( e.g. I ndicators o f
C ompromise used to identify successful
attacks, and guidance on how to address
attacks in progress) aspects to this. Strictly
speaking, ‘vulnerability intelligence’ is a
distinct consideration although in practice it
may be treated as part of threat intel.
“Information an organization uses to
understand the threats that have, will, or are
currently targeting the organization. This
information is used to prepare, identify, and
prevent security and cybersecurity threats
looking to take advantage of valuable
resources” (ISACA glossary). “ Where an
organisation may employ a staff member or
```

```
contractor, or purchase a product to collate
information and advice around all the cyber
security risks the organisation faces ” (UK
Cyber Security Breaches Survey 2023 ).
“Information that has been aggregated,
transformed, analysed, interpreted or enriched
to provide the necessary context for decision-
making and to enable relevant and sufficient
understanding in order to mitigate the impact
of an ICT-related incident or of a cyber threat,
including the technical details of a cyber-
attack, those responsible for the attack and
their modus operandi and motivation”
(DORA). See also threat model.
```
```
T hreat I ntelligence
P latform (TIP)
```
```
System, software, or service to automate the
collection, analysis, communication, and use of
threat intelligence.
```
**T** hreat **-L** ed **P** enetration
**T** est **(TLPT)**

```
Form of penetration testing involving attack
techniques being actively used by determined
and competent adversaries to compromise
victims (according to research and knowledge
of the field, i.e. threat intelligence), as opposed
to more theoretical or academic techniques. “A
framework that mimics the tactics, techniques
and procedures of real-life threat actors
perceived as posing a genuine cyber threat, that
delivers a controlled, bespoke, intelligence-led
(red team) test of the financial entity’s critical
live production systems” (DORA).
```
```
Threat model Conceptual construct, scenario, system, or
service fed by threat intelligence, used to
simulate and explore attack vectors exploiting
exposed vulnerabilities, potentially leading to
incidents unless blocked or mitigated by
```

```
controls. “Used to describe a given threat and
the harm it could to do a system if it has a
vulnerability” (SANS glossary).
```
```
Threat tree Top-down graphical representation generated
by successively deconstructing threats, risks,
hazards, or undesirable outcomes to expose the
contributory factors, elements, or root causes,
such as potential attacks. See also F ailure
M odes and E ffects A nalysis.
```
```
Threat vector See attack vector. “The path or route used by
the adversary to gain access to the target”
(ISACA glossary). “The method a threat uses to
get to the target” (SANS glossary).
```
**Three lines [of defence]
model**

```
Conceptual governance/management control
model that divides risk management and
assurance responsibilities across several
organisational functions. Originally formulated
in the 2000s, then adopted by The I nstitute of
I nternal A uditors in 2013, and now popular
globally. OCEG extended the classical model
by two further levels, becoming the L ines o f
A ccountability model. See also first, second,
third, fourth, and fifth line.
```
```
Threshold Boundary condition that, when reached or
passed, triggers decisions and actions, e.g. if an
unfolding situation has become so serious as to
constitute an incident (passing a significance
threshold relating to, say, its anticipated
adverse impact on important business
activities), management may decide to initiate
the relevant incident response process. Some
thresholds are objectively determined
according to the measured values or trends in
```

```
certain parameters ( e.g. “An office temperature
of 37 Celsius”), while others are at least
partially subjective ( e.g. “Too hot to continue
working”). Either type may have defined
tolerance levels for practical reasons ( e.g. “An
office temperature of 37 ± 2 degrees Celsius”).
```
```
Throttling Rate-limiting technical security controls
designed to reduce the risk of repeated attacks
such as brute force guessing of PIN codes and
passwords or A rtificial I ntelligence model
exfiltration. Once triggered by exceeding a
defined threshold, further interactions, guesses,
queries, etc. from the user are ignored even if
they are correct. The user may or may not be
informed about this, and details of the
associated security events are generally sent to
the security logging, alarming, or alerting
subsystems.
```
```
TIA Abbrev: T ransfer I mpact A ssessment.
```
**Tier 1, 2, or** (^3) Classification labels relating to the availability
requirements or business-criticality of business
processes and the supporting information
systems. Tier 1 is normally the most critical
class.
**T** ime **-** based **O** ne **-T** ime
**P** assword **(TOTP)
M** ulti **F** actor **A** uthentication scheme involves
proving possession of a shared secret using a
SHA-2 based cryptographic challenge and
response specific to a point in time (a **O** ne-
**T** ime **P** assword), preventing later replay.
Specified in RFC 6238. More info:
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6238


```
Time bomb Type of logic bomb or explosive weapon
designed to detonate at a specific time or after
a particular delay. “Resident computer program
that triggers an unauthorized act at a
predefined time” (CNSSI 4009).
```
```
Timeout Function that automatically suspends and
password-locks, or terminates, a computer
session after a specified period (normally
several minutes) without user activity. Reduces
the risk of someone taking advantage of a
system from which the legitimate user has
walked away without having screen-locked or
logged off (naughty naughty).
```
```
Timescale The period during which an event/incident
(such as a fraud) or activity (such as a project)
occurs. “The expected or planned time frame to
achieve an objective or meet a target” (OCEG
GRC Glossary).
```
**Time series analysis** Analysis of audit samples selected at particular

```
times, e.g. testing recoverability of one backup
per month. “The analysis of an ordered
sequence of values of a variable at equally
spaced time intervals” (NIST SP 800-55v1). Cf.
random sample, stratified sample, attribute
sample, convenience sample, discovery
sample.
```
```
Timestamp “Time variant parameter which denotes a point
in time with respect to a common time
reference” (ISO/IEC 11770-1).
```
```
Timing “A measure that estimates when an event or
impact might occur” (OCEG GRC Glossary).
```

```
Tinba (Tiny banker) Species of bank Trojan in the wild in 2016.
Manipulated the lure bank’s logon page using
HTML injection, capturing customers’
credentials and presenting them with an error
message while sending the credentials to a
command and control node for subsequent
exploitation.
```
```
Tiny fragment attack “With many IP implementations it is possible
to impose an unusually small fragment size on
outgoing packets. If the fragment size is made
small enough to force some of a TCP packet ’ s
TCP header fields into the second fragment,
filter rules that specify patterns for those fields
will not match. If the filtering implementation
does not enforce a minimum fragment size, a
disallowed packet might be passed because it
didn ’ t hit a match in the filter. STD 5, RFC 791
states: Every Internet module must be able to
forward a datagram of 68 octets without further
fragmentation. This is because an Internet
header may be up to 60 octets, and the
minimum fragment is 8 octets” (SANS
glossary).
```
```
TIP Abbrev: T hreat I ntelligence P latform.
```
**TISAX (Trusted
Information Security
Assessment eXchange)**

```
Conformity certification and assurance scheme
for supply chain information security within
the automotive industry, assessing companies
against security control requirements specified
in the I nformation S ecurity A ssessment, then
sharing the assessment results in confidence
among members of the scheme. “An
assessment and exchange mechanism for the
information security of enterprises [that]
allows recognition of assessment results among
```

```
the participants. ” More info:
https://enx.com/en-us/tisax/
```
```
TLP Abbrev: T raffic L ight P rotocol.
```
```
TLPT Abbrev: T hreat- L ed P enetration T est.
```
```
TLS Abbrev: T ransport L ayer S ecurity.
```
**TOCTOU (Time Of
Check, Time Of Use)**

```
Type of hack that changes or switches
something (such as a file) after it has been
checked and authorised or granted permission
for access, but before subsequent steps in the
program or process including the actual access.
Similar to a race condition. An example
involves smugglers exploiting the pre-
clearance and consequent enhanced
trustworthiness of frequent travellers, using
them as (presumably unwitting) mules to carry
contraband across borders. Bait-and-switch is
another form.
```
```
TOE Abbrev: T arget O f E valuation.
```
```
Token Something that represents or stands in for
something else, such as a security token
(physically authenticates the user) or a
fictitious value in a file (see tokenisation). “1.
In security systems, a physical device that is
used to authenticate a user, typically in
addition to a username and password; in
programming languages, a single element of
the language. 2. In natural language processing
(NLP), a unit of data representing individual
words, subwords, or characters typically used
as input for models” (ISACA glossary). See
also honeytoken, authenticator.
```

```
Token-based access
control
```
```
“Associates a list of objects and their privileges
with each user. (The opposite of list based.)”
(SANS glossary).
```
```
Tokenisation a. Process of systematically replacing
names, labels, etc. that identify specific
individuals with fictitious, generic, or
randomly generated tokens, tags, code
words, alphanumeric identifiers, etc.,
usually for privacy reasons such as
pseudonymity.
b. [In N atural L anguage P rocessing] “The
process of breaking down text or data into
smaller units” (ISACA glossary).
```
**Tolerance, tolerable
error, margin for error**

```
Willingness to allow, accept, expect, or forgive
variation, imprecision, or error, ‘within reason’
(implying insignificance). “The maximum
error in the population that professionals are
willing to accept and still conclude that the test
objective has been achieved. For substantive
tests, tolerable error is related to professionals’
judgment about materiality. In compliance
tests, it is the maximum rate of deviation from
a prescribed control procedure that the
professionals are willing to accept” (ISACA
glossary). “A range for an indicator that
defines an acceptable, though not preferred,
level of variation around a target the
organization is willing and able to address”
(OCEG GRC Glossary). See also risk
tolerance.
```
```
Topic-specific policy Corporate policy concerning a particular
information security subject, such as
cryptography or access control. “Intentions and
```

```
direction on a specific subject or topic, as
formally expressed by the appropriate level of
management” (ISO/IEC 27002).
```
**Top management, top-
level management**

```
See executive management. “Person or group
of people who directs and controls an
organisation at the highest level. Notes: top
management has the power to delegate
authority and provide resources within the
organization. If the scope of the management
system covers only part of an organization then
top management refers to those who direct and
control that part of the organization” (ISO/IEC
27000 ). “The highest level of management in
the enterprise, responsible for direction and
control of the enterprise as a whole (such as
director, general manager, partner, chief officer
and executive manager)” (ISACA glossary).Cf.
senior management.
```
```
TOP SECRET Commonplace classification label (often
CAPITALISED for emphasis) for information
even more confidential than SECRET. TOP
SECRET information may be further classified
according to its nature and distribution, often
on nationalistic/xenophobic lines, e.g.
‘NOFORN’ (no foreign nationals) or ‘NZ eyes
only.’ While the intention is reasonably self-
evident, the label, definition, and associated
controls are organisation- and context-specific.
“Information, the unauthorized disclosure of
which reasonably could be expected to cause
exceptionally grave damage to the national
security that the original classification
authority is able to identify or desc r ibe”
(Executive Order 13526 ). Cf.
CONFIDENTIAL, SECRET, ULTRA.
```

```
TOP SECRET area “Any area certified to operate at TOP
SECRET, containing TOP SECRET servers,
workstations or associated network
infrastructure” (NZISM). “An area that has
been authorised to process, store or
communicate TOP SECRET data. Such areas
are not necessarily tied to a specific level of
security zone” (AusISM).
```
**Tor (The onion router)** Internet communications application and

```
associated global network. Tor traffic passes
through thousands of Tor relays, using multiple
layers of encryption to reduce (but not
eliminate) the risk of interception, monitoring,
surveillance, and T raffic A nalysis, and so
protect users’ privacy. A mix network.
```
```
Torrentlocker Species of ransomware.
```
```
Tort Legal term for a civil – as opposed to criminal
```
- wrong. The tort victim or plaintiff in a civil
court case may seek compensation for the
damages they have suffered from, and/or court
orders (injunctions) concerning, the defendant
(tortfeasor).

```
Total performance “A model of balanced performance that
includes effectiveness (soundness), efficiency
(leanness), responsiveness (agility), and
resiliency (antifragility)” (OCEG GRC
Glossary).
```
```
TOTP Abbrev: T ime-based O ne- T ime P assword.
```
```
TPM Abbrev: T rusted P latform M odule.
```

```
TPRM Abbrev: T hird P arty R isk M anagement.
```

```
TR Abbrev: T echnical R eport.
```

```
Traceability Ability to link a person, event, incident,
transaction, product, system component, etc.

cause, e.g. telephone callers can be traced
using a pen register; audit trails and change
logs may implicate or exonerate someone in
relation to an information security incidents;
and vulnerable software libraries, etc. can be
identified with an effective S oftware B ill o f
M aterials. “Property that allows the tracking of
the activity of an identity, process, or an
element throughout the supply chain”
(ISO/IEC 27036- 3 ). “1. The degree to which a
relationship can be established between two or
more products of the development process,
especially products having a predecessor-

(ISACA glossary).
```
**Tracert, trace route** Network administration utility to trace and

```
measure (time) the route from the local system
to a given remote device through intermediate
nodes using a sequence of I nternet C ontrol
M essage P rotocol pings or U ser D atagram
P rotocol messages with increasing T ime T o
L ive counters, starting at 1, to query each
```

```
intermediate host individually. “A tool [that]
```

**Track, tracking,
tracing**

```
Path or sequence followed by someone or
something.
a. Accumulating potentially sensitive
information about assets through covert
observation (snooping), monitoring, and
surveillance of their online activities,
physical movements,
interactions/associations with others, etc.
May involve the use of discreet tracking
technologies such as bugs and spyware on
smartphones, and small G lobal
P ositioning S ervice-enabled geolocation
systems in/attached to vehicles, packages,
or valuables. May be performed by agents
such as the police, private investigators,
and spies for criminal or terrorist
profiling, crime detection, etc., or by
third-parties such as the providers of
professional services such as analytics for
targeted advertising and other purposes –
whether illicit or legitimate. Can lead to
privacy breaches, identity fraud, and
targeting of individuals, e.g. kidnapping.
Can help track down lost or stolen
smartphones, vehicles, briefcases and
suitcases, money bags, keys, pets,
children, Alzheimer’s sufferers, etc.
b. Monitoring a parameter or metric over
time, determining trends and anomalies by
analysis.
```

```
Tradecraft Valuable skills and spooky techniques for
spying or performing similar clandestine or
indeed overt activities. Cunning tricks-of-the-
trade accumulated and, in some cases, invented
or actively developed by experienced
professionals and talented amateurs
(lockpicking, for instance). Information risk
management, penetration testing, and auditing
methods are, in effect, forms of tradecraft.
```
```
Trademark, trade
mark
```
```
Legal protection for words/phrases, images,
designs, and other characteristics distinctive of
branded products. An I ntellectual P roperty
R ight, often designated by ® if formally
registered with the authorities or ™ if claimed

or other distinctive symbol closely associated

```
```
Trade secret Confidential information asset such as
proprietary knowledge owned by an
organisation which gives it competitive
advantage so long as it remains unknown
and/or unexploited by competitors, e.g. an
invention may be both valuable and vulnerable
```

```
Traffic The flow of messages, packets, chatter,
vehicles, or products (including arms, drugs,
and people trafficking) through a computer or
social network or communications path,
infrastructure, or supply chain.
```

**T** raffic **A** nalysis **(TA)** Use of metadata relating to communications to

```
derive potentially sensitive and/or valuable
```

```
information. Even if communications between
two or more parties are strongly encrypted so
that the pure information content of the
exchanges themselves remains confidential, an
observer may glean, deduce, or infer useful
information from the nature and volume of the
traffic flows. The mere fact that
communication appears to be occurring at all
may be incriminating in some circumstances,
e.g. if the particular counterparties (identified
by their phone numbers, names, email
addresses, etc. ), or the timing of traffic
indicates what might be going on ( e.g.
secretive negotiations between business
partners, financiers, and other advisors prior to
a merger or deal, or criminals conspiring).
“Inference of information from observation of
traffic flow. Note: Example: Analysis of the
presence, absence, amount, direction, and
frequency of traffic” (ISO/IEC 2382 ). “Gaining
knowledge of information by inference from
observable characteristics of a data flow, even
if the information is not directly available ( e.g .,
when the data is encrypted). These
characteristics include the identities and
locations of the source(s) and destination(s) of
the flow, and the flow ’ s presence, amount,
frequency, and duration of occurrence” (CNSSI
4009 ). See also N etwork T raffic A nalysis.
```
```
Traffic flow filter “A device that has been configured to
automatically filter and control the form of
network data” (NZISM).
```
**T** raffic **L** ight **P** rotocol
**(TLP)**

```
Classification scheme specified by US-CERT
for security information potentially of national
importance, with four traffic-light colours:
```

```
TLP:RED (not to be disclosed),
TLP:AMBER (limited disclosure permitted
within the recipient organisation),
TLP:GREEN (limited disclosure permitted
within the information security community),
and TLP:WHITE (freely disclosable,
distribution unrestricted). In some
jurisdictions, TLP:CLEAR is the unrestricted
label. More info: https://www.us-cert.gov/tlp
```
**Traffic padding** Control against **T** raffic **A** nalysis involves

```
generating and blending in fake
communications traffic (essentially, noise),
making it harder for adversaries to identify
genuine information flows. Note: this is
distinct from the message padding needed to
form fixed-length network packets.
“Countermeasure that generates spurious data
in transmission media to make traffic analysis
or decryption more difficult” (ISO/IEC 2382 ).
“Generation of mock communications or data
units to disguise the amount of real data units
being sent” (CNSSI 4009 ). See also chaff, flare,
mix network.
```
```
Tragedy of the
commons
```
```
While everyone may benefit collectively from
pooling resources and participating in shared
activities, cheats may seize the opportunity to
profit at the expense of others, e.g. by
exploiting I ntellectual P roperty without
considering or compensating its owners
(piracy) or flagrantly using, mining, refining,
selling, and burning fossil fuels without
mitigating the associated environmental harm.
```
```
Trained model Model who knows how to smile alluringly at
the camera, walk, and pivot elegantly on the
```

```
podium, that sort of thing. “Result of model
```

**Training, model
training**

```
Educational activity in which human students
or M achine L earning models are instructed in

administering user access rights or

and abilities, and to improve the performance

“Process to determine or to improve the

a model” (ISACA glossary).Cf. security
```

```
Training data Information or data used for training. “Data
used to train a machine learning model”
(ISO/IEC 22989).
```
```
Transaction a. Commercial/business deal or trade, e.g.
purchasing a product.
b. Group of closely related processing
operations, e.g. updating a bank account
or ledger to record a debit, updating
another account or ledger to record a
credit of the same value, then
simultaneously committing both changes
to the finance system’s D ata B ase.
“Business events or information grouped
together because they have a single or
similar purpose. Note: Typically, a
```

```
transaction is applied to a calculation or
event that then results in the updating of a
holding or master file. [and] 1. A
command, message or input record that
explicitly or implicitly calls for a
processing action, such as updating a file.
```
2. An exchange between an end user and
an interactive system. 3. In a database
management system, a unit of processing
activity that accomplishes a specific
purpose, such as a retrieval, an update, a
modification or a deletion of one or more
data elements of a storage structure”
_(ISACA glossary)._

**T** ransmission **C** ontrol
**P** rotocol **(TCP)**

```
Connection-oriented transport layer
networking protocol that provides reliable,
ordered, and error-checked data delivery
between devices. A key part of the TCP/IP
suite of protocols. Before data are exchanged,
the systems connect at a basic I nternet
P rotocol level to negotiate and agree the
datacommunications protocols and parameters
they will use through a short sequence of
transmissions and acknowledgements. “A
connection-based Internet protocol that
supports reliable data transfer connections.
Notes: Packet data are verified using
checksums and retransmitted if they are
missing or corrupted. The application plays no
part in validating the transfer” (ISACA
glossary). “A set of rules (protocol) used along
with the Internet Protocol to send data in the
form of message units between computers over
the Internet. While IP takes care of handling
the actual delivery of the data, TCP takes care
of keeping track of the individual units of data
```

```
(called packets) that a message is divided into
for efficient routing through the Internet.
Whereas the IP protocol deals only with
packets, TCP enables two hosts to establish a
connection and exchange streams of data. TCP
guarantees delivery of data and also guarantees
that packets will be delivered in the same order
in which they were sent” (SANS glossary).Cf.
U ser D atagram P rotocol.
```
```
Tranquillity a. Information security principle that an
object’s classification level must not
change while it is being processed, except
for privileged, strictly controlled functions
relating to the classification process itself.
b. Sense of calm, quiet reflection,
unwinding, a happy place for stress relief.
```
```
Transcription check “A check to ensure that any data transferred
between any records and/or systems has been
transferred correctly” (FSRCoP).
```
**Transfer cross-domain
solution**

```
“A system that facilitates the transfer of data,
in one or multiple directions (low to high or
high to low), between different security
domains” (AusISM).
```
```
Transfer design option “A special case of a sharing design option
where an attempt is made to give close to
100% of consequence to another party such as
an insurance company” (OCEG GRC
Glossary).
```
```
Transfer gateway “Facilitates the secure transfer of information,
in one or multiple directions ( i.e. low to high or
high to low), between different security
domains” (NZISM).
```

**T** ransfer **I** mpact
**A** ssessment **(TIA)**

```
Formal process potentially required under the
G eneral D ata P rotection R egulation to ensure
that personal data will be adequately protected
if it is sent out of the E uropean U nion, e.g.
passed through a transfer tool to be processed
by cloud applications hosted in countries
whose privacy practices are not deemed
adequate by the European Commission.
Supplementary privacy controls such as
pseudonymisation may be appropriate.
```
```
Transfer tool Mechanism ( e.g. binding contractual clauses)
designed to facilitate the secure transfer of
personal data to countries whose privacy
practices fall short of requirements under the
G eneral D ata P rotection R egulation according
to the European Commission.
```
```
Transformation Notable step-change or discontinuity, e.g. from
ciphertext to plaintext, or pupa to butterfly.
“The conversion of one state or format into
another state or format” (NIST SP 800-55v1).
```
```
Transition Moving between states, modes, phases, or
activities, e.g. from the previous to a new
version of a standard, procedure, system, or
protocol. May be a sharply defined point in
time (a step-change) or more gradually
(evolutionary change). May be proactively
managed and directed/driven, or may occur
naturally.
```
```
Transition audit Recertification audit confirming that the
organisation has successfully adopted and
achieved conformity to a new version of a
standard such as ISO/IEC 27001.
```

```
Transitive trust In many situations, if our trusted colleague,
business partner, computer system, etc. trusts a
third party, we also implicitly trust the third
party to some extent. In effect, trust is capable
of transiting or spanning multiple relationships,
albeit weakening with distance, e.g. placing
trust in an organisation’s ISO/IEC 27001
certificate implies trusting the C ertification
B ody that issued it, and vice versa. Likewise
with P ublic K ey I nfrastructures, where root
certificates from two or more PKIs may be
cross-certified to enable interoperability.
```
**Transmission system** “Transmission grid for the transport of
electrical energy using a high voltage or ultra-
high voltage grid or a gas transmission network
for the transport of natural gas using a high-
pressure pipeline network” _(ISO/IEC 27019)._

```
Transparency,
openness
```
```
Information security governance, management,
privacy, and integrity principle to be open and
honest, freely disclosing ownership, risks,
controls, incidents, etc. under appropriate
circumstances. Strongly associated with trust.
“Property of a system or process to imply
openness and accountability” (ISO/IEC 2 7036-
3 ). “<Organization> Property of an
organization that appropriate activities and
decisions are communicated to relevant
stakeholders in a comprehensive, accessible
and understandable manner. Note:
Inappropriate communication of activities and
decisions can violate security, privacy or
confidentiality requirements. <System>
Property of a system that appropriate
information about the system is made available
to relevant stakeholders. Notes: Appropriate
```

```
information for system transparency can
include aspects such as features, performance,
limitations, components, procedures, measures,
design goals, design choices and assumptions,
data sources and labelling protocols;
Inappropriate disclosure of some aspects of a
system can violate security, privacy or
confidentiality requirements” (ISO/IEC
22989 ). “Open, comprehensive, accessible,
clear and understandable presentation of
information” (ISO 16759). “Refers to an
enterprise’s openness about its activities and is
based on the following concepts: How the
mechanism functions is clear to those who are
affected by or want to challenge governance
decisions; A common vocabulary has been
established; Relevant information is readily
available. Note: Transparency and stakeholder

in the governance process, the more confidence

```
**T** ransport **L** ayer
**S** ecurity **(TLS)**

```
Cryptographic protocol using X.509 digital
certificates for authentication and secure
exchange of session keys used for symmetric
encryption, e.g. of data flowing between a
browser and a web server, or for L ightweight
D irectory A ccess P rotocol, I nternet M essaging
A ccess P rotocol, and FTP traffic. Replaced the
insecure and hence deprecated S ecure S ockets
L ayer in 1999, although several exploitable
vulnerabilities in TLS have since been
discovered ( e.g. Heartbleed, DROWN). “A
cryptographic protocol that provides secure
communications, endpoint security and privacy
on the Internet” (ISACA glossary). “A protocol
that ensures privacy between communicating
```

```
applications and their users on the Internet.
When a server and client communicate, TLS
ensures that no third party may eavesdrop or
tamper with any message. TLS is the successor
to the Secure Sockets Layer” (SANS glossary).
```
**Transport mode** IPsec can encrypt and/or authenticate just the
payload of an IP packet, providing
confidentiality, data, and communications
integrity when sent over a trusted network. “An
IPSec mode that provides a secure connection
between two endpoints by encapsulating an IP
payload” _(NZISM)._ See also tunnel mode.

```
Transposition,
permutation
```
```
Cryptographic process for re-sequencing and
hence scrambling characters or bits from the
plaintext to create the ciphertext, often
systematically such that the process can later
be reversed using the same key. A trivial
example might involve writing the plaintext
into a grid structure column-wise left-to-right,
then reading off the ciphertext row-wise top-to-
bottom, reversing the process for decryption.
Modern cryptographic algorithms make the
transposition process far more complex and
convoluted. Cf. substitution.
```
```
Trap and trace See pen register.
```
```
Trapdoor a. Physical security mechanism (the door)
that permits/encourages someone to enter
into a confined area (the trap) but then
closes behind them to resist/prevent their
escape. Sometimes used as a single-
person portal to regulate ingress and
egress for a highly secure facility such as
```

```
a data centre, bank vault, or fancy
jeweller.
b. In cryptography, a function that is easy to
compute if you know the key/s, e.g.
encrypting a sensitive message, otherwise
extremely hard (computationally
intensive), e.g. decrypting the ciphertext
without the key/s. In other words, it goes
one way. See also backdoor.
c. Covert capability in some programs,
allowing access to hidden functions for
coding and debugging, or for
nefarious/spooky purposes (see
backdoor). “Hidden software or hardware
mechanism, usually created for testing
and troubleshooting, that may be used to
circumvent computer security” (ISO/IEC
2382 ). “Unauthorized electronic exit, or
doorway, out of an authorized computer
program into a set of malicious
instructions or programs” (ISACA
glossary).
```
```
Treason Serious act of betrayal that threatens to cause,
or causes, material harm to the state, the
crown, or a similar authority or ruler, or that
aides, or attempts to aide, an enemy of the
state. An insider threat.
```
**Trembler** Motion-detection device (such as a magnetic

```
reed switch and magnetic steel ball, a blob of
mercury in a glass vial with wire contact
points, or an inertial sensor) attached to or
embedded within an object such as a server,
door, window, safe, media transporter or
vehicle, that is triggered by vibration, shock, or
```

```
tumbling, perhaps indicating unauthorised
removal or penetration.
```
```
Trespass Unauthorised physical entry into private
property, zone, or area, or assaulting or
interfering with property belonging to another
person. Whether a trespasser acts accidentally
or maliciously affects the level of risk to the
victim and has legal ramifications for the
trespasser, while the victim’s negligence ( e.g.
in not clearly designating the area private) may
also affect the outcome in court.
```
```
Triada Species of malware that infected Android
smartphones, in the wild in 2018. Exploited a
privilege elevation vulnerability, allowing it
and other malware to take control of infected
devices.
```
```
Triage Term borrowed from the emergency medical
practice of quickly evaluating an influx of
patients to distinguish and focus limited
resources on those who can probably be saved
from those who stand little if any chance of
survival. Information security is seldom
literally a life-or-death matter but similar
difficult decisions must be made, often rapidly
and with limited, low-quality information,
following serious incidents and disasters.
Establishing the capability to perform triage is
part of B usiness C ontinuity M anagement and
contingency planning.
```
**Trickbot** Hacker/cybercriminal gang and a species of
malware in the wild in 2022.


```
Trigger Action, situation, or condition that initiates,
prompts, or causes something to occur. “Event
that causes the system to initiate a response.
Note: Also known as triggering event”
(ISO/IEC 27031).
```
**T** riple **D** ata **E** ncryption
**S** tandard **(3DES)**

```
Cryptographic algorithm which repeats DES
three times in succession using two (ABA,
AAB, or ABB) or three (ABC) different keys.
Specified in FIPS PUB 46-3. Vulnerable to
brute force attacks and hence deprecated in
favour of A dvanced E ncryption S tandard. “A
block cipher created from the Data Encryption
Standard (DES) cipher by using it three times.
3DES was broken in 2016” (ISACA glossary).
“A block cipher, based on DES, that transforms
each 64-bit plaintext block by applying the
Data Encryption Algorithm three successive
times, using either two or three different keys,
for an effective key length of 112 or 168 bits”
(SANS glossary).
```
```
Triton, Trisis Species of malware in the wild in 2017–2019
that targeted Triconex plant control systems
( O perational T echnology), raising safety and
C ritical N ational I nfrastructure concerns.
```
```
Trojan horse, Trojan Malware program that appears to the user
simply to be genuinely useful and benign, but
in fact contains hidden malicious functions,
typically allowing remote control of the system
by hackers, or installing keyloggers to steal
personal information, passwords, PIN codes,
credit card numbers, or online banking
credentials ( e.g. Man-In-The-Browser).
“Apparently harmless program containing
malicious logic that allows the unauthorized
```

```
collection, falsification, or destruction of data”
(ISO/IEC 2382 ). “A computer program that
appears to have a useful function, but also has
a hidden and potentially malicious function
that evades security mechanisms, sometimes
by exploiting legitimate authorizations of a
system entity that invokes the program”
(CNSSI 4009 ). “Malware that appears to
perform a desirable function for the user but
that mislead the user of its true intent”
(ISO/IEC 27032). “Purposefully hidden
malicious or damaging code within an
authorized computer program” (ISACA
glossary). “A computer program that appears
to have a useful function, but also has a hidden
and potentially malicious function that evades
security mechanisms, sometimes by exploiting
legitimate authorizations of a system entity that
invokes the program” (SANS glossary).
```
```
Troll, trolling Intentionally provoking others online to elicit
strong emotional reactions or disrupt
conversations, typically by repeatedly and
flagrantly posting inflammatory content,
spreading misinformation and off-topic
content, or mounting ad hominem attacks.
```
```
True value “Value that characterizes a quantity perfectly
defined in the conditions which exist when that
quantity is considered. The true value of a
quantity is an ideal concept and, in general,
cannot be known exactly” (FSRCoP).
```
**Trust, trolling** Relatively weak but commonplace information

```
security control in which supposedly
trustworthy people, systems, programs,
functions, organisations, etc. are expected,
```

```
anticipated, or to various extents required to
behave with integrity, predictably,
appropriately, responsibly, honestly, ethically,
transparently, and in the trusting party’s best
interests. Trust usually takes time to be
established and yet can be decimated in an
instant by an incident; hence, contingency
arrangements and/or other controls (such as
compliance checks and predefined liabilities)
are generally advisable, where possible.
“Relationship between two entities and/or
elements, consisting of a set of activities and a
security policy in which element x trusts
element y if and only if x has confidence that y
will behave in a well-defined way (with respect
to the activities) that does not violate the given
security policy” (ISO/IEC 27036-1).
“Determine which permissions and what
actions other systems or users can perform on
remote machines” (SANS glossary). Cf.
trustworthy, untrusted.
```
**Trust boundary** Trust boundary. “The interface between two or
more Trust Zones” _(NZISM)._ “Typically ... the
components of the system under your direct
control. All connections and data from systems
outside of your direct control, including all
clients and systems managed by other parties,
should be consider untrusted and be validated
at the boundary, before allowing further system
interaction” _(SCP QRG)._

```
Trust centre Web page, showcase, dashboard, or portal
typically outlining in general terms the
organisation’s information security and privacy
arrangements (such as its security
certifications, governance, policies, and
```

```
cybersecurity controls) for current and
prospective business partners, customers, etc.
Intended to reduce the need for supply chain
security questionnaires, reviews, and audits,
presuming that the information provided is
sufficiently accurate and complete, and the
organisation is trustworthy. May offer
additional, more sensitive information for
selected third parties and corporate users.
```
```
Trusted computer
system
```
```
“Data processing system that provides
sufficient computer security to allow for
concurrent access to data by users with
different access rights and to data with
different security classification and security
categories” (ISO/IEC 2382).
```
```
T rusted C omputing
B ase (TCB)
```
```
Relatively secure and trustworthy low-level
computing subsystem typically comprising
hardware, software, and firmware specifically
designed to perform certain privileged security
activities, with the integrity necessary to secure
the system as a whole. May be formally
designed and mathematically proven secure for
high assurance.
```
```
Trusted download Special process for exporting information from
a highly classified, lowly classified, or
unclassified system, in an approved simple
data format ( e.g. plain ASCII, HTML, JPG,
BMP, or GIF rather than MS Office or other
complex file types) that can be and in fact is
inspected for any inappropriate content before
being authorised for release.
```
**T** rusted **E** xecution
**E** nvironment **(TEE)**

```
I nformation T echnology systems,
cryptosystems, devices, communication paths,
```

```
etc. protected within a notional design
boundary or situation, sharing a comparable
level of information security and hence
trustworthiness.
```
**Trusted information
communication entity**

```
Trustworthy organisation or individual with
whom even sensitive information relating to
information security, risks, threats,
vulnerabilities, etc. can be shared.
“Autonomous organisation supporting
information exchange within an information
sharing community” (ISO/IEC 27000).
```
```
T rusted P latform
M odule (TPM)
```
```
Type of H ardware S ecurity M odule
incorporated into recent PCs, providing safe
storage for cryptographic keys and functions
such as random number generation, key
storage, and authentication in an embedded
subsystem built around a tamper-resistant TPM
chip. A unique private RSA key, burned into
the chip during manufacturing, allows the TPM
to be authenticated by systems or programs
that need this level of trust ( e.g. for whole disk
encryption or DRM). However, researchers
claim to have overcome the tamper-resistance
physical security features of some TPM chips,
while the N ational S ecurity A gency’s
involvement with RSA indicates the distinct
possibility that TPM security may have been
deliberately weakened, raising doubts about
the value of this physical security control.
```
```
Trusted port Low-numbered network port. “Ports below
number 1024 usually allowed to be opened by
the root user” (SANS glossary).
```

```
Trusted rôle Privileged rôle, position/job, engagement, or
assignment requiring and depending on the
trustworthiness and integrity of a person, team,
or organisation.
```
```
Trusted source “A person or system formally identified as
being capable of reliably producing
information meeting defined parameters, such
as a maximum data classification and reliably
reviewing information produced by others to
confirm compliance with defined parameters”
(NZISM).
```
**T** rusted **T** hird **P** arty
**(TTP)**

```
Organisation or individual that is trusted by
others, and may therefore act as a mutually
acceptable intermediary between them, e.g. to
hold and transfer valuables such as
cryptographic keys or money (escrow) or to
audit one party and report the overall findings
to the others without necessarily disclosing
confidential details ( e.g. C ertification B ody).
```
```
Trust service Digital signature service ensuring integrity
(such as identification, authentication, and
nonrepudiation) for electronic and online
transactions, contracts, etc. “An electronic
service normally provided for remuneration
which consists of: (a) the creation, verification,
and validation of electronic signatures,
electronic seals or electronic time stamps,
electronic registered delivery services and
certificates related to those services, or (b) the
```

```
Measure of the extent to which someone or
```

```
“Ability to meet stakeholders’ expectations in a
verifiable way. Notes: Depending on the
context or sector, and also on the specific
product or service, data, technology and
process used, different characteristics apply
and need verification to ensure stakeholders’
expectations are met. Characteristics of
trustworthiness include, for instance,
accountability, accuracy, authenticity,
availability, controllability, integrity, privacy,
quality, reliability, resilience, robustness,
safety, security, transparency and usability.
Trustworthiness is an attribute that can be
applied to services, products, technology, data
and information as well as to organizations.
Verifiability includes measurability and
demonstrability by means of objective
evidence” (ISO/IEC TS 5723). “The attribute
of a person or enterprise that provides
confidence to others of the qualifications,
capabilities, and reliability of that entity to
perform specific tasks and fulfill assigned
responsibilities” (CNSSI 4009 ). Cf.
untrustworthy.
```

```
Tunnel Relatively secure, trustworthy path through an

“Data path between networked devices which
is established across an existing network
infrastructure. Note: Tunnels can be established

```

```
traffic between different networks when traffic

communication channel created in a computer
network by encapsulating a communication
protocol ’ s data packets in (on top of) a second
protocol that normally would be carried above,
or at the same layer as, the first one. Most
often, a tunnel is a logical point-to-point link –
i.e ., an OSI layer 2 connection – created by
encapsulating the layer 2 protocol in a
transport protocol (such as TCP), in a network
or inter-network layer protocol (such as IP), or
in another link layer protocol. Tunneling can
move data between computers that use a
protocol not supported by the network
connecting them” (SANS glossary).
```

```
data via another network’s connections.
Tunneling works by encapsulating a network
protocol within packets carried by the second
network” (CNSSI 4009).
```

entire IP packet. The entire packet is encrypted

```
ULTRA UK classification level above TOP SECRET for
military intelligence whose very existence would be
strenuously and plausibly denied, since that would
indicate the presence of, and hence threaten, effective
espionage capabilities and compromised sources,
putting the targets on guard. Intelligence gathered
through cryptanalysis of radio intercepts at Bletchley
Park during WWII was classified ULTRA, sustaining
the enemy’s unwarranted trust in Enigma and other
flawed cryptographic devices and practices. While the
intention is reasonably self-evident, the label,
definition, and associated controls are organisation-
and context-specific. Cf. CONFIDENTIAL, SECRET,
TOP SECRET.
```

```
space.
```
```
Unauthorised Lacking the requisite authority, rights, or permission.
Not permitted, accepted, or agreed by management as
being in the best interests of the organisation or other
stakeholders, and therefore implicitly or explicitly
forbidden, prohibited, or restricted. Cf. authorised.
```
**Unauthorised access** Access that is unauthorised – either expressly
forbidden, or perhaps unspecified. “Access to
information or system components that (a) has not
been approved by a person designated to do so by
management and (b) compromises segregation of
duties, confidentiality commitments, or otherwise
increases risks to the information or system
components beyond the levels approved by
management (that is, access is inappropriate)” _(_ **_T_** _rust_
**_S_** _ervices_ **_C_** _riteria)._

```
Unaware Naïve, ignorant, blasé, and hence vulnerable,
particularly but not only to social engineering. Lack of
awareness is a factor in many incidents including
accidents, gradual, slow-acting threats such as climate
change, and attacks involving stealth, deception, and
subterfuge ( e.g. fraud). Workers who do not know
about or fail to appreciate their obligations and
expectations under various laws, policies, and rules
are obviously less likely to comply. More subtly, it
can be difficult to hold those who can legitimately
claim or feign ignorance to account for failings.
```
```
Unbiased Balanced, equitable, fair, objective, reasonable, and
lacking in prejudice or favour towards or away from
one party, view, position, etc. Cf. biased.
```

**Uncertainty, uncertain** Doubted, doubtful, lacking in confidence, assurance,
or surety, unpredictable, risky. “State, even partial, of
deficiency of information related to understanding or
knowledge. Notes: In some cases, uncertainty can be
related to the organization’s context as well as to its
objectives; Uncertainty is the root source of risk,
namely any kind of ‘deficiency of information’ that
matters in relation to objectives (and objectives, in
turn, relate to all relevant interested parties’ needs and
expectations” _(ISO 31 073 )._ “The difficulty of
predicting an outcome due to limited knowledge of all
components” _(ISACA glossary)._ “A state of being
unsure about something due to incomplete knowledge
or underlying randomness making it difficult to
understand with complete confidence” _(OCEG GRC
Glossary)._

```

measurement
```

```
uncertainty and that a value is incomplete without a
statement of accuracy. Sources of uncertainty can
include unrepresentative samples, rounding errors,
approximations and inadequate knowledge of the
effect of external factors” (FSRCoP).
```

```
Unethical Behaviour which is not ethical and hence generally
considered inappropriate, distasteful, or undesirable if
not totally unacceptable and possibly even illegal. The
willingness to disregard social norms and constraints
on behaviour sets liars, cheats, spies, hackers,
fraudsters, criminals, and other reprobates apart from
the general population, and is itself a threat to
unaware victims. At the same time, different social
groups have their own unique ethics, codes, and sense
of what is right or wrong, e.g. hacking is deemed
acceptable (cool or revered in fact) within the hacker
community, whereas cracking is generally frowned
upon and despised (regardless of what may happen in
private).
```

```
Resilient auxiliary power supply connected to
batteries and/or an electrical power generator intended
to maintain power to attached computer equipment,
etc. if the incoming main power source should fail. A
contingency and business continuity control.
Paradoxically, inadequately specified, designed,
manufactured, tested, and managed UPSs are a major
cause of power problems and unplanned outages,
making this a relatively fragile fail-unsafe control
unless professionally engineered, proven, monitored,
and maintained. “A type of power supply that

computer system when the electrical power fails or
drops to an unacceptable voltage level” (ISACA
glossary).
```

```
Standardised serial data interface and connectors for
computer peripherals such as keyboards, displays,
headsets, webcams, memory sticks, and biometric
authentication devices, and for data transfer and
power supply to charge smartphones and other
devices. The maximum datacommunications rates
have increased from 1.5/12 Mbps (USB version 1.1 in
1998) to 80 Gbps (USB 4.2 in 2019), allowing
external portable disk drives to perform similarly to
internal fixed hard drives. Three main variants – USB
A, B, and C – have different connectors, capacity, and
performance. “A hardware interface for low-speed
peripherals such as the keyboard, mouse, joystick,
scanner, printer, and telephony devices” (NIST SP
```

```
800-101). “An external bus standard that provides
capabilities to transfer data at a rate of 12 Mbps. Note:
```

```
related) across domains” (ISACA glossary).
```

```
Unpatched software Software that, for some reason, has not been updated
with all the relevant and available patches due to
ineffective patch management. May exhibit known
and potentially exploitable vulnerabilities in addition
to any that are currently unrecognised or for which
patches are not yet available. The information risks
are complex, relating to: (a) the nature of the
vulnerabilities themselves; (b) the extent, duration,
and visibility of their exposure; (c) the associated
threats ( e.g. hackers and malware); (d) the potential
impacts if compromised; and (e) the presence and
effectiveness of any compensating controls ( e.g.
firewalls and other access controls, antivirus, network
and host security monitoring with alerts, alarms, and
vigilant I nformation T echnology staff, incident
response processes, and business continuity
arrangements). At a higher level, if an organisation
```

```
has accumulated much unpatched software, that
suggests a serious systematic governance issue with
weak cybersecurity, asset, change or risk
management, missing/ineffective vulnerability
assessment, and/or inadequate investment and
resourcing in this area.
```

```
(ISO/IEC 2382 ). “A piece of code that

another program. A virus cannot run by

b. Subcellular parasite consisting of little
more than a protein coat and a strand of
DNA or RNA. Some viruses carry
barely enough genetic information to
encode multiple copies of themselves
that the host cell faithfully assembles
and accumulates until it bursts, thus
releasing the virus to infect (attack)
other vulnerable cells. Others (such as
COVID) encode additional proteins
that cause symptoms of infection such
as sneezing and coughing, spreading
themselves further afield.
```

```
Vulnerability, vuln,
vulnerable,
susceptibility,

```
```
Inherent/latent, potentially exploitable
weakness within an information asset,
system, process, organisation, etc. Note:
sometimes understood to include weak or
missing information security controls, a
related but distinct concern that only
constitutes a risk if the controls are relevant
and necessary; hence, their omission or
failure would expose inherent weaknesses to
threats potentially causing impacts of
concern. “Weakness or flaw in a data
processing system. Note: If a vulnerability
corresponds to a threat, a risk exists”
(ISO/IEC 2382). “ Weakness of an asset or
control that can be exploited by one or more
threats” (ISO/IEC 27000 ). “Weakness of an
asset or control that can be exploited so that
an event with a negative consequence
occurs” (ISO/IEC 27005 ). “Intrinsic
properties of something resulting in
susceptibility to a risk source that can lead
```

```
to an event with a consequence” (ISO
31073 ). “Lack of resilience against an
undesirable intentional action or inability to
recover a new stable condition of an asset”
(ISO 23234). “A weakness in the design,
implementation, operation or internal
control of a process that could expose the
system to adverse threats from threat
events” (ISACA glossary). “A security
weakness in a computer” (NIST SP 800-
114 ). “The probability that a Threat Event
will become a Loss Event; probability that
Threat Capability is greater than Resistance
Strength. (Synonym: Susceptibility)” (O-
RT). “ A weakness that makes the system
susceptible to attack or damage” (SCP
QRG). “Bugs in software programs that
have the potential to be exploited by
attackers” (UK National Cyber Security
Strategy 2022 ). “A weakness, susceptibility
or flaw of an asset, system, process or
control that can be exploited” (DORA). “A
weakness, susceptibility or flaw of a product
with digital elements that can be exploited
by a cyber threat” (EU CRA).
```
**Vulnerability analysis** Vulnerability analysis. “Process of

```
identifying and quantifying something that
creates susceptibility to a source of risk that
can lead to a consequence” (ISO 22300). “ A
process of identifying and classifying
vulnerabilities” (ISACA glossary). See also
vulnerability assessment.
```
```
V ulnerability A nd
P enetration T esting
(VAPT)
```
```
Pretentious name for plain ol’ penetration
testing that may involve additional testing
for security vulnerabilities other than the
```

```
usual network and application security
issues. Or not.
```
```
Vulnerability
assessment
```
```
Systematic analysis of vulnerabilities within
computer systems, networks, applications,
devices, processes, facilities, organisations,
etc. According to the perceived risk level
and resourcing, can range from a cursory
check for unpatched software using a
vulnerability scanner, to an in-depth security
design review, perhaps even a wide-ranging
analysis of potential weak points and gaps in
the defences for an entire supply chain,
industry, or nation. May involve self-
assessment, penetration testing, and
auditing. Daunting, maybe, but not as scary
as only discovering significant
vulnerabilities through serious incidents.
“Process of identifying and quantifying
vulnerabilities” (ISO 22300). “Can consist
of a documentation-based review of a
system’s design, an in-depth hands-on
assessment or automated scanning with
software tools. In each case, the goal is to
identify as many security vulnerabilities as
possible” (AusISM).
```
```

management
```
```
Proactive management (identification,
analysis, evaluation, mitigation, and
monitoring) of vulnerabilities – a critical
part of information risk and security
management.
```

service**

```
National Cyber Security Strategy 2022).
```

```
systems for known vulnerabilities –
```

**War dialling, war
dialler**

```
Old-school hacking or penetration testing
```

```
throughout the entire vulnerable population

```

A civil rights passive-aggressive response to

**Waterfall software
development method,
waterfall development,
waterfall model,
traditional
development**

```
Sequential software development method in
which requirements analysis (including
information security risk analysis) precedes
design and development, leading on to
testing then implementation. As the
software ‘cascades’ through the process, any
poor decisions or other issues experienced
early on can accumulate adverse
consequences downstream – a risk with this
approach. “A procedure-focused
development cycle with formal sign-off at
the completion of each level [and] A model
of the software development process in
which the constituent activities, typically a
```

```
concept phase, requirements phase, design
phase, implementation phase, test phase,
installation and checkout phase, and
operation and maintenance, are performed
in that order, possibly with overlap but with
little or no iteration. It contrasts with
incremental development, rapid prototyping
and spiral model” (ISACA glossary). Cf.
iterative software development.
```

waterhole technique**

```
Hacking method that uses social

Trojans, or other exploits. “Technique
```

```
Wear levelling “A technique used in flash memory that is
used to prolong the life of the media. Data
can be written to and erased from an address
on flash memory a finite number of times.
The wear levelling algorithm helps to
distribute writes evenly across each memory
block, thereby decreasing the wear on the
media and increasing its lifetime. The
algorithm ensures that updated or new data
is written to the first available free block
```

```
with the least number of writes. This creates
free blocks that previously contained data”
(NZISM). “A technique used in non-volatile
flash memory media to prolong the life of
the media. As data can be written to and
erased from memory blocks a finite number
of times, wear-levelling helps to distribute
writes evenly across each memory block,
thereby decreasing wear and increasing its
lifetime” (AusISM).
```

```
Firewall designed to protect a web

Cross-Site Scripting and SQL injection.
```

```
Web bug Tracking hyperlink within a web page that
refers the user’s browser to a particular file,
typically an unnoticeable single-pixel image
or an innocuous image such as this
copyright symbol: © When the user’s
browser reads the page, interprets the
HTML code, and retrieves the file, the web
server records the network access by the
user’s I nternet P rotocol address in its log,
potentially compromising the user’s privacy.
Normally used for relatively benign
marketing purposes, occasionally to indicate
and trace I ntellectual P roperty theft.
“Malicious code, invisible to a user, placed
on Web sites in such a way that it allows
third parties to track use of Web servers and
collect information about the user, including
IP address, host name, browser type and
version, operating system name and version,
and Web browser cookie” (CNSSI 4009).
```

**Whistleblower’s
hotline, ethics hotline,

```
Confidential service for whistleblowers to

or suspicions about improprieties such as
coercion, fraud, bribery, corruption, and
malpractice by various mechanisms, in
```

```
order for them to be formally and
independently investigated. Anonymity,
coupled with discreet investigation by
competent and trustworthy investigators,
reduces the possibility of identification and

```

```
and other crimes typically committed by

```

```
before the software developer knows about

undisclosed to the software developer. Zero-
```

**Zero trust, zero trust
network, zero trust
architecture, zero trust
model**

```
Cybersecurity concept or architecture
founded on the premise that I nformation
T echnology systems and networks are
inherently untrustworthy and must therefore
be proactively secured, continuously
evaluating and dynamically responding to
the evolving external and internal/insider
threats for assurance. Even supposedly well-
secured internal/private L ocal A rea
N etworks cannot be entirely trusted; hence,
information assets (regardless of their
```

```
location) need controls such as continuous
validation of userIDs and monitoring of
network activities, M ulti F actor
A uthentication, least privilege, micro-
segmentation, and strong access controls
such as encrypted communications to
minimise the possibility of
unauthorised/inappropriate access, hacks,
malware, etc. “A security model based on
microsegmentation and the continuous
validation of digital interactions to address
the threat of lateral movement within a
network. [and] A security model anchored
in the assumption of breach, which means
that anything outside or inside the network
cannot be trusted and anyone who tries to
access the network needs to be verified in
advance” (ISACA glossary ). “A security
concept based around the idea that systems
and users should not be given access to any
information without verification, even when
they are connected to internal networks”
(NZISM). See also S ecure A ccess S ervice
E dge.
```

```
involving incompatible technology
standards and I ntellectual P roperties. “An
IEEE 802.15.4 personal area network (PAN)
protocol developed in 1998 that aims to
provide moderate throughput and reliable
connectivity via a mesh topology (similar to
Z-Wave)” (ISACA glossary).
```
```
Zinc whiskers Through mechanical abrasion, microscopic
crystalline zinc fibres can form slowly from
the galvanised plating on typical computer
room floor and ceiling tiles. When spread
by mass air flow, they may cause short
circuits (perhaps being instantly vapourised)
and unreliable operation in electronic
equipment in similar fashion to other
airborne conductive contaminants such as
soot and moisture.
```
```
Zip bomb Malware that decompresses a massive file,
consuming system resources until the
system crawls to a halt and maybe crashes.
A crude type of logic bomb.
```
```
ZKP Abbrev: Z ero- K nowledge P roof.
```
**Zombie, zombie
computer**

```
See bot. “A computer connected to the
Internet that has been compromised by a
hacker, a computer virus, or a trojan horse.
Generally, a compromised machine is only
```

```
one of many in a botnet, and will be used to
perform malicious tasks of one sort or
another under remote direction. Most
owners of zombie computers are unaware
that their system is being used in this way.
Because the owner tends to be unaware,
these computers are metaphorically
compared to zombies” (SANS glossary).
```
**ZombieLoad,
ZombieLoad 2**

```
Exploits capable of compromising some
Intel C entral P rocessing U nits. Design
flaws deep in the CPU hardware can allow
rogue processes (malware) to access
information belonging to other processes
held transiently in internal buffers, despite
higher-level firmware and software controls
meant to prevent precisely that. Firmware
and software patches can mitigate these
attacks by disabling hyperthreading and
improving buffer flushing, but a CPU
hardware redesign is necessary to fix the
underlying vulnerabilities without the
functionality and performance impacts
caused by workarounds. See also Spectre.
```
```
Zone Defined physical area or logical grouping
within which a common physical or logical
security baseline applies. Perimeter controls
such as firewalls, walls, and doors usually
isolate or separate different zones. High-
security zones, such as the keep in a castle,
the data centre, or L ocal A rea N etwork in a
commercial organisation or a cryptographic
system, deserve to be protected more
strongly against unauthorised access than
the surrounding areas. Zoning is akin to
classification in that things within a given
```

```
zone are treated similarly, although their
individual information risks and security
requirements may vary somewhat. See also
domain, security domain.
```
```
Zoo Malware collection typically maintained by
security researchers and antivirus
companies, as well as by VXers, hackers,
and crackers.
```
